220.01 MEMBERSHIP.
   The City Council shall consist of the Mayor and eight Alderpersons, one
Alderperson to be elected from each ward, and one Alderperson elected at-large.
(1977 Code § 13-101; Ord. 2006-21. Passed 5-15-06; Ord. 2007-11. Passed 2-20-
07.)
220.02 TERMS OF OFFICE.
   Alderpersons shall hold office for four years, and until their successors
are elected and qualified. Alderpersons now in office shall continue for the
remainder of the respective terms to which they were elected. The date fixed
for the inauguration of the newly elected Alderpersons shall be during the
second regular City Council meeting during the month of May in respective
election years.
(1977 Code §13-102; Ord. 2012-56. Passed 10-15-12; Ord. 2013-25. Passed 6-3-13;
Ord. 2016- 47. Passed 9-19-16.)
220.03 VACANCIES.
   If a vacancy occurs in the office of Alderperson by reason of resignation,
failure to elect or qualify, death, permanent physical or mental disability,
conviction of a disqualifying crime, abandonment of office, removal from office
or of residence from ward, or otherwise, such vacancy shall be filled in
accordance with the provisions of 65 ILCS 5/3.1-10-50, as amended.
(Ord. 97-14. Passed 4-7-97.)
220.04 QUALIFICATIONS.
   No person shall be eligible to the office of Alderperson unless he or she
shall be a qualified elector and reside within the ward for which he or she is
elected, nor unless he or she is fully qualified to assume and hold such office
under the provisions of 65 ILCS 5/3.1-10-5 et seq., and 5/3.1-55-5, 5/3.1-55-
10, 5/3.1-55-15 and 5/3.1-55-20, as amended.
(1977 Code § 13-104)
220.05 OATH.
   Before entering upon the duties of his or her office each Alderperson shall
take, subscribe and file an oath of office as required by 65 ILCS 5/3.1-10-25,
as amended.
(1977 Code § 13-105)
220.06 COMPENSATION.
   Except as set forth herein, each Alderperson shall be paid the sum of four
thousand five hundred dollars ($4,500) per annum to be paid in twelve monthly
installments, and no other compensation shall be allowed to any Alderperson for
any service whatsoever. Upon the approval of the City Council, an Alderperson
may receive reimbursement for expenses actually paid or expected to be incurred
in the performance of his or her duties as an Alderperson.
(Ord. 96-70. Passed 10-7-96; Ord. 2002-60. Passed 10-8-02; Ord. 2016-53. Passed
11-14-16; Ord. 2024-54a. Passed 10-21-24.)
220.07 JUDGE OF QUALIFICATIONS.
   The City Council shall be the sole judge of the election and qualifications
of its own members, subject only to 65 ILCS 5/3.1-55-15 and quo warranto
proceedings, as provided by 735 ILCS 5/18-101 et seq., as amended.
(1977 Code § 13-107)
220.08 RULES, PUNISHMENT AND EXPULSION.
   The City Council shall determine its own rules of proceedings, punish its
members for disorderly conduct and, with the concurrence of two-thirds of all
the Alderpersons elected, may expel a member, but not a second time for the
same offense.
(1977 Code § 13-108)
220.09 ILLINOIS MUNICIPAL CODE.
   No provision of Sections
220.01 to
220.08 shall be construed as being in conflict with 65 ILCS 5/3-4-7 to 3-4-15,
as amended. If any such conflict exists, the conflicting provisions of Sections
220.01 to
220.08 shall be separable and void. All pertinent and applicable provisions of
the sections of the Illinois Municipal Code cited in this section, as
heretofore and hereafter amended, are incorporated herein by reference.
(1977 Code § 13-109)
220.10 RULES OF COUNCIL.
   (1)   In General. The rules for the conduct of business, hereby established
and adopted, shall be strictly followed, unless temporarily suspended by a two-
thirds vote of the Council, in all matters not particularly specified in this
section or
Chapter 222 of these Codified Ordinances, for parliamentary and legislative
practice and procedure, Robert's Rules of Order (latest edition) shall govern.
   (2)   Time and Place of Meetings. The City Council shall meet regularly at
6:00 p.m. on the first and third Monday of each month in the City Hall or at
another location as designated by the City Council, and may hold adjourned or
special meetings at any time, in its discretion, as it may deem proper. When
the date fixed for any regular meeting shall fall upon a legal holiday,
however, such meeting shall be held on the next business day.
   (3)   Attendance of Certain Officials Required. The City Clerk shall have
charge of the Council Room and shall attend all meetings of the Council. The
City Engineer, City Manager, City Legal Counsel, Finance Director, Community
and Economic Development Director, Public Works Director, Communications
Director, Chief of Police and Fire Chief shall also attend all meetings of the
Council.
   (4)   Open Doors and Journal. The City Council shall sit with open doors. It
shall keep a journal of its proceedings.
   (5)   Special Meetings. The Mayor, or any three Alderpersons, may call
special meetings of the City Council.
   (6)   Written Notice of Special Meetings. Written notice of special meetings
shall be served by the Chief of Police, on each Alderperson, on the Mayor, on
the City Manager, on the City Legal Counsel and on the officers specified in
subsection (3) hereof, personally, or by leaving the same at their usual place
of residence or business. The notice shall state the objects for which the
meeting is called, and no other business shall be transacted. If any City
Official provides for an alternate acceptable form of service by filing the
same in writing with the City Clerk, such service shall be deemed appropriate
under this section, however, the form of the notice itself may not be waived.
   (7)   Presiding Officer. The Mayor shall preside at all meetings of the City
Council. In the absence of the Mayor, the Alderperson present shall appoint one
of their number Chairperson Pro Tem. The Mayor shall not vote on any ordinance,
resolution or motion except:
      A.   Where the vote of the Alderpersons elected has resulted in a tie.
      B.   Where one-half of the Alderpersons elected have voted in favor of an
ordinance, resolution or motion even though there is no tie vote.
      C.   Where a vote greater than a majority of the elected Alderpersons is
required by statute or ordinance.
   In each instance specified, the Mayor shall vote. When an Alderperson is
presiding as Chairperson Pro Tem, he or she shall vote in his or her capacity
as Alderperson, but shall not vote in his or her capacity as Acting Mayor or
Chairperson Pro Tem.
   (8)   Quorum. At all meetings, a majority of all Alderpersons elected shall
constitute a quorum. A minority may adjourn to a day certain, and may compel
the attendance of willfully absent members by a fine of not more than twenty
dollars ($20.00) for each such offense, upon conviction by the Council.
   (9)   Vote Required. The concurrence of a majority of all members elected in
the City Council shall be necessary to the passage of any ordinance,
resolution, motion or other Council action, unless the concurrence of a greater
number is required in particular cases, by ordinance or by the Illinois
Municipal Code. Motions to adjourn, to recess to a time certain, or to refer a
matter to committee, are excepted from the foregoing requirement and in such
cases only a majority of the members present shall be required.
   (10)   Order of Business. The Council shall be called to order by the Mayor,
or, in his or her absence, by the Clerk, who shall proceed to call the roll,
note the absentees, and announce whether a quorum be present. Upon the
appearance of a quorum, and before proceeding to the business before it, the
Council and all others present shall recite the Pledge of Allegiance to the
Flag. The Council shall proceed to the business before it in the order
following:
1st  Approval of the Agenda.
2nd  Reading of the minutes of the last meeting; amendment and approval of the
     same.
3rd  Public comment - agenda items.
4th  Consent agenda.
5th  Communications and written reports.
6th  Ordinances - second reading.
7th  Ordinances - first reading.
8th  Resolutions.
9th  Reports of standing committees.
10th Reports of select committees.
11th Reports of department heads.
12th City Manager’s report.
13th Mayors report.
14th New business.
15th Public comment – any agenda or non-agenda items.
16th Adjournment.
 
   Unless a full reading is requested by a member, the minutes may be approved
without reading if the Clerk has previously furnished each member with a copy
thereof.
   (11)   Preservation of Order. The Mayor, or the Chairperson Pro Tem, shall
preserve order and decorum, and shall decide all questions of order, subject to
appeal to the Council.
   (12)   Decision of Chair. All questions of order, and questions relating to
the priority of business, shall be decided by the Mayor, or Chairperson Pro
Tem, without debate. If there be no appeal, the decision of the Chair shall be
conclusive. If a member appeals to the Council from a decision of the Chair,
and if the appeal is seconded, the question shall be put as follows: "Shall the
decision of the Chair stand as the judgment of the Council?" The Council shall
decide the question without debate.
   (13)   Duty While Question is Being Put. While the Chair is putting the
question, no member shall converse with any other member, or walk across, or
out of, the Council room. No member shall explain his or her vote, speak to the
question or speak otherwise than to cast his or her vote after the commencement
of the roll call by the Clerk.
   (14)   Duty Before Speaking. Every member, before speaking, shall address
the Chair and shall not proceed with his or her remarks until recognized and
named by the Chair.
   (15)   Frequency of Speaking. No member shall speak more than twice to the
same general question, nor more than once to a previous question, without the
unanimous leave of the Council, nor more than once, in any case, until every
member choosing to speak shall have spoken.
   (16)   Order of Motions. Motions upon the subject under consideration shall
have precedence in the following order:
      1st - To lay on the table.
      2nd - To postpone.
      3rd - To commit.
      4th - To amend.
   (17)   Reduction to Writing. All motions or resolutions shall be reduced to
writing, if required by the Chair or a member, and when seconded and stated by
the Chair, shall be open for consideration.
   (18)   Withdrawal. No motion or resolution may be withdrawn after it is
seconded, without the consent of the seconder, nor may it be withdrawn after it
has been amended or decided.
   (19)   Motion to Adjourn. A motion to adjourn is always in order, except
when another motion is pending and voting is in process. A motion to adjourn
shall be decided without debate.
   (20)   Voting. Each member present, when a question is stated, shall vote
thereon, unless he or she be interested in the question, in which case he or
she shall not vote. Upon motions, ordinances or resolutions appropriating
money, imposing taxes or authorizing the borrowing of money, the yeas and nays
shall be called and recorded for all members voting.
   (21)   Voting on Appointments. All appointments made by the Mayor shall be
submitted to the City Council three business days prior to confirmation and
shall be deemed confirmed when approved by the City Council by a vote of yeas
and nays of the majority of all Alderpersons elected and entered upon the
record.
   (22)   Reconsideration of Vote. No vote shall be reconsidered or rescinded
unless there be present as many members as were present when such vote was
taken, nor unless the motion to reconsider shall be made by a member who voted
with the majority on the question to be reconsidered. A motion to reconsider
may be made only at the same, or next succeeding, meeting.
   (23)   Address by Non-Members. Any person not a member of the Council or
officer of the City may address the Council, or its members, at a public
meeting, standing or special committee in accordance with the following rules.
He or she shall rise (if not physically impaired), approach the podium and
speak into the microphone, stating his or her name for the record. No person,
other than the Alderpersons and the person having the floor, shall be permitted
to enter into any discussion, directly or through a member of the Council,
without the permission of the Chair. No question shall be asked of an
Alderperson except through the Chair. Any person making personal, impertinent
abusive, profane or slanderous remarks, or who shall become boisterous,, shall
be forthwith evicted from the chamber by the Chair. The Chair will preserve
order and decorum and the Chair reserves the right to halt or suspend the
public meeting to a later date if the rules are not being followed.
With regards to any written correspondence addressed to the City Council which
is received in advance of a public meeting, the Chair shall read the
correspondence that was received and state the name of the sender. No personal,
impertinent, abusive, profane or libelous statements shall be allowed and the
Chair may refrain from reading such portions of the correspondence that are
personal, impertinent, abusive, profane or libelous. The reading of any piece
of written correspondence shall be limited to three minutes unless further time
is granted by the Council. There shall be no more than six pieces of written
correspondence read on any issue. If there are more than six pieces of written
correspondence, then each side will be granted the same number of pieces of
written correspondence to be read. Any written correspondence addressing an
item not on that meeting's agenda may only be read during the apportion of the
meeting designated for the same.
      A.   Any member of the public wishing to address an item on that
meeting's agenda must sign-in with the Clerk prior to commencement of the
meeting indicating which item they wish to address and whether they will speak
in favor or in opposition to such item. Unless further time is granted by the
Council, such comments shall be limited to three minutes. There shall be no
more than six number of speakers to any issue. If there are more than six
registered speakers, then each side will be granted the same number of
speakers.
      B.   Any member of the public wishing to address an item not on that
meeting's agenda may do so only during that portion of the meeting designated
for the same. Unless further time is granted by the Council, such comments
shall be limited to three minutes.
      C.   Public hearings. Any member of the public wishing to speak during a
public hearing must sign-in with the Clerk prior to commencement of the
meeting. Any person wishing to offer evidence in the form of testimony at a
hearing shall testify under oath. Anyone wishing to cross-examine a witness
must register in advance of the public hearing and assert an interest beyond
that of the general public. Whether such interest exists shall be determined by
the Council prior to the commencement of the public hearing. The Chair may
impose reasonable limitations on evidence or testimony presented by persons and
parties, such as time limits and barring repetitious, irrelevant or immaterial
testimony. Unless further time is granted by the Council, comments shall be
limited to three minutes.
   (24)   Enforcement of Decorum. The Chief of Police, or such member of the
Fire Department as he or she may designate, shall be Sergeant-at-Arms of the
Council meetings. He or she shall carry out all orders and instructions of the
Chair for the purpose of maintaining order and decorum. The Sergeant-at-Arms
shall place any person who violates the order and decorum of the meeting under
arrest, and shall cause him or her to be prosecuted under the provisions of
these Codified Ordinances.
   (25)   Violating Rules. Any member who shall refuse, or neglect, to comply
with any of the foregoing rules, or who shall fail to conduct himself or
herself in an orderly and respectful manner at a Council meeting, shall, for
each offense, forfeit to the City a sum not exceeding one hundred dollars
($100.00), upon being duly convicted by the Council.
   (26)   Illinois Municipal Code. No provision of this section shall be
construed as being in conflict with 65 ILCS 5/3-11-9, 3-11-12 to 3-11-17,
inclusive, or 3-11-20, as amended. If any such conflict exists, the conflicting
provisions of this section shall be separable and void. All pertinent and
applicable provisions of the sections of the Illinois Municipal Code cited in
this section, as heretofore and hereafter amended, are incorporated herein by
reference.
   (27)   Parliamentarian. The Mayor, with the consent of the City Council, may
appoint some City official to act as Parliamentarian for the City Council. The
Parliamentarian shall not receive any additional compensation for these duties.
The Parliamentarian may consult with the City Legal Counsel and shall advise
the presiding officer of the City Council concerning the proper procedures to
be utilized. The Parliamentarian shall be familiar with the provisions of
Robert's Rules of Order (latest edition) and with these Codified Ordinances.
   (28)   Consent Agenda.
      (1)   When the agenda for regular meetings of the City Council is
prepared, the City Manager shall cause to be placed on the consent agenda
section, such matters requiring Council consent that he or she considers to be
routine. All such matters placed on the consent agenda shall be fully stated
reports, motions, resolutions or ordinances.
      (2)   Upon Council consideration of the consent agenda the Chair shall
first inquire if there are any motions to remove items from the consent agenda.
Any item on that agenda may be removed and considered in the order upon which
they otherwise fall in the order of business, or if not otherwise falling under
an order of business, then under the “unfinished business” portion of the order
of business upon a motion and seconded by members of the Council. Such motions
shall not be debatable. After Alderpersons have has an opportunity to make
removal motions, the Chair shall call the questions on the consent agenda. When
approved by a majority vote, the individual reports, motions, resolutions and
ordinances contained on the consent agenda and approved therein shall have the
same effect and force as they would have had if individually approved by the
Council.
(1977 Code §§13-201 to 13-228; Ord. 89-44. Passed 8-21-89; Ord. 89-73. Passed
12-4-89; Ord. 90-48. Passed 6-4-90; Ord. 94-80. Passed 9-19-94; Ord. 2001-55.
Passed 11-19-01; Ord. 2003-43. Passed 6-16-03; Ord. 2003-85. Passed 12-15-03;
Ord. 2006-39. Passed 7-17-06; Ord. 2007-11. Passed 2-20-07; Ord. 2008-12.
Passed 3-3-08; Ord. 2008-42. Passed 7-21-08; Ord. 2009-15. Passed 2-17-09; Ord.

Passed 8-21-23; Ord. 2024-15. Passed 4-1-24.)
220.11 COUNCIL COMMITTEES.
   (a)   Operation of the Committee of the Whole.
      (1)   Establishment. There is hereby established a Committee of the Whole
of the City Council, which shall consist of the Mayor and all Alderpersons.
      (2)   Meetings. The Committee of the Whole shall meet on the 2nd Monday
of each month at 6:00 p.m. in the City Council chambers or from time to time as
called upon by the Mayor or any two Alderpersons. When the date fixed for any
regular meeting shall fall upon a legal holiday, however, such meeting shall be
held on the next business day.
      (3)   Chairperson. The Chair of the Committee of the Whole shall rotate
on a per meeting basis beginning with the Alderperson for Ward One and
consecutively through Ward Seven, followed by the Alderperson at Large. The
Mayor shall not serve as Chair of the Committee of the Whole. Notwithstanding
anything to the contrary in this chapter, the Alderperson presiding over the
meeting of the Committee of the Whole may vote on all matters before the
Committee.
      (4)   Agenda items. Agenda items for the Committee of the Whole shall be
as requested by the Mayor, the City Manager or any two Alderpersons, or as
referred to it by the City Council.
      (5)   Address by non-members. Address by non-members shall be pursuant to
Section
220.10(23), the same as if the meeting were a City Council Meeting.
   (b)   Operation of Executive Committee. There is hereby established an
Executive Committee. Notwithstanding anything to the contrary in any section of
this chapter, the following shall govern the operation of Council's Executive
Committee. The Executive Committee shall be comprised of the five Alderpersons
with the most consecutive years of service as a member of Council. In the event
that there are two or more Alderpersons with equal seniority, then lots shall
be drawn to determine which member shall serve. The Executive Committee shall
have the following duties and powers:
      (1)   Review and recommend to Council and the Mayor changes in the role/
responsibilities and structure of any committees;
      (2)   Review and recommend action on complaints related to Council member
ethics, conduct or other activities that might be deemed inappropriate;
      (3)   Support and participate in the orientation of new Council members;
and
      (4)   Recommend programs that promote the development and recognition of
Council as a whole and individual Council members.
   The Chairperson of the Executive Committee shall be the most senior member
with the most consecutive years of service on the Council. The Chairperson
shall serve a two-year term and not be able to immediately succeed herself or
himself. The Executive Committee shall meet when the Chair or three members
call for a meeting or when matters are referred to it by the Mayor and/or
Council for review and/or recommendation.
   (c)   Special Committees. All special committees shall be appointed by the
Mayor, with the approval of the City Council.
   (d)   LEFT INTENTIONALLY BLANK.
   (e)   Operation of Finance Committee of the Whole.
      (1)   Establishment and purpose. There is hereby established a Finance
Committee of the Whole of the City Council which shall consist of the Mayor and
all Alderpersons. The purpose of the Finance Committee of the Whole is to
review and discuss the finances and budget of the City (working in conjunction
with the City Manager) and to make recommendations on such matters to the
Council and the Mayor.
      (2)   Chairpersons. There shall be a Chair of the Finance Committee of
the Whole as well as a Vice-Chair of the Finance Committee of the Whole. The
Chair and Vice-Chair shall be selected annually from amongst all the
Alderpersons by a simple majority vote of all the Alderpersons. Such selection
of the Chair and Vice-Chair shall take place on or about the first regularly
scheduled City Council meeting in the month of May of each year. The Mayor
shall not serve as the Chair or Vice-Chair of the Finance Committee of the
Whole.
      (3)   Meetings. The Finance Committee of the Whole shall meet from time
to time as called upon by the Chair of the Finance Committee of the Whole, the
Mayor or any three Alderpersons. Meetings of the Finance Committee of the Whole
shall be held in the City Council Chambers or at such location as determined by
the Chair. Meetings of the Finance Committee of the Whole shall be called to
order by the Chair of the Finance Committee of the Whole.
      (4)   Voting. Decisions of the Finance Committee of the Whole shall be by
simple majority vote of all the Alderpersons. The Chair and Vice-Chair may vote
on all matters before the Finance Committee of the Whole. The Mayor shall only
vote in the event of a tie between the Alderpersons.
      (5)   Agenda items. Agenda items for the Finance Committee of the Whole
shall be as requested by the Chair of the Finance Committee of the Whole, the
Mayor, any two Alderpersons or as referred to it by the City Council. The Chair
shall be responsible for placing items on the agenda and for taking the minutes
of the Finance Committee of the Whole meetings.
   (f)   City Manager Recruitment Committee.
      (1)   Establishment. There is hereby established a City Manager
Recruitment Committee of the City, which shall consist of the Mayor, all
Alderpersons and three members of the public. The members of the public shall
not be entitled to vote on committee matters and shall have advisory roles
only.
      (2)   Meetings. The City Manager Recruitment Committee shall meet upon
the call of the Mayor, any two Alderpersons or when matters are referred to it
by the Mayor and/or City Council for review and/or recommendation. The City
Manager Recruitment Committee shall meet in the City Council chambers, or such
other location as may be determined by the Chairperson. Meetings of the City
Manager Recruitment Committee shall conform with all applicable provisions of
the Illinois Open Meeting Act.
      (3)   Chairperson and Vice Chairperson. The Chairperson of the City
Manager Recruitment Committee shall be selected from amongst the Alderpersons
by a majority vote of the Alderpersons. The Vice-Chairperson of the City
Manager Recruitment Committee shall be selected from amongst the Alderpersons
by a majority vote of the Alderperson. All agenda items for consideration shall
be submitted by committee members to the Chairperson and the Chairperson shall
be responsible for drafting the agenda.
      (4)   Public members. The three members of the public shall be selected
by a majority vote of the Alderpersons. Such public members shall be residents
of the City.
      (5)   Agenda items. Agenda items for the City Manager Recruitment
Committee shall be as requested by the Mayor or any two Alderpersons, or as
referred to it by the City Council.
      (6)   Duties and responsibilities. The City Manager Recruitment Committee
shall be responsible for assisting the Mayor and City Council in the hiring
process of a new City Manager. The City Manager Recruitment Committee shall
advise and make recommendations to the City Council on the processes and
procedures to hire a new City Manager, including, but not limited to, the
retention of consultants or a search firm to assist in the hiring of a City
Manager.
      (7)   City Manager annual review. The annual reviews of the City Manager
shall be performed by the Alderman at Large and the Most Senior Alderman and
such review signed by the Mayor.
      (8)   Quorum. No meeting shall occur in the absence of a quorum, which
shall be comprised of seven members of the committee. No action on any agenda
item shall be taken unless a minimum of four voting members are present.
   (g)   Social Justice Committee.
      (1)   Establishment. There is hereby established a Social Justice
Committee of the City, which shall consist of the Mayor, one Alderperson, the
City Chief of Police, the City Fire Chief and up to thirteen members of the
public. The Social Justice Committee will make recommendations on courses of
action to the City Council and shall be an advisory body only.
      (2)   Meetings. The Social Justice Committee shall meet upon the call of
the Chairperson, the Co-Chairperson, any two Alderpersons or when matters are
referred to it by the City Council for review and/or recommendation. The Social
Justice Committee shall meet in the City Council chambers, or such other
location as may be determined by the Chairperson. Meetings of the Social
Justice Committee shall conform with all applicable provisions of the Illinois
Open Meeting Act.
      (3)   Chairperson and Co-Chairperson. The Chairperson of the Social
Justice Committee shall be the Mayor. The Co-Chairperson shall be selected from
amongst the public members by a majority vote of the Alderpersons.
      (4)   Public members. The thirteen members of the public shall be
selected by a majority vote of the Alderpersons.
      (5)   Agenda items. Agenda items for the Social Justice Committee shall
be as requested by the Chairperson, Co-Chairperson, any two Alderpersons, any
two committee members, or as referred to it by the City Council. All agenda
items for consideration shall be submitted to the Chairperson and the
Chairperson shall be responsible for drafting the agenda.
      (6)   Duties and responsibilities. The Social Justice Committee shall be
responsible for reviewing and making recommendations to the City Council on
social injustice issues in the Freeport area and how they can be addressed.
      (7)   Quorum. No meeting shall occur in the absence of a quorum.
      (8)   Term. Each committee member shall be appointed to a six month term.
Members may serve more than one term.
(1977 Code §§13-301 to 13-306; Ord. 79-36. Passed 5-21-79; Ord. 89-19. Passed
5-15-89; Ord. 89-73. Passed 12-4-89; Ord. 93-16. Passed 4-19-93; Ord. 97-74.
Passed 1-5-98; Ord. 99-21. Passed 5-17-99; Ord. 2002-75. Passed 1-6-03; Ord.
2003-36. Passed 5-5-03; Ord. 2005-68. Passed 12-5-05; Ord. 2006-42. Passed 7-
17-06; Ord. 2008-12. Passed 3-3-08; Ord. 2012-18. Passed 2-21-12; Ord. 2016-60.
Passed 11-21-16; Ord. 2017-28. Passed 4-3-17; Ord. 2017-56. Passed 7-17-17;
Ord. 2017-75. Passed 11-20-17; Ord. 2020-32. Passed 6-8-20; Ord. 2020-35.
Passed 6-15-20.)
220.12 COUNCIL ACCESS.
   Alderpersons shall have reasonable access to any department head of the City
regarding matters under the authority of the City Council.
(Ord. 2015-62. Passed 11-16-15.)

222.01 PRESENTATION.
   An ordinance or resolution may be presented for consideration by any member
of Council, including the Mayor, by the City Manager, or by any special
committee of Council. Special zoning ordinances referred to in Section
1242.12 of the Planning and Zoning Code or preliminary or final plats under
Section
1224.05 of the Planning and Zoning Code shall move directly to Council for
consideration from the Planning Commission or Zoning Board of Appeals,
respectively.
(1977 Code §1-301; Ord. 2008-12. Passed 3-3-08; Ord. 2017-56. Passed 7-17-17.)
222.02 FIRST READINGS.
   Upon first reading, an ordinance or resolution shall be read in full if two
members demand that the same be read in full.
(1977 Code § 1-303; Ord. 2008-12. Passed 3-3-08)
222.03 LAYING OVER.
   After the first reading of an ordinance, a member shall move to approve or
deny the proposed ordinance. After this motion is seconded, the proposed
ordinance shall be properly on the floor of the Council for discussion or
debate purposes. If there is no such discussion or debate, or at the completion
of such discussion or debate, such ordinance shall be automatically laid over
until the next regular or special meeting of the Council for second reading,
without further action by Council, unless falling under subsections (a) or (b)
hereunder. Council may take final action on a proposed ordinance at first
reading in the two following instances:
   (a)   If the proposed ordinance has had a proper public hearing at the
Planning Commission or Zoning Board of Appeals and the ordinance would grant a
special use permit or a variance to the requirements of the Zoning Code, a
change in zoning to any parcel, a Planned Unit Development, or an amendment to
the Zoning Code, and the reporting agency unanimously recommended its approval
and no person filed a formal written objection or protest to such ordinance
which would require a supermajority vote by Council for its enactment under the
provisions of Section 1242.12(i)(1) of the Planning and Zoning Code; or
   (b)   If Council, by a two-thirds vote of all elected and qualified members,
waives laying over and the second reading.
(1977 Code §1-304; Ord. 89-64. Passed 11-6-89; Ord. 2001-55. Passed 11-19-01;
Ord. 2007-11. Passed 2-20-07; Ord. 2008-12. Passed 3-3-08; Ord. 2008-66. Passed
1-5-09; Ord. 2012-18. Passed 2-21-12.)
222.04 SECOND READINGS.
   The second reading of an ordinance shall be by title and number only.
(1977 Code §1-305; Ord. 2008-02. Passed 3-3-08; Ord. 2012-18. Passed 2-21-12.)
222.05 SPECIAL OR TERRITORIAL ORDINANCES.
   It shall be sufficient for first reading of special or territorial
ordinances or resolutions if only the distinguishing subject matter,
accompanied by an explanation, is read by the City Clerk.
(1977 Code § 1-306)
222.06 VOTING.
   The yeas and nays shall be taken and recorded upon the passage of all
ordinances and resolutions to create any liability against the City for the
expenditure or appropriation of its money or when so requested by any member of
Council.
(1977 Code § 1-307)
222.07 VETO OR APPROVAL BY MAYOR.
   All ordinances passed by Council shall, before taking effect, be deposited
with the City Clerk. The Mayor shall either approve the same by signature or
return the same to Council, with his or her objections, in writing, at the
first meeting of Council held not less than five days after passage of such
ordinances. Such veto may extend to any one or more separable items, or
appropriations, contained therein, or to the entire ordinance. If the veto only
extends to a part of such ordinance, the residue thereof shall take effect and
be in force. In the absence of a veto in the aforesaid manner, and in the time
aforesaid, the Mayor shall be deemed to have approved the particular ordinance,
and the same shall take effect accordingly.
(1977 Code § 1-308)
222.08 OVERRIDE OF VETOES.
   Upon the veto of an ordinance, the same shall, if again passed by a vote of
two-thirds of all the elected members of Council, with yeas and nays recorded
in the Journal, go into effect notwithstanding the veto as provided in Section
222.07.
(1977 Code § 1-309)
222.09 PUBLICATION.
   All ordinances for which publication is required shall be published in the
form and manner required by the Illinois Municipal Code.
(1977 Code § 1-310)
222.10 ORDINANCE NUMBERS.
   All general, special and territorial ordinances shall be given an ordinance
number, for purposes of first reading and for maintenance of the filing system
of the City Clerk, which numbers shall consist of the year in which such
ordinance is first presented to Council, followed by a dash and the number of
the ordinance in sequence, with a new sequence commencing in each calendar
year.
(1977 Code § 1-311; Ord. 2007-11. Passed 2-20-07.)
TITLE SIX - Administration
CHAPTER 224
City Manager
224.01   Position created, appointment.
224.02   Term and compensation.
224.03   Qualifications of City Manager.
224.04   Powers and duties.
224.05   Absence or disability, vacancy in office.
224.06   Removal.
224.07   Deputy City Manager of Finance, Community Development and Human
Resources, position created, appointment.
224.08   Term and compensation.
224.09   Powers and duties.
224.01   POSITION CREATED, APPOINTMENT.
   There is hereby created the position of City Manager, an administrative
office of the City of Freeport. The position shall be filled by appointment of
the City Council.
(Ord. 2017-10. Passed 2-6-17.)
224.02   TERM AND COMPENSATION.
   The City Manager shall serve until such time as his or her successor has
been appointed and qualified. The City Manager shall receive such compensation
as the City Council may prescribe from time to time.
(Ord. 2017-10. Passed 2-6-17.)
224.03   QUALIFICATIONS OF CITY MANAGER.
   The qualifications of the City Manager shall be as follows:
   (a)   A minimum of a Bachelor's degree, preference given to a Master's
degree in Public Administration or equivalent;
   (b)   A minimum of five years of relevant work experience, or equivalent;
   (c)   At the time of appointment, the City Manager need not be a resident of
the City, but, within six months after appointment, the City Manager shall
reside within the corporate limits of the City. The six month term can be
extended by another six months upon approval of the City Council;
   (d)   Any other qualifications as may be prescribed by ordinance or
resolution of the City Council.
(Ord. 2017-10. Passed 2-6-17.)
224.04   POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The powers and duties of the City Manager shall be as follows:
   (a)   To enforce the laws and ordinances within the City;
   (b)   To appoint and remove all directors of departments or employees of the
City except when such power is vested in the City Council or other commission,
committee or board of the City under this Code or any applicable State statute
or pursuant to the terms of any collective bargaining agreement. The Chief of
Police and the Chief of Fire Department may be removed or discharged by the
City Manager; provided, however, that the City Manager shall file with the
corporate authorities the reasons therefor and such removal or discharge shall
not become effective unless confirmed by a majority vote of the corporate
authorities;
   (c)   To appoint and remove all officers who are not required to be elected
pursuant to State statute;
   (d)   To exercise control of all departments as created under City
ordinance, or that may be created by the City Council;
   (e)   To have all the powers and exercise all the duties granted elsewhere
in this Code to municipal clerks and comptrollers with respect to the
preparation of a report of estimated funds necessary to defray the expenses of
the City for the fiscal year for the consideration of the corporate authorities
prior to the preparation of the annual appropriation ordinance;
   (f)   To attend all meetings of the City Council with the right to take part
in the discussions, but with no right to vote;
   (g)   To recommend to the City Council for adoption such measures as he or
she may deem necessary or expedient;
   (h)   To recommend to the Council the wages and benefits for each position
within the service of the City;
   (i)   To investigate all complaints pertaining to the administration of the
City and to services maintained by the public utilities of the City and see
that all franchises, permits and privileges granted by the City are faithfully
observed;
   (j)   To prepare and submit an annual budget to the City Council in format
prescribed by the City Council or Council committee that is consistent with the
financial priorities set by the City Council after consultation with the
Council or appropriate Council committee;
   (k)   To keep the Council advised of the financial condition and future
needs of the City and make such recommendations as may be deemed desirable;
   (l)   To supervise the coordination of purchasing all materials, supplies,
equipment and services by the Finance Director in conformance with Chapter 238
for which funds are provided in the City's budget;
   (m)   To supervise the negotiation of all collective bargaining agreements
between the City and unions representing employees of the City;
   (n)   To examine all other proposed contracts of the City, advise the City
Council with respect to the same, and supervise the performance of the terms
and conditions of any contract to which the City is a party;
   (o)   To coordinate the management of the City Hall and all other City
buildings, facilities and properties, provide necessary facilities for the
operations and purposes of all boards and commissions of the City and keep a
current inventory of all real and personal property of the City;
   (p)   To coordinate all City operations affecting more than one department,
office or officers; he or she may, if he or she deems necessary, with the
approval of the City Council, consolidate or combine offices, positions or
departments within the City;
   (q)   To submit, or cause to be submitted to the City Council, monthly and
annual written reports of the activities and financial status of all City
departments and operations under his or her management. The annual report,
which shall be consistent with the Council's approval of the format, shall be
submitted within thirty days following the end of each fiscal year;
   (r)   To advise, and as necessary, provide assistance to all duly
constituted boards, commissions and advisory committees of the City;
   (s)   May, as directed by the City Council, be responsible for the
preparation and release of newsletters, brochures, articles and other
informational sources in order to keep the public informed on the activities of
the City government and shall make himself or herself available to the
residents and business community of the City;
   (t)   Shall work with the public to receive suggestions and to hear,
investigate and attempt to resolve complaints relating to matters concerning
the administration of the government of the City and the services rendered by
the City;
   (u)   May, as directed by the corporate authorities, represent the City in
matters concerning the City and other governmental entities;
   (v)   To perform such other duties as may be prescribed or may be required
of him or her by ordinance or resolution of the City Council.
(Ord. 2017-10. Passed 2-6-17.)
224.05   ABSENCE OR DISABILITY, VACANCY IN OFFICE.
   In the case of absence or disability of the City Manager, the Deputy City
Manager shall assume the powers and duties of the City Manager until such time
as the City Manager returns. In the case of a vacancy in the office of the City
Manager, the Deuty City Manager shall assume the powers and duties of the City
Manager until such time as a City Manager is appointed by the Council. In the
event of vacancy in the office of City Manager, the Council shall fill the
vacancy within 120 days after the effective date of such vacancy.
(Ord. 2017-10. Passed 2-6-17; Ord. 2018-45. Passed 9-4-18.)
224.06   REMOVAL.
   The Council may remove the City Manager at anytime by majority vote of
Council, subject to the terms and conditions of the City Manager's employment
agreement, if any.
(Ord. 2017-10. Passed 2-6-17.)
224.07   DEPUTY CITY MANAGER OF FINANCE, COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT AND HUMAN
RESOURCES, POSITION CREATED, APPOINTMENT.
   (a)   There is hereby created the position of Deputy City Manager of
Finance, Community Development and Human Resources, an administrative office of
the City of Freeport, Illinois. The Deputy City Manager may also serve in any
other appointed position for the City of Freeport without any additional
compensation. The position shall be filled by appointment of the City Manager.
The Deputy City Manager shall be subject to the provisions of Sections
288.04 et seq. which provide for the appointment, term of office, removal from
office and vacancy in office.
   (b)   Any person newly appointed to serve as the Deputy City Manager of
Finance, Community Development and Human Resources shall reside within the
corporate limits of the City within six months of the date of his/her
appointment.
(Ord. 2018-19. Passed 4-17-18; Ord. 2022-04. Passed 2-7-22.)
224.08   TERM AND COMPENSATION.
   The Deputy City Manager shall be appointed, and may be removed from office,
with or without cause, by the City Manager. The Deputy City Manager shall
receive such compensation as is set forth in the Salary Schedule provided in
Chapter 290, and the Deputy City Manager shall be subject to all rules and
regulations set forth in
Chapter 290.
(Ord. 2018-19. Passed 4-17-18.)
224.09   POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The Deputy City Manager of Finance, Community Development and Human
Resources shall provide oversight over the Department of Finance and Budget,
the Department of Community and Economic Development, and the Department of
Human Resources. In the absence of the City Manager, the Deputy City Manager
shall assume the powers and duties of the City Manager. The Deputy City Manager
shall also perform such other duties as may be prescribed or may be required of
him by ordinance or resolution of the City Council.
(Ord. 2018-19. Passed 4-17-18.)
CHAPTER 226
Mayor

   Authority re Fire Department - see ADM.

816.15
226.01 QUALIFICATIONS.
   The Mayor shall possess the qualifications stated in Section
288.06.
(1977 Code § 47-201)
226.02 TERM; OTHER OFFICES.
   The Mayor shall hold office for four years, and until his or her successor
is elected and qualified. The Mayor shall not hold any other office under the
City Government during his or her term of office. The date fixed for the
inauguration of the newly elected Mayor shall be during the second regular City
Council meeting during the month of May in respective election years.
(1977 Code §47-202; Ord. 2012-56. Passed 10-15-12; Ord. 2013-25. Passed 6-3-13;
Ord. 2016- 47. Passed 9-19-16.)
226.03 COMPENSATION.
   (a)   The Mayor shall receive as salary the sums as follows: twenty-nine
thousand three hundred thirty dollars ($29,330) from May 19, 2025 through April
30, 2026; thirty-two thousand thirty dollars ($32,030) from May 1, 2026 through
April 30, 2027; thirty-three thousand six hundred thirty dollars ($33,630) from
May 1, 2027 through April 30, 2028; and thirty-six thousand six hundred seventy
dollars ($36,670) from May 1, 2028 through May 21, 2029, per year, payable
every two weeks.
   (b)   During the time period of May 1, 2025 through the swearing in of the
newly elected Mayor on or about May 19, 2025, the Mayor shall receive as salary
the sum of one thousand one hundred seventy-five dollars ($1,175).
(Ord. 96-69. Passed 10-7-96; Ord. 2000-57. Passed 10-16-00; Ord. 2004-59.
Passed 10-18-04; Ord. 2008-44. Passed 9-2-08; Ord. 2012-47. Passed 11-13-12;
Ord. 2016-56. Passed 11-14-16; Ord. 2020-54. Passed 10-5-20; Ord. 2021-39.
Passed 9-20-21; Ord. 2024-54b. Passed 10-21-24.)
226.04 VACANCIES.
   (a)   Reasons for Vacancies. A vacancy may occur in the office of Mayor, by
reason of resignation, failure to elect or qualify, death, permanent physical
or mental disability, conviction of a disqualifying crime, abandonment of
office, removal from office or removal of residence from the City.
   (b)   Vacancies of One Year or Over. When the unexpired term shall be one
year or more from the date when a vacancy in the office of Mayor occurs, it
shall be filled by an election. Council shall elect one of its members to act
as Mayor, and possess all the rights and powers of the Mayor, until a successor
is duly elected and qualified after a special election held for such purpose
within six months after the vacancy occurs.
   (c)   Vacancies of Less Than One Year. If the unexpired term is less than
one year from the occurrence of a vacancy, Council shall elect one of its
members to act as Mayor, who shall possess all the rights and powers of the
Mayor, until the next election and until a successor is elected and qualified.
(1977 Code §§ 47-204 to 47-206)
226.05 MAYOR PRO TEM.
   During the temporary absence or disability of the Mayor, the Council shall
elect one of its members to act as Mayor Pro Tem, who, during such absence or
disability, shall possess and exercise the powers of the Mayor.
(1977 Code § 47-207)
226.06 LOCATION OF OFFICE.
   The Mayor shall keep his or her office at such place in the City Hall as may
be provided by Council.
(1977 Code § 47-208)
226.07 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The Mayor shall:
   (a)   Be considered on a part-time basis in carrying out the duties of the
office of Mayor, and before entering upon the duties of office, take and
subscribe to the oath prescribed by law for City officers.
   (b)   Perform all such duties as are, or may hereafter be, imposed upon him
or her by statute or ordinance, and take care that the laws and ordinances are
faithfully executed.
   (c)   Be hereby authorized to attend tax sales in the county and bid there
at, in behalf of the City, on any real or personal property offered for sale,
to enforce the collection of any tax or special assessment in which the City is
interested; and may purchase at any such sale in behalf of the City.
   (d)   Have the power, at all times, to examine and inspect books, records
and papers of any agent, employee or officer of the City.
   (e)   Appoint all members of boards, commissions, committees of the City,
with the advice and consent of the City Council, except as otherwise provided
in this Code.
   (f)   Following authorization from the City Council, the Mayor or a designee
thereof shall be authorized to sign, approve and enter into intergovernmental
agreements on behalf of the City.
   (g)   Annually, and from time to time, give Council information relative to
the affairs of the City, and recommend, for its consideration, such measures as
he or she may deem expedient.
   (h)   Have the power to administer oaths on all lawful occasions.
   (i)   Whenever an emergency exists or is reasonably anticipated, the Mayor
may, by executive order, exercise the powers and authority of the corporate
authorities of the City which are set forth in this chapter; provided however,
that the Mayor shall not exercise such powers and authority except after
signing under oath a statement that an emergency exists. Such statement shall
set forth facts substantiating that an emergency exists, shall describe the
nature of the emergency and shall declare that an emergency exists. Such
statement shall be filed with the City Clerk as soon as practicable.
(1977 Code § 47-209; Ord. 2017-16. Passed 3-6-17.)
226.08 INCORPORATION OF APPLICABLE STATUTORY PROVISIONS.
   All pertinent and applicable provisions of 65 ILCS 5/3-4-4 to 3-4-6,
inclusive, 65 ILCS 5/3-11-1 to 3-11-7, inclusive, and 65 ILCS 5/3-13-4, as
heretofore and hereafter amended, are hereby incorporated herein by reference,
subject to the provisions of Section
202.05(b) of this Administration Code.

228.01 TERM; OTHER OFFICES.
   The City Clerk shall hold office for four years and until his or her
successor is elected and qualified. He or she shall not hold any other office
under the City Government during his or her term of office. The date fixed for
the inauguration of the newly elected City Clerk shall be during the second
regular City Council meeting during the month of May in respective election
years.
(1977 Code §47-301; Ord. 2012-56. Passed 10-15-12; Ord. 2013-25. Passed 6-3-13;
Ord. 2016- 47. Passed 9-19-16.)
228.02 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   Effective on or before January 1, 1998, the City Clerk shall perform the
customary municipal clerk duties, and more specifically shall:
   (a)   Have charge, custody and control of all instruments, books and papers,
the custody and control of which are not given to any other officers.
   (b)   Attend all meetings of Council and keep a full and correct record of
its proceedings.
   (c)   Keep the corporate seal and use it in all cases where necessary.
   (d)   Perform all duties required of him or her by ordinance or resolution
of Council.
   (e)   Have the power to administer oaths on all lawful occasions.
   (f)   Keep a list of committees of Council and notify committees of the
business referred to them.
   (g)   In conjunction with the Mayor, sign all ordinances and licenses.
   (h)   Keep all records of City elections.
   (i)   Record and index all ordinances passed by Council, and make a
memorandum of the date of passage and of publication of such ordinances, which
record and memorandum, or a certified copy thereof, shall be prima-facie
evidence of the passage and publication of such ordinances for all purposes
whatsoever, and have all ordinances published immediately after their passage,
when required by law or ordinance.
   (j)   Not suffer any records, papers or other writings of the City to be
taken from his or her office under penalty of forfeiture of the amount of all
damages that may accrue by reason of their loss or obliteration.
   (k)   Upon receipt of the annual report of the City Treasury, immediately
cause such report to be published.
   (l)   Be, ex-officio, Town Clerk of the Township of Freeport in the County
of Stephenson and State of Illinois, and pay into the corporate fund of the
City all fees collected for the performance of the duties of Town Clerk.
(Ord. 97-21. Passed 7-21-97; Ord. 2017-56. Passed 7-17-17.)
228.03 COMPENSATION; MEDICAL AND LIFE INSURANCE.
   (a)   The City Clerk shall receive as salary the sums as follows: fifty-
eight thousand two hundred fifty-five dollars ($58,255) from May 19, 2025
through April 30, 2026; sixty-three thousand six hundred fifteen dollars
($63,615) from May 1, 2026 through April 30, 2027; sixty-six thousand seven
hundred ninety-five dollars ($66,795) from May 1, 2027 through April 30, 2028;
and seventy-two thousand eight hundred thirty dollars ($72,830) from May 1,
2028 through May 21, 2029, per year, payable every two weeks.
   (b)   In addition to the above-provided base salary, the City Clerk shall
receive four thousand dollars ($4,000) per annum, on a prorata basis, upon
attaining and maintaining certification as a certified municipal clerk.
   (c)   The City Clerk shall also receive the same medical insurance and life
insurance received by other full-time City employees who are not members of any
certified collective bargaining unit.
   (d)   During the time period of May 1, 2025 through the swearing in of the
newly elected City Clerk on or about May 19, 2025, the City Clerk shall receive
as salary the sum of two thousand three hundred thirty ($2,330) and shall
continue to receive the same medical insurance and life insurance during this
same nineteen-day period.
(Ord. 96-71. Passed 10-7-96; Ord. 2000-58. Passed 10-16-00; Ord. 2004-61.
Passed 10-18-04; Ord. 2008-44. Passed 9-2-08; Ord. 2012-47. Passed 11-13-12;
Ord. 2016-53. Passed 11-14-16; Ord. 2020-54. Passed 10-5-20; Ord. 2024-54c.
Passed 10-21-24.)
228.04 DEPUTIES.
   Deputy City Clerks may be appointed from time to time as provided in the
City's corporate budget approved by the Mayor and as authorized and consented
to by Council. Deputy Clerks may be part-time City employees. Each Deputy Clerk
shall have the power to execute all documents required by any law to be
executed by the City Clerk and to affix the seal of the Clerk thereto wherever
required.
(Ord. 97-21. Passed 7-21-97.)

21, 1997.)

to the provisions of Section
202.05(b) of this Administration Code.
(Ord. 97-21. Passed 7-21-97.)

CHAPTER 232
Department of Public Works
   EDITOR'S NOTE: This chapter, previously titled "City Engineer," and being a
codification of 1977 Code Sections 47-501 through 47-504, Ordinance 84-31,
passed June 4, 1984, Ordinance 90-18, passed February 19, 1990, and new matter
approved, adopted and enacted concurrently with the adoption of these Codified
Ordinances, was re-titled "Department of Public Works" and re-enacted in its
entirety by Ordinance 94-80, passed September 19, 1994.
232.01   Establishment.
232.02   Divisions.

   CROSS REFERENCES

232.01 ESTABLISHMENT.
   There is hereby established a Department of Public Works in and for the
City, as an executive branch of the City Government, which shall consist of a
Director of Public Works and subordinate members in such numbers, and at such
compensation, as may be provided annually by ordinance of the City.
(Ord. 94-80. Passed 9-19-94.)
232.02 DIVISIONS.
   The Department of Public Works shall consist of two primary divisions:
   (a)   A Division of Streets, the duties of which shall include forestry and
cemetery management.
   (b)   A Division of Engineering, the duties of which shall include the
management of public works construction, traffic and street lighting and public
property records and maps.
   (c)   A Division of Transportation Program Administration and Planning, the
duties of which shall include working with the City regarding the Freeport
Albertus Municipal Airport.
(Ord. 94-80. Passed 9-19-94; Ord. 2002-36. Passed 6-3-02; Ord. 2007-40. Passed
6-18-07; Ord. 2018-03. Passed 1-22-18.)
232.03 PUBLIC WORKS DIRECTOR.
   (a)   Establishment and Incidents of Office. There is hereby established the
office of Public Works Director. The office of Public Works Director shall be
subject to the provisions of Sections
288.04  et seq., which provide for appointment, term of office, removal from
office and vacancy in office.
   The Public Works Director shall be appointed, and may be removed from office
with or without cause, by the City Manager. The Public Works Director shall
receive such compensation as is set forth in the Salary Schedule provided in
Chapter 290, and the Director shall be subject to all rules and regulations set
forth in Chapter 290.
   Commencing August 1, 2017 and thereafter, any person newly appointed to
serve as the Public Works Director shall reside within the corporate limits of
the City within six months of the date of his/her appointment.
   (b)   Duties. The Public Works Director shall:
      (1)   Be the executive head of the Department of Public Works.
      (2)   Have the daily supervision, direction and control of employees
within the Division of Health and Environment.
      (3)   Locate and establish the lines and grades of any sidewalk, street
or other public way when requested by the City Manager, and furnish such lines
and grades to persons desiring the same for properly locating and constructing
any sidewalk, curbing or building. He or she shall make any and all surveys in
and for the City ordered by City Manager.
      (4)   Prepare, or arrange for preparation and submission of, all
necessary plans, maps, plats, profiles, specifications and estimates for any
public works or improvements proposed or ordered by City Manager.
      (5)   Except in those cases when the City shall, by ordinance or
contract, provide for a special inspector or consultant, superintend the
construction of all streets, pavements, bridges, storm sewers and other public
improvements; receive, inspect and measure, when required, any and all lumber,
bricks, stone or other material to be used in the construction of any public
works; and inspect and examine daily, or as often as necessary, all public
works in progress of construction. (Ord. 2012-24. Passed 4-16-12.)
      (6)   Preserve all field notes, maps, plans, profiles, papers, books,
writings and records made by him or her, or in his or her hand, and arrange and
index the same.
      (7)   Keep a complete and systematic record of all transactions within
his or her department, and record, in a suitable book, all grades and bench
marks established by the City Manager. All such records shall be the exclusive
property of the City.
      (8)   Attend all meetings of Council and perform such other duties
pertaining to the office as may, from time to time, arise or be imposed by the
City Manager.
      (9)   Annually, or more frequently if requested, submit to the City
Manager a complete report of all operations, including a general abstract of
all public works or improvements undertaken or completed, during the preceding
fiscal year, and of all such other matters and information as may be deemed of
importance or be required by the City Manager.
(Ord. 94-80. Passed 9-19-94.)
      (10)   Effective on or before January 1, 1998, maintain a record of any
payments or cash receipts, issue receipts for all payments or cash received and
daily turn over all cash payments or cash received to the Finance Director or
his or her designee.
(Ord. 97-21. Passed 7-21-97; Ord. 2002-36. Passed 6-3-02.)
      (11)   [Left intentionally blank.]
(Ord. 2007-40. Passed 6-18-07; Ord. 2013-47. Passed 10-7-13; Ord. 2017-52.
Passed 7-3-17; Ord. 2018-03. Passed 1-22-18; Ord. 2019-03. Passed 1-14-19.)
232.04 SUPERINTENDENT OF STREETS.
   (a)   Establishment of Office. There is hereby established the office of
Superintendent of Streets, which shall be subject to the supervision and
direction of the Public Works Director.
   (b)   Appointment and Removal. The Superintendent shall be appointed, and
may be removed without cause, by the City Manager.
   (c)   Compensation. The Superintendent shall receive such compensation as
Council shall annually provide in the appropriation ordinance.
   (d)   Powers and Duties. The powers, duties and responsibilities of the
Superintendent shall be as set forth in the job description for the
Superintendent as may be amended by the City from time to time.
(Ord. 2022-75. Passed 12-19-22.)
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: Former Section 232.04 was repealed by Ordinance No. 2019-03,
passed January 14, 2019.)
232.05 DIVISION OF HEALTH AND ENVIRONMENT.
   (a)   Right of Entry. The Public Works Director, or his or her designated
agent, may, at any reasonable time, enter any house, store, restaurant,
warehouse, business, building or property to make examination and check for
compliance with all ordinances and rules and regulations under the Public Works
Director's jurisdiction as long as such entry is in accordance with applicable
laws.
   (b)   Procedure in Abating Nuisances. The Public Works Director shall
inspect any public or private nuisance and determine the best and most
economical method by which it may be abated or removed. He or she shall then
serve, in person or by mail, or by posting on the premises of the owner,
occupant or agent, if such person is unknown, written notice providing notice
of such action and directions for abatement or removal in the most economical
and sanitary manner. No owner, occupant or agent shall refuse or neglect to
strictly comply with any and all requirements or directions in such notice.
   (c)   Violations of Orders. No person shall violate any lawful order of the
Public Works Director, nor disturb, mutilate or conceal any sign or notice
posted by authority of the Public Works Director, without authority to do so.
(Ord. 2012-24. Passed 4-16-12.)
CHAPTER 234
City Legal Counsel
234.01   Position created.
234.02   Appointment, term and compensation.
234.03   Qualifications of city legal counsel and attorneys.
234.04   Powers and duties.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Election of municipal attorneys - see 65 ILCS 5/3-4-19
   Qualifications - see 65 ILCS 5/3-14-1
   Duties re complaints to the Human Relations Commission - see ADM.
270.16
   Authority re condominiums - see B. & H.
1484.23
234.01 POSITION CREATED.
   There is hereby created the position of City Legal Counsel of the City of
Freeport, Illinois. The position shall be filled by a private law firm.
(Ord. 2016-24. Passed 4-30-17.)
234.02 APPOINTMENT, TERM AND COMPENSATION.
   The position of City Legal Counsel shall be appointed by the City Manager.
The City Legal Counsel shall serve until such time as its successor has been
appointed and qualified. The City Legal Counsel shall receive such compensation
as the City Council may prescribe from time to time.
(Ord. 2016-24. Passed 4-30-17; Ord. 2017-56. Passed 7-17-17.)
234.03 QUALIFICATIONS OF CITY LEGAL COUNSEL AND ATTORNEYS.
   The City Legal Counsel and each attorney employed by the City Legal Counsel
shall be a licensed attorney, admitted to practice by and before the Supreme
Court of the State of Illinois.
(Ord. 2016-24. Passed 4-30-17.)
234.04 POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The City Legal Counsel shall:
   (a)   Superintend and conduct all the legal affairs of the City;
   (b)   Be the legal adviser of the City in all matters connected with the
administration of the City Government;
   (c)   Prepare all ordinances required by Council, or by any committee
thereof;
   (d)   Prepare all leases, deeds, contracts and other legal instruments for
the City, or any department thereof;
   (e)   Furnish written or oral legal opinions on subjects connected with the
administration of the City Government, when requested by the Mayor, Council,
any committee of Council or any department;
   (f)   Have control of all litigation in which the City is in any way
interested. No suits on behalf of the City, except prosecutions for the
recovery of fines and penalties, or for breaches of City ordinances, shall be
instituted or dismissed without its approval and direction.
   (g)   Attend all meetings of Council;
   (h)   Take appeals in all cases where, in its opinion, the interests of the
City require it;
   (i)   Prosecute or defend all appeals in which the City is in any way
interested;
   (j)   For the purpose of prosecuting or defending any litigation or appeal,
make and execute all necessary pleadings, affidavits or other documents;
   (k)   Defend all suits against the City, or any of its officers, and all
cases in which the interests of the City, or official acts of any officer or
agent of the City, are involved;
   (l)   Prosecute all actions for the violation of any ordinances of the City,
and for the recovery of fines and penalties, including but not limited to,
traffic violations and DUI violations;
   (m)   Cause executions to be issued on judgments, and attend to their prompt
collection;
   (n)   Be entitled to all the privileges of an Alderperson, except the
privilege of voting, upon all questions, resolutions or motions before Council,
enacting, amending, repealing or in any manner affecting any ordinance or
resolution;
   (o)   Take all steps necessary to collect delinquent special taxes and
assessments, and render such assistance as is necessary to the State's Attorney
of Stephenson County, in the collection of delinquent taxes and assessments;
   (p)   Be entitled to collect, on behalf of the City, reasonable attorneys'
fees for the time expended by any of its employees in any civil lawsuit brought
to collect a debt or obligation owed to the City, other than for the
prosecution of any ordinance violation. The hourly rate for such attorneys'
fees shall not exceed the actual costs to the City for the compensation and
benefits of the employees, including, but not limited to, the appropriated
office expenses of the City Legal Counsel.
(Ord. 2016-24. Passed 4-30-17.)
CHAPTER 236
Accounting and Finance
