1044.10
236.01 SCOPE.
   The provisions of this chapter include matters relating to the fiscal year,
accounts against the City, the supervision and control of the receipt and
disbursement of money, and the accounting records to be kept by City officers
charged with the collection and disbursement of money. Further duties relating
to each such office imposed by the statutes of the State or by ordinance of the
City are set forth elsewhere in this Administration Code.
(1977 Code § 58-201)
236.02 FISCAL YEAR. 
   Effective January 1, 2020 and thereafter, the fiscal year of the City shall
begin on January 1 and end on December 31 of each year.
(1977 Code § 58-202; Ord. 2019-06. Passed 1-28-19.)
236.03 CLAIMS AGAINST THE CITY.
   All claims against the City, except salaries and fixed charges, shall be
filed with the Finance Director or his or her designee. The claimant shall file
a statement, under oath, as to the correctness of such claim and the facts
connected therewith, whenever so required by the Finance Director or his or her
designee. The Finance Director or his or her designee shall prepare
disbursements and present the same to the City Manager in the form of the
Accounts Payable register for approval prior to actual disbursement. The
Finance Director or his or her designee shall have the authority to approve
exceptions to prior presentment, if the claim is so noted on the Accounts
Payable register, however, such approval remains subject to ratification by the
City Manager.
(Ord. 97-21. Passed 7-21-97; Ord. 2002-61. Passed 10-21-02; Ord. 2003-68.
Passed 9-15-03; Ord. 2017-56. Passed 7-17-17.)
236.04 SALARIES AND FIXED CHARGES.
   The salaries of all City officers and employees shall be entered upon proper
payrolls by the Finance Director or his or her designee, and certified as
correct by him or her. After approval by the Finance Director or his or her
designee, the payrolls shall be presented to the City Manager for final review.
After review by the City Manager, all salaries and fixed charges shall be
presented to the Council for final approval.
(Ord. 97-21. Passed 7-21-97; Ord. 2017-56. Passed 7-17-17.)
236.05 DEPARTMENT OF FINANCE AND BUDGET; FINANCE DIRECTOR.
   (a)   Establishment of Department. There is hereby established as an
executive department of the City a Department of Finance and Budget, which
Department shall consist of the Finance Director or his or her designee and
subordinate members in such number and at such compensation as may be provided
annually by City ordinance.
   (b)   Finance Director. The position of Finance Director shall be subject to
the provisions of Sections
288.04  et seq., which provide for appointments, terms of office, removals from
office and vacancies in the offices of City officers and the appointment, terms
of position, and removals and vacancies of City positions. The Finance Director
shall be appointed and may be removed from his/her position, with or without
cause, by the City Manager. The Finance Director shall receive such
compensation as is set forth in the salary schedule provided in
Chapter 290  and shall be subject to all rules and regulations set forth in
Chapter 290 . The position of Finance Director shall not be an office of the
City.
   Commencing August 1, 2017 and thereafter, any person newly appointed to
serve as the Finance Director shall reside within the corporate limits of the
City within six months of the date of his/her appointment.
   Commencing December 28, 2018 and thereafter, the Finance Director shall also
serve as ex officio City Treasurer and shall have all the powers of and perform
all duties required of, a City Treasurer as set forth by State statute,
including, but not limited to the following:
      (1)   Deposit money received from all sources to his or her credit in one
or more lawfully designated places of deposit. Interest upon such deposits
shall be collected by the Finance Director, shall be reported in his or her
next statement following such collection, shall be credited and paid into the
particular fund upon which such interest accrued and shall be considered a part
of such fund.
      (2)   Invest City funds in accordance with the City Investment Policy.
Deposits which are not needed for immediate disbursement shall be invested
within two working days at prevailing rates or better.
      (3)   At least once per month, or more frequently if required, submit a
report, in the format designated, to the City Manager or his or her designee,
showing the state of the Treasury at the date of the report, all deposits into
and transfers from each fund, the balance in each fund and for all investments,
report in accordance with the City Investment Policy.
      (4)   Hold, as a special fund, all moneys received on any special
assessment, to be applied to the payment for which the assessment was made.
Such money shall be used for no other purpose whatever, except to reimburse the
City for money expended for such improvement.
      (5)   Perform all other duties that the City Manager may from time to
time direct.
      (6)   May combine moneys from more than one fund of the City for the
purpose of investing those funds and join with other municipal treasurers or
municipalities for the purpose of investing the City funds in accordance with
the City Investment Policy.
   Wherever in this Code, or in other ordinances or resolutions of the Council
or in the State statutes the term "treasurer" is used, this term shall mean and
refer to the Finance Director.
   (c)   Segregation of Duties. The Department of Finance and Budget shall be
responsible for the functions of accounting, purchasing and accounts
receivable, and shall be organized so that such duties are distinct and
segregated by assigning a different individual to perform each of the following
general responsibilities:
      (1)   Authorize or approve transactions, including performance of bank
reconciliations;
      (2)   Maintain a system for purchasing and other obligations;
      (3)   Record transactions and maintain the general ledger; and
      (4)   Receive moneys due the City.
   (d)   Duties and Responsibilities. Except as specifically provided by other
ordinance provisions, the Department of Finance and Budget shall:
      (1)   Exercise general supervision over the accounting system in all
offices of the City charged with the receipt, collection or disbursement of
revenues.
      (2)   Perform all duties required of a municipal comptroller pursuant to
65 ILCS 5/3.1-35-100, 3.1-35-105, 3.1-35-110 and 3.1-35-115.
      (3)   Perform all duties required of a municipal collector pursuant to 65
ILCS 5/3.1-35-125 and 3.1-35-130.
      (4)   Establish standard accounting practices; keep controlling accounts
with every City department and with all activities whatever that are owned or
controlled by the City or in which the City has any pecuniary interest;
prepare, as from time to time directed or required, forms of accounts,
vouchers, reports, bills, orders, receipts, checks and other necessary forms to
be used by the several City departments in the transaction of all public
business involving City finances.
      (5)   Keep in proper books a full and accurate account of all moneys
received and disbursed on behalf of the City, specifying the time of receipt
and disbursement, from whom received and to whom disbursed, on what account
received and disbursed, and how paid.
      (6)   Keep a true and correct account of all money belonging to the City,
stating from whom and on what account such money was received.
      (7)   Keep the account of each fund separate and distinct, charging such
fund with all payments and crediting it with all receipts on account thereof.
      (8)   Receive all moneys paid to the City; demand and receive all moneys
and fees owing to the City whenever any person is indebted to the City in any
manner; and report to the City Legal Counsel for prosecution any claim deemed
uncollectible by other methods.
      (9)   Ensure that officers receiving money pay the same into the City
Treasury, when required, and that all necessary financial reports are made by
officers, and report all delinquent payments or reports to the City Manager.
      (10)   Examine and review accounts of all officers and departments,
subject to approval by the City Manager.
      (11)   Authorize payment from the Treasury of such sums of money as may
be ordered by Council. The warrants therefor shall be signed by the City
Manager and countersigned by the City Clerk and shall state for what purpose
the money is appropriated and the fund from which it is payable.
      (12)   Cancel all warrants and other evidences of debt against the City,
with the date of payment written or stamped thereon.
      (13)   Monthly, and more frequently if required, render an account to the
City Manager, under oath, showing the state of, and the balance of money in,
the Treasury; and state in such accounts all moneys received by the Treasury
and on what account, and all warrants redeemed and paid.
      (14)   Transmit to the City Manager, at least monthly, statements of cash
on hand and of classified unencumbered appropriation balances for the city as a
whole and such other financial statements as the City Manager may from time to
time require, and keep all departments, boards or commissions informed of their
classified unencumbered appropriation balances.
      (15)   File with the City Manager a full and detailed account of all
receipts and expenditures, and of all the Director's transactions, during the
preceding fiscal year, and show in such account the state of the Treasury at
the close of the fiscal year. The annual report shall be filed on or before
June 1 of each year, all as provided in 65 ILCS 5/3.1-35-60, as amended.
      (16)   Keep and administer all securities, bonds or other forms of
negotiable instruments owned by or belonging to the City; keep a list of all
outstanding bonds of the City, showing the number and registered owner of each;
keep a record of bonds purchased, paid or canceled; and, in his or her annual
report, the Director shall describe the bonds sold during the year, the terms
of sale and the expense thereof.
      (17)   Deposit the proceeds of all sales of bonds with the Finance
Director immediately after such proceeds have been received, and, until such
deposit, be responsible for the amount thereof.
      (18)   Serve as the Collector of Special Taxes and Assessments and
exercise all the power vested in, and perform all the duties imposed upon, the
Collector of Special Taxes and Assessments as provided in 65 ILCS 5/9-1-1 et
seq., as amended.
      (19)   On or before April 1 of each year, submit to the City Manager the
Director's estimates of the classified expenses of the City during the next
fiscal year. for such purpose, he or she shall require of all officers
statements of the expenses of their respective offices or departments, with any
proposed improvements and probable expenses thereof, all contracts made and
uncompleted, and the amount of all unexpended appropriations of the preceding
year. He or she shall, in such report, show the aggregate income of the
preceding fiscal year from all sources, the amount of liabilities outstanding
upon which interest is to be paid and the bonds and debts payable during the
next year. He or she shall give such other information as may be necessary for
the City Manager to understand the financial exigencies and demands of the
City.
(Ord. 97-21. Passed 7-21-97; Ord. 2017-36. Passed 5-1-17; Ord. 2017- 52. Passed
7-3-17; Ord. 2018-39. Passed 8-6-18; Ord. 2018-67. Passed 12-17-18.)
236.06 DUTIES OF FINANCE AND INTERGOVERNMENTAL RELATIONS COMMITTEE.
   The Finance and Intergovernmental Relations Committee shall examine the
records of all officers relating to the receipt and expenditure of money and
shall take necessary steps to protect the City from all delinquencies or
improper applications of funds. The Committee shall investigate all errors and
discrepancies in accounts and records having to do with the receipt and
disbursement of funds. The Committee shall decide any controversies in the
adjustment of accounts between offices.
(1977 Code § 58-207)
236.07 DOUBLE-ENTRY BOOKKEEPING. (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: Section 236.07 was repealed by Ordinance 97-21, passed July
21, 1997.)
236.08 ANNUAL FINANCIAL STATEMENTS.
   On or before April 30, 1998, and for each subsequent fiscal year, the annual
statement of the City shall be prepared in accordance with Generally Accepted
Accounting Principles (GAAP).
(Ord. 97-21. Passed 7-21-97.)
236.09 CASH RECEIPTS BOOK AND APPROPRIATION EXPENSE LEDGER.
   Effective on or before January 1, 1998, the Finance Director or his or her
designee shall maintain a cash receipts book and an appropriation expense
ledger, and shall keep a record of receipts of his or her office from licenses,
permits, taxes, fees and miscellaneous items of income.
(Ord. 97-21. Passed 7-21-97.)
236.10 WARRANTS.
   (a)   Signatures Required. A warrant shall be signed by the City Manager and
countersigned by the City Clerk, and shall state the fund to which such warrant
has been charged and the payee thereof.
   (b)   Sufficient Funds Required for Payment of Warrants. No warrant payable
on demand shall be drawn unless, at the time of the drawing, there is
sufficient money in the appropriate fund to pay the warrant.
   (c)   Presentation of Warrant for Payment. No warrant drawn on the City
Treasury shall be paid unless presented for payment by the person in whose
favor it is drawn or such person's assignee. The signature of the payee must be
endorsed on the back of such warrant, as well as the signature of the person to
whom such warrant is paid. The register of warrants redeemed and paid shall
described such warrant and shall show the date, the amount and the number of
the warrant and the fund from which such warrant has been paid, as well as the
name of the person to whom such warrant has been paid and the date of payment
thereof.
(Ord. 97-21. Passed 7-21-97; Ord. 2017-36. Passed 5-1-17.)
236.11 INDICATION OF BILL APPROVAL BY COMMITTEE. (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: Section 236.11 was repealed by Ordinance 2017-56, passed
July 17, 2017.)
236.12 PAYMENT OF SMALL BILLS. (REPEALED) 
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: Section 236.12 was repealed by Ordinance 97-21, passed July
21, 1997.)
236.13 PAYMENT OF SPECIAL ASSESSMENT AND MOTOR FUEL TAX INVOICES. 
   Effective on or before January 1, 1998, the Finance Director or his or her
designee is authorized and empowered to pay special assessment invoices and
motor fuel tax invoices when presented and before committee approval.
(Ord. 97-21. Passed 7-21-97.)
236.14 CASH TRANSFERS.
   The Finance Director is authorized and empowered to make transfers of cash
funds for investment purposes with the specific prior permission of the City
Manager.
(Ord. 97-21. Passed 7-21-97; Ord. 2017-56. Passed 7-17-17; Ord. 2018-67. Passed
12-17-18.)
236.15 PREPARATION OF MONTHLY TRIAL BALANCE.
   Effective on or before January 1, 1998, the Finance Director or his or her
designee shall prepare a monthly trial balance to show, in condensed form, a
complete record of the City's revenues, expenses, assets and liabilities.
(Ord. 97-21. Passed 7-21-97.)
236.16 SPECIAL ASSESSMENTS.
   (a)   Records. As special assessments are levied, a journal entry shall be
made, charging "Uncollected Tax Assessment No." with the amount of the levy and
crediting "Special Assessment Bonds Payable" account. As bonds are issued
against an assessment, a journal entry shall be made charging "Special
Assessment Bonds Payable" account with the amount of bonds issued and crediting
"Bonds Outstanding Assessment No." account. As such bonds are redeemed, a
journal entry shall be made charging "Bonds Outstanding Assessment No." account
with the amount of bonds redeemed and crediting "Special Assessment Bonds
Payable" account. The "Special Assessment Bonds Payable" account shall be
charged with the amount of principal collected during the month, as shown by
the "Special Collector's Report" and the "Uncollected Tax Assessment No."
credited.
    (b)   Deposit of Moneys and Use of Interest. The deposit of special
assessment money and the use of interest therefrom shall be in accordance with
the provisions of 65 ILCS 5/8-1-10, as heretofore and hereafter amended, which
section is incorporated herein by reference.
(1977 Code §§ 58-221, 58-222)
236.17 GENERAL BOND RECORDS.
   Effective on or before January 1, 1998, as bonds are issued, an entry shall
be made in the Bond Record kept by the Finance Director or his or her designee
of the details of the bonds, charging "Taxes to be Levied" with the amount of
the issue, and crediting the "Bonds Payable" account with the amounts redeemed
and crediting the "Taxes to be Levied" account.
(Ord. 97-21. Passed 7-21-97.)
236.18 ISSUANCE OF BONDS.
   No general obligation bonds of the City shall be issued except in accordance
with the provisions of 65 ILCS 5/8-1-3 and 5/8-4-1 et seq., the applicable and
pertinent provisions of which, as heretofore and hereafter amended, are
incorporated herein by reference.
(1977 Code § 58-104)
236.19 CLOSING BOOKS.
   At the end of each fiscal year, all corporate revenue and expense accounts
shall be closed into the General Corporate Account to show the working surplus
of the City.
(1977 Code § 58-224)
236.20 DAILY PAYMENT OF CASH RECEIVED. (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: Section 236.20 was repealed by Ordinance 2018-67, passed
December 17, 2018.)
236.21 FINANCE DIRECTOR'S MONTHLY REPORT RE APPROPRIATIONS.
   A monthly report shall be made to the City Manager and the City Council by
the Finance Director or his or her designee, which report shall include a
schedule showing appropriations in detail, the amount expended, the unexpended
balance in each account and the revenue for the period.
(Ord. 97-21. Passed 7-21-97; Ord. 2017-56. Passed 7-17-17.)
236.22 FINANCIAL BOOKS AND RECORDS.
   Effective on or before January 1, 1998, the Finance Director or his or her
designee shall maintain the following books:
   (a)   Cash Receipts Book.
   (b)   Cash Disbursements Book.
   (c)   General Ledger and Journals.
   (d)   Water and Sewer Department Funds.
   (e)   Streets Division Funds.
   (f)   Special Assessment Collection and Expenditures.
   (g)   Special Assessment Forfeiture Record.
   (h)   Special Assessment Judgment Record.
   (i)   Motor Fuel Tax Receipts and Disbursements.
   (j)   Water Revenue Bond Register.
   (k)   Sewage Revenue Bond Register.
   (l)   Special Assessment Roll by Improvement.
   (m)   Special Assessment Bond Register.
   (Ord. 97-21. Passed 7-21-97; Ord. 2002-36. Passed 6-3-02.)
236.23 RECEIPTS AND DISBURSEMENTS OF THE FINANCE DIRECTOR.
   Effective on or before January 1, 1998, the Finance Director or his or her
designee shall enter all receipts in the Cash Receipts Book as collections are
made. Special assessment receipts shall also be credited by the Finance
Director or his or her designee to the improvement accounts affected in the
Special Assessment Collection and Expenditure Record. Warrants for payment
shall be entered in the Cash Disbursements Book by the Finance Director or his
or her designee as payments are made. Special assessment warrants paid shall be
charged by the Finance Director to the improvement accounts affected in the
Special Assessment Collection and Expenditure Record.
(Ord. 97-21. Passed 7-21-97; Ord. 2018-67. Passed 12-17-18.)
236.24 FINANCE DIRECTOR'S MONTHLY REPORTS RE GENERAL FUNDS.
   (a)   Generally. A monthly report shall be made to the City Manager and the
City Council by the Finance Director or his or her designee of the general
funds of the City, including Corporate Library Funds, Fireman's Pension Funds,
the Police Pension Fund, Special Assessment Funds, the Motor Fuel Tax Fund and
any other general or special funds collected.
   (b)   Water and Sewer Fund Reports. The Finance Director or his or her
designee shall also make a separate monthly report on the Water and Sewer
Department, which report shall include the Water Revenue Fund, the Water
Maintenance and Operations Fund, the Water Bond and Interest Fund, the Water
Depreciation and Reserve Fund, the Water Extension and Improvement Fund, Sewage
Revenue Funds, the Sewage Maintenance and Operation Fund and the Sewage
Depreciation Reserve Fund.
(Ord. 97-21. Passed 7-21-97; Ord. 2002-36. Passed 6-3-02; Ord. 2017-56. Passed
7-17-17.)
236.25 TAX ANTICIPATION WARRANTS.
   The issuance and payment of tax anticipation warrants, and the investment of
funds therefrom, shall be in accordance with the provisions of 65 ILCS 5/8-1-11
to 8-1-14, inclusive, as heretofore and hereafter amended, the provisions of
which sections are incorporated herein by reference.
(1977 Code § 58-232)
236.26 ANNUAL AUDITS.
   An annual audit of the accounts of the City shall be made in accordance with
65 ILCS 5/8-8-1 et seq., as heretofore and hereafter amended, which sections
are incorporated herein by reference.
(1977 Code § 58-233)
236.27 APPROPRIATION LIMITATIONS.
   Expenditures within the annual appropriation ordinance, additional
appropriations, borrowing to pay judgments, making of contracts and
commencement of public works shall be in accordance with 65 ILCS 5/8-1-6 and 8-
1-7, as heretofore and hereafter amended, the provisions of which sections are
incorporated herein by reference.
(1977 Code § 58-231)
236.28 ANNUAL APPROPRIATION ORDINANCE.
   The City Council shall, in the first quarter of each fiscal year, pass an
appropriation ordinance in accordance with the provisions of 65 ILCS 5/8-2-9,
the applicable and pertinent provisions of which section, as heretofore and
hereafter amended, are incorporated by reference. However, pending the passage
of the annual appropriation ordinance for any fiscal year, the City Council
hereby authorizes the City Manager to make necessary expenditures for the
support thereof upon the basis of the appropriations of the preceding fiscal
year.
(Ord. 92-14. Passed 5-18-92; Ord. 2017-56. Passed 7-17-17.)
236.29 UNEXPENDED BALANCES OF APPROPRIATION.
   All unexpended balances of any item or items of any appropriation made by
ordinance may be expended in making up any deficiency or deficiencies in any
other item or items of the same general appropriation or in any like
appropriation made by ordinance, and all appropriations unexpended at the close
of the fiscal year shall be placed to the credit of the fund as may be proper,
provided that no such disposition shall be made of any fund covered by any
contract or liability entered into upon the strength of any such appropriation
and which shall remain unpaid at the close of said fiscal year, or of any
special funds that by law are applicable to specific purposes only.
(Ord. 97-21. Passed 7-21-97.)
236.30 DEBT LIMITATIONS.
   All limitations on the indebtedness of the City shall be in accordance with
the provisions of 65 ILCS 5/8-5-1 et seq., the applicable and pertinent
provisions of which, as heretofore and hereafter amended, are incorporated
herein by reference.
(1977 Code § 58-105)
236.31 ALLOCATION OF SURTAX REVENUE. (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: Section 236.31 was repealed by Ordinance 97-21, passed July
21, 1997.)
236.32 INCORPORATION OF APPLICABLE STATUTORY PROVISIONS (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: Section 236.32 was repealed by Ordinance 97-21, passed July
21, 1997.)
236.33   REPORT OF CHANGE IN CITY BOND RATING.
   The City Manager, in conjunction with the City Finance Director, shall
notify the City Council anytime the City’s bond rating changes. Such
notification shall be provided to the City Council at the next City Council
meeting after the City Manager and City Finance Director are informed of the
rating change.
(Ord. 2017-65. Passed 9-18-17.)
CHAPTER 238
Purchases and Contracts

238.01 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   "City Purchasing Policy" means the Policy adopted by official action
of the City Council which sets forth purchasing and procurement guidelines and
procedures.
   (b)   "Contractual services" means and includes all purchased utility
service; towel and cleaning service; insurance; leases for all grounds,
buildings, offices or other space required by the using agencies; and the
rental, repair or maintenance of equipment, machinery and other City-owned
property. The term shall not include professional and other contractual
services which are in their nature unique and not subject to competition. The
term shall also not include the collection of garbage and recyclables, as well
as the processing and disposal of solid wastes.
   (c)   "Supplies" means and includes all supplies, materials and equipment.
   (d)   "Using agency" means any department, agency, commission, bureau or
other unit in the City Government using supplies or procuring contractual
services.
(Ord. 97-19. Passed 4-21-97; Ord. 2017-56. Passed 7-17-17.)
238.02 CONTRACTS NOT IN COMPLIANCE.
   Except as herein provided, it shall be unlawful for any City officer to
purchase any supplies or make any contract within the purview of this chapter
or the City Purchasing Policy, other than through the Purchasing Agent. Any
purchase or contract made contrary to the provisions hereof shall not be
approved by the City Manager, and the City shall not be bound thereby.
(Ord. 97-19. Passed 4-21-97; Ord. 2017-56. Passed 7-17-17.)
238.03 FINANCE DIRECTOR AS PURCHASING AGENT.
   The Finance Director shall be the Purchasing Agent for the City in
accordance with the provisions of 65 ILCS 5/3-6-4, as amended.
(Ord. 97-19. Passed 4-21-97.)
238.04 POWERS AND DUTIES OF PURCHASING AGENT.
   (a)   The Purchasing Agent shall have the power, and it shall be his or her
duty, to purchase or contract for all supplies and contractual services needed
by any using agency, in accordance with the City Purchasing Policy and
procedures adopted in accordance with said Policy.
   (b)   In addition to the purchasing authority conferred in subsection (a)
hereof, and in addition to any other powers and duties conferred by this
chapter, the Purchasing Agent shall:
      (1)   Procure for the City the highest quality in supplies and
contractual services at the least expense to the City.
      (2)   Endeavor to obtain as full and open competition as possible on all
purchases and sales.
      (3)   Keep informed of current developments in the field of purchasing,
prices, market conditions and new products, and secure for the City the
benefits of research in the field of purchasing by other governmental
jurisdictions, national technical societies, trade associations having national
recognition, and private businesses and organizations.
      (4)   Prescribe and maintain such forms as he or she shall find
reasonably necessary for the operation of this chapter and the City Purchasing
Policy.
      (5)   Prepare and adopt a standard purchasing procedure for using
agencies and suppliers.
      (6)   Exploit the possibilities of buying "in bulk" so as to take full
advantage of discounts.
      (7)   Procure for the City all Federal tax exemptions to which it is
entitled.
      (8)   Maintain a list of vendors who default on their obligations and
undertakings to be irresponsible bidders and to disqualify them from receiving
any business from the City for a stated period of time, in accordance with the
City Purchasing Policy.
      (9)   Prepare and adopt specifications for all standard supplies.
      (10)   Exempt any using agency from use of such standard supplies.
(Ord. 97-19. Passed 4-21-97.)
238.05 REQUISITIONS AND ESTIMATES.
   (a)   All using agencies shall file detailed requisitions or estimates of
their requirements for supplies and contractual services in such a manner, at
such times and for such future periods as the Purchasing Agent shall prescribe,
in accordance with the City Purchasing Policy.
   (b)   A using agency may file, at any time, a requisition or estimate for
any supplies and contractual services, the need for which was not foreseen when
the detailed estimates were filed.
   (c)   The Purchasing Agent or his or her designee shall examine each
requisition or estimate it as to quantity, quality or estimated cost.
   (d)   Requisitions shall be signed by the officer or head of the department
for whose use the purchase is to be made, and shall specify, in detail, the
material, supplies or equipment desired.
(Ord. 97-19. Passed 4-21-97.)
238.06 UNENCUMBERED APPROPRIATION BALANCE REQUIRED PRIOR TO ISSUANCE OF
DELIVERY ORDERS.
   Except in cases of emergency, the Purchasing Agent shall not issue any order
for delivery on a contract or purchase unless there is, to the credit of the
using agencies concerned, a sufficient unencumbered appropriation balance, in
excess of all unpaid obligations, to defray the amount of such order.
(Ord. 97-19. Passed 4-21-97.)
238.07 CONFLICTS OF INTEREST. (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: Section 238.07 was repealed by Ordinance 97-19, passed April
21, 1997.)
238.08 ACCEPTANCE OF REBATES, GIFTS, MONEY, ETC., PROHIBITED. (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: Section 238.08 was repealed by Ordinance 97-19, passed April
21, 1997.)
238.09 COMPETITIVE BIDDING REQUIRED.
   Except in the case of an emergency or sole source purchase, all purchases
of, and contracts for, supplies and contractual services shall be based on
competitive bids in accordance with the City Purchasing Policy.
(Ord. 97-19. Passed 4-21-97.)
238.10 FORMAL CONTRACT PROCEDURE FOR PURCHASES OVER $5,000.
   Except in the case of an emergency, all supplies and contractual services
with an estimated cost in excess of five thousand dollars ($5,000) shall be
purchased by formal, written contract from the lowest responsible bidder, after
due notice inviting proposals, in accordance with the City Purchasing Policy.
Prior to advertising for bids, the specifications for each purchase shall be
reviewed and approved by the City Manager.
(Ord. 97-19. Passed 4-21-97; Ord. 2017-56. Passed 7-17-17.)
238.11 BIDDING PROCEDURE.
   (a)   Publication of Notice Inviting Bids. Notice inviting bids shall be
published once in an official newspaper of general circulation within the City,
at least five days preceding the day set for the receipt of proposals. The
notice shall include a general description of the articles to be purchased or
sold or work to be performed, a statement where bid blanks and specifications
may be secured, and the time and place for opening bids.
   (b)   Bid Deposits. When deemed necessary by the Purchasing Agent, bid
deposits shall be prescribed in the notice inviting bids. Unsuccessful bidders
shall be entitled to return of deposits. A successful bidder shall forfeit any
deposit upon his or her failure to enter into a contract within ten days after
the award.
   (c)   Form of Bids. Bids shall be sealed, shall be identified as bids on the
envelope and shall be opened in public at the time and place stated in the
notice.
   (d)   Rejection of Bids. Any bid, parts of a bid or bids, or all bids, may
be rejected for any one or more items or contractual services included in the
bid or proposal, when the public interest will be served thereby.
   (e)   Bids From Contractors in Default of Money Owed to the City. The bid of
a contractor who is in default on the payment of taxes, licenses or other
moneys due the City shall be rejected.
   (f)   Determination of Lowest Responsible Bidder. Contracts shall be awarded
to the lowest responsible bidder, subject to final approval of Council. In
determining the lowest responsible bidder, the Purchasing Agent shall consider,
in addition to price:
      (1)   The ability, capacity and skill of the bidder to perform the
contract or provide the service required;
      (2)   Whether the bidder can perform the contract or provide the service
promptly, or within the time specified, without delay or interference;
      (3)   The quality of performance of previous contracts or services;
      (4)   The previous and existing compliance by the bidder with laws and
ordinances relating to the contract or service;
      (5)   The sufficiency of the financial resources and the ability of the
bidder to perform the contract or provide the service;
      (6)   The quality, availability and adaptability of the supplies, or
contractual services, to the particular use required;
      (7)   The ability of the bidder to provide future maintenance and service
required to support the purchase; and
      (8)   The number and scope of conditions attached to the bid by the
vendor.
   (g)   Statement of Reasons for Not Awarding Contract to Lowest Bidder. When
the award is not given to the lowest bidder, a full and complete statement of
the reasons for placing the order elsewhere shall be prepared by the department
director for submittal to the Purchasing Agent or the City Manager and filed
with the other papers relating to the transaction.
   (h)   Tie Bids. If all bids received are for the same total amount or unit
price, quality and service being equal, the contract shall be awarded to a
local bidder, if any.
(Ord. 97-19. Passed 4-21-97; Ord. 2012-60. Passed 12-3-12; Ord. 2017-56. Passed
7-17-17.)
238.12 PERFORMANCE BONDS.
   The Purchasing Agent may require a performance bond before entering into a
contract, in such an amount as he or she shall find reasonably necessary to
protect the best interests of the City.
(Ord. 97-19. Passed 4-21-97.)
238.13 SUBDIVISION OF CONTRACTS.
   No contract or purchase shall be subdivided to avoid the requirements of
this chapter.
(Ord. 97-19. Passed 4-21-97.)
238.14 PARTICIPATION OF COUNCIL COMMITTEES.
   All procedures and action under this chapter shall be taken in accordance
with the City Purchasing Policy and performed in close cooperation with the
City Manager and the Council.
(Ord. 97-19. Passed 4-21-97; Ord. 2017-56. Passed 7-17-17.)
238.15 OPEN MARKET PROCEDURE FOR PURCHASES.
   (a)   Generally. All purchases of supplies and contractual services of less
than an estimated value of five hundred dollars ($500.00) shall be made in open
market, without newspaper notice and without observing the procedure prescribed
by Section
238.10.
   (b)   Competitive Bids. All open market purchases shall, wherever possible,
be based on at least three competitive bids, and shall be awarded to the lowest
responsible bidder in accordance with the standards set forth in Section
238.10.
(Ord. 97-19. Passed 4-21-97.)
238.16 MANNER OF SOLICITING BIDS.
   The Purchasing Agent or the appropriate department director shall solicit
bids from prospective vendors in accordance with the City Purchasing Policy.
(Ord. 97-19. Passed 4-21-97.)
238.17 MAINTENANCE OF RECORDS.
   The Purchasing Agent and the appropriate department directors shall maintain
purchasing records in accordance with the City Purchasing Policy, and such
records shall be open to public inspection in accordance with provisions of the
Illinois Freedom of Information Act.
(Ord. 97-19. Passed 4-21-97.)
238.18 APPLICATION OF ILLINOIS MUNICIPAL CODE. (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: Section 238.18 was repealed by Ordinance 97-19, passed April
21, 1997.)
238.19 SURPLUS STOCK.
   (a)   All using agencies shall submit to the Purchasing Agent, at such times
and in such form as he or she shall prescribe, reports showing stocks of all
supplies which are no longer used or which have become obsolete, worn out or
scrapped.
   (b)   The Purchasing Agent may transfer surplus stock to other using
agencies.
   (c)   The Purchasing Agent may sell all surplus stock, or exchange the same
for, or trade in the same on, new supplies.
   (d)   Sales under this section shall be made to the highest responsible
bidder and in conformance with Section
238.24.
(Ord. 97-19. Passed 4-21-97.)
238.20 COOPERATIVE PURCHASING.
   The Purchasing Agent may join with other units of government in cooperative
purchasing plans when the best interests of the City would be served thereby.
(Ord. 97-19. Passed 4-21-97.)
238.21 DELEGATION OF AUTHORITY BY PURCHASING AGENT. (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: Section 238.21 was repealed by Ordinance 97-19, passed April
21, 1997.)
238.22 DISCRIMINATION IN CONTRACTS.
   (a)   It shall be unlawful for any department of the City or any City
official, his or her agent or employee, for or on behalf of the City, to refuse
to employ or to discharge any person, otherwise qualified, on account of race,
color, creed, national origin or ancestry; to discriminate for the same reasons
in regard to tenure, terms or conditions of employment; to deny a promotion or
an increase in compensation solely for the same reasons; to publish an offer of
employment based on the same reasons; to adopt or enforce any rule or
employment policy which discriminates between employees on account of the same
reasons; to seek such information as to any employee as a condition of
employment; or to penalize any employee or discriminate in the selection of
personnel for training, solely on the basis of the same reasons.
   (b)   All contracting agencies of the City, or any department thereof, shall
include in all contracts hereafter negotiated or renegotiated by them a
provision obligating the contractor not to discriminate against any employee or
applicant for employment because of race, color, creed, national origin or
ancestry, and shall require him or her to include a similar provision in all
sub-contracts.
   (c)   All purchase orders of the City, or any department thereof, shall
include a provision that the vendor does not and will not discriminate against
any of its employees or applicants for employment because of race, color,
creed, national origin or ancestry.
   (d)   In the event that any contracting agency or vendor shall so
discriminate, the City shall have the right to cancel any contract or revoke
any purchase order with any contractor or vendor guilty of discrimination.
(Ord. 97-19. Passed 4-21-97.)
238.23 CODE OF CONDUCT.
   (a)   Establishment; Application. There is hereby established a Code of
Conduct, as provided in the following sections, which shall apply to the
performance of duties by every official, employee or agent of the City who is
engaged in the award and administration of any contract or agreement supported
in whole or in part, by Federal or State funds.
   (b)   Definitions. As used in this section:
      (1)   "Conflict of interest" means whenever any person, as defined
herein, or any of his or her immediate family, partner or an organization which
employs or is about to employ any person, his or her immediate family or
partner, possesses or receives a financial or other valuable interest in a firm
selected for an award of a contract.
      (2)   "Contract" means any written contract or agreement to which the
City is a party and which is supported, in whole or in part, by Federal or
State funds.
      (3)   "Contractor" means any party to a contract, as defined herein,
other than the City.
      (4)   "Person" means any official, employee or agent of the City who is
engaged in the selection, award or administration of any contract, as defined
herein.
   (c)   Prohibited Acts. No person shall:
      (1)   Participate in the selection or in the award or administration of
any contract if a conflict of interest would be created;
      (2)   Solicit or accept gratuities, favors or anything of monetary value
from contractors, potential contractors or parties to subcontracts;
      (3)   Violate any applicable State or Federal statutes which govern the
selection, award or administration of public contracts; or
      (4)   Fail to disclose to the City Legal Counsel the possibility of any
conflict of interest within forty-eight hours of learning of the same.
   (d)   Exemption. Any person may accept a gift or gratuity without violating
any of the provisions of this section if the item is of a nominal value of
twenty-five dollars ($25.00) or less. A person shall not accept any amount of
United States currency or coinage as a gift or gratuity.
   (e)   Penalties. The penalties for the violation of this section shall be as
follows:
      (1)   An elected official shall be subject to censure by Council.
      (2)   An appointed official may be removed from office in accordance with
and as provided in the Illinois Municipal Code or these Codified Ordinances, or
be suspended without pay.
      (3)   An employee may be subject to the applicable disciplinary
provisions provided in these Codified Ordinances.
      (4)   An agent of the City may have his, her or its contract or agreement
with the City terminated immediately upon discovery of the violation.
(Ord. 97-19. Passed 4-21-97; Ord. 2017-56. Passed 7-17-17.)
238.24 SALE OF OBSOLETE PROPERTY.
   (a)   All sales of personal property which has become obsolete and unusable,
with an estimated value of five hundred dollars ($500.00) or less, shall be
made in open market, without newspaper notice and without competitive bidding.
   (b)   All personal property which has become obsolete and unusable, with an
estimated value in excess of five hundred dollars ($500.00), shall be sold,
after due notice inviting proposals, by formal written contract to the highest
responsible bidder, as determined to be in the best interests of the general
public.
(Ord. 97-19. Passed 4-21-97.)
238.2 CONTRACTS FOR OUTSIDE PROFESSIONAL CONSULTANTS.
   Notwithstanding the formal contract and bidding procedures set forth in this
Chapter (along with any other provision to the contrary contained in this
Chapter 238) from time to time, as determined by a two-third (2/3) majority
vote of the corporate authorities, the corporate authorities may select, retain
and contract for outside professional consultants which require technical
training or knowledge, including, but not limited to, engineers, auditors,
legal counsel, land planners and other professional consultants and the
corporate authorities may appropriate funds to provide for such services.
(Ord. 2016-23B. Passed 4-30-17.)
State Law Reference-
   Contractual liabilities: limitations, 65 ILCS 5/8-1-7.
CHAPTER 239
Municipally Owned Real Estate
239.01   Definitions.
239.02   Transactions involving public property.
239.03   Authority of City Manager.
239.04   Acquisition of interests in real property.
239.05   Disposition of interests in real property.
239.01 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter, the following terms shall have the meaning assigned
in this section.
   (a)   "Acquisition" means the purchase, lease or license by the City for the
City's use or acceptance by the City of a dedication or gift.
   (b)   "City" means the City of Freeport, or any boards, commissions, or
committees formed pursuant to these Ordinances or otherwise authorized by State
statute.
   (c)   "Disposition" means the sale, lease, transfer, release, or license of
some or all of the City's interest in public property to a third party whether
by deed or other instrument.
   (d)   "Public property" means real property that is either titled in the
name of the City or any beneficial interest the City may hold in real property,
including, but not limited to leases, easements, licenses or other partial
interests whether vested or contingent, regardless of whether said interest is
equitable or legal in nature.
(Ord. 2020-34. Passed 7-6-20.)
239.02 TRANSACTIONS INVOLVING PUBLIC PROPERTY.
   The City Council may authorize the acquisition or disposition of interests
in public property in accordance with the provisions of this chapter. The
provisions of this chapter are enacted pursuant to the Home Rule authority of
the City and shall supersede all otherwise applicable provisions of State
statute within the Illinois Municipal Code, now existing or hereinafter
enacted, concerning the acquisition and disposition of real property. Provided,
nothing in this chapter shall be deemed to prevent the City from exercising any
rights with respect to the transfer of property which is otherwise available to
municipalities under State statute or regulation if such exercise does not
expressly conflict with the terms hereof.
(Ord. 2020-34. Passed 7-6-20.)
239.03 AUTHORITY OF CITY MANAGER.
   The City Manager is authorized as the City's agent to execute or accept
deeds, easements, licenses, leases, dedications or other documents necessary to
consummate the acquisition or disposition of real property, or any interests
therein, subject to the provisions of this chapter. Prior to any acquisition or
disposition involving real property interests, the City Attorney shall approve
the form of the documents utilized in the transaction.
(Ord. 2020-34. Passed 7-6-20.)
239.04 ACQUISITION OF INTERESTS IN REAL PROPERTY.
   The City Manager shall have the authority to make acquisitions of interests
in real property in accordance with this section.
   (a)   The City Manager is authorized to negotiate and execute agreements for
the acquisition of real property on behalf of the City for public purposes
according to the provisions of this section, without further action by the City
Council, in the following circumstances:
      (1)   When such acquisition has been previously authorized by an adopted
Council Policy or resolution; or
      (2)   When the cost for such real property interests or option does not
exceed the greater of (A) US$10,000.00, or (B) the maximum cost provided for in
Chapter 238 for purchases permitted to be made by the Purchasing Agent.
         For any acquisitions not otherwise formally approved by the City
Council via duly adopted resolution or ordinance, the City Manager shall make a
written report of any such transactions to the City Council within thirty (30)
days after the date the transaction is completed including, at a minimum, the
name of the grantor, the property address (including PIN), estimated and/or
appraised market value, and the amount paid. Any acquisition of an interest in
real property which is not specifically authorized in this section shall only
be executed by authorization by the City Council granted by resolution or
ordinance.
   (b)   The City Manager may make acquisitions of interest in real property
authorized by this section according to commercially reasonable and practical
methods. Said methods may include but are not limited to the following:
      (1)   Making bids or offers at any tax, foreclosure, or other judicially
ordered or sanctioned sale;
      (2)   Purchasing interests in real property in lieu of foreclosure of a
City lien on that property in an amount not to exceed the lien, unless a higher
figure is specifically authorized by the Council; and
      (3)   Purchasing interests in real property from a financial institution
where such property has been obtained by such financial institution in lieu of
foreclosure or through a foreclosure proceeding; and
      (4)   Accepting gifts or donations of interests real property;
      (5)   By the use of a statutory procedure afforded to municipalities
under State statute, including, but not limited to, eminent domain.
   (c)   This section shall only be deemed to authorize the purchase of
property which is located:
      (1)   Within the corporate limits of the City;
      (2)   Contiguous to the City; or
      (3)   Within 1.5 miles of the corporate limits and as part of a
development plan or annexation agreement;
   (d)   Acquisitions made by the City Manager shall be made for compensation
in an amount not to exceed the greater of (A) the fair market value of the
property as determined by an appraisal or (B) the amount of the City's lien on
the property, if applicable under subsection (b)(2) of this section.
Notwithstanding the foregoing, a higher price may be offered for any property
if specifically authorized by the City Council in a duly adopted resolution or
ordinance.
   (e)   The City Manager may establish procedures and standards for
acquisition of property consistent with this chapter and standard set forth
herein.
(Ord. 2020-34. Passed 7-6-20.)
239.05 DISPOSITION OF INTERESTS IN REAL PROPERTY.
   The City Manager shall have the authority to make dispositions of interest
in real property in accordance with this section.
   (a)   The City Manager is authorized to negotiate and execute agreements for
the disposition of real property on behalf of the City according to the
provisions of this section, without further action by the City Council, in the
following circumstances:
      (1)   lf the City Council, by duly executed resolution or ordinance
declares specific parcels of public property to no longer be necessary for the
City's use;
      (2)   If the City Manager declares specific parcels of public property to
no longer be necessary for the City's use and the value of the particular
interest to be conveyed is less than the greater of (A) US$10,000.00 or (B) the
maximum cost provided for in
Chapter 238 for purchases permitted to be made by the Purchasing Agent. For
purposes of determining the limit the City Manager's authority pursuant to this
section, the value of each parcel or interest therein shall be deemed a
separate transaction, and multiple transactions proximate in time shall not be
aggregated; or
      (3)   By the use of a statutory procedure afforded to municipalities
under State statute, including, but not limited to, vacation of public ways.
   (b)   The resolution or ordinance which declares that public property is no
longer necessary for the City's use may set forth the method of determining a
sales price and the manner of disposition. In the event that a method or price
or both are not established in the resolution or ordinance:
      (1)   In the event that a specific method is not specified, the City
Manager shall utilize commercially reasonable methods to market and sell the
public property, including, but not limited to, negotiating directly with an
adjacent landowner or potential developer for the parcel, engaging a licensed
real estate broker, auctioneer, or other sales agent to market the public
property for sale, or by inviting proposals for use from interest persons;
      (2)   In the event the price is not established, the City Manager shall
obtain an appraisal from a licensed real estate appraiser regularly doing
business in the City. The sales price shall not be less than eighty percent
(80%) of the appraised value without express authorization from the City
Council;
      (3)   Notwithstanding anything contained in subsections (1) or (2) above,
if the estimated value of the property is less than the greater of (A)
US$10,000.00 or (B) the maximum cost provided for in
Chapter 238 for purchases permitted to be made by the Purchasing Agent, the
City Manager may, in lieu of an appraisal, determine the sales price by
utilizing other objective methods, including valuation for real estate tax
purposes or recent comparable sales.
   (c)   The City Council, or the City Manager, if the estimated value of the
public property deemed no longer necessary for the City's use is less than
US$10,000.00, may elect to donate public property, without monetary
consideration, to a qualified charitable organization, governmental unit or
individual, if such donation would either:
      (1)   Assist in an economic development project or other community
building project which would not occur without City financial assistance; or
      (2)   Eliminate the City's responsibility to maintain otherwise vacant or
underutilized property and the disposition would further an articulated policy.
   (d)   In connection with any disposition of real estate, the City may elect
to restrict such transfer by conditioning the disposition upon:
      (1)   The City's retention of an interest in the form of a permanent
easement, right of first refusal, option, reverter, or other retained interest
in real property conveyed to any party; and/or
      (2)   The performance of specific contractual obligations contained in a
Redevelopment Agreement, covenant, or other similar instrument requiring
certain improvements or land uses upon which the City is relying as part of its
decision to make a particular disposition.
(Ord. 2020-34. Passed 7-6-20.)
CHAPTER 240
Police Department
   EDITOR'S NOTE: The City executes labor agreements from time to time with
recognized representatives of members of the Police Department, which
agreements provide for wages, benefits and conditions of employment for such
members. The provisions of this chapter, therefore, apply only to those members
of the Department, and to those subjects, not otherwise provided for in such
agreements. Copies of the latest relevant legislation and of such agreements
may be obtained, at cost, from the City Clerk.
