266.01 ESTABLISHMENT; MEMBERSHIP; DUTIES.
   (a)   There is hereby established a Liquor Commission, which shall consist
of four members, who shall be residents of the City, to be appointed by the
Mayor. The Mayor or his or her designee, acting as Liquor Commissioner, shall
also serve as a member and as Chair of the Liquor Commission. Each member shall
serve a four-year term, or until a successor is appointed and qualified. For
purposes of this section, any member (with the exception of the Mayor) who
misses three consecutive meetings of the Liquor Commission may be removed by
the Mayor, subject to confirmation of such removal by the City Council.
   (b)   The Liquor Commission shall have the following powers and duties:
      (1)   Licenses in general. To grant, to suspend and to revoke for cause
all licenses issued under
Chapter 806 of the Business Regulation and Taxation Code for premises within
its jurisdiction;
      (2)   Suspension and revocation of licenses. To hear violations of
Chapter 608, Alcoholic Liquor, of the General Offenses Code, and
Chapter 806, Alcoholic Liquor Sales, of the Business Regulation and Taxation
Code, and to suspend or revoke the license of any licensee for any violations
of said chapters;
      (3)   Examination of applicants. To examine or cause to be examined under
oath any applicant for a local license or for a renewal thereof, or any
licensee upon whom notice of hearing has been served, and to hear testimony and
take proof for its information in the performance of its duties;
      (4)   Rules and regulations. To establish, promulgate, amend, repeal and
enforce such reasonable rules and regulations, relating to the administration
and enforcement of the provisions of this chapter, as it deems advisable; and
      (5)   Exercise of powers granted under State law. To exercise all powers,
functions and duties which now or hereafter may be granted by the Illinois
Liquor Control Act or by City ordinance.
(Ord. 94-106. Passed 12-19-94.)
   (c)   Except as may otherwise be provided by ordinance, the fiscal
responsibility of the Commission is of an advisory nature only, and the
Commission shall not have authority to authorize the expenditure of public
funds.
(Ord. 95-2. Passed 2-6-95; Ord. 2017-85. Passed 12-18-17.)
266.02 REPORTS TO CITY MANAGER; RECORDS; COMPENSATION.
   The Liquor Commission shall make a written report to the City Manager in
January and July of each year of facts and doings for the preceding six months,
and shall keep a written record of its meetings wherein action is taken in
regard to the issuance or revocation of any liquor license. The City Manager,
Alderpersons and other officers of the City shall have access to such records
for inspection at all reasonable times.
   The members of the Liquor Commission shall be compensated as provided in
Section
288.12 of this Administration Code. Such compensation shall be paid quarterly.
(Ord. 94-106. Passed 12-19-94; Ord. 2017-56. Passed 7-17-17.)
266.03 DUTIES OF CITY CLERK.
   The City Clerk shall receive all license applications and issue all licenses
when directed to do so by the Liquor Commission, and perform such other duties
and functions as are assigned to him or her by City ordinance.
(Ord. 94-106. Passed 12-19-94.)

CHAPTER 270
Human Relations Commission (Fair Housing and Human Relations)

662.03
270.01 ESTABLISHMENT, PURPOSE; DECLARATION OF POLICY.
   (a)   The City Council shall establish a Human Relations Commission in
accordance with 65 ILCS 5/11-11.1-1 . It is hereby declared to be the policy of
the City and the purpose of this chapter, in the exercise of the City's police
and regulatory powers for the protection of the public safety, health, morals,
and welfare, and for the maintenance and promotion of commerce, industry,
education, healthcare, good government and other public services in the City,
to secure for all persons living and/or working or desiring to live and/or work
in the City a fair opportunity to purchase, lease, rent or occupy real estate
without discrimination based on race, color, ancestry, national origin,
religion, sex (including sexual harassment), pregnancy, age (40 and over),
order of protection status, marital status, sexual orientation (including
gender-related identity), military status, unfavorable military discharge,
disability, arrest record, familial status, citizenship status and source of
income.
   (b)   The mission of the Human Relations Commission shall be to foster and
promote understanding, mutual respect, cooperation and positive relations
between and among all residents of the City of Freeport, regardless of race,
color, ancestry, national origin, religion, sex (including sexual harassment),
pregnancy, age (40 and over), order of protection status, marital status,
sexual orientation (including gender-related identity), military status,
unfavorable military discharge, disability, arrest record, familial status,
citizenship status and source of income, to the end that a sense of shared
community among residents is strengthened, mutual trust toward each other is
promoted, the value of each individual is affirmed and the constitutional
rights of all are realized.
(Ord. 2024-09. Passed 3-18–24.)
270.02 LIBERAL CONSTRUCTION.
   This chapter shall be construed according to the fair import of its terms
and shall be liberally construed to further the purposes and policy stated in
Section
270.01 and the special purposes of the particular provision involved.
(Ord. 2024-09. Passed 3-18–24.)
270.03 DEFINITIONS.
   For purposes of this chapter:
   (a)   "Commission" means the City Human Relations Commission.
   (b)   "Commission panel" or "panel" means a panel, comprised of three or
more members of the Commission, designated by the Chairperson of the
Commission, to investigate and to attempt to conciliate a complaint filed or
made under Section
270.11.
   (c)   "Lease" includes sublease, assignment and rental, and includes any
contract to do any of the foregoing.
   (d)   "Lending institution" means any bank, insurance company, savings and
loan association, other person in the business of lending money or guaranteeing
loans, any person in the business of obtaining, arranging or negotiating loans
or guarantees as an agent or broker and any person in the business of buying or
selling loans or instruments for the payment of money which are secured by
title to, or a security interest in, real estate.
   (e)   "National origin" includes the national origin of an ancestor.
   (f)   "Owner" means any person who holds legal or equitable title to, or
owns any beneficial interest in, any real property or who holds legal or
equitable title to shares of, or holds any beneficial interest in, any real
estate cooperative which owns any real property.
   (g)   "Person" means one or more individuals, corporations, partnerships,
associations, legal representatives, mutual companies, unincorporated
organizations, trusts, trustees, trustees in bankruptcy, receivers and
fiduciaries.
   (h)   "Purchase" includes any contract to purchase.
   (i)   "Real estate agent" means any real estate broker, any real estate
salesperson and any other person who, as employee, agent or otherwise, engages
in the management or operations of any real property.
   (j)   "Real estate broker" means any person licensed as a real estate broker
in accordance with the provisions of 225 ILCS 455/1 et seq., or required
thereby to be so licensed.
   (k)   "Real estate salesperson" means any person licensed as a real estate
salesperson in accordance with the provisions of 225 ILCS 455/1 et seq., or
required thereby to be so licensed.
   (l)   "Real estate transaction" means the purchase, sale, exchange or lease
of any real property, and an option to do any of the foregoing.
   (m)   "Real property" means any real estate, vacant land, building or
structure within the City limits and includes lands, tenements and
hereditaments and all legal and equitable rights and interests therein and
thereto.
   (n)   "Sale" includes any contract to sell, exchange or convey, transfer or
assign legal or equitable title to, or a beneficial interest in, real property.
(Ord. 2024-09. Passed 3-18–24.)
270.04   UNLAWFUL REAL ESTATE PRACTICES BY OWNERS OF REAL PROPERTY.
   (a)    Discriminatory Terms, Conditions or Privileges. It shall be an
unlawful housing practice and a violation of this chapter for any owner or
other person to sell or lease real property on terms, conditions or privileges
that discriminate between persons because of race, color, ancestry, national
origin, religion, sex (including sexual harassment), pregnancy, age (40 and
over), order of protection status, marital status, sexual orientation
(including gender-related identity), military status, unfavorable military
discharge, disability, arrest record, familial status, citizenship status and
source of income.
   (b)   Refusals to Negotiate. It shall be an unlawful real estate practice
and a violation of this chapter for any owner or other person to refuse to
negotiate for, enter into or perform any sale or lease of any real property
because of the race, color, ancestry, national origin, religion, sex (including
sexual harassment), pregnancy, age (40 and over), order of protection status,
marital status, sexual orientation (including gender-related identity),
military status, unfavorable military discharge, disability, arrest record,
familial status, citizenship status and source of income of any party to such
sale or lease, of any member of the family of any such party, of any person
using or occupying, or intending to use or occupy, such real property or of any
person using or occupying any real property in the area in which such real
property is located.
   (c)   Withholding of Housing. It shall be an unlawful real estate practice
and a violation of this chapter for any owner or other person to represent to
any person that any real property is not available for inspection, purchase,
sale, lease or occupancy when in fact it is so available, or otherwise to
withhold real property from any person because of race, color, ancestry,
national origin, religion, sex (including sexual harassment), pregnancy, age
(40 and over), order of protection status, marital status, sexual orientation
(including gender-related identity), military status, unfavorable military
discharge, disability, arrest record, familial status, citizenship status and
source of income.
   (d)   Unlawful Advertisements. It shall be an unlawful real estate practice
and a violation of this chapter for any owner or other person to publish or
circulate a statement, advertisement or notice of an intention to sell or lease
any real property in a manner that is unlawful under this chapter, or to
consent thereto.
   (e)   Unlawful Signs and Notices. It shall be an unlawful real estate
practice and a violation of this chapter for any owner or other person to post
or erect, or cause any person to post or erect, any sign or notice upon any
real property indicating an intent to sell or lease any real property in a
manner that is unlawful under this chapter.
   (f)   Limitations; Exceptions. Nothing in this chapter shall require an
owner to offer real property to the public at large before selling or renting
it, provided that he or she complies with all other provisions of this chapter,
require an owner or his or her agent to offer real property for sale or lease
to any person if the owner or his or her agent has reasonable cause, which can
be substantiated, to believe that such person is not negotiating for the
purchase or lease of such real property in good faith, or prohibit owners from
giving preference to prospective tenants or buyers for any reason other than
race, color, ancestry, national origin, religion, sex (including sexual
harassment), pregnancy, age (40 and over), order of protection status, marital
status, sexual orientation (including gender-related identity), military
status, unfavorable military discharge, disability, arrest record, familial
status, citizenship status and source of income.
(Ord. 2024-09. Passed 3-18–24.)
270.05   UNLAWFUL REAL ESTATE PRACTICES BY REAL ESTATE AGENTS AND LENDING
INSTITUTIONS.
   (a)   Withholding of Housing. It shall be an unlawful real estate practice
and a violation of this chapter for any real estate agent or other person to
represent to any person that any real property is not available for inspection,
sale, lease or occupancy when in fact it is so available, or otherwise to
withhold real property from any person because of race, color, ancestry,
national origin, religion, sex (including sexual harassment), pregnancy, age
(40 and over), order of protection status, marital status, sexual orientation
(including gender-related identity), military status, unfavorable military
discharge, disability, arrest record, familial status, citizenship status and
source of income.
   (b)   Unlawful Refusal of Offers. It shall be an unlawful real estate
practice and a violation of this chapter for any real estate agent or other
person to refuse to receive or to fail to transmit a bona fide offer for the
purchase, sale, exchange or lease of any real property because of the race,
color, ancestry, national origin, religion, sex (including sexual harassment),
pregnancy, age (40 and over), order of protection status, marital status,
sexual orientation (including gender-related identity), military status,
unfavorable military discharge, disability, arrest record, familial status,
citizenship status and source of income of the person making such offer.
   (c)   Unlawful Advertisements. It shall be an unlawful real estate practice
and a violation of this chapter for any real estate agent or other person to
publish or circulate a statement, advertisement or notice of an intention to
sell or lease any real property in a manner that is unlawful under this
chapter.
   (d)   Unlawful Signs and Notices. It shall be an unlawful real estate
practice and a violation of this chapter for any real estate agent or other
person to post or erect, or cause or permit any person to post or erect, any
sign or notice upon any real property, managed by or in the custody, care or
control of such real estate agent or other person, indicating an intent to sell
or lease any real property in a manner that is unlawful under this chapter.
   (e)   Discrimination in Lending. It shall be an unlawful real estate
practice and a violation of this chapter for any lending institution, in
making, agreeing to make, arranging or negotiating any loan or guarantee of
funds for the purpose of financing the purchase or sale, construction, lease,
rehabilitation, improvement, renovation or repair of any real property, to
offer, seek or agree to terms, conditions or privileges that discriminate
between persons because of race, color, ancestry, national origin, religion,
sex (including sexual harassment), pregnancy, age (40 and over), order of
protection status, marital status, sexual orientation (including gender-related
identity), military status, unfavorable military discharge, disability, arrest
record, familial status, citizenship status and source of income.
   (f)   Refusals to Deal in Lending. It shall be an unlawful real estate
practice and a violation of this chapter for any lending institution to refuse
to negotiate for, enter into or perform any agreement to lend or guarantee the
loan of funds for the purchase, sale, construction, lease, rehabilitation,
improvement, renovation or repair of any real property because of the race,
color, ancestry, national origin, religion, sex (including sexual harassment),
pregnancy, age (40 and over), order of protection status, marital status,
sexual orientation (including gender-related identity), military status,
unfavorable military discharge, disability, arrest record, familial status,
citizenship status and source of income, of any party to such agreement, any
member of the family of any such party or residents of the area in which such
real property is located.
   (g)   Application of Section; Exceptions. This section shall apply,
respectively, to every real estate agent who, within the City, performs any
function as such real estate agent but does not maintain an office or place of
doing business within the City. Further, this section applies to every real
estate agent and lending institution who or which maintains an office or place
of doing business within the City, provided, however, that the provisions of
this chapter shall not be so construed as to prohibit a real estate broker or
real estate agent, on behalf of the owner, from inquiring into and reporting
upon qualifications of any prospective buyer or tenant with respect to
limitations or exclusions other than those of race, color, ancestry, national
origin, religion, sex (including sexual harassment), pregnancy, age (40 and
over), order of protection status, marital status, sexual orientation
(including gender-related identity), military status, unfavorable military
discharge, disability, arrest record, familial status, citizenship status and
source of income.
(Ord. 2024-09. Passed 3-18–24.)
270.06   UNLAWFUL REPRESENTATIONS IN REAL ESTATE TRANSACTIONS.
   It shall be an unlawful real estate practice and a violation of this chapter
for any person, for the purpose of inducing any other person to enter into a
real estate transaction with such person, his or her principal or his or her
agent:
   (a)   To represent that a change has occurred, will occur or may occur with
respect to race, color, ancestry, national origin, religion, sex (including
sexual harassment), pregnancy, age (40 and over), order of protection status,
marital status, sexual orientation (including gender-related identity),
military status, unfavorable military discharge, disability, arrest record,
familial status, citizenship status and source of income in the composition of
the owners or occupants in any block, neighborhood or area in which the real
property (which is the subject of the real estate transaction) is located; or
   (b)   To represent that a change with respect to the race, color, ancestry,
national origin, religion, sex (including sexual harassment), pregnancy, age
(40 and over), order of protection status, marital status, sexual orientation
(including gender-related identity), military status, unfavorable military
discharge, disability, arrest record, familial status, citizenship status and
source of income in the composition of the owners or occupants in any block,
neighborhood or area will result in the lowering of property values, in an
increase in criminal or antisocial behavior or in a decline in the quality of
schools in such block, neighborhood or area.
(Ord. 2024-09. Passed 3-18–24.)
270.07 OTHER UNLAWFUL REAL ESTATE PRACTICES.
   It shall be an unlawful real estate practice and a violation of this chapter
for any person to:
   (a)   Aid, abet, incite or coerce a person to engage in an unlawful real
estate practice.
   (b)   Deceive, exploit, cheat or overcharge any person in a real property
transaction in the City, or make any distinction, discrimination or restriction
against any person as to the conditions or privileges of any kind relating to
the sale, rental, lease or occupancy of any real property.
   (c)   Deliberately and knowingly refuse examination of copies of any listing
of real property in the City to any person because of race, color, ancestry,
national origin, religion, sex (including sexual harassment), pregnancy, age
(40 and over), order of protection status, marital status, sexual orientation
(including gender-related identity), military status, unfavorable military
discharge, disability, arrest record, familial status, citizenship status and
source of income.
   (d)   Enter into a listing agreement which prohibits the inspection, sale,
lease, or occupancy of real property to any person because of race, color,
ancestry, national origin, religion, sex (including sexual harassment),
pregnancy, age (40 and over), order of protection status, marital status,
sexual orientation (including gender-related identity), military status,
unfavorable military discharge, disability, arrest record, familial status,
citizenship status and source of income.
   (e)   Act or undertake to act with respect to any real property, the
disposition of which is prohibited to any person because of race, color,
ancestry, national origin, religion, sex (including sexual harassment),
pregnancy, age (40 and over), order of protection status, marital status,
sexual orientation (including gender-related identity), military status,
unfavorable military discharge, disability, arrest record, familial status,
citizenship status and source of income.
   (f)   Willfully interfere with the performance of a duty or the exercise of
a power by the Human Relations Commission or one of its members or
representatives; or
   (g)   Willfully obstruct or prevent a person from complying with the
provisions of this chapter or an order issued hereunder.
(Ord. 2024-09. Passed 3-18–24.)
270.08   EQUAL EMPLOYMENT OPPORTUNITIES; SEXUAL HARASSMENT; UNLAWFUL
DISCRIMINATION.
   (a)   Declaration of Policy. It is the public policy of this City:
      (1)   Freedom from harassment and unlawful discrimination. To secure for
all individuals within the City the freedom from discrimination because of
race, color, ancestry, national origin, religion, sex (including sexual
harassment), pregnancy, age (40 and over), order of protection status, marital
status, sexual orientation (including gender-related identity), military
status, unfavorable military discharge, disability, arrest record, familial
status, citizenship status and source of income.
      (2)   Public health, welfare and safety. To promote the public health,
welfare and safety by protecting the interest of all people in the City in
maintaining personal dignity, in realizing their full productive capacities and
in furthering their interests, rights and privileges as citizens of this City.
      (3)   Implementation of constitutional guarantees. To secure and
guarantee the rights established by Sections 17, 18 and 19 of Article I of the
Illinois Constitution of 1970, as amended.
      (4)   Equal opportunity. To establish equal opportunity as the policy of
this City in all of its decisions, programs and activities.
      (5)   Unfounded charges. To protect citizens of this City against
unfounded charges of sexual harassment or unlawful discrimination in private
employment.
   (b)   Definitions. As used in this section, unless the context requires
otherwise:
      (1)   "Age," "aggrieved party," "charge," "complainant," "handicap,"
"labor organization," "marital status," "national origin," "person,"
"religion," "sex," "sexual harassment," "unfavorable military discharge" and
"unlawful discrimination" shall have the same meanings given to such terms in
the Illinois Human Rights Act (775 ILCS 5/1-101 et seq.), as now or hereafter
amended.
      (2)   "Employee" is defined as set forth in this subsection:
         A.   "Employee" includes:
            1.   Any individual performing services for remuneration within
this City for an employer;
            2.   An apprentice; or
            3.   An applicant for any apprenticeship.
         B.   "Employee" does not include:
            1.   Any person employed by a "public employer," as such term is
defined in this section;
            2.   Individuals who are "employers," as such term is defined in
this subsection;
            3.   Elected public officials or members of their immediate
personal staffs;
            4.   Principal administrative officers of a "public employer," as
such term is defined in this subsection; or
            5.   A person in a vocational rehabilitation facility certified
under Federal law who has been designated an evaluee, trainee or work-activity
client.
      (3)   "Employer" means:
         A.   Any person (other than a "public employer," as such term is
defined in this subsection) employing five or more employees within the City
during twenty or more calendar weeks within the calendar year of or preceding
an alleged violation;
         B.   Any person (other than a "public employer," as such term is
defined in this subsection) employing one or more employees when a complainant
alleges a civil rights violation because of unlawful discrimination based on
his or her physical or mental handicap unrelated to ability; or
         C.   A joint apprenticeship or training committee without regard to
the number of employees.
         D.   "Employer" shall not include any "public employer," as such term
is defined in this subsection, or any religious corporation, association,
educational institution, society or nonprofit nursing institution conducted by
and for those who rely on treatment by prayer through spiritual means in
accordance with the tenets of a recognized church or religious denomination
with respect to the employment of individuals of a particular religion to
perform work connected with the carrying-on by such corporation, association,
educational institution, society or nonprofit nursing institution of its
activities.
      (4)   "Employment agency" means a private employment agency and any
person (other than a "public employer," as such term is defined in this
subsection), labor organization or labor union having a hiring hall or hiring
office regularly undertaking, with or without compensation, to procure
opportunities to work, or to procure, recruit, refer or place employees.
      (5)   "Public employee" means an employee of a "public employer," as such
term is defined in this subsection.
      (6)   "Public employer" means the United States Government, the State
Government, an agency or department of either, a unit of local government, a
school district or an instrumentality or political subdivision of the State.
   (c)   Civil Rights Violations in Private Employment. It is a civil rights
violation:
      (1)   Private employers. For any employer to refuse to hire, to segregate
or to act with respect to recruitment, hiring, promotion, renewal of
employment, selection for training or apprenticeship, discharge, discipline,
tenure or terms, privileges or conditions of employment, on the basis of
unlawful discrimination.
      (2)   Employment agencies. For any employment agency to fail or to refuse
to classify properly, accept applications and register for employment, referral
or apprenticeship referral, refer for employment, or refer for apprenticeship,
on the basis of unlawful discrimination, or to accept from any person any job
order, requisition or request for referral of applicants for employment or
apprenticeship which makes, or has the effect of making, unlawful
discrimination a condition of referral.
      (3)   Labor organizations. For any labor organization to limit, segregate
or classify its membership, to limit employment opportunities, selection or
training for apprenticeship in any trade or craft, or otherwise to take, or
fail to take, any action which affects adversely any person's status as an
employee, as an applicant for employment, as an apprentice, or as an applicant
for apprenticeships, wages, tenure, hours of employment or apprenticeship
conditions, on the basis of unlawful discrimination.
      (4)   Sexual harassment. For any employer, employee, agent of an
employer, employment agency or labor organization to engage in sexual
harassment, provided that an employer shall be responsible for sexual
harassment of the employer's employees by nonemployees or nonmanagerial and
nonsupervisory employees only if the employer becomes aware of the conduct and
fails to take reasonable corrective measures.
      (5)   Training and apprenticeship programs. For any employer, employment
agency or labor organization to discriminate against a person on the basis of
age in the selection for, referral for or conduct of apprenticeship or training
programs.
      (6)   Arrest records. For any employer, employment agency or labor
organization to inquire on a written application whether a job applicant has
ever been arrested. This section shall not prohibit the City or school district
from utilizing conviction information obtained from the Illinois Department of
State Police under the provisions of subparagraph (e) of paragraph 6 of Section
55a of The Civil Administrative Code of Illinois, as amended, in evaluating the
qualifications and character of an employee or a prospective employee.
   (d)   Exemptions. The exemptions granted under 775 ILCS 5/2-104 (the
Illinois Human Rights Act), as now or hereafter amended, are hereby
incorporated in this section by reference and shall apply to all proceedings
under this section.
   (e)   Enforcement Proceedings. The proceedings to enforce this section and
Section
270.09 shall be in accordance with the procedures set forth in Sections
270.10 through
270.14.
   (f)   Regulations. The Commission is hereby authorized to issue any and all
regulations which it deems necessary in order to fulfill its duties under this
section.
   (g)   Enforcement of Settlements. Any party to a written settlement
agreement signed by all of the parties to a proceeding under this section may
enforce the provisions of the settlement agreement by instituting an action in
the local circuit court in the same manner as other written contracts or
agreements are enforced.
(Ord. 2024-09. Passed 3-18–24.)
270.09   CIVIL RIGHTS IN PLACES OF PUBLIC ACCOMMODATION.
   (a)   Definitions. The following definitions are applicable strictly in the
context of this section. In addition to the definitions provided in this
section, the definitions contained in Section
270.08(b) are hereby incorporated by reference for use in this section.
      (1)   "Operator" means any owner, lessee, proprietor, manager,
superintendent, agent or occupant of a place of public accommodation, or an
employee of any such person or persons.
      (2)   "Place of accommodation" means a business, accommodation,
refreshment, entertainment, recreation or transportation facility of any kind,
whether licensed or not, the goods, services, facilities, privileges,
advantages or accommodations of which are extended, offered, sold or otherwise
made available to the public. "Places of accommodation" include the facilities
of, but are not limited to:
         A.   Inns;
         B.   Restaurants;
         C.   Eating houses;
         D.   Hotels and motels;
         E.   Soda fountains;
         F.   Soft drink parlors;
         G.   Taverns;
         H.   Roadhouses;
         I.   Barber shops;
         J.   Department stores;
         K.   Clothing stores;
         L.   Hat stores;
         M.   Shoe stores;
         N.   Bathrooms;
         O.   Restrooms;
         P.   Theatres;
         Q.   Skating rinks;
         R.   Public golf courses;
         S.   Public golf driving ranges;
         T.   Concerts;
         U.   Cafes;
         V.   Bicycle rinks;
         W.   Elevators;
         X.   Ice cream parlors or rooms;
         Y.   Railroads;
         Z.   Omnibuses;
         AA.   Buses;
         BB.   Trolleys;
         CC.   Stages;
         DD.   Airplanes;
         EE.   Street cars;
         FF.   Boats;
         GG.   Funeral hearses;
         HH.   Crematories;
         II.   Cemeteries;
         JJ.   Public conveyances on land, water or air;
         KK.   Public swimming pools; and
         LL.   Other places of public accommodation and/or amusement.
   (b)   Civil Rights Violations. It is a civil rights violation on the basis
of unlawful discrimination for:
      (1)   Any person to deny or refuse to another person the full and equal
enjoyment of facilities and services of any public place of accommodation; or
      (2)   The operator of a place of public accommodation to directly or
indirectly publish, circulate, display or mail any written communication which
the operator knows is to the effect that any of the facilities of the place of
public accommodation will be denied to any person or that any person is
unwelcome, objectionable or unacceptable because of unlawful discrimination.
   (c)   Exemptions. Nothing in this section shall apply to:
      (1)   A facility, in regard to discrimination based upon sex, which is
distinctly private in nature, such as a restroom, shower room, bath house,
health club or other similar facility for which the Illinois Department of
Human Rights or the City Human Relations Commission, in their rules or
regulations, may grant exemptions based upon bona fide considerations of public
policy; or
      (2)   A facility, in regard to discrimination based upon sex, which
restricts the rental of rooms to individuals of one sex.
(Ord. 2024-09. Passed 3-18–24.)
270.10   HUMAN RELATIONS COMMISSION.
   (a)   Establishment; Composition. There is hereby established a Human
Relations Commission for the City, which shall consist of nine members
appointed by the Mayor with the consent of the Council. The Mayor may appoint a
designee to attend meetings of the Commission on his or her behalf and as a
nonvoting member.
   (b)   Appointments at Large. All nine members of the Commission shall be
appointed from the community at large.
   (c)   Appointments and Removals by Mayor; Terms; Chairperson; Quorum.
Members shall be appointed and may be removed for cause by the Mayor, with the
consent of Council, upon charges and after public hearing. Each member
appointed shall serve for a term of three years or until his or her successor
is duly appointed and qualified. Each year the terms of three members of the
Commission shall expire. The members of the Commission shall designate one of
their members to be its Chairperson. A majority of the Commission or panel
thereof shall constitute a quorum for the purpose of conducting official
business.
   (d)   Duties and Powers. The Commission shall have and exercise, with
respect to all real property and with respect to all persons subject to this
chapter, the power to:
      (1)   Act to eliminate unlawful real estate practices;
      (2)   Act to ensure to persons living, working or desiring to live in the
City, or on any particular real property, the opportunity to purchase, lease or
occupy real property without discrimination because of race, color, ancestry,
national origin, religion, sex (including sexual harassment), pregnancy, age
(40 and over), order of protection status, marital status, sexual orientation
(including gender-related identity), military status, unfavorable military
discharge, disability, arrest record, familial status, citizenship status and
source of income.
      (3)   Receive, initiate and investigate noncriminal complaints of
tensions, practices of discrimination, and acts of prejudice and intolerance
against any person or group because of race, color, ancestry, national origin,
religion, sex (including sexual harassment), pregnancy, age (40 and over),
order of protection status, marital status, sexual orientation (including
gender-related identity), military status, unfavorable military discharge,
disability, arrest record, familial status, citizenship status and source of
income, and seek to resolve such matters.
      (4)   Seek conciliation of, hold hearings on and make findings of fact
with respect to any such complaint.
      (5)   Recommend the issuance of orders, subject to approval by Council,
and to publish its findings of fact and recommended orders in accordance with
the provisions of this chapter, after submission of such orders to Council.
      (6)   Render, from time to time, but no less than every six months, a
written report to Council of its activities and recommendations with respect to
fair real estate practices, which written reports shall be made public after
submission to Council.
      (7)   Adopt, after approval of Council, such rules and regulations as may
be necessary or desirable to carry out the purpose and policy of this chapter.
      (8)   Perform those functions specified in Section 270.12 in order to
prevent and resolve matters of unlawful discrimination in employment and in
public accommodations.
      (9)   Receive, investigate and suggest solutions to organizations and/or
individuals dealing with disputes brought before the Mayor or City Council, in
an attempt to resolve such differences prior to any legal proceedings.
   (e)   Fiscal Responsibility. Except as may otherwise be provided by
ordinance, the fiscal responsibility of the Commission is of an advisory nature
only, and the Commission shall not have authority to authorize the expenditure
of public funds.
(Ord. 2024-09. Passed 3-18–24.)
270.11   FILING OF COMPLAINTS WITH THE HUMAN RELATIONS COMMISSION;
CONCILIATION.
   (a)   Any person aggrieved in any manner of any violation of any provision
or this chapter may file with the Human Relations Commission a written verified
complaint setting forth his or her grievance.
      (1)   The complaint shall state the following:
         A.   The name and address of the complainant;
         B.   The name and address of the person against whom the complaint is
brought, if known to the complainant;
         C.   The alleged facts surrounding the alleged violation of this
chapter; and
         D.   The name and address of all persons believed to have knowledge
concerning the alleged facts.
      (2)   The Commission shall provide a printed form of complaint for the
use of aggrieved persons.
   (b)   (1)   After the filing of any complaint, the Commission shall serve a
copy of the complaint on the party or parties charged, and the Chairperson of
the Commission shall designate a panel to make a prompt investigation in
connection therewith. The panel shall be comprised of three or more members of
the Commission, selected on an alternating basis by the Chairperson. The
Chairperson may act as facilitator of the panel, in an ex officio, non-voting
capacity only.
      (2)   In the event that more than one complaint is pending before the
Commission, the complaints shall be processed in the most expedient manner in
the order of priority as received by the Commission.
   (c)   (1)   If such panel determines after such investigation that probable
cause exists for the allegations or the complaint, the panel shall set a time
and date for a meeting, and at such meeting the panel, or any member thereof,
shall interview the complainant and the person or persons against whom the
complaint has been directed and shall attempt to resolve the complaint by all
proper methods of conciliation and persuasion.
      (2)   If, at any time within sixty days after the date of filing of the
complaint, such panel determines that such attempts at conciliation would not
be in furtherance of the objectives of this chapter, the Commission shall
thereupon proceed promptly to a full hearing of the complaint in accordance
with Section
270.12.
   (d)   No person may file a complaint with the Human Relations Commission
pertaining to any matter filed in any other forum, including, but not limited
to, legal proceedings.
(Ord. 2024-09. Passed 3-18–24.)
270.12   HEARINGS BY HUMAN RELATIONS COMMISSION.
   (a)   A hearing shall be conducted by the Human Relations Commission, or a
panel thereof, upon due and reasonable notice to all parties. The Commission
shall have power to administer oaths and to take sworn testimony. Any party
alleged to have violated this chapter shall be entitled to be represented by
counsel and shall have the right to call witnesses on his or her own behalf and
to cross-examine witnesses.
   (b)   At the conclusion of such hearing, the Commission shall render to
Council a written nonbinding report with recommendations, which shall also be
served by mail upon the complainant and the party or parties charged. No report
shall be delayed more than sixty days after the date of the first issuance of
notice for commencement of a hearing.
(Ord. 2024-09. Passed 3-18–24.)
270.13   ENFORCEMENT; INJUNCTIVE RELIEF.
   (a)   The Human Relations Commission shall be empowered, at the conclusion
of the proceedings held under Section
270.12, to recommend to Council that Council order any person found to be
engaging in an unfair real estate practice to cease and desist from such
practice, upon such terms as shall be necessary and proper for the enforcement
of this chapter.
   (b)   The Commission shall be empowered, at the conclusion of proceedings
held under Section
270.12, as part of its report, to recommend to Council that it request the
Corporation Counsel of the City to do any one or more of the following in
response to a finding of a violation of any provision of this chapter, except
Section
270.10:
      (1)   To institute and prosecute proceedings to enforce, against any
person found in violation of this chapter, the fine provided for in Section
270.99.
      (2)   To apply to any court of competent jurisdiction for:
         A.   An order restraining any person from violating any provision of
this chapter;
         B.   Such other or future relief as may seem to the court appropriate
for the enforcement of this chapter and for the elimination of violations
thereof.
      (3)   To petition or institute proceedings with the Illinois Department
of Professional Regulation for the purpose of causing the Department to revoke,
suspend or refuse to renew the license granted by such Department to any real
estate broker or real estate salesperson found to have violated any provisions
of this chapter.
      (4)   In the case of any unlawful real estate practice or violation of
this chapter by any person in the course of performing under a contract or
subcontract with the State or any political subdivision or agency thereof, or
with the United States of America or any agency or instrumentality thereof, to
petition or institute proceedings with such contracting agency for the purpose
of causing it to terminate such contract or any portion thereof, either
absolutely or on condition of compliance with the provisions of this chapter.
   (c)   After receipt of the report of the Commission, Council may issue cease
and desist orders and may request such action by the Corporation Counsel,
including the procedures set forth in subsection (b) hereof, as shall be
necessary for the enforcement of any provision of this chapter, except Section
270.10.
   (d)   If, during the course of any proceedings prescribed herein, the
Commission, on the basis of the evidence before it, concludes that a violation
of this chapter is imminent, it may relay such evidence to Council, together
with its recommendation that the Corporation Counsel be instructed to seek
injunctive relief in any court of competent jurisdiction to prohibit such
violation.
(Ord. 2024-09. Passed 3-18–24.)
270.14   LIMITATION OF TIME TO FILE COMPLAINTS.
   Any complaint filed hereunder with the Human Relations Commission must be
filed within 120 days after the alleged discriminatory practice occurred or it
shall be barred.
(Ord. 2024-09. Passed 3-18–24.)
270.15   REMEDIES.
   Any person aggrieved in any manner by a violation of any provision of this
chapter (but not of Section
270.10), and who has exhausted the remedies provided in Sections
270.11 and
270.12, may apply to any court of competent jurisdiction for appropriate relief
from such violations, including:
   (a)   An order compelling compliance with this chapter;
   (b)   An order prohibiting any person, found by a court to have violated any
provision of this chapter, from participating in the sale, lease, exchange,
transfer, conveyance or assignment of any real property;
   (c)   Compensatory damages;
   (d)   Such other and further relief as may seem appropriate to the court for
the enforcement of this chapter and the elimination of violations hereof.
(Ord. 2024-09. Passed 3-18–24.)
270.16   DUTY OF LEGAL COUNSEL.
   The City's Legal Counsel shall only act as the advisor to the Human
Relations Commission during any of the proceedings conducted by the Commission
under this chapter. No member of the Legal Counsel shall act as the attorney
for, or as the advisor to, any complainant or respondent in any proceeding
conducted by the Commission. The Legal Counsel shall also represent the
Commission in any court of competent jurisdiction for any cause of action
arising from the performance by the Commission of any actions authorized by
this chapter.
(Ord. 2024-09. Passed 3-18–24.)
270.17   SEVERABILITY.
   If any provision of this chapter, or the application thereof to any person
or circumstance, is held invalid, the remainder of this chapter and the
application of the provision to other persons not similarly situated or to
other circumstances shall not be affected thereby.
(Ord. 2024-09. Passed 3-18–24.)
270.99   PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter, except Section
270.10, shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more
than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense.
(Ord. 2024-09. Passed 3-18–24.)
CHAPTER 272
Americans With Disabilities Act Compliance Commission
272.01   Establishment.
272.02   Grievance procedure for accessibility claims.
272.03   Fiscal responsibility.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Minimum standards for disability income protection coverage - see 215 ILCS
5/355a
   Continuance privilege for disabled municipal officers and employees - see
215 ILCS 5/367j
   Right of way of blind persons - see TRAF.
446.05
   Parking for disabled persons - see TRAF.  
480.24,
482.06,
484.04
272.01 ESTABLISHMENT.
   There is hereby established an Americans With Disabilities Act Compliance
Commission, which shall be composed of seven members and whose membership shall
include representatives from elected officials, the disabled community, the
business or nonprofit sector and the health/medical profession. To the extent
the Commission is required to be convened pursuant to Section
272.02 below, the Mayor, with the consent of Council, shall appoint the members
of this Commission at such time. For purposes of this section, any member who
misses three consecutive meetings of the American With Disabilities Act
Compliance Commission may be removed by the Mayor, subject to confirmation of
such removal by the City Council.
(Ord. 95-2. Passed 2-6-95; Ord. 2017-56. Passed 7-17-17; Ord. 2017-85. Passed
12-18-17.)
272.02 GRIEVANCE PROCEDURE FOR ACCESSIBILITY CLAIMS.
   There is hereby adopted the following grievance procedure for persons who
claim the City is violating the facility and program accessibility requirements
of the regulations issued by the United States Department of Justice pursuant
to the Federal Americans With Disabilities Act (ADA):
   (a)   A complainant shall submit any complaint regarding access or alleged
discrimination, in writing, to the City's ADA Compliance Officer for
investigation and resolution. The ADA Compliance Officer shall maintain files
containing all complaints and of all action taken. The ADA Compliance Officer
shall render his or her written decision within fifteen working days after
receipt of the complaint.
   (b)   If the complaint is not resolved to the satisfaction of the
complainant by the ADA Compliance Officer, then the complainant may appeal the
ADA Compliance Officer's decision by sending a request, in writing, to the ADA
Compliance Officer. The complaint shall then be referred to the City's ADA
Compliance Commission.
   (c)   The Commission shall establish ground rules or procedures for hearing
complaints, requests or suggestions from disabled persons regarding access to
and participation in public facilities, services, activities and functions in
the community. Further, the Commission shall conduct hearings on all such
complaints only in strict compliance with the Illinois Open Meetings Act and in
an objective, unbiased manner. The Commission shall issue a written decision
within thirty days of receipt of the request for referral. All hearings
conducted by the Commission shall be recorded by a court reporter or by
electronic means. Transcripts shall be prepared only upon request and payment
of the applicable cost by the requestor, unless such fee is waived by the
Commission for good cause shown as being in the public interest. The Commission
shall maintain its files and tapes for no less than three years after it
concludes its work on such complaint.
   (d)   The complainant may appeal the decision of the Commission to the City
Manager, by sending a written notice of such appeal to the office of the City
Clerk within fifteen working days of the complainant's receipt of the decision
of the Commission. In such notice, the complainant shall state why the decision
of the Commission is in error and shall state the complainant's requested
action by the City to remedy the violations alleged in the complaint. The City
Manager shall conduct a hearing and shall issue his or her written decision
within thirty days of the closing of the hearing. The decision of the City
Manager shall be final.
   (e)   A record of action taken on each request or complaint shall be
maintained as part of the records or minutes at each level of the grievance
process.
   (f)   The complainant's right to a prompt or equitable resolution of the
complaint shall not be impaired by his or her pursuit of other remedies, such
as the filing of a complaint with the United States Department of Justice or
any other appropriate Federal agency. Furthermore, since the filing of a
lawsuit in State or Federal court can occur at any time, the use of this
grievance procedure is not a prerequisite to the pursuit of other remedies.
(Res. R-92-30. Passed 7-20-92; Ord. 2017-56. Passed 7-17-17.)
272.03 FISCAL RESPONSIBILITY.
   Except as may otherwise be provided by ordinance, the fiscal responsibility
of the Commission is of an advisory nature only, and the Commission shall not
have authority to authorize the expenditure of public funds.
(Ord. 95-2. Passed 2-6-95.)

CHAPTER 285
Arts and Culture Commission
285.01   Creation.
285.02   Purpose and scope.
285.03   Powers and duties.
285.01   CREATION.
   There is hereby established the Freeport Arts and Culture Commission. The
Freeport Arts and Culture Commission shall consist of no less than five members
and up to nine members. The Commission members shall be appointed by the mayor
subject to the approval of a majority of the City Council.
   (a)   Qualifications. The members shall be appointed on the basis of
expertise, experience, or interest in the fine arts and the cultural vitality
of our community.
   (b)   Terms. Members of the Commission first taking office shall serve
respectively for the following terms: Three for one year, three for two years,
and three for three years, with initial terms to be determined by lot. The
successors to the initial members shall serve for a term of three years.
Vacancies (whether by resignation or removal) shall be filled by the
appointment of the mayor subject to the approval of a majority of the City
Council. Vacancies shall be filled for the unexpired term only. Commission
members will serve without compensation. Members absent for three or more
consecutive meetings will be removed from the Commission.
   (c)   Officers. Members of the Commission shall elect a Chairperson, Vice-
Chairperson, and Secretary from amongst themselves. Officers shall serve for a
term of one year and may be reelected, but no person may serve as chairman for
more than two consecutive years. The Chairperson shall preside over meetings.
In the absence of the Chairperson, the Vice-Chairperson shall perform the
duties of the Chairperson. If both are absent, a temporary Chairperson shall be
elected from and by those present. The Secretary to the Commission shall have
the following duties:
      (1)   Take minutes of each Commission meeting;
      (2)   Be responsible for publication and distribution of copies of the
minutes, reports, decisions, of the Commission to the members of the
Commission;
      (3)   Give notice as provided herein or by law for all public hearings
conducted by the Commission;
      (4)   Advise the Mayor of vacancies on the Commission and expiring terms
of members; and
      (5)   Prepare and submit to the City Council a complete record of the
proceedings before the Commission on any matter requiring Council
consideration.
   (c)   Meetings.
      (1)   A quorum shall consist of a simple majority of the members. All
decisions or actions of the Commission shall be made by a simple majority vote
of those members present and voting at any meeting where a quorum exists.
Meetings shall be held at regularly scheduled times to be established by
resolution of the Commission at the beginning of each calendar year or at any
time upon the call of the Chairperson or two members of the Commission.
      (2)   There shall be a minimum of twelve meetings per year. No member of
the Commission shall vote on any matter that may materially or apparently
affect the property, income or business interest of that member. No action
shall be taken by the Commission that could in any manner deprive or restrict
the owner of property of its use, modification, maintenance, disposition, or
demolition until such owner shall first have had an opportunity to be heard at
a public meeting of the Commission, as provided for herein. The Chairperson,
and in his or her absence, the acting Chairperson, may administer oaths and
compel the attendance of witnesses. All meetings of the Commission shall be
open to the public. The Commission shall keep minutes of its proceedings,
showing the vote, indicating such fact, and shall keep records of its
examinations and other official actions, all of which shall be immediately
filed in the office of the Commission and shall be public record.
(Ord. 2024-06. Passed 3-18-24.)
285.02   PURPOSE AND SCOPE.
   (a)   The Commission has two primary goals focused in arts and culture.
First, to increase the public's awareness of all visual and fine arts,
including, but not limited to, exhibition of sculptures, paintings, mosaics,
photography, murals, and video. And, also, to increase cultural awareness and
elevate the diversity within our community.
   (b)   The purpose of the Arts and Culture Commission shall be to:
      (1)   Increase citizen access to the arts by providing leadership,
advocacy, and the support for art that enriches the cultural vitality of our
community; and
      (2)   Provide advice and work cooperatively with the city council to
promote fine and cultural arts in the city; and
      (3)   Foster and promote an appreciation of fine arts within the city by
enlisting and encouraging public and private agencies, as well as the general
public, to support art and cultural events within the city; and
      (4)   Assist in creating and maintaining a city-wide arts and culture
webpage on the city website that includes links to art related organizations
and individuals who advance art in the city.
(Ord. 2024-06. Passed 3-18-24.)
285.03   POWERS AND DUTIES.
   The powers and duties of the Arts and Culture Commission shall be:
   (a)   To adopt its own procedural regulations, including but not limited to,
processes regarding the Open Meetings Act and grant procurement;
   (b)    To prepare and present a Public Arts and Culture Work Plan to the
Mayor and City Council for their approval;
   (c)   To find applicable grant funding and present any match-able grant
opportunities to the Mayor and City Council;
   (d)   To investigate and recommend to the City Council the creation of
Public Art Policies, and amendments to the Public Art Policies;
      (1)   To advise and make recommendations on the maintenance, relocation,
or removal of Public Art.
      (2)   To conduct an ongoing survey to identify potential sites for public
art displays.
   (e)   To research, procure, and select art for public display. The selection
must be approved by majority vote of the Commission;
   (f)    To collaborate with key institutions and organizations to promote the
awareness of all visual and fine arts and increase cultural awareness within
our community;
   (g)   To research and make recommendations on how to celebrate and highlight
the diverse cultures within our community.
(Ord. 2024-06. Passed 3-18-24.)
CHAPTER 286
Freeport/Stephenson County Convention and Visitors Bureau
286.01   Participation of City; composition and appointment of Board of
Directors.
286.02   Duties.
286.03   Terms; vacancies.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Encouraging purchases from local suppliers - see 20 ILCS 605/46.57
   Promotion of municipal conventions and conferences; hotel operators tax -
see 65 ILCS 5/8-3-14
   Sales of intoxicating liquor at conventions and conferences -see 235 ILCS 5/
6-15
   Tourism Promotion Fund - see B.R. & T.
886.04
   Lincoln-Douglas Debate Site - see S.U. & P.S.
Ch. 1074
286.01 PARTICIPATION OF CITY; COMPOSITION AND APPOINTMENT OF BOARD OF
DIRECTORS.
   Council hereby expresses its approval of the participation of the City in
the Freeport/Stephenson County Convention and Visitors Bureau, a non-profit
entity incorporated under the laws of the State of Illinois, which shall be
governed by a Board of Directors to be composed of nine members. The Mayor is
hereby authorized to appoint, subject to Council approval, five members of the
Board of Directors of said Bureau, to include one Alderperson, two at-large
members, one member from the local lodging industry and one member from the
local chamber of commerce. The Mayor may remove any such appointed Director,
subject to confirmation of such removal by the City Council. Any Director
appointed by the Mayor who misses three consecutive meetings of the Board of
Directors of the Freeport/Stephenson County Convention and Visitors Bureau may
be removed by the Mayor, subject to confirmation of such removal by the City
Council. The Chairperson of the Stephenson County Board shall appoint, subject
to County Board approval, four members of the Board of Directors, to include
one County Board member, two at-large members and one member from the local
lodging industry. If there exists a hotel or motel located in an incorporated
area of Stephenson County, other than in the City, then one of the County Board
Chairperson's at-large appointments must be a domiciliary of that incorporated
community. The Board of Directors shall elect its Chairperson from among its
members.
   All five of the Mayoral appointees shall be domiciliaries of the City.
   All four of the County Board Chairperson's appointees shall be domiciliaries
of the County of Stephenson.
(1977 Code §31-204; Ord. 90-4. Passed 2-5-90; Ord. 2004-52. Passed 9-7-04; Ord.
2017-85. Passed 12-18-17.)
286.02 DUTIES.
   The duties of Board members of the Board of Directors of the Freeport/
Stephenson County Convention and Visitors Bureau shall be established by an
intergovernmental agreement between the City and the County of Stephenson,
except as provided herein. The duties shall include, but are not limited to,
the requirement to supervise the operation of the tourism promotion programs,
an obligation to use its best efforts in meeting performance parameters as set
out by the City and the County, the recommendation and preparation of an annual
budget, for which the City and the County will have had the opportunity to
comment upon prior to adoption, an annual marketing plan to be presented to
both the City and the County no later than January 31 of each year, and a
written semi-annual report to be presented to both Council and the County Board
no later than March 1 and September 1 of each year.
(1977 Code § 31-204; Ord. 90-4. Passed 2-5-90; Ord. 2004-52. Passed 9-7-04.)
286.03 TERMS; VACANCIES.
   At its initial meeting, the members of the Board of Directors of the
Freeport/Stephenson County Convention and Visitors Bureau shall draw lots in
order to assign each member to a one, two or three-year term of office on the
Board of Directors. Three members of the Board of Directors shall be assigned
to each of the terms of office. Except as noted below for vacancies occurring
during the term of office, all new appointments or reappointments after the
initial appointments creating the Board of Directors shall be for a full term
of three years only. An appointment made to fill a vacancy on the Board of
Directors shall be made in the same manner as the original appointment. A
person appointed to fill a vacancy occurring during a term of office shall
serve only for the unexpired portion of that term of office.
(1977 Code § 31-204; Ord. 90-4. Passed 2-5-90; Ord. 2004-52. Passed 9-7-04.)
CHAPTER 287
Removal, Resignation of Members
287.01   Removal, resignation of members.
287.01 REMOVAL, RESIGNATION OF MEMBERS.
   (a)   Members of boards, committees and commissions sit at the pleasure of
the Mayor and City Council, except where the City's Home Rule powers are
specifically restricted by law.
   (b)   Members of boards, committees and commissions may be removed by the
Mayor for the following reasons:
      (1)   In the event that the Mayor loses confidence in the ability of a
board, committee or commission member to work cooperatively with the City
Council, the other members of the board, committee or commission or the City
staff;
      (2)   In the event that the Mayor believes that there is a need for a
different board, committee or commission composition to assist the body in the
conduct of its work;
      (3)   In the event that the Mayor believes that such removal is in the
best interest of the City.
   The Mayor shall send notice of such removal to the affected member of the
board, committee or commission. The Mayor shall notify the City Council of the
removal as well as the secretary of the affected board and the City Manager.
   (c)   When a member has been absent for three or more consecutive meetings,
such absences and the reasons therefore, if known, shall be communicated to the
Mayor by the chair of the board, committee or commission. The Mayor may elect
to treat such absences as the member's resignation.
   (d)   Resignations shall be effective when accepted by the Mayor. Upon
acceptance of the resignation, the position on the board, committee or
commission shall be deemed vacant. The Mayor shall thereupon notify members of
the Council and the chair of the board, committee or commission when any
resignation has been accepted.
(Ord. 2019-01. Passed 1-14-19.)
TITLE TEN - Employment Provisions
CHAPTER 288
Officers and Employees Generally

recognized representatives of various classes of Municipal employees, which
agreements provide for wages, benefits and conditions of employment for such
employees. The provisions of this chapter, and Chapter 290, therefore, apply
only to those officers and employees of the City, and to those subjects, not
otherwise provided for in such agreements. Copies of the latest relevant
legislation and of such agreements may be obtained, at cost, from the City
Clerk.

288.01 GENERAL EMPLOYMENT POWERS OF CITY.
   The City shall have, and may exercise, through its authorized officers and
departments, all of the applicable and pertinent powers provided for it in
Division 4 of Article 10 of the Illinois Municipal Code, as amended.
(1977 Code § 23-201)
288.02 DESIGNATION OF OFFICIALS OF CITY.
   All elected officers of the City, all members of the Police Department and
of the Fire Department, all officers, all commissioners, all employees whose
appointment are made by the City Manager or Mayor with the consent of the City
Council, and all officers or deputies required to file official bonds, shall be
officials of the City.
(1977 Code §47-119;Ord. 2017-56. Passed 7-17-17.)
288.03 APPLICATION OF CHAPTER.
   This chapter does not purport to provide for the appointment of all officers
of the City. However, the provisions of this chapter shall be applicable to all
officers and offices provided for in any chapter of these Codified Ordinances,
in the absence of particular and specific provisions to the contrary.
(1977 Code § 47-117)
288.04 APPOINTED OFFICERS AND POSITIONS.
   (a)   General Authority of the City Manager. In the absence of specific
provisions of statute or ordinance to the contrary, the City Manager shall make
all appointments for all appointive offices and positions. All such
appointments shall be made at the first regular meeting of Council when the
Mayor is sworn into office, or as soon thereafter as is convenient, and at
other times as vacancies occur.
   (b)   Interim Appointments. In the interim period after a vacancy occurs and
prior to a permanent appointment by the City Manager or the Mayor with advice
and consent of Council, as applicable and in accordance with law, the Mayor or
City Manager, as applicable, may appoint some suitable person to discharge the
duties of the office or position for a period not to exceed ninety days at a
time. The City Manager or Mayor, as applicable, shall give written notice of
such interim appointment to the City Council no later than the first City
Council meeting after such interim appointment. The City Manager or the Mayor
with advice and consent of Council, as applicable, may extend such interim
appointment for additional periods of ninety days each should the City Manager
or Mayor with advice and consent of Council decide in their discretion that
such extension is in the best interests of the City, provided that the City
Manager give written notice of such extensions to the Mayor and to the City
Council within ten days of such extension.
   (c)   Terms of Office or Position. Every appointive officer or position
holder of the City shall hold his or her office or position until his or her
successor is appointed and qualified, unless such officer's or position
holder’s term is otherwise provided by statute or ordinance. The term of every
such officer or position holder appointed by the City Manager shall
automatically expire as soon after the end of the term of the Mayor in office
or as of the date of the City Manager appointment (as the case may be) and said
appointee shall remain in office or in the position until the successor to such
officer or position holder is appointed and qualified.
(1977 Code §§47-101 to 47-103; Ord. 2004-27. Passed 5-3-04; Ord. 2017-56.
Passed 7-17-17; Ord. 2018-39. Passed 8-6-18.)
288.05 VACANCIES.
   A vacancy in office shall exist when the office holder dies, resigns, is
removed or becomes ineligible to hold office under 730 ILCS 5/5-5-5, as
amended.
(1977 Code § 47-104)
288.06 ELIGIBILITY.
   No person shall be elected or appointed to any office of the City who shall
not have resided in the City one year next preceding his or her election or
appointment to such office and who is not a qualified elector of the City.
However, this shall not apply to the appointment of a Public Works Director,
Community Development Director or officers of whom technical training or
knowledge is required. No person shall be eligible to any office of the City
who is in default to the City.
(Ord. 94-80. Passed 9-19-94.)
288.07 OATH OF OFFICE.
   All officers of the City, whether elected or appointed, shall, before
entering upon the duties of their respective offices, take and subscribe the
following oath or affirmation:
   I do solemnly swear (or affirm) that I will support the Constitution of the
United States, and the Constitution of the State of Illinois, and that I will
faithfully discharge the duties of the office of ________ according to the best
of my ability.
   The oath, or affirmation, so subscribed, shall be filed in the office of the
City Clerk.
(1977 Code § 47-106; Ord. 90-26. Passed 3-19-90.)
288.08 COMMISSION.
   All officers elected or appointed, except the City Clerk, Alderpersons and
the Mayor, shall be commissioned by a warrant under the corporate seal, signed
by the Mayor and the City Clerk. The Mayor shall issue a certificate of
election, under the seal of the City, to the City Clerk.
(1977 Code § 47-107)
288.09 ASSIGNMENT OF DUTIES.
   The City Manager may assign to any officer any duty which is not assigned by
statute or ordinance to some other officer. He or she shall determine disputes
relating to the respective powers and duties of officers, after consultation
with the City Legal Counsel.
(1977 Code §47-108; Ord. 2017-56. Passed 7-17-17.)
288.10 INSPECTION OF RECORDS.
   Except as stated below, all records of any office shall be open to
inspection by the City Manager, Mayor or any member of the City Council, at all
reasonable times, whether or not such records are required to be kept by
statute or ordinance. All records kept by any officer or employee shall be and
remain the property of the City and, as such, access to and/or copies of
records under this section may be available only to the extent specifically
allowed by applicable Federal and/or State statutory and regulatory
restrictions (including, but not limited to, those applicable to the privacy of
such records and/or applicable to records pertaining to employment, health,
credit, background, etc.).
(1977 Code §47-109; Ord. 2015-62. Passed 11-16-15; Ord. 2017-56. Passed 7-17-
17.)
288.11 OFFICE HOURS OF CITY DEPARTMENTS.
   The offices and departments of the City which are open to the public, other
than the Library, shall be open for business from 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m.,
Monday through Friday, unless a special waiver has been approved by the City
Manager, with good cause shown, based upon the demonstrated needs of specific
departments. Should such a waiver be granted by the City Manager, the City
Manager shall notify the Mayor and the Council of the same. All of the
foregoing times shall be the prevailing time under the laws of the State. Any
department head shall have the right to keep his or her office open to the
public over the noon hour, i.e., from 12:00 noon to 1:00 p.m. Further, such
offices shall be open on all days, except Saturdays, Sundays, and those
holidays enumerated in the City of Freeport Employee Handbook or as otherwise
specified by applicable collective bargaining agreement. Certain City offices
and departments which maintain separate schedules shall remain open. For all of
the enumerated holidays, when the holiday falls on a Saturday, the preceding
Friday shall be observed as the legal holiday, and when the holiday falls on a
Sunday, the following Monday shall be observed as the legal holiday. The
operational hours of the Library shall be set by the Board of Library Trustees.
(Ord. 96-39. Passed 7-1-96; Ord. 2010-29. Passed 5-17-10; Ord. 2013-28. Passed
6-17-13; Ord. 2017-56. Passed 7-17-17; Ord. 2022-47. Passed 11-7-22.)
288.12 COMPENSATION.
   Officers shall receive such salaries as may be provided from time to time by
Council in the annual appropriation ordinance, or otherwise. Compensation of
elected officers, after the same has been once fixed, shall not be increased or
diminished, to take effect during the term for which any such officer was
elected. Every officer shall make, and return to the City Manager, a semi-
annual report, verified by affidavit, of all fees and emoluments received by
him or her. Salaries shall be paid once a month, except in the case of the
Mayor and the City Clerk, which officers shall be paid bi-weekly in accordance
with
Chapter 290 of this Administration Code. Pay shall be pro-rated to ensure that
all payments are in accordance with the salary ordinances of the City and that
payments do not exceed the yearly salary of each official. Nothing in this
chapter shall be construed to bring such officers under the purview of
Chapter 290 for any other purpose.
(Ord. 99-26. Passed 5-17-99; Ord. 2017-56. Passed 7-17-17; Ord. 2018-67. Passed
12-17-18.)
288.13 ARRESTS.
   After receiving a certificate attesting to the successful completion of a
training course administered by the Illinois Law Enforcement Training Standards
Board, the City Manager, the Mayor, Alderpersons, the Chief of Police and all
police officers shall be conservators of the peace and shall have power to
arrest, or cause to be arrested, with or without process, all persons who break
the peace or are found to be violating any ordinance of the City or any
criminal law of the State; to commit such persons for examination and, if
necessary, detain such persons in custody overnight or Sunday in the Stephenson
County Jail or any other safe place, or until they can be brought before the
proper magistrate; and, further, shall have and exercise such other powers as
conservators of the peace as Council may prescribe.
(Ord. 98-4. Passed 2-2-98; Ord. 2017-56. Passed 7-17-17.)
288.14 WITNESS FEES.
   No officer or employee of the City shall be entitled to keep any witness
fees paid to him or her for services as witness in a case in which the City is
a party and the testimony given relates to the duties of such officer or
employee. All fees so received shall be turned over to the Finance Director or
his or her designee.
(Ord. 97-21. Passed 7-21-97.)
288.15 REMOVALS.
   Subject and in conformance with any and all applicable statutes, laws and
ordinances regarding the removal of appointed officers, the City Manager or
Mayor, as applicable, shall have power to remove any officer appointed by him
or her whenever, in his or her sole opinion, the interests of the City demand
such removal. The City Manager or Mayor, as applicable, shall report any
removal to Council at the first meeting after such removal. If applicable and
in accordance with law, the Council, by a two-thirds vote of all members, by
yeas and nays entered upon the record, disapproves of such removal, such
officer shall thereupon be restored to the office, but he or she shall give a
new bond and take a new oath of office.
(1977 Code §47-115; Ord. 2017-56. Passed 7-17-17.)
288.16 COMPLIANCE WITH LAWFUL ORDERS OF OFFICERS.
   No person shall resist, hinder or delay any City officer or employee in the
discharge of any official act or duty, or neglect or refuse to obey any lawful
order or direction of any such officer or employee.
(1977 Code § 47-116)
288.17 PHYSICAL EXAMINATIONS.
   No person shall enter the full-time and permanent employment of the City
without submitting, before entering such employment, to a thorough physical
examination by a duly licensed physician designated by the City. Such
examination shall be sufficient to disclose the existence of any disease and/or
disability which would interfere with the ability of the employee to perform
the job. The report and results of such examination shall be preserved in the
employee's file. Such report shall be submitted to the City Manager when first
received, and he or she may, in his or her sole discretion, refuse such
employment on the basis of such report.
(1977 Code §23-202; Ord. 86-1. Passed 1-20-86; Ord. 2017-56. Passed 7-17-17;
Ord. 2024-15. Passed 4-1-24.)
288.18 INDEMNIFICATION.
   Each officer, employee or agent of the City, including an employee of the
Board of Library Trustees, shall be defended, indemnified and held harmless by
the City for any suit, damages, obligation or liability whatsoever growing out
of any act, or failure to act, in the course of his or her particular
employment, except for an act of willful misconduct.
(1977 Code §23-203; Ord. 2024-15. Passed 4-1-24)
288.19 MEDICAL AND LIFE INSURANCE.
   (a)   Any employee of the City who retires and is immediately eligible for a
Police, Fire or IMRF pension, and who, at the time of retirement, is covered by
City group medical insurance coverage, may elect, in writing, at the time of
retirement, to continue on the City group medical insurance coverage plan,
provided that the retired employee, as a condition to continuing under such
plan, will be required to pay, when due, all future premiums for his or her
coverage.
   (b)   The City shall make available, to full-time employees and their
dependents, group hospital and medical insurance, and to employees, fifty
thousand dollars ($50,000) in term life insurance coverage. The City will pay
for the cost of the life insurance premium. If an employee chooses to
participate in the City's group health and dental insurance coverage, the
employee's cost shall be 18% of the premium, which may change from time to
time, for the single, single plus one, and family rate. The employee shall be
solely financially responsible for the amounts specified above for each group
health and dental insurance coverage premium before the City's obligation to
pay arises.
