460.04 SPEED LIMITATIONS.
   (a)   Except as provided herein, in accordance with Section 5/11-601(c) of
the Illinois Vehicle Code, which Code is adopted by reference pursuant to
Section 420.01 of these Codified Ordinances, no person shall drive a vehicle at
a speed in excess of thirty miles per hour upon any City street, or fifteen
miles per hour upon any City alleyway.
   (b)   No person shall drive a vehicle at a speed in excess of fifty-five
miles per hour along the following streets:
      (1)   Fairgrounds Road from Illinois Route 26 west to the City corporate
limits.
      (2)   Stephenson Street Road from City corporate limits to Van Brocklin
Road.
   (c)   No person shall drive a vehicle at a speed in excess of forty miles
per hour along the following streets:
      (1)   Forest Road from Pearl City Road south to the City corporate
limits. (Ord. 97-57. Passed 9-2-97.)
      (2)   Stephenson Street Road from Kiwanis Drive to the City corporate
limits.
   (d)   No person shall drive a vehicle at a speed in excess of twenty miles
per hour along the following City streets:
      (1)   Addison Street from Green Street to West End.
      (2)   Highland Drive from Stephenson Street Road to Park Boulevard.
      (3)   Hooker Avenue from East Stephenson Street to East Album Street.
      (4)   Westwood Lane from Stephenson Street Road to Highland Drive.
      (5)   Woodside Drive from Illinois Route 26 to South Park Road.
      (6)   North Walnut Avenue from Ringold to Summit.
      (7)   Burchard Avenue from Empire Street to American Street.
(Ord. 99-53. Passed 9-7-99; Ord. 2003-67. Passed 9-2-03; Ord. 2005-40. Passed
8-1-05.)
   (e)   Appropriate signs shall be posted along the above-listed streets to
indicate the speed limitations as set forth herein. (Ord. 97-67. Passed 11-3-
97.)
460.05 SCHOOL ZONES.
   (a)   No person shall drive a vehicle at a speed in excess of twenty miles
per hour while passing a school zone, or while traveling upon any roadway on or
across which child ren pass going to and from school, on school days when
school children are present. Appropriate signs shall be posted to indicate the
restriction.
   (b)   School zones are designated as follows:
      (1)   Empire from Park to McKinley.
      (2)   Empire from West to Walnut.
      (3)   Empire from Blackhawk 200 feet east.
      (4)   Empire from Blackhawk 200 feet west.
      (5)   Laurel from Park to the City limits.
      (6)   Moseley from West to Locust.
      (7)   Harlem from Staver to Stephenson.
      (8)   Blackhawk from Empire 850 feet south.
      (9)   Walnut from Winnifred 200 feet north.
      (10)   Walnut from Winnifred 200 feet south.
      (11)   Fruit from Center to Garden.
      (12)   Center from Fruit 620 feet east.
      (13)   Illinois from Miami 250 feet east.
      (14)   Miami from Illinois to Garden.
      (15)   E. Empire beginning 240 feet east of S. Galena and continuing east
for 890 feet to a point 120 feet west of S. Bauscher.
   (c)   This section shall apply regardless of whether or not children are
crossing the street, so long as they are present within the school zone.
(1977 Code § 42-804; Ord. 79-12. Passed 3-6-79; Ord. 79-70. Passed 10-1-79;
Ord. 85-2. Passed 2-4-85; Ord. 89-51. Passed 9-5-89; Ord. 89-79. Passed 12-4-
89; Ord. 2014-47. Passed 11-17-14.)
460.06 TURNING AT INTERSECTIONS, ALLEYS, PRIVATE ROADS AND DRIVEWAYS.
   (a)   The driver of a vehicle intending to make a right turn within an
intersection or into an alley, private road or driveway shall approach for the
right turn and make the right turn as closely as practicable to the right-hand
curb or edge of the roadway.
   (b)   The driver of a vehicle intending to make a left turn within an
intersection or into an alley, private road or driveway shall yield the right
of way to any vehicle approaching from the opposite direction which is so close
as to constitute an immediate hazard, but, after having so yielded, such driver
may proceed at such time as a safe interval occurs.
(1977 Code § 42-908; Ord. 78-65. Passed 8-7-78; Ord. 90-61. Passed 8-6-90.)
460.07 BUSES.
   Buses shall be driven as closely as possible to the right hand curb, and
shall be driven to the curb for the purpose of receiving and discharging
passengers.
(1977 Code § 42-1012)
460.08 OBSTRUCTION OF TRAFFIC.
   No vehicle shall be operated, made to stand or be parked in such a manner as
to form an unreasonable obstruction to traffic or to impede or block the normal
and reasonable movement of traffic.
(1977 Code § 42-1208)
460.09 NEGLIGENT DRIVING.
   No person shall operate a motor vehicle in a negligent manner over and along
the public streets and highways of the City. For the purpose of this section,
to "operate a motor vehicle in a negligent manner" means to operate a vehicle
upon the streets and roadways of the City in a manner that endangers or is
likely to endanger any person or property.
(Ord. 94-11. Passed 3-21-94.)
460.10 LITTERING FROM VEHICLES OR AIRCRAFT.
   No person in any motor vehicle, motorcycle, bicycle, wagon, horse-drawn
vehicle or wagon, self-propelled vehicle or vehicle of any type, or in any
aircraft, shall throw therefrom or drop within the City any candy, gum, food,
litter, handbills or other object.
(Ord. 94-52. Passed 7-18-94.)
460.11 SECURING OF LOADS ON VEHICLE; TRACKING MUD OR OTHER SUBSTANCES ON
STREETS AND ALLEYS.
   No person shall drive or move any vehicle unless such vehicle is so
constructed or loaded as to prevent any load, contents or litter from being
blown or shaken therefrom. No person shall drive or move any vehicle in a
manner which causes the wheels or tires of such vehicle to carry onto any
street or alley mud, dirt, sticky substances, litter or foreign matter of any
kind
(Ord. 94-52. Passed 7-18-94.)
460.15 TRUCKS PROHIBITED ON CERTAIN STREETS.
   (a)   Except for the purpose of servicing persons or businesses within the
corporate limits of the City of Freeport it shall be unlawful to operate any
vehicle having an overall length (including any trailer) in excess of forty-
five feet upon any of the following streets, except to cross said streets at an
intersection of said street or streets with a street not hereinafter listed:
      (1)   Carroll Street between Adams Street and South Street; and
      (2)   RESERVED.
   (b)   For purposes of this section, "service" or "servicing" shall be
defined as delivering or picking up material or goods to and from residents or
businesses on otherwise restricted streets, provided that vehicles shall enter
or exit said streets from the closest and most direct route practically
available from and to a non-prohibited street.
   (c)   This section shall not apply to governmental vehicles in the
performance of governmental functions, public utility vehicles in the
performance of utility activities, school buses, public transportation
carriers, or construction vehicles (public or private) performing work under a
government contract upon any of the above enumerated streets or serving
residents along said streets.
   (d)   The Public Works Director shall place appropriate signs on the above
streets designating the prohibition contained in this section.
   (e)   Notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained in this section, it
shall be a defense to any claimed violation of this section that the address
being serviced by a driver of an otherwise prohibited vehicle could only be
accessed via a restricted street, or section thereof.
(Ord. 2018-27. Passed 5-7-18.)
460.16 WRITTEN PERMITS REQUIRED FOR OVERWEIGHT VEHICLES.
   Vehicles exceeding weight, width, height or length limitations imposed by
the City of Freeport shall only be permitted to use City streets for specific
purposes, as specifically stated by the route indicated on a written permit
obtained from the Director of Public Works or his or her designee (the
"Director"). Permits shall be issued pursuant to Chapter 625 ILCS, Section 5/
15-301 of the Illinois Vehicle Code, at the Director's sole discretion. Fees
for such permits are charged based on the established schedule posted by the
Director as updated from time to time. All permits issued pursuant hereto shall
be kept in the vehicle whenever such vehicle is operated on any otherwise
prohibited streets. In issuing such permits, the Director shall be permitted to
specify with such particularity as is deemed necessary, the route over streets
any vehicle shall be permitted to travel pursuant to any issued permit.
(Ord. 2018-27. Passed 5-7-18.)
460.17 EXCESSIVE ENGINE BRAKING NOISE PROHIBITED.
   (a)   No person shall operate or cause to be used or operated on designated
City roadways an engine braking system that emits excessive noise on any
commercial vehicle. For the purposes of this ordinance, an “engine braking
system” shall be deemed to be any device which uses the force of the engine in
any commercial vehicle to slow or alter the speed of the vehicle by the
application of force to the drive train thereof, including but not limited to
engine brakes, exhaust brakes, or other similar systems. A commercial vehicle
shall be deemed to be emitting excessive noise if the vehicle is operating an
engine braking system, and if the vehicle is not equipped with an adequate
sound muffling system on the exhaust thereof. It is a defense to this paragraph
that the driver used an engine braking system that emits excessive noise in an
emergency to avoid a collision with a person or another vehicle on the roadway.
   (b)   Excessive engine braking noise signs. In accordance with Section 12-
602.1 of the Illinois Vehicle Code, the City Engineer shall cause signs to be
erected and maintained that prohibit the driver of a commercial vehicle, as
defined in Section 1-111.8 of the Illinois Vehicle Code (625 ILCS 5/1-111.8),
from operating or actuating any engine braking system that emits excessive
noise. The sign shall state, “EXCESSIVE ENGINE BRAKING NOISE PROHIBITED”.
   (c)   Any violation of this section shall be punishable by a fine of
seventy-five dollars ($75.00).
(Ord. 2022-66. Passed 12-5-22.)
460.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section 422.99 for general Code penalty if no specific
penalty is provided.)
CHAPTER 462
Bicycles
462.01   Application of chapter.
462.02   Licenses.
462.03   Rental agencies.
462.04   Speed.
462.05   Parking.
462.06   Riding on sidewalks.
462.07   Bells, sirens and whistles.
462.08   Brakes.
462.09   Violations.
462.10   Fine or impounding.
462.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Application of rules - see IVC §§ 5/11-1501, 5/11-1502
   Clinging to vehicles - see IVC § 5/11-1504
   Riding on roadways - see IVC §§ 5/11-1505, 5/11-1505.1
   Lamps and other equipment - see IVC § 5/11-1507
   Inspections - see IVC § 5/11-1509
462.01    APPLICATION OF CHAPTER.
   The provisions of this chapter shall apply whenever a bicycle is operated
upon any street or sidewalk.
(1977 Code § 42-1803)
462.02    LICENSES.
   (a)   Required. No resident of the City shall ride a bicycle unless such
bicycle has been licensed.
   (b)   Application. Application for a bicycle license shall be made to the
Chief of Police upon a form provided by the Chief. A license fee of fifty cents
(50¢) shall be paid.
   (c)   Issuance Generally; Effective Period. The Chief of Police is
authorized to issue a bicycle license, which shall be effective until the next
succeeding May 1 of even-numbered years.
   (d)   Issuance to Owners Only. The Chief of Police shall not issue a license
for any bicycle when he or she knows, or has reasonable ground to believe, that
the applicant is not the owner thereof.
   (e)   Records. The Chief of Police shall keep a record of the number of each
license, the date issued, the name and address of the person to whom issued,
the number on the frame of the bicycle for which issued and all bicycle license
fees collected by him or her.
   (f)   Plates, Tags or Decals.
      (1)   Issuance. The Chief of Police, upon issuing a bicycle license,
shall also issue a license plate, tag or decal bearing the license number
assigned to the bicycle, the name of the City and the calendar years for which
such license is issued.
      (2)   Attachment. The license plate, tag or decal shall be attached to
the frame of the bicycle for which issued so as to always be plainly visible.
      (3)   Removal. No person shall remove the license plate, tag or decal
from a bicycle during the period for which such license is issued.
   (g)   Unsafe Bicycles. The Chief of Police shall refuse a license for any
bicycle which he or she determines is in unsafe mechanical condition.
   (h)   Renewal. Upon the expiration of any bicycle license, the same may be
renewed upon application and payment of a fee as upon an original application.
   (i)   Transferability. Upon the transfer of a licensed bicycle, the license
shall remain on such bicycle and shall be assigned to the transferee upon
proper application.
(1977 Code §§ 42-1804 to 42-1814; Ord. 92-50. Passed 9-8-92.)
462.03    RENTAL AGENCIES.
   A rental agency shall not rent any bicycle unless it is licensed and
equipped as provided in this chapter and in the Illinois Vehicle Code.
(1977 Code § 42-1815)
462.04    SPEED.
   No person shall operate a bicycle at a speed greater than is reasonable and
prudent under the conditions then existing.
(1977 Code § 42-1820)
462.05    PARKING.
   No person shall park a bicycle other than upon a roadway against the curb,
upon a sidewalk in a rack, or against a building, with the least obstruction to
pedestrian traffic.
(1977 Code § 42-1822)
462.06    RIDING ON SIDEWALKS.
   (a)   No person shall ride a bicycle upon a sidewalk in the business
district, as defined in Section 202.03(3) of the Administration Code.
   (b)   No person over fourteen years of age shall ride a bicycle upon any
sidewalk.
(1977 Code § 42-1823)
462.07    BELLS, SIRENS AND WHISTLES.
   Every bicycle shall be equipped with a bell or other audible signal device,
but shall not have a siren or whistle.
(1977 Code § 42-1826)
462.08    BRAKES.
   Every bicycle shall be equipped with a brake which will enable the operator
to make a braked wheel skid on dry, level, clean pavement.
(1977 Code § 42-1827)
462.09    VIOLATIONS.
   Any person, regardless of age, who violates any of the provisions of this
chapter shall be guilty of an offense punishable under Section 462.99.
(1977 Code § 42-1802)
462.10    FINE OR IMPOUNDING.
   Every person convicted of a violation of any provision of this chapter, or
of any provision of the Illinois Vehicle Code relating to bicycles, shall be
punished by a fine or by having his or her vehicle impounded for a period not
to exceed thirty days.
462.99    PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section 422.99 for general Code penalty if no specific
penalty is provided.)
CHAPTER 464
Public Nuisances
464.01   Purpose; intent.
464.02   Declaration of public nuisance.
464.03   Length of impoundment and fines.
464.04   Notice to registered owner.
464.05   Notice of impoundment and record of towed vehicle.
464.06   Administrative fee procedure.
464.07   Unclaimed vehicles.
464.08   Towing and storage fees.
464.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Illinois Vehicle Code generally - see TRAF. Ch. 420
   Motor vehicle operation generally - see TRAF. Ch. 460
   Nuisances generally - see GEN. OFF. Ch. 658
464.01    PURPOSE; INTENT.
   This chapter is declared necessary for the preservation of the public peace,
health, safety and welfare of the general public, and is intended to address a
public nuisance created by individuals operating motor vehicles upon the
streets and highways of the City. (Ord. 98-16 Passed 4-6-98.)
464.02    DECLARATION OF PUBLIC NUISANCE.
   (a)   A motor vehicle which is used in any of the following circumstances
shall be declared a public nuisance:
      (1)   The registered owner or any other person in possession of a motor
vehicle wherein the operation of any sound amplification system which can be
heard outside the vehicle from seventy-five or more feet when the vehicle is
being operated upon a highway, unless such system is being operated to request
assistance or warn of a hazardous situation.
(Ord. 99-17. Passed 5-3-99.)
      (2)   The registered owner or any other person in possession of a motor
vehicle where the windows of the motor vehicle are obstructed in violation of
Sections 12-503(a) and (b) of the Illinois Vehicle Code (625 ILCS 5/12-503 (a)
and (b)), as adopted in Section 420.01 of these Codified Ordinances.
      (3)   The registered owner or any other person in possession of a motor
vehicle in violation of Section 650.08 of these Codified Ordinances relating to
curfew.
      (4)   The registered owner or any other person in possession of a motor
vehicle in violation of Section 7-601 of the Illinois Vehicle Code (625 ILCS 5/
7-601, entitled "Required Liability Insurance Policy"), as adopted in Section
420.01 of these Codified Ordinances.
      (5)   The registered owner or any other person in possession of a motor
vehicle while being twenty years of age or younger in possession of alcoholic
liquor in violation of Section 608.10 of these Codified Ordinances.
      (6)   The registered owner or any other person in possession of a motor
vehicle in violation of Chapter 626 of these Codified Ordinances.
      (7)   The registered owner or any other person in possession of a motor
vehicle in violation of Section 692.03 of these Codified Ordinances.
      (8)   The registered owner or any other person in possession of a motor
vehicle in violation of Section 11-204 of the Illinois Vehicle Code (625 ILCS
5/11-204, entitled "Fleeing or Attempting to Elude Police Officer"), as adopted
in Section 420.01 of these Codified Ordinances.
   (b)   Any motor vehicle used in violation of this chapter may be impounded
for the periods of time set forth in Section 464.03, and the registered owner
of such motor vehicle shall be subject to minimum penalties set forth in
Section 464.99, in addition to fees for towing and storage of the motor
vehicle.
(Ord. 98-16 Passed 4-6-98.)
464.03    LENGTH OF IMPOUNDMENT AND FINES.
   (a)   Whenever a motor vehicle is used in any of the circumstances set forth
in Section 464.02(a), such motor vehicle shall be impounded for the following
lengths of time:
      (1)   A motor vehicle used in violation of Section 464.02(a)(1) or (2)
shall be impounded for five calendar days.
      (2)   A motor vehicle used in violation of Section 464.02(a)(3) shall be
impounded for seven calendar days.
      (3)   A motor vehicle used in violation of Section 464.02(a)(4) or (5)
shall be impounded for fourteen calendar days.
      (4)   A motor vehicle used in violation of Section 464.02(a)(6), (7) or
(8) shall be impounded for twenty calendar days.
   (b)   Any person reclaiming his or her motor vehicle, upon expiration of the
applicable time period set forth in this section or upon payment of the
administrative fee pursuant to Section 464.06, shall pay all costs of towing
and storage for release of such motor vehicle.
(Ord. 98-16 Passed 4-6-98.)
464.04    NOTICE TO REGISTERED OWNER.
   Whenever a police officer has reasonable suspicion to believe that a motor
vehicle is being used in violation of this chapter, the officer shall determine
whether the person in possession of said motor vehicle is the registered owner.
If the person in possession of the motor vehicle is not the registered owner
and the police officer has no record of the same prior offense related to the
use of such motor vehicle, the police officer shall provide notice to the
registered owner that any subsequent offense under this chapter shall subject
the motor vehicle to impoundment.
(Ord. 98-16 Passed 4-6-98.)
464.05    NOTICE OF IMPOUNDMENT AND RECORD OF TOWED VEHICLE.
   (a)   Whenever a police officer has reasonable suspicion to believe that a
motor vehicle is being used in violation of this chapter, the officer shall
provide for the impoundment and towing of such motor vehicle, except as
provided in Section 464.04. The officer shall notify the person found to be in
possession of the vehicle at the time of the alleged violation, if there is
such a person, and the registered owner of such motor vehicle, of the
impoundment and of the registered owner's right to pay the administrative fee
as set forth in Section 464.06.
   (b)   Upon towing and impoundment of the motor vehicle, the Police
Department shall maintain a record of the vehicle towed, including the
following information concerning the impounded vehicle:
      (1)   The color;
      (2)   The year of manufacture;
      (3)   The manufacturer's trade name;
      (4)   The manufacturer's series name;
      (5)   The body style;
      (6)   The vehicle identification number;
      (7)   The license plate;
      (8)   The license plate number;
      (9)   The registration sticker year;
      (10)   The registration number displayed;
      (11)   The date and hour of the towing;
      (12)   The location from which the vehicle was towed;
      (13)   The location to which the vehicle was towed;
      (14)   The reason for the towing; and
      (15)   The City employee authorizing the towing.
(Ord. 98-16 Passed 4-6-98.)
464.06    ADMINISTRATIVE FEE PROCEDURE.
   (a)   Whenever the registered owner of a motor vehicle which has been
impounded pursuant to this chapter desires to retrieve his or her vehicle prior
to the expiration of the time specified in Section 464.03 or prior to the
related court appearance, he or she may pay an administrative fee in the amount
of two hundred dollars ($200.00). Said administrative fee shall be paid at the
City Police Station between the hours of 8:30 a.m. and 4:00 p.m., Monday
through Friday.
   (b)   Upon payment of the administrative fee, in addition to payment of all
costs of towing and storage, the impounded vehicle shall be released to the
owner.
   (c)   In the event that the registered owner is found not guilty of any
violation of this chapter in the related court proceeding, the vehicle owner
shall be reimbursed the entire amount paid as an administrative fee pursuant to
this section.
(Ord. 98-16 Passed 4-6-98.)
464.07    UNCLAIMED VEHICLES.
   Any motor vehicle which is not reclaimed within thirty calendar days after
the final adjudication of a violation of the provisions of Section 464.02 (a)
shall be disposed of as an unclaimed vehicle in accordance with Section 4-201
et seq. of the Illinois Vehicle Code, as adopted in Section 420.01 of this
Traffic Code, and with Section
480.10 of this Traffic Code.
(Ord. 98-16 Passed 4-6-98.)
464.08    TOWING AND STORAGE FEES.
   Fees for the towing and storage of a motor vehicle under this chapter shall
be the same as those charged pursuant to contract for towing service with the
City in effect at the time of such violation.
(Ord. 98-16 Passed 4-6-98.)
464.99    PENALTY.
   (a)   Any person who violates the provisions of this chapter shall be fined
not less than the amount indicated in this section. Enforcement proceedings may
be commenced by either a notice to appear or by a summons.
      (1)   A fine of not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than
five hundred dollars ($500.00) shall be imposed for a violation of Section
464.02(a)(1) or (2).
      (2)   A fine of not less than one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) nor
more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) shall be imposed for a violation of
Section 464.02(a)(3).
      (3)   A fine of not less than two hundred dollars ($200.00) nor more than
five hundred dollars ($500.00) shall be imposed for a violation of Section
464.02(a)(4) or (5).
      (4)   A fine of not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) nor
more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) shall be imposed for a violation of
Section 464.02(a)(6).
      (5)   A fine of not less than three hundred dollars ($300.00) nor more
than five hundred dollars ($500.00) shall be imposed for a violation of Section
464.02(a)(7) or (8).
   (b)   In addition to the above fines, the registered owner of any impounded
motor vehicle shall be responsible for all costs of towing and storage of such
motor vehicle in accordance with Section 464.08.
(Ord. 98-16 Passed 4-6-98.)
CHAPTER 466
Additional Hazardous Materials
466.01   Purpose.
466.02   Definitions.
466.03   Declaration of nuisance.
466.04   Liability for abatement of nuisance.
466.05   Prohibition.
466.06   Declaration of nuisance.
466.07   Liability for abatement of nuisance.
466.99   Penalty.
466.01. PURPOSE.
   The purpose of this Chapter is to promulgate rules and regulations for the
use, storage, manufacturing and clean up of hazardous materials within the City
of Freeport.
(Ord. 2003-74. Passed 10-20-03.)
466.02    DEFINITIONS.
   (a)   Definitions. The following words and phrases shall have the meaning
ascribed to them hereafter.
      (1)   Hazardous materials. As used herein, the term "hazardous materials"
shall mean a substance or material in the quantity and form which has been
determined by the United States Department of Transportation to be capable of
posing an unreasonable risk to health and safety or property.
      (2)   Person. Any natural person or individual, governmental body, firm,
association, partnership, co-partnership, joint venture, company, corporation
joint stock company, trust, estate, or any other legal entity or their
representative, agent or assigns.
      (3)   Toxic substance. Any substance, mixture, or compound containing a
substance which is listed in:
         A.   The Code of Federal Regulations, 29 C.F.R. 1910.1000 through 29
C.F.R. 1910.1500 inclusive.
         B.   A list of toxic substances promulgated by the Illinois
Environmental Agency pursuant to Illinois Compiled Statutes, Chapter 415, Act
85, Section 4.
         C.   The United States Department of Health and Human Services, Public
Health Service National Toxicology Program, Second Annual Report on
Carcinogens-December, 1981 and its periodic updates.
         D.   A list of toxic substances promulgated by the Director of the
Illinois Department of Labor pursuant to Illinois Compiled Statutes, Chapter
820, Act 255, Section 4.
   (b)   All other definitions, not contained herein, shall be as defined in
the Hazardous Material Emergency Response Reimbursement Act.
(Ord. 2003-74. Passed 10-20-03.)
466.03    DECLARATION OF NUISANCE.
   The actual or threatened discharge of hazardous materials within the City of
Freeport is hereby declared a nuisance.
(Ord. 2003-74. Passed 10-20-03.)
466.04    LIABILITY FOR ABATEMENT OF NUISANCE.
   Any person who owns, leases, operates or controls any facility, equipment,
or vehicles from which a discharge or hazardous materials or toxic substance
has occurred or is threatened to occur, shall be liable to the City of Freeport
for any expense incurred by the City in connection with preventing, cleaning
up, or disposing of or attempting to prevent, clean up, or dispose of any such
discharge or threatened discharge.
(Ord. 2003-74. Passed 10-20-03.)
466.05    PROHIBITION.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to dispose of hazardous materials within
the limits of the City of Freeport, unless such disposal is conducted in
accordance with applicable state and federal rules and regulations pertaining
to the disposal of such materials.
(Ord. 2003-74. Passed 10-20-03.)
466.06    DECLARATION OF NUISANCE.
   The unlawful disposal of hazardous materials within the City of Freeport is
hereby declared a nuisance.
(Ord. 2003-74. Passed 10-20-03.)
466.07    LIABILITY FOR ABATEMENT OF NUISANCE.
   Any person who engages in the unlawful disposal of hazardous materials shall
be liable to the City of Freeport for any and all expenses incurred by the city
in connection with cleaning up and lawfully disposing of said materials.
(Ord. 2003-74. Passed 10-20-03.)
466.99    PENALTY.
   In addition to the liability of imposing by the preceding section, any
person who unlawfully disposes of hazardous materials within the City of
Freeport shall, upon conviction, be subject to a fine of no less than five
hundred dollars ($500.00) and no more than five hundred dollars ($500.00).
(Ord. 2003-74. Passed 10-20-03.)

846.10,

480.01 PARALLEL AND ANGLE PARKING.
   (a)   Where parallel parking is permitted upon a roadway, every vehicle
shall be so parked that the right wheels, or the left wheels where parking on
the left side is permissible, are parallel to, and within eighteen inches of,
the curb, or within the confines of a marked parking place.
   (b)   Where angle parking is permitted upon a roadway, every vehicle shall
be parked such that the front of the vehicle is pointed toward the curb and
such that one of the front wheels is within eighteen inches of the curb.
   (c)   All streets on which parking is permitted shall be parallel parking
streets, except those streets which are specifically designated as angle
parking streets.
   The following are angle parking streets:
      (1)   Beach Street (Avenue D), south side from Waddell 460 feet west.
(1977 Code §§ 49-101, 49-101.1, 49-126; Ord. 81-37. Passed 7-21-81; Ord. 81-46.
Passed 7-20-80; Ord. 2001-57. Passed 12-3-01; Ord. 2009-61. Passed 9-21-09;
Ord. 2011-02. Passed 1-18-11; Ord. 2013-59, passed 12-2-13.)
480.02 DISPLAY OF LIGHTS ON PARKED VEHICLES.
   No properly parked vehicle need display lights at any time. Any lighted
headlamps upon a parked vehicle shall be depressed or dimmed.
(1977 Code § 49-102)
480.03 PROHIBITED PARKING AREAS.
   No person shall park a vehicle in, or move a vehicle not lawfully in his or
her control into, any of the following places, except when necessary to avoid
conflict with other traffic or in compliance with the direction of an
authorized officer or traffic-control device:
   (a)   On a sidewalk;
   (b)   In front of or within five feet of a driveway in a street or alley;
   (c)   In front of or within five feet of a sidewalk or stairway that is the
primary ingress/egress to a residential property without other street access;
   (d)   In an intersection or crosswalk, or within twenty feet thereof;
   (e)   Within fifteen feet of a fire hydrant located on a corner at
intersecting streets and within seven and one-half feet on either side of all
other fire hydrants;
   (f)   Within thirty feet of a traffic-control device at the side of a
roadway;
   (g)   Between signs designating passenger loading zones at any church,
during services;
   (h)   Within fifty feet of a railroad crossing;
   (i)   Alongside or opposite any street excavation or obstruction when
parking would obstruct traffic;
   (j)   On the roadway side of any vehicle stopped at the edge of a street;
   (k)   Upon a bridge or elevated structure or within a tunnel;
   (l)   Where parking will reduce the usable width of an alley to less than
ten feet;
   (m)   Between the sidewalk line and the curb line;
   (n)   In any front yard, except on legally established driveways or parking
lots;
   (o)   In a bus or taxicab standing or loading zone;
   (p)   On the left side of a roadway, except for one-way streets;
   (q)   Where official signs prohibit or regulate parking or standing, and
then only in compliance with such signs;
   (r)   On any dedicated street or road where no street or road has been
opened;
   (s)   In a traffic lane of any street or roadway;
   (t)   In a fire zone;
   (u)   Where the curb line has been painted yellow;
   (v)   At a school entrance or between signs designating school entrances and
school loading zones. If such signs designate the no parking place at a school
to be a tow-away zone, then the vehicle may be towed away under the provisions
of Section
480.10(a).
   (w)   Between signs designating passenger loading zones at any hotel or
theater.
(1977 Code § 49-103; Ord. 77-68. Passed 11-7-77; Ord. 78-9. Passed 4-17-78;
Ord. 78-26. Passed 4-3-78; Ord. 79-55. Passed 8-6-79; Ord. 79-67. Passed 10-15-
79; Ord. 80-69. Passed 8-4-80; Ord. 2005-34. Passed 7-18-05; Ord. 2009-45.
Passed 7-6-09.)
480.04 TIME LIMITATION.
   Unless a shorter parking time limit is applicable as specified in this
chapter, no person shall park a vehicle on any street for longer than twenty-
four consecutive hours. Notwithstanding the foregoing, residents in the Central
Business District may park on streets within the Central Business District for
longer than twenty-four consecutive hours however such residents must still
comply with any applicable shorter parking time limits set forth in this
chapter, including, but not limited to Sections
480.09(b) regarding street cleaning. Section
486.03(a)(1) regarding snow events and Section
480.20 regarding two-hour parking. Central Business Districts residents will be
issued at City Hall, for a cost of ten dollars ($10.00), a placard to be hung
in the car window when parking on streets within the Central Business District.
(1977 Code § 49-104; Ord. 2017-84. Passed 12-18-17.)
480.05 PARKING FOR PURPOSES OF SALES OR NONEMERGENCY REPAIRS.
   No person shall park a vehicle upon any roadway for purposes of display for
sale, greasing or nonemergency repair, or for selling merchandise therefrom,
unless otherwise licensed or authorized to do so by the City.
(1977 Code § 49-105)
480.06 METHOD OF PARKING IN BUSINESS DISTRICTS.
   A driver, to park a vehicle in a business district, if there are cars parked
at both ends of the parking space, shall drive past, and shall then back into
such parking space.
(1977 Code § 49-106)
480.07 INTERFERENCE WITH OTHER DRIVERS ATTEMPTING TO PARK.
   No person shall attempt to enter a parking space after a driver of a vehicle
has started to park in such parking space.
(1977 Code § 49-107)
480.08 UNATTENDED VEHICLES; DUTY TO REMOVE KEY, SET BRAKE, ETC.
   No person driving or in charge of a motor vehicle shall permit it to stand
unattended under any of the following circumstances:
   (a)   With the key in the engine ignition switch.
   (b)   When parked in a parking space on a perceptible grade, without
effectively setting the brake and turning the front wheels to the curb.
(Ord. 2000-19. Passed 4-3-00.)
480.09 STREET CLEANING.
   (a)   No person shall park a vehicle on a block of any street when such
street block is being cleaned. Signs regulating parking for street cleaning
purposes may be posted permanently, with designated time periods, pursuant to
Council resolution.
   (b)   Within the Central Business District, residents of the Central
Business District with approved placards shall only be parked on the south/east
side of the street on odd days and north/west sides of the streets on even days
to allow for street cleaning. Only residents of the Central Business District
with approved placards will be allowed to park on the street for longer than
twenty-four consecutive hours, subject to the following restrictions: residents
of the Central Business District with approved placards must comply with
Section
486.03(a)(1) regarding snow events; and during customary business hours within
the Central Business District of 8:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m., residents of the
Central Business District with placards shall be subject to the parking time
limits set forth in Section
480.20 (Two Hour Parking Limits) and
480.22 (Courtesy Zones, Fifteen-, and Thirty-Minute Parking Zones) so as to
allow customer access to businesses.
(1977 Code § 49-110; Ord. 77-102. Passed 1-3-78; Ord. 96-11. Passed 4-1-96;
Ord. 2017-84. Passed 12-18-17.)
480.10 REMOVAL OF ILLEGALLY PARKED VEHICLES AND CERTAIN OTHER LEGALLY PARKED
VEHICLES.
   The Police Department may remove, or have towed away by a commercial towing
service, any illegally parked vehicle, and certain legally parked vehicles,
under the following circumstances:
   (a)   Emergencies. Vehicles illegally parked in a fire zone, as provided in
Section
480.03 (s), within fifteen feet of a fire hydrant located on a corner at
intersecting streets, and within seven and one-half feet on either side of all
other fire hydrants, as provided in Section 480.03(d), on a bridge, as provided
in Section 480.03(j), and parked illegally during a snow emergency, as provided
in Section
486.03 (a), or in a traffic lane of any street or roadway, as provided in
Section
480.03 (r), are hereby declared to create emergency situations and may be
immediately towed away without notice.
   (b)   Unforeseen Emergencies. In the event of an unforeseen emergency, such
as a water main break or a fallen tree, an otherwise legally parked vehicle may
be towed by a commercial towing service at the direction of the Chief of
Police, or his or her designee, to the commercial towing service's storage
lots. All tows will be completed solely at the vehicle owner's expense,
including but not limited to, any towing charges and storage fees which may be
charged by the commercial towing service.
   (c)   Nonemergencies.
      (1)   Motor vehicles blocking driveways. Upon complaint or observation of
any illegally parked motor vehicle upon any public property, which blocks the
ingress or egress to a property, said motor vehicle may be immediately towed
away without notice.
      (2)   Except as provided in subsection (a) hereof, upon complaint or
observation of any illegally parked motor vehicle upon any public or private
property, an authorized representative of the City shall issue a notice to the
owner of such illegally parked motor vehicle as follows:
         A.   For a motor vehicle with proper registration and licensing,
notice shall be sent by certified or registered mail, return receipt requested,
or by personal delivery as provided in Section 2-203 of the Illinois Code of
Civil Procedure; or
         B.   For a motor vehicle without identifiable licensing, registration
or ownership, the notice shall be affixed to the illegally parked motor vehicle
in a conspicuous location.
      (3)   The notice provided in paragraph (c)(2) hereof shall contain the
following information:
         A.   That the vehicle is parked illegally as defined by this Traffic
Code;
         B.   That the owner has three days within which to remove the motor
vehicle;
         C.   That the owner is entitled to a hearing concerning the City's
decision to classify the vehicle as illegally parked;
         D.   That a request for a hearing must be made within three days of
the date of the notice; and
         E.   That the failure of the owner to remove the motor vehicle will
subject the motor vehicle to being towed and stored at the owner's expense and
will subject the owner of the motor vehicle to the penalties prescribed in
Section
480.99.
      (4)   The Police Department is hereby authorized to cause the towing,
removal and storage of any motor vehicle which is in violation of this chapter,
and whose owner has not removed or caused the removal of such motor vehicle
after the service of the notice as provided in this subsection within the
three-day period. The owner of the vehicle towed shall be financially
responsible for the costs of such towing, removal and storage.
      (5)   Upon the towing and removal of the illegally parked motor vehicle,
the City shall keep and maintain a record of the vehicle towed, including the
following information concerning such vehicle:
         A.   The color;
         B.   The year of manufacture;
         C.   The manufacturer's trade name;
         D.   The manufacturer's series name;
         E.   The body style;
         F.   The vehicle identification number;
         G.   The license plate;
         H.   The license plate number;
         I.   The registration sticker year;
         J.   The registration number displayed;
         K.   The date and hour of the tow;
         L.   The location from which such vehicle was towed;
         M.   The location to which such vehicle was towed;
         N.   The reason for the tow; and
         O.   The City employee authorizing the tow.
      (6)   A person who fails to remove such motor vehicle within three days
of the delivery of the receipt of the first parking citation shall be deemed to
be in violation of this chapter.
      (7)   The failure of the owner of an inoperable motor vehicle to remove
such vehicle duly served as required by this section upon the expiration of the
three-day period shall subject the vehicle to removal and possible disposal in
accordance with Section 4-201 et seq. of Chapter 4, Article II, of the Illinois
Vehicle Code, as adopted in Section
420.01.
   (d)   Recovery of Towed Vehicles. Illegally parked vehicles which are towed
shall be stored on the commercial towing service’s storage lots. After towing,
every effort shall be made to notify the owner or lawful possessor of the
illegally parked vehicle of the location of the vehicle and of the right of the
owner or lawful possessor to recover possession of the vehicle. Any owner or
lawful possessor of a towed vehicle, before the same is returned to his or her
possession, shall be required to pay all outstanding parking fines and other
fines in connection therewith, towing charges and storage charges.
   (e)   Disposition of Unclaimed Vehicles. In the event the owner or lawful
possessor of a towed motor vehicle does not reclaim the same within six months
of the date it is towed away, the City may sell the same at auction or destroy
it. Before doing so, the City will obtain a court order permitting such
disposition.
(1977 Code §49-111; Ord. 78-26. Passed 4-3-78; Ord. 79-39. Passed 6-18-79; Ord.
91-73. Passed 10-21-91; Ord. 2001-49. Passed 11-19-01; Ord. 2021-84. Passed 11-
1-21.)

480.14 DOUBLE PARKING.
   No person shall double park a vehicle.
(1977 Code § 49-115)
480.15 LOADING OR UNLOADING OF SEMITRAILERS.
   The loading or unloading of semitrailers with more than one set of dual
wheels is prohibited in the Central Business District from 6:00 a.m. to 6:00
p.m. However, such semitrailers may stand in such District at the curb only for
a period not to exceed four hours, during the prohibited hours, in the
discretion of the Chief of Police, during the time and in the space as reserved
on a day prior to the day of standing and upon payment of the established daily
fee.
(1977 Code § 49-116)
480.16 PARKING OF TRUCKS, COMMERCIAL VEHICLES AND PASSENGER VANS IN RESIDENTIAL
DISTRICTS.
   (a)   The parking of trucks or vehicles with gross vehicle weight rating in
excess of 14,000 lbs, on any street in a residential district for more than
four consecutive hours within any twenty-four hour period, is prohibited.
   (b)   The parking of trucks or vehicles with gross vehicle weight rating in
excess of 14,000 lbs, on any private property in a residential district for
more than four consecutive hours within any twenty-four hour period, is
prohibited, unless such vehicle is wholly contained within an enclosed garage.
   (c)   The parking of any trailer other non-motorized vehicle intended to be
pulled behind another motorized vehicle on any public street or private
property in a residential district for more than four consecutive hours within
any twenty-four hour period, is prohibited, unless such vehicle is wholly
contained within an enclosed garage, or on a paved parking surface located
within the buildable area of the rear portion of the residential lot or as
otherwise allowed pursuant to subsection (e) of this section.
   (d)   No vehicle or equipment intended to be used primarily in a
construction trade or business, including, but not limited to, powered lifts,
excavators, loaders, bulldozers, or other similar equipment shall be allowed on
any public street or private property within a residential district for more
than twelve consecutive hours within any twenty-four hour period.
   (e)   Exceptions. Notwithstanding anything herein to the contrary, nothing
contained in this chapter shall prohibit:
      (1)   The parking of a recreational vehicle or pull-behind travel trailer
designed as a mobile living space in a residential driveway for any period of
time.
      (2)   The parking of an open trailer carrying recreational watercraft,
snowmobiles, jet skis (personal watercraft), ATV's, or other similar mechanical
conveyances designed primarily for offroad recreational use in a residential
driveway for any period of time. Provided, this exception shall be deemed to
allow only seasonally appropriate parking, and shall not allow year-round
storage of seasonally specific conveyances such as boats or snowmobiles.
Further, nothing contained herein shall be deemed to allow the parking of a
trailer of any kind which is used primarily in conjunction with a trade or
business.
      (3)   The parking of vehicles with a gross vehicle weight rating in
excess of 14,000 lbs or other construction equipment in a residential district
for more than four hours in a twenty-four hour period, if said vehicles or
equipment are being actively used in conjunction with a validly issued building
permit which specifically states the terms under which such equipment is
allowed to remain on site. It shall be the sole obligation of the operator of
the vehicles and/or equipment to request such accommodation at the time of
application for the building permit, and the grant of such permission shall be
within the sole discretion of the permitting officer.
      (4)   Parking of a vehicle on a street in a residential district for more
than four, but less than twelve consecutive hours within a twenty-four hour
period while being loaded or unloaded or while the custodian of the vehicle is
performing services for hire in or about a residence or site abutting the
street on which the vehicle is parked.
   The exceptions contained in this subsection (e) shall be strictly construed
within the context of this chapter, and shall not be deemed to excuse
compliance with any other chapter or section of these Codified Ordinances.
Further provided, that any exception shall be deemed to require that any such
exempted vehicle is validly licensed and is located upon the lot in such a
manner as to avoid interference with traffic visibility or line-of-sight for
passing vehicles.
(1977 Code §49-117; Ord. 78-82. Passed 9-18-78; Ord. 2019-14. Passed 3-4-19.)
480.17 PARKING OF VEHICLES USED TO TRANSPORT FLAMMABLE LIQUIDS OR HAZARDOUS
MATERIALS IN RESIDENTIAL DISTRICTS.
   The parking of vehicles used for the transport and delivery of flammable
liquids or hazardous materials, in a residential district for more than two
consecutive hours in one location within any twenty-four hour period, is
prohibited.
(1977 Code § 49-118)
480.18 PARKING OF WASTE TRANSPORTERS IN RESIDENTIAL DISTRICTS.
   The parking of vehicles designed or regularly used for the transportation of
junk, garbage, refuse, waste or trash, for more than two consecutive hours in
one location in a residential district within any twenty-four hour period, is
prohibited.
(1977 Code § 49-119)

480.21 SPECIAL EVENT PARKING PERMITS.
   Upon application duly made, and after the payment of a three dollar ($3.00)
fee, the City Clerk is hereby authorized to issue a special event parking
permit to any person attending a special civic event within the City within the
Central Business District, as defined in Section
202.03(5) of these Codified Ordinances. A "special civic event" means any
partial or full-day program occurring not more often than semi-annually within
the Central Business District held by a nonprofit or for-profit entity and for
which off-street parking is not readily available because of location or the
number of attendants. The City Manager or his or her authorized representative
shall have sole authority to determine whether an event qualifies as a special
civic event.
   A special event parking permit shall allow a person to park a vehicle in a
parking space within a designated area for not longer than the hours specified
in the permit, but in no event shall a person park a vehicle longer than
twenty-four hours in the same space. Such parking permit shall apply to only
one calendar day, and additional parking permits must be obtained for each day
of a multi-day event. Any individual receiving such a special event parking
permit shall prominently display such permit in the lower right hand corner of
the front windshield of the vehicle.
(Ord. 95-64. Passed 1-2-96; Ord. 2017-56. Passed 7-17-17.)

without limitation on the length of time the vehicle remains parked in any such
space, subject, however, to the twenty-four hour limitation provided in Section
480.04. The provisions of this section shall not apply on Sundays or legal
holidays.
   (b)   Thirty-Minute Parking Zones. Areas depicted on the

marked on the pavement. The time limits for parking in each such space shall be
thirty minutes on Monday through Saturday from 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. The
provisions of this section shall not apply on Sundays or legal holidays.

480.23 RESPONSIBILITY FOR VIOLATIONS.
   The owner, as well as the driver, of any vehicle operated or parked in
violation of any of the provisions of this chapter shall be liable and
responsible for any such violation and for the penalties therefor provided in
Section 480.99.
(1977 Code § 49-125; Ord. 80-6. Passed 1-21-80.)
480.24 DISABLED PERSONS AND VETERANS.
   (a)   Parking Privileges; Exemptions. A motor vehicle bearing a registration
plate, special decal or device issued by the State or any other jurisdiction
designating that the vehicle is operated by or for a disabled person or
veteran, and which is being operated by or for a disabled person or veteran,
shall be exempt from any State statute or local ordinance imposing time
limitations on parking, except limitations of one-half hour or less, on any
City street or highway and on any City-owned or leased parking lot or parking
place. Any motor vehicle bearing any such registration plate, decal or device
which is being operated by or for a disabled person or veteran may be parked,
in addition to any other lawful place, in any parking place specifically
reserved for such vehicles by the posting of a sign. Parking privileges granted
as provided in this section are strictly limited to the persons to whom the
special registration plates, special decals or devices are issued and to
qualified operators acting under the express direction and in the presence of
the disabled person or veteran. Such parking privileges granted by this
subsection are also extended to motor vehicles of not-for-profit organizations
used for the transportation of disabled persons and/or veterans when any such
motor vehicle displays any such registration plate, special decal or device and
when such motor vehicle is being used for the transportation of one or more
disabled persons and/or veterans. This subsection shall not permit the parking
of any motor vehicle in violation of the provisions of Section 480.03. This
subsection shall not permit the parking of any motor vehicle in violation of an
official sign expressly prohibiting parking at any time or during certain hours
in the area controlled by the sign. When using the parking privileges for
persons with disabilities, the parking decal or device must be displayed
properly in the vehicle where it is clearly visible to law enforcement
personnel, either hanging from the rearview mirror or placed on the dashboard
of the vehicle in clear view.
   (b)   Unauthorized Use of Reserved Parking Places. No person shall park any
motor vehicle in any parking place, including any private or public off-street
parking facility, specifically reserved, by the posting of a sign, for a
disabled person or veteran, or a motor vehicle bearing a registration plate,
decal or device designating that the vehicle is operated by or for a disabled
person and/or veteran, unless the parked motor vehicle is operated by a
disabled person or veteran or by a qualified operator acting under the express
direction, and in the presence of, a disabled person or veteran. The owner of a
privately-owned parking place in which a motor vehicle is parked in violation
of this subsection, after notifying the police, may remove it or cause it to be
removed to the nearest garage or other place of safety, and the police may
remove or cause to be removed any motor vehicle parked in any City-owned
parking place in violation of this subsection to the nearest garage or other
place of safety.
   (c)   Officers Authorized to Remove Vehicles. Whenever any police officer
finds a vehicle parked in violation of any of the provisions of this section,
such officer is hereby authorized to move such vehicle, or require the driver
or other person in charge of the vehicle to move the same, to a position off
the roadway where it may be lawfully parked. This provision shall not limit the
authority of the officer to require that the vehicle be towed to a garage or to
a place of safety.
   (d)   Designation of Parking Spaces. Parking spaces reserved for disabled
persons and/or veterans shall be properly posted by an official sign in
accordance with the provisions of the Illinois Accessibility Code, as set forth
in Title 71, Part 400 of the Illinois Administrative Code, and the American
National Standard for Buildings and Facilities, published by the American
National Standards Institute, Inc. and commonly known as ANSI A117.1-1986,
“Providing Accessibility and Usability for Physically Handicapped People,” as
amended and in accordance with 625 ILCS 5/11-1301.3. It shall not be a defense
to a charge under this section that either the sign posted pursuant to this
section or the intended accessible parking place does not comply with the
technical requirements of this section if a reasonable person would be made
aware by the sign or notice on or near the parking place that the place is
reserved for a person with disabilities. In addition to those spaces required
pursuant to the above, parking spaces shall be designated as follows:
      (1)   Any location designated as reserved for Handicapped Parking on the
Master Parking Plan from time to time adopted in accordance with Chapter 488 of
these Codified Ordinances and indicated by a sign in accordance with the
requirements stated above.
      (2)   Bauscher Avenue, east side, 188 feet north of East Empire Street to
213 feet north of East Empire Street.
      (3)   Beach Street (Avenue D), south side, 120 feet west of Waddell.
      (4)   Beach Street (Avenue D), south side, 145 feet west of Waddell.
      (5)   Beach Street (Avenue D), south side, 215 feet west of Waddell.
      (6)   Beach Street, (Avenue D), south side, 300 feet west of Waddell.
      (7)   W. Broadway Street, north side, 182 feet west of Oak Ave. (218 W.
Broadway).
      (8)   Elk Street (west), north side, 110 feet east of S. Pine Avenue.
      (9)   Elk Street (west), south side, 50 feet west of S. Blackhawk Avenue
to 80 feet west of S. Blackhawk Avenue.
      (10)   Galena Avenue, north side, 115 feet west of Carroll Avenue.
      (11)   Galena Avenue, north side, 135 feet west of Carroll Avenue.
      (12)   Galena Avenue, east side, 40 feet north of Pleasant.
      (13)   E. Jackson Street, south side, 98 feet east of S. Galena Avenue.
      (14)   S. Oak Avenue, west side, 170 feet south of Homer Street (916 S.
Oak Ave.).
      (15)   W. Pleasant, north side, 66 feet east to 115 feet east of S.
Galena Avenue.
      (16)   Prospect Terrace, south side, 225 feet west of South Float Avenue.
      (17)   State Street, east side, 375 feet south of East Pleasant Avenue to
419 feet south of East Pleasant Avenue.
      (18)   W. Stephenson Street, north side, 315 feet west of Harlem (1146 W.
Stephenson St.).
   (e)   The owner or occupant of any property which is required under
subsection (d) hereof to display any accessible parking sign shall ensure that
such sign is in compliance with current state signage requirements. Correction
of the sign, specifically including, but not limited to the fine amount, must
be completed within ninety days of the effective date of Ordinance No. 2007-71.
A violation of this section shall be punishable by a fine not to exceed one
hundred dollars ($100.00) for each day the accessible parking sign has not been
corrected.
(1977 Code §§ 49-122A, 49-128; Ord. 88-67. Passed 11-21-88; Ord. 89-6. Passed

480.25 CONTRACTOR PARKING PERMITS.
   Upon application duly made and after payment of a three dollar ($3.00) per
day fee and a twenty-five dollar ($25.00) deposit, the Building Commissioner is
hereby authorized to issue a special contractor's parking permit to any
contractor engaged in the construction, repair, renovation or maintenance of
any building in the City of Freeport. A special contractor's parking permit
shall allow a person to park a vehicle in a parking space within a designated
area for not longer than the hours specified in the permit.
   A special contractor's parking permit may be issued for more than one
calendar day, upon payment of the appropriate per day fees. Any individual
receiving such a special contractor's parking permit shall prominently display
such permit in the lower right-hand corner of the front windshield of the
vehicle. Upon return of such permit without damage, the twenty-five dollar
($25.00) security deposit shall be refunded to the individual.
(Ord. 95-65. Passed 1-2-96; Ord. 2002-16. Passed 4-1-02; Ord. 2013-10. Passed
3-4-13.)
480.26 UNAUTHORIZED PARKING OF UNREGISTERED MOTOR VEHICLES.
   No person shall park, upon any public property or public right-of-way, any
vehicle which is not currently and properly registered with a duly authorized
Illinois or other state's or nation's department of motor vehicles,
transportation, secretary of state, registration or other applicable agency or
department.
(Ord. 98-48. Passed 8-3-98.)
480.99 PENALTY.
   (a)   Whoever violates any of the provisions of Section
480.03(j), (o), (s) or (u),
480.04 or
480.08(a) or (b) shall be fined not less than twenty dollars ($20.00) nor more
than two hundred dollars ($200.00) for each violation, if the fine is paid
within five days from the issuance of the ticket, and, if not paid within five
days, then not less than forty dollars ($40.00) nor more than two hundred
dollars ($200.00) for each such violation.
   (b)   Whoever violates Section
480.10(c)(5) shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than
five hundred dollars ($500.00) for a first offense, and not less than one
hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for a
second and each subsequent offense. Each day that a violation occurs or
continues shall constitute a separate offense. Enforcement proceedings may be
commenced by either a notice to appear or by a summons.
   (c)   Whoever violates any of the provisions of Section
480.20 shall be fined not less than ten dollars ($10.00) nor more than two
hundred dollars ($200.00) for each violation, if the fine is paid within five
days from the issuance of the ticket, and, if not paid within five days, then
not less than twenty dollars ($20.00) nor more than two hundred dollars
($200.00) for each such violation.
   (d)   Any person violating any of the provisions of Section
480.24 shall be fined no less than two hundred and fifty dollars ($250.00), in
addition to any costs or charges connected with the removal or storage of any
motor vehicle.
   (e)   Whoever violates any of the provisions of Section
480.03(d) shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than two
hundred dollars ($200.00) for each violation, if the fine is paid within five
days from the issuance of the ticket, and, if not paid within five days, then
not less than seventy five dollars ($75.00) nor more than two hundred dollars
($200.00) for each such violation.
   (f)   Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter for which
no penalty is otherwise provided shall be fined not less than ten dollars
($10.00) nor more than two hundred dollars ($200.00) for each such violation,
if the fine is paid within five days from the issuance of the ticket, and, if
not paid within five days, then not less than twenty dollars ($20.00) nor more
than two hundred dollars ($200.00) for each such violation.

482.04 PARKING PERMITS.
   (a)   No person shall park a motor vehicle or other vehicle in any City
parking lot in the Central Business District (excluding Lot 12) overnight,
between the hours of 2:00 and 5:00 a.m. without displaying on said vehicle a
valid parking placard issued by the City. No person shall park a motor vehicle
or other vehicle overnight in City Lot 12. Upon payment of an annual fee of
twenty-five dollars ($25.00) to the Finance Director or his or her designee,
the Licensing Officer shall issue a parking placard to any person paying such
fee. Such parking placards shall expire on April 30 of each year. No person
shall deface, alter or forge any such parking placard, nor shall any person
knowingly possess, use or display any such defaced, altered or forged parking
placard.

other vehicle in any City parking lot for a period of time longer than twenty-

482.05 METHOD OF PARKING.
   In all off-street parking lots, vehicles shall be parked or left unattended
only within the confines of a marked parking place. Any vehicle parked in an
off-street parking lot shall, at all times when so parked, bear the same
current and valid registration as is required by the laws of this State to
operate said vehicle on the public streets and highways of this State.
(Ord. 92-76. Passed 12-7-92; Ord. 2012-43. Passed 8-20-12.)

482.07 LEGAL PARKING LIMIT.
   (a)   Subject to the snow emergency provisions set forth in Section 486.03
of the Code, no person shall permit a vehicle to remain in any parking space in
any off-street parking lot for a period of time longer than one week.
(Ord. 94-16. Passed 4-18-94; Ord. 2023-43. Passed 10-2- 23.)
482.08 PROHIBITED PARKING.
   The parking of trucks of vehicles in excess of one ton capacity or
semitrailers, used primarily for the transportation of property or for other
commercial use, shall be prohibited in any city off-street parking lot, with
the exception of parking in conjunction with a Special Events permit issued by
the City or City vehicles in pursuance of operational needs of the City.
Whoever violates this section shall be fined in accordance with Section 482.99
(c).
(Ord. 2002-03. Passed 3-4-02.)

484.01 DESIGNATION OF LOADING ZONES; SIGNS REQUIRED.
   The Director of Public Works shall determine, in compliance with this
Chapter, the location of loading zones, and shall maintain appropriate signs
indicating the location and applicable hours.
(1977 Code § 52-101) (Ord. 2002-79. Passed 2-3-03)
484.02 TYPES OF LOADING AND COURTESY ZONES.
   There are hereby established the following types of loading zones:
   (a)   Commercial Loading Zones. A commercial loading zone is defined as a
space adjacent to a curb, for the exclusive use of vehicles during the loading
or unloading of goods or materials
   (b)   Business Loading Zones. A business loading zone is defined as a fee-
based loading zone permitted by the City under application and approval of the
Public Works Director under consideration of the following factors:
      (1)   Ten (10) or more deliveries or pickups per day;
      (2)   Delivery or pickup of perishable items;
      (3)   Heavy or cumbersome items for delivery or pickup;
      (4)   Business owned delivery vehicles being used for delivery or pickup.
There shall be no more than one business loading zone permitted to any at a
given time, unless extraordinary circumstances are shown.
   (c)   Customer Courtesy Zones. A customer courtesy zone is a designated
parking space for the purpose of providing "quick stop" parking for businesses
located in the vicinity. Such spaces shall be as designated from time to time
by the Director of Public Works and are intended to be located at each corner
or mid-block, on each side of the street where practicable, in the Downtown
District.
   (d)   Passenger Loading Zones. A passenger loading zone is a designated
parking space for the purpose of dropping off passengers, and is intended to
encompass such uses as churches, daycare facilities, schools, hospitals,
doctors' offices and other areas where loading and pickup of passengers is
needed.
(Ord. 2002-79. Passed 2-3-03; Ord. 2005-35. Passed 7-18-05.)
484.03 BUSINESS LOADING ZONE PERMITS; FEES.
   Business loading zone permits may be obtained by compliance with the
following:
   (a)   Any person desiring a business loading zone permit shall make
application to the Director of Public Works, setting forth all relevant
information, including the location, number of feet and the time desired, the
number of deliveries or pickups per day, the type of deliveries or pickups, and
the type and ownership of any vehicles dedicated to such pickup or deliveries.
   (b)   The Director of Public Works may grant or refuse such application if
an applicant makes a substantial showing of the factors as listed in Section
484.02 above.
   (c)   If a permit is approved, the Public Works Director shall issue a
permit stating the location, frontage, time limits and any other limitations.
   (d)   The permit may be withdrawn or further limited by the Director of
Public Works at any time for noncompliance.
   (e)   All signs shall be prepared and lettered by the Division of Streets,
and the cost thereof shall be paid by the applicant.
   (f)   A permit shall continue in force indefinitely, provided that the
annual fee is paid until revoked by the Director of Public Works.
   (g)   The fee for such permit shall be two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00)
per year for each twenty linear feet, or portion thereof, for the hours as
designated in accordance with the approved permit.
   (h)   The fee for renewal of a permit shall be the same as the fee for the
original issuance.
   (i)   Fees shall be paid with the original application, subject to refund if
denied, and on or before each anniversary date. No refund shall be given if a
permit is revoked after initial issuance.
   (j)   If the provisions of this section or the permit are violated by the
holder of the permit or any of his or her employees by use of the loading zone
parking space for parking of vehicles of the holder of the permit or his or her
employees three times in any fiscal year of the City (May 1 through April 30 of
the following year), the loading zone permit shall be revoked and not be
renewable upon its expiration on April 30, and the holder shall not be eligible
to obtain a loading zone permit for such space until the expiration of twelve
months following the April 30 expiration date. The Police Department shall
ticket vehicles parked in violation of the provisions of this section. Payment
of a fine or forfeiture of a bond for three or more such violations within any
one fiscal year shall render the loading zone permit nonrenewable when it
expires on April 30.
(1977 Code § 52-102; Ord. 78-47. Passed 7-3-78; Ord. 81-67. Passed 10-19-81;
Ord. 82-30. Passed 6-7-82; Ord. 97-21. Passed 7-21-97; Ord. 2002-36. Passed 6-
3-02; Ord. 2002-79. Passed 2-3-03; Ord. 2011-33. Passed 5-16-11.)
484.04 PUBLIC CARRIER STANDS.
   Council may establish, by resolution, bus stands and taxicab stands in the
Central Business District, for the convenience of the public. Every such stand
shall be designated by an appropriate sign. The following rules shall apply:
   (a)   A driver shall not stand or park a bus upon any street in such
District at any place other than a bus stand.
   (b)   The driver of a bus shall enter a bus stand so that the bus, when
stopped, is parallel to, and the front wheel is not more than eighteen inches
from, the curb.
   (c)   A driver shall not stand a taxicab to solicit or receive passengers,
other than in response to a specific call, in the Central Business District at
any place other than in a taxicab stand.
   (d)   No person shall stand a vehicle, other than a bus or taxicab, in a bus
stop or a taxicab stand, if such standing will interfere with any bus or
taxicab.
(1977 Code § 52-103; Ord. 88-71. Passed 11-21-88; Ord. 2002-79. Passed 2-3-03.)
484.05 DISABLED PERSONS.
   Areas depicted on the
Chapter 488 Master Parking Plan map as accessible placard parking shall be
reserved for the parking of vehicles properly displaying a “Persons with
Disabilities Certification for Parking Placard” issued by the State of Illinois
indicating a right to park in accessible parking zones.
(Ord. 2002-79. Passed 2-3-03; Ord. 2013-08. Passed 1-22-13; Ord. 2017-21.
Passed 4-3-17; Ord. 2023-07. Passed 3-6-23; Ord. 2024-15. Passed 4-1-24.)
