   Reserved spaces for the parking of motor vehicles of officials are depicted
on the
Chapter 488 Master Parking Plan map.
(1977 Code § 52-105; Ord. 79-40. Passed 7-2-79; Ord. 2002-35. Passed 6-3-02;
Ord. 2002-79. Passed 2-3-03; Ord. 2004-34. Passed 6-7-04; Ord. 2007-49. Passed
6-18-07; Ord. 2013-08. Passed 1-22-13; Ord. 2017-21. Passed 4-3-17; Ord. 2023-
07. Passed 3-6-23.)
484.07 LOADING, UNLOADING, AND COURTESY ZONE SPACES.
   No person shall stand or park a vehicle:
   (a)   In a commercial loading zone space between the hours of 6:00 a.m. and
8:00 p.m. Monday through Saturday, except during the loading or unloading of
goods or materials;
   (b)   In a business loading zone except in accordance with the permit issued
hereunder;
   (c)   In a customer courtesy zone for a period in excess of fifteen (15)
minutes.
(Ord. 94-1. Passed 2-21-94; Ord. 2002-79. Passed 2-3-03.)
484.08 LOADING ZONES FOR PERSONS WITH DISABILITIES.
   Council shall have authority to establish and recall loading zones for
persons with disabilities on any public street located within the City. Loading
zones for persons with disabilities may be issued to any natural person who, as
determined by a licensed physician:
   (a)   Cannot walk 200 feet without stopping to rest;
   (b)   Cannot walk without the use of, or assistance from, a brace, cane,
crutch, another person, prosthetic device, wheelchair or other assistive
device;
   (c)   Is restricted by lung disease to such an extent that his or her forced
(respiratory) expiratory volume of one second, when measured by spirometry, is
less than one liter, or the arterial oxygen tension is less than sixty mm/hg on
room air at rest;
   (d)   Uses portable oxygen;
   (e)   Has a cardiac condition to the extent that the person's functional
limitations are classified in severity as Class III or Class IV, according to
standards set by the American Heart Association; or
   (f)   Is severely limited in the person's ability to walk due to an
arthritic, neurological or orthopedic condition.
   (g)   Otherwise qualifies under any local, state or federal law or
regulation as disabled.
   Application for a loading zone for persons with disabilities shall be made
at the Public Works office. The Public Works Director, in consultation with the
Police Chief and the City Legal Counsel, shall determine the anticipated effect
upon public safety and whether the application complies with City ordinances.
Upon approval of the loading zone application by said City officers, Council
shall determine, by resolution, the location of such loading zone, and shall
provide that appropriate signs or curb markings indicating the location and
length of said loading zone are properly posted. Any application for such
loading zone which is denied by said City officers may be appealed to the City
Manager.
   All such authorized loading zones shall be renewed annually to determine
whether the applicant continues to qualify for such loading zone. Any
resolution to establish a loading zone for persons with disabilities may be
revoked by Council at any time.
   A loading zone for persons with disabilities shall be for standing vehicles
only and not for parking.
(Ord. 96-76. Passed 11-4-96; Ord. 2002-79. Passed 2-3-03; Ord. 2017-56. Passed
7-17-17.)
484.99 PENALTY.
   (a)   Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter shall be fined
not less than twenty dollars ($20.00) nor more than two hundred dollars
($200.00) for each such violation, if the fine is paid within five days from
the issuance of the ticket, and, if not paid within five days, then not less
than forty dollars ($40.00) nor more than two hundred dollars ($200.00) for
each such violation. (1977 Code § 49-121) (Ord. 2001-48. Passed 11-5-01.)
   (b)   Whoever violates Section 484.07 shall be fined one hundred dollars
($100.00), in addition to any costs or charges connected with the removal or
storage of any motor vehicle. (Ord. 96-76. Passed 11-4-96.)
CHAPTER 486
Winter Parking Regulations
486.01   Definitions.
486.02   Application of chapter.
486.03   Parking prohibited under certain conditions.
486.04   Snow on right-of-way.
486.05   Towing of vehicles.
486.06   Presumption of responsibility for violations.
486.07   Delegation of authority.
486.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Size and weight exceptions for snow removal equipment - see IVC § 5/15-101;
S.U. & P.S. 1020.17
   Snowmobiles on streets - see TRAF. 440.04
   Depositing snow and ice on streets - see S.U. & P.S. 1020.11
   Removal of snow from sidewalks - see S.U. & P.S. 1026.21
486.01 DEFINITIONS.
   The following words and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the
meanings respectively ascribed to them:
   (a)   “Central Business District” means all streets and portions of streets
within the area described as follows: beginning at the southwesterly corner of
Jackson and Walnut, thence easterly along the southerly side of Jackson to
Liberty, thence northerly along the easterly side of Liberty to Exchange,
thence westerly along the northerly side of Exchange to Adams, thence northerly
along the easterly side of Adams to Douglas, thence westerly along the
northerly side of Douglas to Cherry, thence southerly along the westerly side
of Cherry to Spring, thence easterly along the southerly side of Spring to
Walnut, thence to the point of beginning.
   (b)   “Cul-de-sac” shall be defined as a street, lane, etc., closed at one
end.
   (c)   “Motor vehicle” means a vehicle which is self-propelled, or any device
towable by a motor vehicle.
   (d)   “Odd-numbered and even-numbered sides of the street” means the usual
residence or building numbers assigned by the proper authority. Even numbers
are on the north and west sides of the street, and odd numbers are on the south
and east sides of the streets.
   (e)   “'Odd-numbered days” and “even-numbered days” of the month means the
days as numbered on the calendar of the particular current month and year.
   (f)   “Snow emergency” shall be defined as any time the Director of Public
Works, or his/her designee, declares that a snow fall of two or more inches, or
any other inclement weather has occurred, and shall continue for a period of
forty-eight hours thereafter. Notification of such “snow emergency” shall be
presumed upon posting on the City’s website and/or upon reporting the
declaration of a snow emergency to local news stations.
   (g)   “Superintendent of Streets” means the Superintendent of Streets of the
City of Freeport, or his or her designee.
   (h)   “Winter months” shall be defined as the time period of November 1
through March 31.
(1977 Code §49-201; Ord. 78-70. Passed 8-7-78; Ord. 91-51. Passed 9-3-91; Ord.
2002-36. Passed 6-3-02; Ord. 2008-64. Passed 12-15-08; Ord. 2009-65. Passed 11-
2-09; Ord. 2012-66. Passed 12-10-12; Ord. 2019-03. Passed 1-14-19; Ord. 2021-
84. Passed 11-1-21; Ord. 2022-75. Passed 12-19-22.)
486.02 APPLICATION OF CHAPTER.
   The provisions of this chapter regulating the standing or parking of motor
vehicles on certain designated streets or parts of streets shall apply during
all winter months.
(1977 Code § 49-202; Ord. 91-51. Passed 9-3-91; Ord. 2002-36. Passed 6-3-02;
Ord. 2008-64. Passed 12-15-08.)
486.03 PARKING PROHIBITED UNDER CERTAIN CONDITIONS.
   (a)   At any time when there has been at least one-half inch of snow
accumulation, no person shall obstruct the orderly removal of snow from the
City's streets by parking or otherwise leaving unattended any motor vehicle
upon:
      (1)   Central Business District:
         A.   All Central Business District residents must have their cars
removed from the street when there has been at least one-half inch of snow
accumulation; and
         B.   Parking lots in the Central Business District shall be divided to
have an east and west side of the parking lot. The City will install signage
indicating the east and west side of the parking lot. Between November 1,
through March 31 of each year, or anytime when there has been at least one-half
inch of snow accumulation, all motor vehicles shall be parked or left standing
in the east half of the parking lot on even-numbered days of the month and on
the west side of the parking lot on odd-numbered days of the month. For the
purpose of this chapter, "odd" and "even" numbered days shall be considered as
beginning at the hour of 8:00 a.m. and vehicles must be moved no later than 9:
00 a.m. All persons in the Central Business District who receive a parking
permit pursuant to Section
482.04, Parking Permits, must abide by the foregoing odd/even parking rules.
      (2)   All other City streets as provided for herein. Between November 1
through March 31 of each year when there has been at least one-half inch of
snow accumulation, all motor vehicles shall be parked or left standing on even-
numbered days of the month on the even-numbered side of the street and on odd-
numbered days of the month on the odd-numbered side of the street in the City.
For the purpose of this chapter, "odd" and "even" numbered days shall be
considered as beginning at the hour of 8:00 a.m. and vehicles must be moved no
later than 9:00 a.m.
      (3)   Excepting N. Van Buren from E. Clark 135 feet north (to the alley);
and
      (4)   Cul-de-sacs. When there has been at least one-half inch of snow
accumulation, no person shall leave parked or standing any motor vehicle in the
roadway of a cul-de-sac.
   Nothing contained in this subsection shall be construed to permit parking on
streets where parking is otherwise restricted or prohibited. Violations of this
subsection will result in the offending vehicle being towed in addition to the
issuance of a parking citation to the vehicle's owner.
   (b)   The provisions of this section shall be in effect as provided for
herein. Signs shall be posted on primary roads at or near their points of
intersection with the corporate boundaries of the City stating: "Winter Parking
Regulations November 1 through March 31."
   (c)   Streets that have designated parking on one side only for an entire
city block, shall be exempt from this section.
(1977 Code §49-205; Ord. 91-51. Passed 9-3-91; Ord. 2008-64. Passed 12-15-08;
Ord. 2009-06. Passed 1-5-09; Ord. 2009-65. Passed 11-2-09; Ord. 2012-66. Passed
12-10-12; Ord. 2017-84. Passed 12-18-17; Ord. 2021-84. Passed 11-1-21; Ord.
2022-02. Passed 1-18-22; Ord. 2023-43. Passed 10-2-23; Ord. 2024-45. Passed 9-
3-24.)
486.04 SNOW ON RIGHT-OF-WAY.
   No person shall pile or cause to be piled any snow on avenues, streets,
boulevards, alleys, sidewalks or any other City-owned property, except at the
direction of the Director of Public Works and/or the Superintendent of Streets.
Further, no person shall pile or cause to be piled any snow so as to obstruct
the vision at any intersection of any street, avenue, boulevard or alley within
the City.
(1977 Code §49-208; Ord. 91-51. Passed 9-3-91; Ord. 2002-36. Passed 6-3-02;
Ord. 2008-64. Passed 12-15-08; Ord. 2019-03. Passed 1-14-19; Ord. 2022-75.
Passed 12-19-22.)
486.05 TOWING OF VEHICLES.
   (a)   During a snow emergency, the Chief of Police, or his or her designee,
may direct that vehicles parked in violation of this chapter, subject to the
limitations set forth in Section 486.03, be towed away by a commercial towing
service, in addition to the issuance of a citation. Neither the City nor the
towing service shall be liable for any damage to any vehicle, device or
property so towed. Such towing shall be considered as an emergency removal of
an illegally parked vehicle as set forth in Section 480.10(a). Further, all
tows will be completed solely at the vehicle owner's expense, including but not
limited to, any towing charges and storage fees which may be charged by the
commercial towing service.
   (b)   Such emergency towing shall be deemed necessary for public health and
safety as the presence of such vehicle constitutes a hazard to the public and
hampers snow removal.
(1977 Code §§49-204, 49-209; Ord. 91-51. Passed 9-3-91; Ord. 2008-64. Passed
12-15-08; Ord. 2021-84. Passed 11-1-21.)
486.06 PRESUMPTION OF RESPONSIBILITY FOR VIOLATIONS.
   For purposes of prosecution under this chapter, if a vehicle is found parked
or left unattended in violation of the provisions of this chapter, the
registered owner thereof shall be responsible for such violation.
(1977 Code § 49-207; Ord. 91-51. Passed 9-3-91; Ord. 2008-64. Passed 12-15-08.)
486.07 DELEGATION OF AUTHORITY.
   The Chief of Police may designate persons to act as winter parking
enforcement personnel to enforce this chapter through the issuance of
citations.
   (a)   Persons appointed as winter parking enforcement personnel shall be
employees or officials of the City of Freeport.
   (b)   Persons appointed as winter parking enforcement personnel are subject
to the following limitations:
      (1)   No winter parking enforcement personnel shall be deemed a peace
officer.
      (2)   No winter parking enforcement personnel shall be required to
complete training as a peace officer.
      (3)   No winter parking enforcement personnel shall have the power or
authority to enforce other traffic, civil, or criminal laws.
      (4)   No winter parking enforcement personnel shall possess or carry
firearms or other weapons for the purpose of or while acting as a winter
parking enforcement personnel.
(Ord. 2011-12. Passed 3-21-11.)
486.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any of the provisions of this chapter shall be fined not
less than twenty dollars ($20.00) nor more than two hundred dollars ($200.00)
for each violation, if the fine is paid within five days from the issuance of
the ticket, and, if not paid within five days, then not less than forty dollars
($40.00) nor more than four hundred dollars ($400.00) for each such violation.
Such fines will be in addition to any and all other fees in connection
therewith. The offending vehicle owner shall be solely responsible for all
towing charges and storage fees imposed by the commercial towing service.
(Ord. 98-11. Passed 2-2-98; Ord. 2021-84. Passed 11-1-21.)

PART SIX - GENERAL OFFENSES CODE
 CHAPTER 604
General Provisions; Administration, Enforcement and Penalty
604.01   Enforcement.
604.02   Aiding or abetting violations.
604.03   Interfering with police officers.
604.04   Interfering with fire-fighting operations; unlawful reconnection of
utilities.
604.05   Resisting police; escaping from custody.
604.06   Duty to assist police officers.
604.07   Aiding jail escapes.
604.08   Compliance with lawful order of police officers.
604.09   Right of forcible entry into gambling or disorderly house; arrests.
(Repealed)
604.10   Impersonating a police officer.
604.11   Treatment of police dogs.
604.12   Use of high frequency police radio sets.
604.13   Answering or interfering with police calls.
604.14   False reports.
604.15   Acting as a lookout for illegal acts.
604.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Anti-crime advisory council - see 20 ILCS 3910/0.01 et seq.
   Penalty assessments - see 50 ILCS 705/9.1; 730 ILCS 5/5-9-1
   Crimes and offenses generally - see 720 ILCS 5/1-1 et seq.; 725 ILCS 5/100-
1 et seq.
   Interference with public officers - see 720 ILCS 5/31-1 et seq.
   Crime prevention and correction compacts - see 730 ILCS 5/3-3-11.3
   Crime Victims Compensation Act - see 740 ILCS 45/1 et seq.
604.01 ENFORCEMENT.
   All of the provisions of this General Offenses Code shall be enforced by the
Police Department.
(1977 Code § 46-401; Ord. 78-62. Passed 8-7-78.)
604.02 AIDING OR ABETTING VIOLATIONS.
   No person shall aid or abet another in the violation of any provision of
these Codified Ordinances.
(1977 Code § 54-201)
604.03 INTERFERING WITH POLICE OFFICERS.
   No person shall interfere, or attempt to interfere, with the Chief of Police
or any member of the Police Department in the discharge of his or her duty.
(1977 Code § 54-202)
604.04 INTERFERING WITH FIRE-FIGHTING OPERATIONS; UNLAWFUL RECONNECTION OF
UTILITIES.
   No person shall interfere, or attempt to interfere, with the Fire Chief or
any member of the Fire Department in the discharge of his or her duty, nor,
without permission of the Chief, connect or attempt to connect any electric
wire, gas pipe, water pipe or water connection after the same has been
disconnected by the Chief or under his or her order.
(1977 Code § 26-202)
604.05 RESISTING POLICE; ESCAPING FROM CUSTODY.
   No person shall resist any member of the Police Department in the discharge
of his or her duty, or assist any person in custody to escape, or attempt to
escape, from such custody.
(1977 Code § 54-203)
604.06 DUTY TO ASSIST POLICE OFFICERS.
   It shall be the duty of all persons, when called upon by any member of the
Police Department, promptly to aid and assist the Department member in the
execution of his or her duties.
(1977 Code § 54-204)
604.07 AIDING JAIL ESCAPES.
   No person shall aid or abet the escape from jail of any person legally
committed, or supply, or attempt to supply, any such person with any weapon,
implement or means of escape while in jail in the City.
(1977 Code § 54-205)
604.08 COMPLIANCE WITH LAWFUL ORDER OF POLICE OFFICERS.
   All persons shall obey the lawful commands and directions of any member of
the Police Department stationed at a public place for the preservation of order
and enforcing the laws.
(1977 Code § 54-206)
604.09 RIGHT OF FORCIBLE ENTRY INTO GAMBLING OR DISORDERLY HOUSE; ARRESTS. 
(REPEALED)
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: Section 604.09 was repealed by Ordinance 96-09, passed March
4, 1996.)
604.10 IMPERSONATING A POLICE OFFICER.
   No person shall falsely represent himself or herself to be an officer of the
Police Department, or, without being duly authorized, exercise, or attempt to
exercise, any of the duties, functions or powers of such officer.
(1977 Code § 54-208)
604.11 TREATMENT OF POLICE DOGS.
   No person shall willfully or maliciously torture, torment, beat, kick,
strike, mutilate, injure, disable or kill any dog used by the Police Department
in the performance of the functions of the Department, or interfere with or
meddle with any such dog while it is being used by such Department or any
member thereof.
(1977 Code § 54-209)
604.12 USE OF HIGH FREQUENCY POLICE RADIO SETS.
   (a)   No person shall equip or operate within the City any motor vehicle
with a high frequency police radio receiving set, unless such motor vehicle is
being used by the Federal, State, City or County Government or by a peace
officer, or unless a permit for such use shall have been granted.
   (b)   Any person desiring such permit shall file an application with the
Chief of Police, in writing, stating the name of the applicant, the license
number, engine number, model and make of the motor vehicle, and the reason for
such installation, and shall furnish a photograph of the applicant and his or
her fingerprints. If the Chief finds that the public interest will be served,
he or she shall issue a permit for the installation and use of the set upon
payment of a fee of ten dollars ($10.00) per year. An application must be filed
and a new permit must be secured for each year such radio is used.
   (c)   Any permit so issued shall not be transferable to any other person or
any other motor vehicle. In case of a change in license number of the motor
vehicle, the owner shall notify the Chief of such change within five days.
(1977 Code § 54-210)
604.13 ANSWERING OR INTERFERING WITH POLICE CALLS.
   No operator of a motor vehicle, other than authorized City officers and
Police and Fire Department members in the line of duty, shall answer police
radio calls, or in any way interfere with any such officer or member answering
such calls.
(1977 Code § 54-211)
604.14 FALSE REPORTS.
   No person shall provide information in any oral or written report required
by these Codified Ordinances, or in any oral or written report given to the
Police Department or the Fire Department, or to any member of such Departments
or to any official of the City, with knowledge or reason to believe that such
information is false.
(1977 Code § 46-143; Ord. 77-93. Passed 12-5-77.)
604.15 ACTING AS A LOOKOUT FOR ILLEGAL ACTS.
   No person shall act as a guard or lookout for any building, premises or
establishment used for gambling, prostitution, illegal sale of alcoholic liquor
or any other form of vice or illegal act, or for any person soliciting,
offering or engaging in prostitution, gambling or other illegal act, nor shall
any person give any warning of the approach of any police officer to any such
person or place.
(1977 Code § 46-114)
604.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
202.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
CHAPTER 608
Alcoholic Liquor
608.01   Definitions; classification of licenses.
608.02   Offenses by licensees.
608.03   Offenses by employees of licensees.
608.04   Possession or consumption in public places.
608.05   Consumption on licensed premises.
608.06   Permitted hours of sales and operation.
608.07   Purchase by intoxicated or underage persons.
608.08   Underage persons on licensed premises.
608.09   Purchase for persons under minimum age.
608.10   Possession by persons under minimum age.
608.11   Consumption by persons under minimum age.
608.12   Access to premises.
608.13   Revocation or suspension of licenses.
608.14   Illegal, disorderly activities or crowds on or about premises.
608.15   Reporting of incidents to police; telephone required on premises.
608.16   Unlicensed delivery.
608.17   BYOB prohibited establishments.
608.18   Other prohibited activities.
608.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Alcoholic beverages - see 235 ILCS 5/1-1 et seq.
   Local licenses - see 235 ILCS 5/4-1
   Liquor Commission - see ADM.
Ch. 266
   Drug/Alcohol Commission - see ADM.
Ch. 268
   Conflicting provisions re alcoholic beverages - see B.R. & T.
802.33
   Alcoholic beverage sales - see B.R. & T.
Ch. 806
   Sale or use of alcohol at teen dance centers - see B.R. & T.
869.13
608.01 DEFINITIONS; CLASSIFICATION OF LICENSES.
   Unless the context otherwise requires, words and phrases used in this
chapter shall be defined as provided in Section 806.01 of the Business
Regulation and Taxation Code, and classification of licenses shall be as
provided in Section
806.03 of the Business Regulation and Taxation Code.
(Ord. 2018-12. Passed 3-5-18.)
608.02 OFFENSES BY LICENSEES.
   No licensee under the provisions of this chapter or
Chapter 806 of the Business Regulation and Taxation Code shall, either
individually or through his or her agents or employees:
   (a)   Sell or possess for sale any package containing alcoholic liquor
unless the same shall have affixed thereto all canceled revenue stamps which
may be required by State or Federal law;
   (b)   Sell or deliver alcoholic liquor during prohibited hours;
   (c)   Except for holders of licenses authorizing package sales only, fail,
neglect or refuse to lock all doors and entrances to the licensed premises and
to keep the same continuously locked during prohibited hours, except that such
doors and entrances may be temporarily unlocked from time to time during
prohibited hours to permit the egress of any person or to permit the ingress of
any authorized person. As used in this subsection, "authorized person" means
the licensee, his or her spouse, his or her employees or any independent
contractors summoned to the premises for purposes of rendering construction or
repair services to the licensed premises or to any equipment utilized for the
operation of such licensed premises;
   (d)   Permit any gambling on the premises, unless pursuant to a validly
issued supplemental video gaming license issued by the City and otherwise
validly licensed by the State of Illinois;
   (e)   Permit any intoxicated person to loiter on the licensed premises, or
permit any conduct which shall tend to disturb the peace or quiet of the
neighborhood or the premises;
   (f)   Serve or permit any person to consume any alcoholic liquor in any
curtained booth or enclosure;
   (g)   Make sales of alcoholic liquor in excess of or contrary to the powers
granted in the license for the premises, in violation of the Liquor Control Act
of the State, or in violation of any other statute of the State;
   (h)   Serve any alcoholic beverage to any person for consumption on the
streets of the City, except as permitted by a valid Sidewalk Cafe or Parklet
permit issued pursuant to
Chapter 1026 or
Chapter 1034 of these Codified Ordinances, in any theater or in or upon any
other public place in the City, or to any persons in motor vehicles on such
streets;
   (i)   Except as otherwise permitted by a validly issued BYOB license, permit
any person to consume any alcoholic liquor on the licensed premises unless such
alcoholic liquor has been purchased on the premises or is in conjunction with a
bona fide product sampling in an amount and manner consistent with 235 ILCS 5/
6-31 and with five days written notice to the City Clerk, if such product
sampling is done by someone other than the licensee;
   (j)   Sell or deliver alcoholic liquor to any person under the age of
twenty-one;
   (k)   Sell or deliver alcoholic liquor to any intoxicated person;
   (l)   Employ or permit any person under the age of twenty-one to draw, pour,
deliver or mix alcoholic liquor;
   (m)   Have in his or her possession, or have registered in his or her name,
a Federal Wagering Stamp or Stamps, as provided by the Revenue Acts of the
United States of America;
   (n)   Permit any person under twenty-one years of age, other than an
employee, in or on any licensed premises at any time, except premises on which
alcoholic liquor is sold only for off-premises consumption, unless such person
under twenty-one years of age is accompanied by his or her parent, legal
guardian or spouse who is at least twenty-one years of age, or unless such
person is present upon a licensed premises, or portion thereof, which is
exempted from the provisions of Section
608.08;
   (o)   Prevent or refuse the inspection of the licensed premises by the
Liquor Commissioner, or his or her designated agent, or any police officer of
the City, without a search warrant, at any time, for the purpose of enforcing
this chapter;
   (p)   Permit any person to carry an alcoholic beverage in an open container
from the licensed premises onto public property or private property other than
the licensed premises;
   (q)   Except for holders of Class R, Class LR, Class CR, Class BYOB, and
Class H Licenses only, employ or permit any person under the age of twenty-one
to sell or serve alcoholic liquor. Holders of Class R, Class LR, Class CR,
Class BYOB, and Class H Licenses may not employ or permit any person under the
age of eighteen to sell or serve alcoholic liquor;
   (r)   Permit any person serving or selling alcoholic liquor at the licensed
premises to be visibly impaired or intoxicated on the licensed premises while
on duty;
   (s)   Permit any person to sell or serve alcoholic liquors without being
properly BASSETT certified as required by the State of Illinois. Proof of
certification of any person selling or serving alcoholic liquor shall be
available on site and produced upon request by any law enforcement officer;
   (t)   Permit any illegal, disorderly activities or crowd on or about the
premises as described in Section
608.14;
   (u)   Sell any alcoholic liquor using a drive-up or drive-through window,
unless said window is equipped with a recording security camera of a type and
placement approved by the Chief of Police, and maintained and operated in a
manner consistent with Section
874.13(c) of these Codified Ordinances.
(Ord. 2018-12. Passed 3-5-18; Ord. 2019-16. Passed 4-1-19; Ord. 2020-55. Passed
11-2-20.)
608.03 OFFENSES BY EMPLOYEES OF LICENSEES.
   It shall be unlawful for any bartender, agent or employee of a licensee to
commit any of the acts prohibited in Section
608.02.
(Ord. 2018-12. Passed 3-5-18.)
608.04 POSSESSION OR CONSUMPTION IN PUBLIC PLACES.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to carry or possess any alcoholic
beverage, other than in the original package and with the seal unbroken, or to
consume any alcoholic beverage upon any public street in the City, or in or
upon any other public place in the City, except areas which are part of the
licensed premises of an existing licensed establishment pursuant to a sidewalk
cafe or parklet permit utilized in conjunction with
Chapter 806 (Alcoholic Liquor Sales), or the specific premises licensed for a
special event in compliance with the provisions of
Chapter 806 regarding temporary liquor licenses.
(Ord. 2018-12. Passed 3-5-18; Ord. 2019-16. Passed 4-1-19; Ord. 2024-19. Passed
5-6-24.)
608.05 CONSUMPTION ON LICENSED PREMISES.
   (a)   It shall be unlawful for any person to consume any alcoholic liquor on
any licensed premises unless such alcoholic liquor has been purchased from the
licensee or is a product sampling under 235 ILCS 5/6-31 and Section
608.02(i), except as provided for in subsection (b) or (c) below.
   (b)   At the option of a licensee, except holders of a Class TH license,
persons may bring alcoholic liquor onto the licensed premises for the purpose
of consumption on the licensed premises pursuant to the following conditions:
      (1)   Only one bottle of wine or champagne shall be allowed per person
over the age of twenty-one years;
      (2)   Consumption of any alcoholic liquor brought onto the licensed
premises pursuant to this section shall be in conjunction with the purchase and
consumption of a meal on the licensed premises;
      (3)   A corkage fee of no less than ten dollars (US$10.00) shall be
charged per bottle, by the licensee;
      (4)   The licensee shall provide glassware and control service of all
alcoholic liquors. Service of all alcoholic liquors shall be by a BASSETT
trained employee of the licensee; and
      (5)   Partially consumed bottles may be removed from the licensed
premises only in strict accordance with 235 ILCS 5/6-33.
   Nothing contained herein shall be deemed to require any licensee to allow
persons to carry in alcoholic liquor at any time, and no signage shall be
deemed necessary to prohibit such activity.
   (c)   When the premises are validly licensed to a BYOB licensee, persons may
bring alcoholic liquor onto the licensed premises for the purposes of personal
consumption or for the purposes of serving other guests at no charge. Provided,
that no person shall be allowed to consume any alcoholic liquor in such
premises which he or she did not personally bring onto the premises unless
served by a duly-certified BASSETT trained server.
(Ord. 2018-12. Passed 3-5-18; Ord. 2019-16. Passed 4-1-19; Ord. 2020-55. Passed
11-2-20; Ord. 2024-19. Passed 5-6-24.)
608.06 PERMITTED HOURS OF SALES AND OPERATION.
   (a)   For holders of licenses authorizing sales for off premises consumption
only, liquor sales and deliveries are permitted during the hours of 7:00 a.m.
to 1:00 a.m. unless excepted under subsection (b) below. For holders of all
other classes of liquor licenses, liquor sales and deliveries are permitted
during the hours of 7:00 a.m. to 1:00 a.m. on Sunday through Thursday,
inclusive; and between 7:00 a.m. and 2:00 a.m. on Fridays and Saturdays,
inclusive, unless excepted under subsection (b) below.
   (b)   Notwithstanding any of the provisions of this section all license
holders may be open for the retail sale of alcoholic liquors until 2:00 a.m. on
the following special dates, when falling on a Sunday through Thursday in any
given year: New Year's Eve, Superbowl Sunday, Memorial Day Eve, July 4th Eve,
July 4th, Labor Day Eve, Thanksgiving Eve, Christmas Eve or Christmas Day. As
used herein, "eve" shall refer to the calendar day commencing immediately prior
to the referenced holiday and extending to 2:00 a.m. on the referenced holiday.
   (c)   All times specified herein shall be determined in accordance with the
prevailing time under laws of the State.
   (d)   Except for holders of licenses authorizing sales of alcoholic liquor
for off premises consumption only, no licensee shall permit or allow any
person, except those authorized, to remain on or within the licensed premises
before one-half hour prior to permitted hours of sales or after one-half hour
after permitted hours of sales. As used in this section, "authorized persons"
means the licensee, his or her spouse, his or her employees or any independent
contractors summoned to the premises by any of the above for purposes of
rendering construction or repair services to the licensed premises or to any
equipment utilized for the operation of such licensed premises.
   (e)   All displays of liquor in any market which remains open during hours
in which liquor sales are not allowed shall be secured during such hours in
such a manner as to prohibit access to alcoholic liquor by any persons other
than employees of the licensee. If an entire area can not be closed to public
access, displays located in any such area shall be locked or otherwise secured.
   (f)   Holders of BYOB licenses shall not permit any person on the premises
to possess or consume any alcoholic liquor during hours in which alcoholic
liquors may not be sold or delivered by other licensees pursuant to subsections
(a) and (b) of this Section
608.06.
(Ord. 2018-12. Passed 3-5-18; Ord. 2019-16. Passed 4-1-19; Ord. 2020-55. Passed
11-2-20.)
608.07 PURCHASE BY INTOXICATED OR UNDERAGE PERSONS.
   (a)   It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of twenty-one years
to purchase any alcoholic liquor.
   (b)   It shall be unlawful for any intoxicated person to purchase alcoholic
liquor.
   (c)   It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of twenty-one years
to misrepresent his or her age or for any other person to misrepresent the age
of such person who is under the age of twenty-one years for the purpose of
inducing any licensee, agent or employee to sell or give any person under the
age of twenty-one years any alcoholic liquor.
   (d)   Each licensee shall display in a prominent place in the licensed
premises a card or sign warning persons under the age of twenty-one years of
penalties for violations of any of the provisions of this section.
(Ord. 2018-12. Passed 3-5-18; Ord. 2019-16. Passed 4-1-19.)
608.08 UNDERAGE PERSONS ON LICENSED PREMISES.
   It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of twenty-one years to be
in or on any premises licensed to sell alcoholic liquor for on premises
consumption, unless such person is accompanied by his or her parent, legal
guardian or a spouse who is at least twenty-one years of age. Likewise, it
shall be unlawful for any parent or legal guardian to knowingly permit his or
her child or ward under the age of twenty-one years to go upon or into any
licensed premises in violation of the provisions of this section. This section
shall not apply to:
   (a)   The licensed premises of any licensee holding a current and valid R,
LR, M or H license;
   (b)   Any licensed premises being currently served by a holder of a CR
license;
   (c)   Any licensed premises, or portion thereof, being served by the holder
of a duly issued temporary license, if specifically permitted in the issuance
of the temporary license, and as provided for therein;
   (d)   Any portion of the licensed premises of a licensee holding a Class A,
K, or W license, if such portion of the licensed premises is:
      (1)   Clearly delineated as reserved for a private function;
      (2)   Access to such portion of the licensed premises is not accessible
to the general public without invitation;
      (3)   Access to the portion of the licensed premises being utilized for
the private function is actually made only via a separate entrance which does
not require entrance through any area in which alcoholic liquor is being served
to the general public; and
      (4)   Access to the public area of the licensed premises is not made
directly from the area reserved for the private function.
(Ord. 2018-12. Passed 3-5-18.)
608.09 PURCHASE FOR PERSONS UNDER MINIMUM AGE.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to purchase for, offer to purchase for,
sell, offer to sell, dispense or give away any alcoholic liquor to any person
under the age of twenty-one years.
(Ord. 2018-12. Passed 3-5-18.)
608.10 POSSESSION BY PERSON UNDER MINIMUM AGE.
   It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of twenty-one years to
have in his or her possession any alcoholic liquor.
(Ord. 2018-12. Passed 3-5-18.)
608.11 CONSUMPTION BY PERSONS UNDER MINIMUM AGE.
   It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of twenty-one years to
consume any alcoholic liquor.
(Ord. 2018-12. Passed 3-5-18.)
608.12 ACCESS TO PREMISES.
   No licensee licensed under the provisions of
Chapter 806 of these Codified Ordinances shall permit any portion of the
licensed premises to be locked or otherwise prohibit ingress or egress to the
licensed premises at any time persons are on the premises and consuming
alcoholic liquor.
(Ord. 2020-55. Passed 11-2-20.)
608.13 REVOCATION OR SUSPENSION OF LICENSES.
   In addition to the penalty provided in Section
608.99, any license issued to any person under
Chapter 806 of the Business Regulation and Taxation Code may be revoked or
suspended, as provided therein, if such person is convicted of or pleads guilty
to a violation of any of the provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. 2018-12. Passed 3-5-18.)
608.14 ILLEGAL, DISORDERLY ACTIVITIES OR CROWDS ON OR ABOUT PREMISES.
   (a)   No licensee under the provisions of this chapter or
Chapter 806, nor any officer, associate, member, representative, agent or
employee of such licensee shall engage on or about the licensed premises, or
upon any parking lot which is utilized by the licensee to fulfill its parking
requirements, in any activity or conduct or permit any other person to engage
in loitering, unlawful assembly, or any other activity which is prohibited by
any ordinance of the City or law of the State or the United States. Every
licensee under this chapter or
Chapter 806, shall at all times keep a good and orderly house.
   (b)   Fees will be assessed at the rate of one hundred fifty dollars
($150.00) per officer hour, in hourly increments, for any portion thereof, with
a minimum charge of one hour for Police Department responses to a licensed
establishment as a result of disorderly activities on or about the premises,
including, but not limited to crowd and/or traffic control. No fee shall be
assessed if less than two police officers respond to the licensed premises or
adjacent property. No fee shall be assessed for the first qualifying incident
in each calendar year. Nothing in this subsection shall abrogate a licensee's
duty to fully comply with Section
608.15.
   (c)   All such City police responses shall be documented in a Police
Department report by a responding officer and include the reason for police
response to the scene, the time of arrival at and departure from the scene, and
a list of all City Police Department responding officers. Said fees are due and
payable upon written demand from the City Legal Counsel. No liquor license
shall be renewed upon expiration of the same unless all fees assessed pursuant
to this section are paid in full.
(Ord. 2018-12. Passed 3-5-18; Ord. 2019-16. Passed 4-1-19; Ord. 2022-70. Passed
12-5-22.)
608.15 REPORTING OF INCIDENTS TO POLICE; TELEPHONE REQUIRED ON PREMISES.
   Each licensee under this chapter or
Chapter 806 and each of his agents and employees shall promptly report to the
Police Department of the City any incident occurring in, on or about the
licensed premises and in his knowledge or view relating to the commission of
any crime, including any violation of this chapter or
Chapter 806, and shall truthfully and fully answer all questions and
investigations of any identified police officer who makes inquiry concerning
any persons in or about the licensed premises any events taking place in and
about the licensed premises, and cooperate fully in any such investigation
including the giving of any oral or written statements, and any other physical
evidence in their possession or control, including but not limited to:
photographs, videotape, compact disc, and digital video disc depictions of the
events in question, at such reasonable times and in such reasonable locations
to any police officer engaged in said investigation.
(Ord. 2018-12. Passed 3-5-18; Ord. 2025-08. Passed 2-3-25.)
608.16 UNLICENSED DELIVERY.
   No person shall deliver, or knowingly cause to be delivered, any alcoholic
liquor unless such delivery is made in strict accordance with the requirements
set forth in Section
806.19 of these Codified Ordinances.
(Ord. 2019-16. Passed 4-1-19.)
608.17 BYOB PROHIBITED ESTABLISHMENTS.
   (a)   The following establishments are prohibited from allowing the
possession or consumption of alcohol which was not sold on the premises unless
duly licensed pursuant to the provisions of
Chapter 806 pertaining to BYOB establishments:
      (1)   Any establishment which charges a fee for entrance or charges any
rate for use of space within a structure, including, but not limited to,
meeting halls, banquet halls and conference facilities;
      (2)   Any social club or community gathering place, whether operated for
profit or otherwise, where persons bring liquor purchased elsewhere onto the
premises.
   (b)   The provisions of this section shall in no event apply to any property
or establishment owned or leased by:
      (1)   A governmental unit or political subdivision whose boundaries
contain any property within the corporate limits of the City; or
      (2)   Any business entity when conducting meetings held in space normally
occupied by such entity in its day to day operations and furthering the
principal purpose of such entity, so long as no entry fee or room rental is
charged to any person.
      (3)   A church or other religious organization keeping a permanent house
of worship within the corporate limits of the City.
      (4)   Any private individual and occupied by him or her as a primary
residence.
   (c)   In no event shall this section require any person to obtain a license
where alcoholic liquors are brought onto premises solely:
      (1)   Pursuant to a validly issued temporary license issued pursuant to
Chapter 806 of these Codified Ordinances; or
      (2)   By a licensed caterer pursuant to a valid Class CR license issued
pursuant to
Chapter 806 of these Codified Ordinances.
(Ord. 2020-55. Passed 11-2-20.)
608.18 OTHER PROHIBITED ACTIVITIES.
   (a)   No person or entity, other than a licensee, shall allow the service of
alcoholic liquors on any premises owned or operated by said person or entity as
a business except in the case of a validly issued special use permit issued in
compliance with Section
806.03A. Said prohibition shall apply to all service, whether with or without
monetary consideration, and shall apply whether or not liquor is offered as
part of a package. This prohibition shall not apply to gatherings of eight (8)
or less persons where the gathering is not open to the public and service of
liquor is not intended to promote the sale of any goods or services.
   (b)   No person shall give away any alcoholic liquor for commercial purposes
or in connection with the sale of non-alcoholic products or to promote the sale
of non-alcoholic products. This prohibition shall include, but is not limited
to "paint and pour" and "champagne toast" events, and applies to both for-
profit and not-for-profit entities.
(Ord. 2025-08. Passed 2-3-25.)
608.99 PENALTY.
   Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be fined
not more than seven hundred and fifty dollars ($750.00). The levy or payment of
any penalty herein provided for shall not be deemed a waiver of the power of
the Liquor Commission to revoke or suspend any license. Each day any offense
continues shall be deemed a separate offense.
(Ord. 2018-12. Passed 3-5-18.)
  CHAPTER 612
Animals

   CROSS REFERENCES
   Prevention of cruelty to animals - see 65 ILCS 5/11-5-6
   Regulating animals at large - see 65 ILCS 5/11-20-9
   Pounds - see 410 ILCS 40/8, 40/13
