Ch. 869
650.01 ABUSE.
   No person having the care, custody or control of a minor shall willfully
cause or permit the life, health or morals of such minor to be endangered;
willfully cause or permit such minor to be placed in such a situation, business
or occupation where his or her life, health or morals shall be endangered;
willfully or negligently deprive such minor of necessary food, clothing or
shelter; or in any other manner injure such minor.
(1977 Code § 40-101)
650.02 MISUSE.
   No person having the care, custody or control of any minor shall cause or
permit such minor to be exhibited or used for begging or peddling or for any
obscene, indecent or other purpose dangerous to the morals, life or health of
such minor, or cause, procure or encourage any minor to engage therein.
(1977 Code § 40-102)
650.03 LOITERING ABOUT RAILWAYS.
   No minor shall loiter around the depot or yard of any railway, impede,
molest or obstruct the officers or employees engaged in running cars or
locomotives on such railroad, or fail, on request, to immediately leave such
depot or yard.
(1977 Code § 40-103)
650.04 SALE OF CIGARETTES OR TOBACCO TO MINORS.
   (a)   No person shall, directly or indirectly, sell, give, distribute
samples of, furnish or deliver any cigar, cigarette, smokeless tobacco nor any
other tobacco accessory, tobacco products or electronic nicotine delivery
device in any form to any person under twenty-one years of age, or buy the same
for any such person.
   (b)   For the purposes of this section, "tobacco accessory", "tobacco
products", and "electronic nicotine delivery device" shall have the meaning
ascribed to said term in Section
874.02 of these Codified Ordinances.
   (c)   No person, with or without a retail tobacco dealer's license, shall
locate, install, keep, maintain or use, or permit the location, installation,
keeping, maintenance or use of, upon his or her premises, any vending machine,
automatic vending machine, coin-controlled or coin-operating machine or other
mechanical device used or intended to be used for the sale or distribution of
cigarettes or other tobacco products anywhere within the City, except as
follows:
      (1)   Premises where access is limited to members of a bona fide private
club or organization and their guests;
      (2)   That portion of a building or structure which is permitted as a
licensed premises for the sale, at retail, of alcoholic liquor and the
consumption of alcoholic liquor on the licensed premises as provided in
Chapter 806 of these Codified Ordinances; or
      (3)   Premises of a business, factory or other private entity where
access is limited to employees only.
(1977 Code §40-104; Ord. 91-78. Passed 10-21-91; Ord. 91-85. Passed 11-18-91;
Ord. 2019-32. Passed 6-3-19.)
650.05 FALSIFICATION.
   No minor shall make false statements, present or exhibit any fictitious or
false registration card, identification card, note or other document or present
or exhibit a document issued to a person other than the one presenting the
same, for the purpose of gaining admission to a restricted place or for the
purpose of procuring the purchase, gift or delivery of a restricted article.
(1977 Code § 40-105)
650.06 UNLAWFUL UTILIZATION OF SERVICES.
   No minor shall engage or utilize the services of any person, whether for
remuneration or not, to procure for such minor any article which the minor is
forbidden by law to purchase.
(1977 Code § 40-106)
650.07 INDUCEMENT.
   No adult shall request, urge, induce or in any way encourage the violation
of any ordinance by any minor.
(1977 Code § 40-108)
650.08 CURFEW.
   (a)   It shall be unlawful for any person 16 years of age to be present at
or upon any public assembly, building, place, street or highway between 10:00
p.m. and 6:00 a.m. on the following day from Sunday through Thursday and 12:00
a.m. and 6:00 a.m. on the following day on Friday and Saturday.
   (b)   It shall be unlawful for any person 12, 13, 14, 15 years of age to be
present at or upon any public assembly, building, place, street or highway
between 9:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. on the following day from Sunday through
Thursday and 11:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. on the following day on Friday and
Saturday.
   (c)   It is unlawful for any person 11 years of age or under to be present
at or upon any public assembly, building, place, street or highway between 8:00
p.m. and 6:00 a.m. on the following day from Sunday through Thursday and 10:00
p.m. to 6:00 a.m. on the following day on Friday and Saturday.
   (d)   It is a defense to a violation under this chapter that the child
engaged in the prohibited conduct while:
      (1)   Accompanied by the child's parent, legal guardian, custodian,
sibling, or step sibling at least 18 years of age;
      (2)   Accompanied by an adult at least 21 years of age approved by the
child's parent, legal guardian, or custodian.
      (3)   Married or having had the disabilities of minority removed.
      (4)   Participating in, going to, or returning from:
         A.   Employment which the laws of this State authorize a person less
than 17 years of age to perform:
         B.   A school recreational activity;
         C.   A religious event:
         D.   An emergency involving the protection of a person or property
from an imminent threat of serious bodily injury or substantial damage:
         E.   An activity involving the exercise of the child's rights
protected under the First Amendment to the United States Constitution or
Article 1, Sections 3, 4. and 5 of the Constitution of the State of Illinois,
or both:
         F.   An activity conducted by a not for profit community organization
registered with the State or government entity that provides recreation,
education, training, or other care under the supervision of one or more adults.
   A citation for a violation of subsection (a) of this Section may be issued
by a police officer only if he or she reasonably believes that a violation has
occurred, and none of the defenses listed in subsection (d) apply.
   (e)   It shall be unlawful for any custodial parent or guardian of any
unemancipated person under eighteen (18) years of age to allow or permit such
person to violate the provisions of this subsection. The fact that prior to the
present offense a parent, guardian or custodian was informed in writing by a
law enforcement officer of a separate violation of this subsection by the same
minor occurring within ninety (90) days prior to the present offense shall
constitute a rebuttable presumption that such parent, guardian or custodian
allowed or permitted the present violation. In addition to being a violation
hereunder, the parent or legal guardian having custody of a minor subject to
this section shall be liable for any and all costs incurred by the City for
providing personnel to remain in the company of a minor who has been as a
curfew violator if said parent or guardian does not pick up the minor within
one hour after receiving notice from the City that said minor is being detained
for curfew violation.
(1977 Code § 40-109; Ord. 77-90. Passed 12-5-77; Ord. 78-21. Passed 3-6-78;
Ord. 2004-28. Passed 5-17-04; Ord. 2007-34. Passed 5-21-07; Ord. 2008-24.
Passed 5-5-08; Ord. 2013-43. Passed 9-3-13.)
650.09 STATUS AS A MINOR NO DEFENSE.
   A person's status as a minor shall not excuse the violation of any
ordinance, nor shall it be a defense to any charge or proceedings for such
violation, except where the ordinance specifically, or inherently, excepts
minors.
(1977 Code § 40-107)
650.10 TRUANCY PROHIBITED.
   (a)   Generally. No person who is required by law to attend school and who
is subject to the compulsory attendance requirements of the Illinois School
Code and/or who is enrolled in a public, private (including a home school) or
parochial school within the corporate limits of the City, shall absent himself
or herself from attendance at school during the hours in which he or she is
enrolled. Any person who shall so absent himself or herself shall be guilty of
the offense of truancy and shall be subject to the penalties set forth in
Section
650.99(b).
   (b)   Parental Responsibility. It shall be unlawful for any custodian parent
or guardian of any unemancipated person under eighteen (18) years of age to
allow or permit such person to violate the provisions of subsection (a) above.
The fact that prior to the present offense a parent, guardian or custodian was
informed in writing by a law enforcement officer of a separate violation of
subsection (a) by the same minor occurring within ninety (90) days prior to the
present offense shall constitute a rebuttable presumption that such parent,
guardian or custodian allowed or permitted the present violation.
   (c)   Contributing to Truancy. No person eighteen years of age or older
shall knowingly or willfully cause, aid or encourage any person to be or to
become a truant, knowingly or willfully commit an act which directly tends to
render any person a truant, or knowingly or willfully fail to do that which
will directly tend to prevent such state of truancy.
   (d)   Defenses to Truancy. Those defenses, exceptions and valid causes for
absence, as set forth in the Illinois School Code for compulsory attendance or
enrollment in school, shall apply as defenses to violations of this section.
(Ord. 99-52. Passed 9-7-99; Ord. 2013-43. Passed 9-3-13.)
650.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
202.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
   (a)   Whoever violates any of the provisions of Section
650.08 shall be fined not less than ten dollars ($10.00) nor more than one
hundred dollars ($100.00).
(1977 Code § 40-109(b))
   (b)   Whoever violates the provisions of Section
650.10 shall be subject to the following:
      (1)   Whoever violates Section
650.10(a) shall be sentenced to do not less than ten community service hours.
      (2)   Whoever violates Section
650.10(b) shall be sentenced to do not less than ten community service hours
for a first offense, not less than twenty-five community service hours for a
second offense nor more than fifty community service hours for each offense
thereafter, and may be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than
five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense.
      (3)   Whoever violates Section 560.10(c) shall be sentenced to do not
less than ten community service hours for a first offense, not less than
twenty-five community service hours for a second offense nor more than fifty
community service hours for each offense thereafter, and may be fined not less
than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for
each offense.
      (4)   In addition to or in lieu of the penalties set forth in paragraph
(b)(2) hereof, the parent of a truant person may be required to participate in
a parenting program, a list of which available programs will be maintained by
the City.
(Ord. 99-52. Passed 9-7-99.)
CHAPTER 658

   CROSS REFERENCES

658.01 TERRITORIAL JURISDICTION.
   The provisions and regulations for nuisances, whether provided for in this
chapter or elsewhere in these Codified Ordinances, shall be applicable within
the territorial boundaries of the City, as now existing or hereafter changed,
and within one-half mile of such corporate limits as provided by 65 ILCS 5/7-4-
1, as amended.
(1977 Code § 45-107)
658.02 DEFINITIONS.
   Terms used in this chapter shall be defined as provided in Section
1060.01 of the Streets, Utilities and Public Services Code. In addition:
   (a)   "Handbill" means any printed or written matter, sample, device,
dodger, circular, leaflet, pamphlet, paper, booklet or other printed or
otherwise reproduced original or copies of any matter of literature.
   (b)   "Nuisance" means and includes any act, condition or offense, or any
violation of any section of these Codified Ordinances, which is injurious to
safety or health, is indecent or offensive to the senses or morals, or is an
obstruction to the free use of any public property or way.
   (c)   “Tarp” shall be defined as a heavy or closely woven fabric or plastic
material, used with or without tie-downs to hide, cover or protect objects from
view or weather. (Ord. 2017-09. Passed 2-6-17.)
   (d)   “Orchard” shall be defined as a yard or other green space where fruit-
bearing trees or shrubs have been planted in such numbers, rows or quantities
as to completely dominate or obscure the grass yard-space attendant to a
residential dwelling in a R-1 through R-7 zoning jurisdiction.
   (e)   “Vineyard” shall be defined as a yard or other greenspace where grape-
bearing vines have been planted or maintained for harvesting purposes.
(Ord. 2017-35. Passed 4-17-17.)
658.03 PROHIBITED.
   No person shall permit the existence of a nuisance, as herein defined, upon
any premises which he or she owns, occupies or controls.
(1977 Code § 45-109)
658.04 CESSPOOLS AND PRIVIES.
   (a)   No person shall cover, with earth or other material, any privy vault,
cesspool or water closet, without first removing the contents thereof; tap or
drain any privy vault, cesspool or water closet into any other excavation, or
into any opening, except a sanitary sewer; or allow any privy vault, cesspool
or water closet to become filled within two feet of the surface of the ground.
   (b)   No privy shall be erected or continued unless it is finished with a
substantial vault, not less than five feet deep, and walled with brick, stone
or two-inch plank. In case the depth thereof is more than six feet, the walls
of such vault shall be constructed of brick or stone. All privy vaults shall be
so constructed as to be easily cleaned, made tight so that the contents cannot
escape therefrom and be sufficiently secured and closed, and the owner of the
premises on which any privy is situated shall disinfect the same whenever it
shall be necessary.
   (c)   Whenever any person owning, leasing or occupying any premises on which
is situated any privy vault, cesspool or water closet is notified by the Chief
of Police, Community Development Director or the Public Works Director to have
the contents thereof removed, the person so notified shall forthwith comply.
(1977 Code §§ 45-110, 45-111; Ord. 94-97. Passed 11-7-94; Ord. 2013-10. Passed
3-4-13; Ord. 2013-47. Passed 10-7-13.)
658.05 OFFENSIVE PREMISES.
   No person shall own, occupy or keep any cellar, vault, private drain, pool,
privy, stable, pen yard, lot, grounds or premises in such condition as to be
offensive to any person or to become nauseous, foul or injurious to the public
health.
(1977 Code § 45-112)
658.06 ACCUMULATION OR PLACEMENT OF OFFENSIVE SUBSTANCES.
   No person shall permit to accumulate upon his or her premises, place upon
any street or public place or permit to be placed upon the premises of other
persons or upon public ways, by an animal he or she keeps or harbors, any
manure, offal, garbage or any other offensive or noxious substance.
(1977 Code § 45-113; Ord. 77-72. Passed 11-7-77.)
658.07 POLLUTING WATERCOURSES.
   No person shall throw or place any decaying vegetables, garbage, dead
animals or any other filth, refuse or other offensive matter in any
watercourse, or upon the banks thereof.
(1977 Code § 45-114)
658.08 RODENTS.
   (a)   No person shall keep or maintain, on any premises owned or controlled
by him or her, any wood pile, metal pile, junk pile, refuse pile, rotting and
accessible floors or foundations or other structure or collection of material
attractive to, or likely to be used as nesting places for, rats and rodents.
   (b)   All cost of rodent extermination and control shall be assessed against
offending owners of property as provided in 65 ILCS 5/11-20-8, as amended,
which section is incorporated herein by reference.
(1977 Code § 45-115)
658.09 STABLES AND PENS.
   No person shall keep, use or maintain any stable, pen, yard, lot, place or
premises in which any horses, cattle, hogs, fowl or other animals may be
confined or kept in such manner as to be nauseous, foul, offensive, dangerous
or in any way annoying to any person.
(1977 Code § 45-116)
658.10 BARBED WIRE.
   No person shall erect or maintain any barbed wire unless the lowest strand
of such wire is more than six feet above the ground surface. This section shall
not apply to a tract of land of more than two acres legally used for farming or
the keeping of farm animals.
(1977 Code § 45-118)
658.11 INCORPORATION OF STATE STATUTES.
   In addition to all of the provisions of this chapter, all pertinent and
applicable provisions of 740 ILCS 105/0.01 et seq., as amended, are
incorporated herein by reference as to acts or conditions prohibited, and as to
procedures, subject to Section
202.05(b) of the Administration Code.
658.12 ABATEMENT.
   (a)   Court Order. When any person shall have been convicted of erecting,
keeping or maintaining a nuisance, the court before which such conviction is
had may order the defendant forthwith to abate and remove such nuisance within
such time as may be specified by ordinance or by the order of such court.
   (b)   Continuing Offenses. Whoever neglects or refuses to remove or abate a
nuisance within twenty-four hours after the first conviction, or within such
other time as may be specified by ordinance or by order of the court, shall be
fined a like sum for every twenty-four hours, or such other specified time
thereafter, that such nuisance is so continued.
   (c)   Abatement by Police Chief. Whenever any person, upon having been found
guilty of creating, keeping or maintaining a nuisance, shall fail to abate or
remove the same as provided in subsection (a) hereof, or in accordance with the
provisions of any ordinance, the Chief of Police shall proceed forthwith, with
due care and without any unnecessary destruction of property, to remove or
abate such nuisance, to keep an accurate account of all expenses attending such
abatement and to report the same to the City Legal Counsel, which shall bring
suit against such person to recover all such expenses and costs. (Adopting
Ordinance) (Ord. 2017-56. Passed 7-17-17.)
   (d)   Summary Abatement. Nothing contained herein shall prevent the summary
abatement by the Chief of Police, the Community Development Director, the
Building Commissioner or the Public Works Director of any nuisance from which
there is imminent danger to the life, health or limb of any person, without
such conviction.
(Ord. 94-97. Passed 11-7-94; Ord. 2012-24. Passed 4-16-12; Ord. 2013-10. Passed
3-4-13.)
   (e)   Liability for Costs. In addition to the penalty provided in Section
658.99, any person found guilty of keeping, maintaining, permitting or failing
to abate a nuisance shall be compelled to abate such nuisance and shall be
liable for all costs and expenses of such abatement.
658.13 APPLICATION OF PENALTY AND PROCEDURAL PROVISIONS.
   The provisions of this chapter shall be applicable to all nuisances
prohibited in this chapter or in any other section or chapter of these Codified
Ordinances.
(1977 Code §§ 45-101 to 45-106)
658.14 DISTRIBUTION AND PLACEMENT OF HANDBILLS AND NEWSPAPERS.
   (a)   Distribution in General. Any person may hand, without charge to the
receiver, any noncommercial handbill to any person willing to accept it.
   (b)   Placement on Vehicles. No person shall throw, affix or deposit any
handbill in or upon any vehicle, without the express consent of the owner of
such vehicle.
   (c)   Placement on Vacant Premises. No person shall throw or deposit any
handbill or newspaper in or upon any private premises which are continuously
uninhabited or vacant.
   (d)   Placement on Posted Property. No person shall throw, deposit or
distribute any handbill or unsolicited newspaper upon any private premises, if
requested by anyone thereon not to do so or if there is on such premises a sign
bearing the words "No Trespassing," "No Peddlers or Agents," "No Advertisement"
or any similar notice indicating that the occupants desire not to be molested
or have their privacy disturbed.
   (e)   Distribution to Inhabited Private Premises. Handbills may be
distributed to inhabited private premises which are not posted if the same are
so placed or deposited, other than in a mailbox, as to prevent the materials
from being carried by the elements.
   (f)   Newspapers. No newspaper shall be delivered or placed upon sidewalks
or other public property. No newspapers shall be delivered or placed upon
inhabited private property unless placed in a designated receptacle or in such
a manner so as to prevent the contents thereof from being exposed to the
elements. Non-subscribed newspapers shall only be delivered or placed in
designated receptacles or the doorstep of such location.
   (g)   Size. Any handbill permitted to be distributed by this section,
whether commercial or noncommercial, shall not be less than six square inches
nor more than forty-eight square inches in size.
   (h)   Violations. Any non-compliance under this section shall be considered
a violation of this chapter and any individual and any entity in control of
distribution of such materials by the individual may be held jointly and
severally responsible for any violation(s) hereunder.
(Ord. 94-52. Passed 7-18-94; Ord. 2014-11. Passed 3-17-14.)
658.15 POSTING OF NOTICES.
   No person shall post or affix any notice, poster or other paper or device to
any lamppost, public utility pole or shade tree, or upon any public structure
or building, except as may be authorized or required by law.
(Ord. 94-52. Passed 7-18-94.)
658.16 ILLEGAL DUMPING.
   (a)   No person shall throw or cause to be deposited any solid waste, stable
matter or hazardous waste upon or along any public or private street, lane,
alley, creek, culvert or other public or private property within the City.
   (b)   The originator of any solid waste, stable matter or hazardous waste
shall ensure that such is properly stored and collected by an appropriate and
lawful disposer, and shall not throw or cause such to be deposited along any
public or private street, lane, alley, creek, culvert or other public or
private property within the City.
   (c)   In addition to all other penalties and remedies provided for in this
chapter, the City shall have the right to seek and obtain a mandatory
injunction against the responsible party who is in violation of any of the
provisions of this section, enjoining and ordering him or her to remove all
solid waste, stable matter or hazardous waste in compliance with the provisions
of this section.
(Ord. 94-52. Passed 7-18-94.)
658.17   TARPS.
   No person shall utilize tarps that are threadbare, ripped, stained, loose,
damaged or unsightly to hide, cover or protect objects that are visible from a
public right-of-way or alley.
(Ord. 2017-09. Passed 2-6-17.)
658.18   TREE STUMPS AS A NUISANCE.
   Tree stumps shall be considered a nuisance if a quantity greater than three
exist upon a private property and are visible from a public right-of-way. No
person shall permit more than three tree stumps to remain on private property
more than thirty days after tree removal has occurred if said stumps are
visible from a public right-of-way. Tree stump removal shall be to four inches
below ground grade. This section shall apply to tree stumps in existence at the
time of passage. This section does not apply to tree stumps carved with
decorative art work on an elongated stump within sixty days of tree removal.
(Ord. 2017-35. Passed 4-17-17.)
658.19   ORCHARD OR VINEYARD PROHIBITED.
   No person shall cause an orchard or vineyard to be planted or maintained in
the front yard of a residential property. For the purpose of this section, the
side-yard of a corner lot is also considered a front yard. Nothing in this
section shall apply to an orchard or vineyard planted or maintained upon any
school grounds or upon any public property.
(Ord. 2017-35. Passed 4-17-17.)
658.20 OUTDOOR WOOD PILES.
   The stacking or piling of cut wood for use as fuel or otherwise is expressly
prohibited within the City, except in strict accordance with the requirements
of this section.
   (a)   No more than two cords of cut wood shall be stored outdoors on a
single property;
   (b)   Any wood pile shall:
      (1)   Consist of individual cut wood segments no longer than twenty-four
inches in length;
      (2)   Be maintained on a suitable and stable rack no less than six inches
off of the ground;
      (3)   Be covered with a suitable and properly secured tarp or other
covering to prevent water intrusion from the top of the pile; and
      (4)   Shall be no less than ten feet from any residential structure.
   (c)   This section does not apply to:
      (1)   The storage of any other types of cut or uncut wood, timber,
branches, or other woody waste not specifically authorized herein;
      (2)   The indoor storage of cut wood. "Indoor" for purposes of this
section shall mean wholly enclosed within a weatherproof structure properly
permitted to be maintained on the property;
      (3)   The storage of wood ancillary to the otherwise valid operation of a
lumber yard or construction supply business; nor
      (4)   The landfill facility maintained by the City of Freeport at 2133
South Walnut Road.
   (d)   For purposes of this section, a "cord" of wood shall refer to a stack
of wood four feet in width, by four feet in height, and eight feet in length.
(Ord. 2019-71. Passed 12-2-19.)
658.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
202.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
   Any person who violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of
Section
658.16 shall, upon conviction for a first offense, be fined not less than one
hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), and
upon conviction for a second or subsequent offense within a twelve-month
period, shall be fined not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) nor
more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). Each day during which a violation or
noncompliance occurs or continues shall be deemed to be a separate offense.
(Ord. 94-52. Passed 7-18-94.)
CHAPTER 659
Chronic Nuisances
659.01   Abatement of chronic nuisance properties.
659.02   Definitions.
659.03   Remedies; effect of determination.
659.04   Abatement of nuisance. (Repealed).
659.05   Procedure.
659.06   Commencement of action, burden of proof; order.
659.07   Emergency closing procedure. (Repealed).
659.08   Severability; remedies not exclusive.
659.01 ABATEMENT OF CHRONIC NUISANCE PROPERTIES.
   (a)   Any certain property within the City which becomes a chronic nuisance
property is in violation of this chapter and is subject to its remedies.
   (b)   Any owner who permits property under his or her ownership or control
to be a chronic nuisance property shall be in violation of this chapter and
subject to its remedies.
(Ord. 2005-66. Passed 12-5-05; Ord. 2020-44. Passed 9-8-20.)
659.02 DEFINITIONS.
   The following words and terms, for purposes of this chapter, shall have the
meanings herein provided:
   (a)   "Chronic nuisance property" means a property upon which three or more
of the behaviors listed below have occurred during any six-month period, as a
result of any three separate factual events that have been independently
investigated by any law enforcement agency, or in the case of ordinance
violations, independently investigated by the Community Development Director or
his or her designee.
      (1)   Disorderly conduct as defined in 720 ILCS 5/26-1.
      (2)   Unlawful use of weapons as defined in 720 ILCS 5/24-1 et seq.
      (3)   Mob action as defined in 720 ILCS 5/25-1.
      (4)   Discharge of a firearm as defined in 720 ILCS 5/24-1.2 and 1.5.
      (5)   Gambling as defined in 720 ILCS 5/28-1.
      (6)   Possession, manufacture or delivery of controlled substance as
defined in 720 ILCS 570/401 et seq.
      (7)   Assault or battery or any related offense as defined in 720 ILCS 5/
12-1 et seq.
      (8)   Sexual abuse or related offenses as defined in 720 ILCS 5/12-15 et
seq.
      (9)   Public indecency as defined in 720 ILCS 5/11-9 et seq.
      (10)   Prostitution as defined in 720 ILCS 5/11-14 et seq.
      (11)   Criminal damage to property as defined in 720 ILCS 5/21-1 et seq.
      (12)   Illegal possession, use, cultivation, manufacture, sale or
delivery of cannabis as defined in the Cannabis Control Act 720 ILCS 550/1 et
seq. and the Cannabis Regulation and Tax Act, 410 ILCS 701/1 et seq.
      (13)   Illegal consumption or possession of alcohol as defined in 235
ILCS 5/1 et seq.
      (14)   Violation of any provision of Part Fourteen (Building and Housing
Code) or Part Sixteen (Fire Prevention Code) of these Codified Ordinances.
      (15)   Violation of any City ordinance or State of Illinois statute
controlling or regulating the sale or use of alcoholic beverages.
      (16)   Violation of any provision of Part Six of the Codified Ordinances
(General Offenses Code) related to the use or condition of the property at
issue or where the violation occurred on the property.
      (17)   Violation of any provision of
Chapter 1040 (Utilities Generally),
Chapter 1042 (Water Generally),
Chapter 1046 (Sewers Generally), or
Chapter 1050 (Storm Sewers) of Title Four of Part Ten (Utilities) of the
Codified Ordinances.
      (18)   Violation of any provision of
Chapter 1060 (Garbage and Rubbish Collection and Disposal) or
Chapter 1068 (Forestry) of Title Six of Part Ten (Other Public Services) of the
Codified Ordinances.
      (19)   Violation of any provision of Title Four of Part Twelve (Zoning)
of the Codified Ordinances.
   (b)   "Control" means the ability to regulate, restrain, dominate,
counteract or govern conduct that occurs on that property.
   (c)   "Director" shall mean the Community Development Director, or his or
her designee specifically appointed for purposes of nuisance abatement.
   (d)   "Nuisance activity" means any of the actions specified in subsection
(a)(1) through (19) hereof.
   (e)   "Owner" means any person, agent, firm, corporation, limited liability
company, or other legal entity having any legal or equitable interest in the
property. Owner includes, but is not limited to:
      (1)   The legal owner of record of the property;
      (2)   A mortgagee in possession in whom is vested:
         A.   All or part of the legal title to the property; or
         B.   All or part of the beneficial ownership and the right to the
present use and enjoyment of the premises;
      (3)   An occupant who can control what occurs on the property, excluding
tenants who are occupying the property pursuant to a lease, whether written or
verbal.
      For purposes of this chapter, the presumptive owner of a property shall
be the person in whose name property taxes are assessed, as it appears in the
records of the County Assessor. The address of the owner shall be presumed to
be the address of the owner listed in the records of the County Assessor for
the property at issue.
   (f)   "Permit" means to suffer, allow, consent to, acquiesce by failure to
prevent, or expressly assent or agree to the doing of an act.
   (g)   "Person" means any natural person, association, partnership or
corporation capable of owning or using property in the City.
   (h)   "Property" means any real property, including land in that which is
affixed, incidental or pertinent to land, including but not limited to any
premises, room, house, building, or structure or any separate part or portion
thereof, whether permitted or not.
(Ord. 2005-66. Passed 12-5-05; Ord. 2007-78. Passed 11-19-07; Ord. 2012-24.
Passed 4-16-12; Ord. 2018-52. Passed 11-5-18; Ord. 2019-57. Passed 11-18-19;
Ord. 2020-44. Passed 9-8-20.)
659.03 REMEDIES; EFFECT OF DETERMINATION.
   (a)   In the event a property is determined to be a chronic nuisance
property through an administrative order entered under this chapter, the
property shall be thereafter deemed a nuisance as said term is used in all
other sections of this Code. In addition to remedies provided for nuisances
generally within these Codified Ordinances, the following remedies shall be
specifically available to the City after the determination a property is a
chronic nuisance pursuant to this chapter, without further action:
      (1)   The City may elect to mitigate any nuisances existing upon the
property, whether or not such conditions gave rise to the determination of a
chronic nuisance. In proceeding with mitigation, City personnel or their agents
may enter onto any portion of the property not occupied as a residence, without
notice at any time and conduct such activities as are reasonably necessary to
correct a nuisance. Such activities may include, but are not limited to,
mowing, removing trash or garbage, removing inoperable vehicles, or demolishing
accessory structures.
      (2)   In the event the property is occupied by a person other than the
owner of record of the property, the City may order the property closed and
secured against all use for a period of up to 180 days. If the City elects such
a remedy, the City shall notify all parties entitled to notice under Section
659.06, in the manner provided in that section, no less than 30 days prior to
securing the property.
      (3)   Any such other and further remedies deemed appropriate by the
Hearing Officer, within his or her discretion, as specifically reflected in the
order. Provided, that if any injunctive relief is sought or awarded, personal
service of the notice required in Section
659.05(b) shall be required, and personal service shall be made of any written
order directing any person to take a particular action or refrain from any
particular activity.
   (b)   In addition to the remedies provided in subsection (a) hereof, there
shall be imposed upon the owner of the property a civil penalty in the amount
of one hundred dollars ($100.00) per day, payable to the City, for each day a
property is permitted to remain a chronic nuisance property. The fines imposed
hereby shall accrue commencing on the date of entry of an order declaring a
property a chronic nuisance property pursuant to Section
659.06 through such date as the Director determines that the conditions giving
rise to the finding of a chronic nuisance have been abated or repaired. If the
Director does not make such a finding upon request of the owner, the owner may
appeal the decision of the Director by filing a request for appeal with the
Director at any time. Upon receipt of an appeal, the Director shall set the
matter for hearing before the Hearing Officer at the next available hearing
date for the administrative court which occurs not less than seven calendar
days after the date the appeal is received.
   (c)   Any amounts expended by the City to mitigate any conditions or secure
a property under subsection (a) hereof, and all fines accrued pursuant to
subsection (b) hereof, shall be assessed against the owner as a part of the
judgment amount, and shall further constitute a lien against the property until
paid. The City may file a notice of lien against the property for any such
costs and fees, and shall provide a copy thereof to the owner within three
business days of filing any such lien.
(Ord. 2005-66. Passed 12-5-05; Ord. 2020-44. Passed 9-8-20.)
659.04 ABATEMENT OF NUISANCE (REPEALED).
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: Section 659.04 was repealed by Ordinance 2020-44, passed
September 8, 2020.)
659.05 PROCEDURE.
   When the Director receives two or more police reports or ordinance violation
reports documenting the occurrence of nuisance activity on or within a
property, the Director shall independently review such reports to determine
whether they describe acts in violation of this chapter. Upon such findings,
the Director may:
   (a)   Notify the owner, in writing, that the property is in danger of being
declared a chronic nuisance. The notice shall contain, at a minimum, the
following information:
      (1)   The street address or a legal description sufficient for
identification of the property.
      (2)   A statement that the Director has information that the property may
be chronic nuisance property, with a concise description of the nuisance
activities that have been documented. The Director shall offer the owner an
opportunity to propose a course of action that the Director agrees will abate
the nuisance activities giving rise to the violation.
      (3)   A concise list of remedies and penalties available to the City
should the property be declared a chronic nuisance property.
   (b)   After complying with the notification procedures described in
subsection (a), when the Director receives a police report or an ordinance
violation report documenting the occurrence of a subsequent nuisance activity
at or within a property during any six-month period and determines that the
property has become a chronic nuisance property, the Director shall:
      (1)   Notify the owner in writing that the property has been determined
to be a chronic nuisance property. The notice shall contain, at a minimum, the
following information:
         A.   The street address or legal description sufficient for
identification of the property.
         B.   A statement that the Director has determined the property to be
chronic nuisance property with a concise description of the nuisance activities
leading to his or her findings.
         C.   Demand that the owner respond within ten days to the Director and
propose a course of action that the Director agrees will abate the nuisance
activities giving rise to the violation.
         D.   Service shall be made either personally or by certified mail,
postage pre-paid, return receipt requested, addressed to the owner at the
address of the property believed to be a chronic nuisance property, or such
other place which is likely to give the owner notice of the determination by
the Director.
         E.   A copy of the notice shall also be served on the owner at such
address as shown on the rolls of the Stephenson County Assessor, and/or the
occupant, if known, at the address of the property, if the occupant is not the
owner, and shall be made either personally or by first class mail, postage pre-
paid.
         F.   A copy of the notice shall also be posted at the property after
ten days has elapsed from the service or mailing of the notice if the owner has
not contacted the Director in accordance with subsection C. hereof.
         G.   The failure of any person to receive notice that the property may
be a chronic nuisance property shall not invalidate or otherwise affect the
proceedings under this chapter, so long as notice has been mailed to the
persons specified and in the manner set forth in this section,
      (2)   If prior to a determination that a property is a chronic nuisance
pursuant to this chapter, the owner stipulates in writing with the Director
that the owner will pursue a course of action the parties agree will abate the
nuisance activities giving rise to the violations, the Director may agree to
delay or continue proceedings for not more than 30 days. If the agreed course
of action does not result in the abatement of the nuisance activity within said
30-day period, the Director shall proceed with the administrative adjudication
process.
   (c)   When an owner makes a response to the Director as required above, any
conduct or statements made in connection with the furnishing of that response
shall not constitute an admission that any nuisance activities have or are
occurring. This subsection does not require the exclusion of any evidence which
is otherwise admissible or offered for any other purpose.
(Ord. 2005-66. Passed 12-5-05; Ord. 2012-24. Passed 4-16-12; Ord. 2017-56.
Passed 7-17-17; Ord. 2020-44. Passed 9-8-20.)
659.06 COMMENCEMENT OF ACTION, BURDEN OF PROOF.
   After the City has complied with the notice and procedures in Section
659.05, if the Director believes the conditions giving rise to the violations
have not been adequately remedied, the Director may institute an action through
the administrative adjudication process set forth in
Chapter 299 of these Codified Ordinances requesting a finding that the property
constitutes a chronic nuisance property. Notice of any scheduled hearing shall
be provided to the same persons, and in the same manner, as required of the
notice required by Section
659.05 hereof.
   (a)   In an action seeking a finding that a property is a chronic nuisance
property, the City shall have the initial burden of showing by preponderance of
the evidence that the property is a chronic nuisance property. Provided, there
shall be a rebuttable presumption that a property is a chronic nuisance
property if three or more violations of any of the provisions of State statute
or these Codified Ordinances set forth in Section
659.02 have been determined to exist on three distinct occasions through a
determination of the City’s Administrative Hearing Officer or by a court of
competent jurisdiction.
   (b)   It is a defense to an action seeking a finding that a property is a
chronic nuisance property that the conditions giving rise to the violations
forming the basis for the Director’s decision have been remedied prior to a
hearing on a determination of chronic nuisance.
   (c)    If, after hearing, the Hearing Officer determines that a property is
a chronic nuisance property as defined in this chapter exists, he or she shall
enter a written order, stating the basis for the finding. A copy of said order
shall be provided to any persons present at the hearing, and shall be mailed
within three business days to any other persons entitled to notice of the
hearing.
   (d)   If the Director specifically so requests in the charging documents,
the Hearing Officer may also make a determination that any structure on the
property is a dangerous and unsafe building as defined in
Chapter 1456 of these Codified Ordinances and/or within the meaning of 65 ILCS
5/11-31-1. Any such finding shall be included in the written order required by
subsection (c) above. The failure of the Hearing Officer to make such a finding
shall not preclude the Building Commissioner from proceeding in any manner
otherwise available under
Chapter 1456, in his or her discretion, but a finding by the Hearing Officer in
accordance with this section shall create a presumption that the decision of
the Building Commissioner to declare a building dangerous and unsafe pursuant
to
Chapter 1456 or 65 ILCS 5/11-31-1 is valid.
(Ord. 2020-44. Passed 9-8-20.)
659.07 EMERGENCY CLOSING PROCEDURE (REPEALED).
   (EDITOR’S NOTE: Section 659.07 was repealed by Ordinance 2020-44, passed
September 8, 2020)
659.08 SEVERABILITY; REMEDIES NOT EXCLUSIVE.
   (a)   If any provision of this chapter or its application, or any person or
circumstance are held to be invalid for any reason, the remainder of said
application of its provisions to the other persons or circumstances shall not
be in any way affected.
   (b)   The remedies provided under this chapter shall be in addition to, and
not exclusive of, all other remedies otherwise available to the City of
Freeport. Nothing contained herein shall be deemed to require the City to avail
itself of any remedies or procedures set forth herein as a prerequisite to
initiating any other action, and shall not preclude the City from seeking
relief in any State or Federal court, for any violation of the Codified
Ordinances.
(Ord. 2005-66. Passed 12-5-05; Ord. 2020-44. Passed 9-8-20.)
CHAPTER 660
Additional Hazardous Materials
660.01   Purpose.
660.02   Definitions.
660.03   Discharge of hazardous materials.
660.04   Discharge of hazardous materials; liability for abatement.
660.05   Prohibition.
660.06   Disposal of hazardous materials.
660.07   Unlawful disposal; liability for abatement.
660.08   Hazardous material storage tanks; registration; required testing;
permits and fees.
660.99   Penalty.
660.01 PURPOSE.
   The purpose of this Chapter is to promulgate rules and regulations for the
use, storage, manufacturing and clean up of hazardous materials within the City
of Freeport.
(Ord. 2003-74. Passed 10-20-03.)
660.02 DEFINITIONS.
   (a)   Definitions. The following words and phrases shall have the meaning
ascribed to them hereafter.
      (1)   Hazardous materials. As used herein, the term "hazardous materials"
shall mean a substance or material in the quantity and form which has been
determined by the United States Department of Transportation to be capable of
posing an unreasonable risk to health and safety or property.
      (2)   Person. Any natural person or individual, governmental body, firm,
association, partnership, co-partnership, joint venture, company, corporation
joint stock company, trust, estate, or any other legal entity or their
representative, agent or assigns.
      (3)   Toxic substance. Any substance, mixture, or compound containing a
substance which is listed in:
         A.   The Code of Federal Regulations, 29 C.F.R. 1910.1000 through 29
C.F.R. 1910.1500 inclusive.
         B.   A list of toxic substances promulgated by the Illinois
Environmental Agency pursuant to Illinois Compiled Statutes, Chapter 415, Act
85, Section 4.
         C.   The United States Department of Health and Human Services, Public
Health Service National Toxicology Program, Second Annual Report on
Carcinogens-December, 1981 and its periodic updates.
         D.   A list of toxic substances promulgated by the Director of the
Illinois Department of Labor pursuant to Illinois Compiled Statutes, Chapter
820, Act 255, Section 4.
   (b)   All other definitions, not contained herein, shall be as defined in
the Hazardous Material Emergency Response Reimbursement Act.
(Ord. 2003-74. Passed 10-20-03.)
660.03 DISCHARGE OF HAZARDOUS MATERIALS.
   The actual or threatened discharge of hazardous materials within the City of
Freeport is hereby declared a nuisance.
(Ord. 2003-74. Passed 10-20-03.)
660.04 DISCHARGE OF HAZARDOUS MATERIALS; LIABILITY FOR ABATEMENT.
   Where the City is eligible to seek reimbursement as permitted by law, mutual
aid agreement, or declared emergency, the following rates shall be utilized to
determine the expenses incurred by the City:
Team Member (Hazardous Materials (“HM” or Technical Rescue Team “TRT”) Hourly
Rates of Pay:
Awareness Fire Fighter/    $30.00/hour
Paramedic
Operations Certified       $50.00/hour
Technician Certified       $75.00/hour
Command Staff              $100.00/hour
Vehicle & Equipment Hourly Reimbursement Rates:
Specialty Trailers (HM &   $300.00/hour
TRT)
Command Vehicle            $30.00/hour
Fire Engine                $100.00/hour
Ladder Aerial Platform     $200.00/hour
Ambulance                  $50.00/hour
Support Trailers and Light $150.00/hour
Tower
 
   In addition, the City shall also be reimbursed for the costs of all
materials used and equipment repairs which may be required as a result of the
City preventing, cleaning up, or disposing of or attempting to prevent, clean
up, or dispose of any such discharge or threatened discharge.
(Ord. 2003-74. Passed 10-20-03; Ord. 2020-39. Passed 8-3-20.)
660.05 PROHIBITION.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to dispose of hazardous materials within
the limits of the City of Freeport, unless such disposal is conducted in
accordance with applicable state and federal rules and regulations pertaining
to the disposal of such materials.
(Ord. 2003-74. Passed 10-20-03.)
660.06 DISPOSAL OF HAZARDOUS MATERIALS.
   The unlawful disposal of hazardous materials within the City of Freeport is
hereby declared a nuisance.
(Ord. 2003-74. Passed 10-20-03.)
660.07 UNLAWFUL DISPOSAL; LIABILITY FOR ABATEMENT.
   Any person who engages in the unlawful disposal of hazardous materials shall
be liable to the City of Freeport for any and all expenses incurred by the city
in connection with cleaning up and lawfully disposing of said materials.
   Where the City is eligible to seek reimbursement as permitted by law, mutual
aid agreement, or declared emergency, the following rates shall be utilized to
determine the expenses incurred by the City:
Team Member (Hazardous Materials (“HM” or Technical Rescue Team “TRT”) Hourly
Rates of Pay:
Awareness Fire Fighter/    $30.00/hour
Paramedic
Operations Certified       $50.00/hour
Technician Certified       $75.00/hour
Command Staff              $100.00/hour
Vehicle & Equipment Hourly Reimbursement Rates:
Specialty Trailers (HM &   $300.00/hour
TRT)
Command Vehicle            $30.00/hour
Fire Engine                $100.00/hour
Ladder Aerial Platform     $200.00/hour
Ambulance                  $50.00/hour
Support Trailers and Light $150.00/hour
Tower
 
   In addition, the City shall also be reimbursed for the costs of all
materials used and equipment repairs which may be required as a result of the
City cleaning up and lawfully disposing of hazardous materials.
(Ord. 2003-74. Passed 10-20-03; Ord. 2020-39. Passed 8-3-20.)
660.08   HAZARDOUS MATERIAL STORAGE TANKS; REGISTRATION; REQUIRED TESTING;
PERMITS AND FEES.
   (a)   The owners of all underground and aboveground hazardous material
storage tanks shall register them with the City Fire Department Inspection
Bureau. All storage tanks will be registered within twelve months from the
effective date of this section. If registered within such timeframe, the fee
for registration shall be waived. After that timeframe, the fee for registering
new and existing storage tanks will be one hundred dollars ($100.00) each. A
fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) will also be charged for a permit for the
removal of each storage tank. Anyone not registering all tanks during the
twelve-month period will be fined the maximum general penalty allowable, in
addition to any applicable fee.
   (b)   All aboveground and underground storage tanks shall be removed not
more than 120 days after abandonment.
   (c)   The storage of hazardous waste or hazardous material in fifty-five
gallon drums in nonapproved storage areas is strictly prohibited.
   (d)   Aboveground containers, cylinders and tanks that contain hazardous
waste or have previously contained hazardous material shall be disposed of
immediately in accordance with EPA 40 CFR part 260 listed in chapter 44, or
other regulating authority, or maintained as indicated for the storage of the
hazardous materials.
(Ord. 2009-60. Passed 9-8-09.)
660.99 PENALTY.
   In addition to the liability imposed by the preceding section, any person
who unlawfully disposes of hazardous materials within the City of Freeport
shall, upon conviction, be subject to a fine of no less than five hundred
dollars ($500.00) and no more than five hundred dollars ($500.00).
(Ord. 2003-74. Passed 10-20-03.)
CHAPTER 662
Offenses Relating to Persons
662.01   Violation of Illinois Criminal Code.
662.02   Assault.
662.03   Interfering with liberties and rights of others.
662.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Assault and battery - see 720 ILCS 5/12-1 et seq.
   Petty offenses - see 730 ILCS 5/5-5-3
   Fair housing and human relations - see ADM.
Ch. 270
   Use of offensive products upon persons - see GEN. OFF.
670.07
   Injury to persons in bowling and billiard establishments - see B.R. & T.
812.04
662.01 VIOLATION OF ILLINOIS CRIMINAL CODE.
   No person shall commit any act prohibited by the Illinois Criminal Code of
1961, as heretofore and hereafter amended.
(1977 Code § 46-129)
662.02 ASSAULT.
   (a)   No person shall assault or confine another with malice or with intent
to commit a felony or bodily injury where no considerable provocation appears,
nor be guilty of an affray, challenge or offer to fight another person.
   (b)   A person commits an assault when, without lawful authority, he or she
engages in conduct which places another in reasonable apprehension of receiving
a battery.
   (c)   A person commits battery if he or she intentionally or knowingly,
without legal justification and by any means, causes bodily harm to an
individual or make physical contact of an insulting or provoking nature with an
individual.
(1977 Code §§ 46-101, 46-101.1, 46-101.2; Ord. 86-19. Passed 4-7-86.)
662.03 INTERFERING WITH LIBERTIES AND RIGHTS OF OTHERS.
   No person shall interfere with the liberties and rights of others. A person
commits the offense of interfering with the liberties and rights of others if
he or she places himself or herself in a public way, park or shopping area and
harasses, blocks the passage of or intimidates others and is not conducting a
political, religious or civil demonstration or activity.
(1977 Code § 46-142; Ord. 77-73. Passed 11-21-77.)
662.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
202.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
CHAPTER 664
Offenses Relating to Property
664.01   Criminal trespass.
664.02   Tampering with utilities.
664.03   Tampering with or damaging public or private property.
664.04   Possession of tools used for burglary.
664.05   Interfering with radio and television broadcasts.
664.06   Sale of equipment which may interfere with radio and television
broadcasts.
664.07   Unauthorized possession or use of license plates and tags.
664.08   Misuse of hoses or hydrants.
664.09   Tampering with signal boxes and alarm systems.
664.10   Fallen structures and vegetation.
664.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Property damage - see 720 ILCS 5/21-1
   Criminal trespass - see 720 ILCS 5/21-1 et seq.
   Use of offensive products upon property - see GEN. OFF.
670.07
   Damaging private property by building movers - see B.R. & T.
814.07
   Damaging or removing barricades and warning lights - see S.U. & P.S.
1024.16
   Destruction of Library property - see S.U. & P.S.
1072.08
664.01 CRIMINAL TRESPASS.
   (a)   No person shall enter upon the land or any part thereof of another,
after receiving, immediately prior to such entry, notice from the owner or
occupant that such entry is forbidden, or remain upon the land or part thereof
of another after receiving notice from the owner or the occupant to depart.
   (b)   A person has received notice from the owner or occupant within the
meaning of subsection (a) hereof if he or she has been notified personally,
either orally or in writing, or if printed or written notice forbidding such
entry has been conspicuously posted or exhibited at the main entrance of such
land or the forbidden part thereof.
   (c)   For the purposes of this section, the terms "owner or occupant" shall
include any law enforcement officer whose department has received written
authorization from the owner or lessee to communicate an order to depart the
property in the case of a threat to public safety or welfare.
(1977 Code § 46-148; Ord. 86-18. Passed 4-7-86; Ord. 2006-31. Passed 6-5-06.)
664.02 TAMPERING WITH UTILITIES.
   No person shall alter, change or tamper with any utility or service pipe,
line, wire or meter, or with the register or apparatus thereof, so that such
meter does not correctly show or register the amount of service or so that any
service may be obtained without proper payment therefor.
(1977 Code § 46-126)
664.03 TAMPERING WITH OR DAMAGING PUBLIC OR PRIVATE PROPERTY.
   No person shall willfully or negligently break, deface, destroy, remove or
otherwise damage, injure, tamper with or impair the usefulness of any public or
private property.
(1977 Code § 46-116)
664.04 POSSESSION OF TOOLS USED FOR BURGLARY.
   No person shall have in his or her possession any nippers of the description
known as burglar's nippers, picklocks, skeleton keys, bit keys, bits, jimmies
or any other burglar's instrument, unless it can be shown that such possession
is innocent or for a lawful purpose.
(1977 Code § 46-102)
664.05 INTERFERING WITH RADIO AND TELEVISION BROADCASTS.
   No person shall operate, or cause to be operated, any device, appliance,
equipment or apparatus which creates or causes electrical high frequency
oscillations which interfere with the reception of radio or television
broadcast signals. However, X-ray pictures, examinations or treatments and
diathermy treatments may be made or given, as the case may be, if machines or
apparatus used therefor are equipped to avoid all unnecessary or reasonably
preventable interference and are not negligently operated.
(1977 Code § 46-118)
664.06 SALE OF EQUIPMENT WHICH MAY INTERFERE WITH RADIO AND TELEVISION
BROADCASTS.
   No person shall sell or offer any equipment, appliance, device or apparatus
which will cause interference with radio or television broadcast signals unless
the same is equipped with a suitable device which will reasonably prevent such
interference.
(1977 Code § 46-119)
664.07 UNAUTHORIZED POSSESSION OR USE OF LICENSE PLATES AND TAGS.
   No person shall, without the consent of the owner or licensee, take, carry
away, detach or mutilate any metal plate, tag, badge or license worn by, or
attached to, any person, animal, vehicle, article, substance or thing
whatsoever, used as a mark of identification or otherwise in compliance with
any statute or ordinance.
(1977 Code § 46-113)
664.08 MISUSE OF HOSES OR HYDRANTS.
   No person, not being the owner or occupant thereof or otherwise authorized,
shall willfully turn a stream of water from any hose or hydrant upon any person
or premises.
(1977 Code § 46-109)
664.09 TAMPERING WITH SIGNAL BOXES AND ALARM SYSTEMS.
   No person, other than a member of the Fire Department, shall open any signal
box, except to give a fire alarm with cause and reason. No person, other than a
member of the Fire Department, shall break, cut, injure, deface, derange or in
any manner meddle or interfere with any signal box, key box, fire alarm wire or
other alarm apparatus or equipment.
(1977 Code § 26-204)
664.10   FALLEN STRUCTURES AND VEGETATION.
   (a)   No person shall allow any structure or vegetation which has fallen
from property owned by him or her onto an adjacent property to remain on said
adjacent property for a period in excess of 48 hours, unless removal is delayed
for good cause shown. The burden shall be on the landowner to prove good cause
through the exercise of reasonable diligence.
   (b)   No person shall allow any structure or vegetation which has fallen
from property owned by him or her onto an adjacent property to remain on said
adjacent property for a period in excess of seven days for any reason.
   (c)   No person shall allow any structure or vegetation which has fallen or
is otherwise no longer independently self-supporting to remain on any property
owned by him or her for a period in excess of 30 days for any reason.
(Ord. 2021-30. Passed 8-2-21.)
664.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
202.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
CHAPTER 670
Peace Disturbances
670.01   Disorderly conduct.
670.02   Unlawful assemblages.
670.03   Disturbing religious assemblies.
670.04   False alarms.
670.05   Noise.
670.06   Loitering and obstructing or interfering with public access or
business.
670.07   Use of offensive products upon persons or property.
670.08   Abuse of emergency 911 telephone system.
670.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Prevention of disorderly conduct - see 65 ILCS 5/11-5-2, 5/11-5-3
   Breach of the peace - see 725 ILCS 135/1
   Noise by animals - see GEN. OFF.
612.07
   Disturbances in bowling and billiard establishments - see B.R. & T.
812.04
   Noise from sound advertising - see B.R. & T.
866.05
670.01 DISORDERLY CONDUCT.
   No person shall commit disorderly conduct. A person commits disorderly
conduct when he or she knowingly:
   (a)   Does any act in such unreasonable manner as to provoke, make or aid in
making a breach of the peace;
   (b)   Does or makes any unreasonable or offensive act, utterance, gesture or
display which, under the circumstances, creates a clear and present danger of a
breach of the peace or an imminent threat of violence;
   (c)   Refuses or fails to cease and desist any peaceful conduct or activity
likely to produce a breach of the peace where there is an imminent threat of
violence, and where the police have made all reasonable efforts to protect the
otherwise peaceful conduct and activity, have requested that such conduct and
activity be stopped and have explained the request if there is time;
   (d)   Fails to obey a lawful order of dispersal by a person known by him or
her to be a peace officer under circumstances where three or more persons are
committing acts of disorderly conduct in the immediate vicinity, which acts are
likely to cause substantial harm or serious inconvenience, annoyance or alarm;
   (e)   Assembles with three or more persons for the purpose of using force or
violence to disturb the peace; or
   (f)   Appears in any public place manifestly under the influence of alcohol,
narcotics or other drug, not therapeutically administered, to the degree that
he or she may endanger himself or herself or other persons or property, or
annoy persons in his or her vicinity.
(Ord. 93-24. Passed 4-19-93.)
670.02 UNLAWFUL ASSEMBLAGES.
   No person shall assemble on public or private property with intent to do an
unlawful act or, being assembled, mutually agree or act in concert to do an
unlawful act, with force or violence, against the person or property of another
or against the peace, or make any movement or preparation therefor. Every
person present at such meeting or assembly shall endeavor to prevent the
commission or preparation of such unlawful act.
(1977 Code § 46-124)
670.03 DISTURBING RELIGIOUS ASSEMBLIES.
   No person shall disturb any congregation or assembly for religious worship
by making a noise, by rude or indecent behavior or by profane discourse, within
the place of worship, or so near thereto as to disturb the order or solemnity
of the meeting.
(1977 Code § 46-120)
670.04 FALSE ALARMS.
   No person shall give, transmit or turn in an alarm of fire, by any means
whatsoever, when there is no reasonable ground to fear the existence of a fire.
(1977 Code § 26-206)
670.05 NOISE.
   (a)   Application. The provisions of this section shall apply to all
business, commerce and activities for profit within the City and within the
distance of one mile beyond the City limits, as provided by 65 ILCS 5/11-42-9,
as amended, and to all other activities within the City and within the distance
of one-half mile beyond the City limits, as provided by 65 ILCS 5/7-4-1, as
amended.
   (b)   General Prohibitions. No person shall make, continue or cause to be
made or continued any loud, unnecessary or unusual noise, or any noise which
either annoys, disturbs, injures or endangers the comfort, repose, health,
peace or safety of others, or own or be in possession or control of any
building or premises used in such a manner or permit the use of the same in
such a manner. It shall be the joint and several responsibility of the legal
owner and occupant of the property to ensure that no such violation occurs. It
shall be an affirmative defense to prosecution under this subsection that the
legal owner of a property produces a legally binding document showing another
to be in possession or control of such property at the time of the offense.
   (c)   Specifically Prohibited Acts. The following acts, among others, are
declared to be loud, disturbing and unnecessary noises in violation of this
section, but such enumeration shall not be deemed to be exclusive:
      (1)   Horns and signaling devices. The sounding of any horn or signaling
device on any vehicle, except as a danger warning; the creation, by means of
any such signaling device, of any unreasonably loud or harsh sound; the
sounding of any such device for an unnecessary and unreasonable period of time;
the use of any signaling device except one operated by hand or electricity; the
use of any horn, whistle or other device operated by engine exhaust; and the
use of any such signaling device when traffic is for any reason held up.
      (2)   Musical and sound instruments. The using, operating or permitting
to be played, used or operated of any radio, television set, tape recorder,
musical instrument, phonograph or other machine or device for the producing or
reproducing of sound in such manner as to disturb the peace, quiet and comfort
of the neighboring inhabitants or at any time with louder volume than is
necessary for convenient hearing for the persons who are in the room, yard or
vehicle in which such machine or device is operated and who are voluntary
listeners thereto.
      (3)   Advertising. The using, operating or permitting to be played, used
or operated of any radio, musical instrument, phonograph, loudspeaker, sound
amplifier or other machine or device for the producing or reproducing of sound
which is cast upon the public streets for the purposes of commercial
advertising or attracting the attention of the public to any event or building,
except licensed sound trucks.
      (4)   Yelling, shouting and singing. Yelling, shouting, hooting,
whistling or singing on the public streets, particularly between the hours of
11:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. of the following day, or at any time or place so as to
annoy or disturb the quiet, comfort or repose of persons in any office,
dwelling, hotel or other type of residence, or of any persons in the vicinity.
      (5)   Animals and birds. The keeping of any animal or bird which, by
causing frequent or long continued noise, shall disturb the comfort or repose
of any persons in the vicinity.
      (6)   Steam whistles. The blowing of any locomotive steam whistle or
steam whistle attached to any stationary boiler, except to give notice of the
time to begin or stop work, as a warning of fire or danger or upon request of
City authorities.
      (7)   Exhausts; muffler systems. The discharge into the open air of the
exhaust of any steam engine, stationary internal combustion engine, motor boat
or motor vehicle, except through a muffler or other device which will
effectively prevent loud or explosive noises therefrom.
      (8)   Defects in vehicle or load. The use of any vehicle so out of
repair, so loaded or used in such manner as to create loud and unnecessary
grating, grinding, rattling or other noise.
      (9)   Loading or unloading; opening of boxes. The creation of a loud and
excessive noise in connection with loading or unloading any vehicle or the
opening and destruction of bales, boxes, crates or containers.
      (10)   Construction or repair. The erection, demolition, alteration or
repair of any building project or roadway, other than between the hours of 7:00
a.m. and 8:00 p.m. on any day, except in case of urgent necessity in the
interest of public health and safety, and then only with a permit from the
Public Works Director.
      (11)   Excessive noise adjacent to schools, courts, churches, hospitals.
The creation of any excessive noise on any street adjacent to any school,
church or court while the same is in use, or adjacent to any hospital, which
noise unreasonably interferes with the working of such institution or which
disturbs or unduly annoys patients in the hospital.
      (12)   Hawkers and peddlers. The shouting and crying of peddlers, hawkers
and vendors which disturbs the peace and quiet of the neighborhood.
      (13)   Transporting metal rails, pillars and columns. The transportation
of rails, pillars or columns of iron, steel or other material, so as to cause
loud noises or disturb the peace and quiet.
   (d)   Exceptions. Loudspeakers and an amplifier system may be installed and
operated on the light poles in the Pedestrian Plaza located on Stephenson
Street, between State Avenue and Van Buren Avenue. Such system may be used for
oral communication during emergencies or special events approved by Council,
and for the playing of music. However, such music shall be limited to soft,
soothing, background or dinner music not disturbing the legitimate use of areas
within a reasonable distance, and shall not be raucous, shrill or heavily
rhythmic. Such music shall not be played between the hours of 9:00 p.m. and 8:
00 a.m. of the following day.
(1977 Code §§ 44-101 to 44-103; Ord. 94-33. Passed 5-2-94; Ord. 94-80. Passed
9-19-94; Ord. 2003-71. Passed 11-3-03.)
670.06 LOITERING AND OBSTRUCTING OR INTERFERING WITH PUBLIC ACCESS OR BUSINESS.
   No person shall loiter in or around, or obstruct the free access to or free
use of, public buildings, stores, shops, public streets, public ways or public
shopping malls, or obstruct corridors, stairways or doorways so as to prevent
free access by members of the public, officers, employees, occupants or any
other persons. No person shall, by his or her presence or by his or her
conduct, either alone or in consort with others, interfere with or interrupt
the conduct of business in such stores or shops or in the offices located in
any such buildings in the City. No person shall sit, stand, lie or recline on
any improvement, such as pools, planters, walls, retaining fixtures, sidewalks
and curbings or on any such improvement which is not specifically provided for
or intended for such purpose or use in any public place, including public
plazas and shopping malls such as the Stephenson Street Shopping Mall between
State Avenue and Van Buren Avenue. A person commits a violation if he or she,
singly or with others, loiters or prowls in a place, at a time or in a manner
not usual for law abiding individuals, under circumstances that warrant alarm
for the safety of persons or property in the vicinity. Among the circumstances
which may be considered in determining whether such alarm is warranted is the
fact that the actor takes flight upon appearance of a police officer, refuses
to identify himself or herself or manifestly endeavors to conceal himself or
herself or any object. Unless flight by the actor or other circumstances make
it impracticable, a police officer shall, prior to any arrest for an offense
under this section, afford the actor the opportunity to dispel any alarm which
would otherwise be warranted by requesting him or her to identify himself or
herself and explain his or her presence and conduct. No person shall be
convicted of an offense under this section if the police officer did not comply
with the preceding sentence, or if it appears that the explanation given by the
actor was true and, if believed by the police officer at the time, would have
dispelled the alarm. This section shall not be construed to prohibit innocent
public assembly or political, religious or civil demonstrations, gatherings or
activities, but rather to prohibit conduct calculated to do harm to the persons
or property of others and to the rights and freedom of others.
(1977 Code § 46-145)
670.07 USE OF OFFENSIVE PRODUCTS UPON PERSONS OR PROPERTY.
   (a)   No person shall throw, drop, pour, deposit or discharge upon the
person or property of another, any liquid, gas or solid substance which is
injurious to such person or property, or which is nauseous, sickening,
irritating or offensive to any of the senses.
   (b)   This section shall not apply to police officers acting in the line of
duty or to the use of such substances for the protection of property or for
repelling law violators.
(1977 Code § 46-122)
670.08 ABUSE OF EMERGENCY 911 TELEPHONE SYSTEM.
   It shall be unlawful for any person within the City to do either of the
following:
   (a)   With the intent to make a false alarm or complaint, telephone the
number 911 and report false information which could result in the emergency
response of any public safety agency, whether publicly or privately-owned,
including, but not limited to, law enforcement agencies, fire departments or
fire protection districts or ambulance companies; or
   (b)   Knowingly telephone the number 911 for any nonemergency purpose or
reason, after having been notified, either in writing or verbally, that such
calls are not to be made on the Emergency 911 line.
(Ord. 92-12. Passed 5-4-92.)
670.99 PENALTY.
   (a)   Any violation of the provisions of Section
670.05(b) and (c)(2) is punishable by a fine of not less than one hundred fifty
dollars ($150.00). A second violation of either Section
670.05(b) or (c)(2) by the same person or at the same property, which occurs
within ninety (90) days of receiving a previous ticket, is punishable by a fine
of not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00). A third or subsequent
violation of either Section
670.05(b) or (c)(2) by the same person or at the same property at any time
thereafter is punishable by a fine of not less than five hundred dollars
($500.00).
      Each occurrence of a violation of Section
670.05, or, in the case of continuing violations, each day a violation occurs
or continues, constitutes a separate offense and may be punished separately.
   (b)   Nothing in this section shall be construed as requiring the Freeport
Police Department to cite a person or property owner for violation of Section
670.05, if in its discretion, the Department determines that it is in the best
interest of the community to utilize other lawful means to gain compliance.
(Ord. 2013-51. Passed 10-7-13.)
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
202.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
