678.01 STORING, TRANSPORTING, ETC., DISCONNECTED ICE BOXES AND REFRIGERATORS.
   No person shall stand, store, deposit, transport, dump or abandon any
refrigerator, ice box or freezer when it is not connected to the gas or
electric current or offered for sale, without first removing bolts, locks or
other apparatus from the door so that it may be opened from the inside.
(1977 Code § 46-110)
678.02 ABANDONED WELLS AND CISTERNS.
   No person shall permit, upon any property owned or occupied by him or her ,
any unused or abandoned well, cistern, shaft or other similar opening to remain
uncovered and unsealed without suitable covering sufficient to prevent any
person or animal from falling therein.
(1977 Code § 46-127)
678.03 SMOKING.
   (a)   Prohibited in City Hall. City Hall is hereby declared a smoke-free
premises, and threfore no person shall smoke any cigar, cigarette or pipe
anywhere within City Hall. A designated smoking area is hereby established at
the exterior of City Hall on Exchange Street at its intersection with Walnut
Street.
(Ord. 98-24. Passed 5-4-98.)
   (b)   Prohibited in Fire Stations; Exceptions. No person shall smoke any
cigar, cigarette or pipe anywhere within the fire stations of the City, except
on an apparatus floor area which is posted as a smoking-permitted area.
(1977 Code §§ 46-149, 46-150; Ord. 87-35. Passed 5-4-87; Ord. 88-24. Passed 5-
16-88.)
678.04 EXPECTORATING IN PUBLIC.
   No person shall expectorate upon any sidewalk, street, public floor or any
other public place.
(1977 Code § 46-104)
678.05 EMISSION OF SMOKE AND GASES.
   (a)   Definitions. As used in this section:
      (1)   "Dense smoke" means smoke which has a density of No. 2 or greater
as established by the Ringelmann Chart.
      (2)   "Cinders," "dust," "fly ash," "noxious acids," "fumes" and "gases"
mean all matter other than dense smoke, including coke, cinders, dust and soot
formed as a result of the combustion of fuel, which are carried in the gas
stream so as to reach the external air and which have not been completely
consumed by the combustion process.
      (3)   "Ringelmann Chart" means that standard published by the United
States Bureau of Mines to determine the density of smoke.
   (b)   Exceptions. The provisions of this section shall not be applicable to
private residences in which no more than two families are or can be housed, nor
when a fire box, furnace, boiler, locomotive or other fuel-consuming device is
being cleaned out and a new fire is being built therein, in which event dense
smoke shall be permitted for a period not to exceed six minutes in any hour.
   (c)   Emission of Dense Smoke; Declaration of Nuisance. No person shall
permit the emission of dense smoke from any source whatsoever. The emission of
dense smoke is declared to be a public nuisance and may be summarily abated by
the Public Works Director.
   (d)   Escape of Soot, Noxious Acids and Gases; Declaration of Nuisance. No
person shall permit or cause the escape of such quantities of soot, cinders,
noxious acids, fumes and gases in such place or manner as to be detrimental to
any person or to the public or to endanger the health, comfort and safety of
any person, or in such manner as to cause injury or damage to property or
business. The escape of such matter is declared to be a public nuisance and may
be summarily abated by the Division of Health and Environment.
   (e)   Use of Smokeless Solid Fuel. No person, firm or corporation shall use
or consume in any solid fuel-burning equipment any solid fuel which does not
meet the standards of a smokeless solid fuel. Smokeless fuel shall be
considered a fuel, the volatile content of which is twenty percent or less on a
dry basis.
   (f)   Equal Standards. If a fuel contains volatile matter in excess of
twenty percent on a dry basis, it shall be acceptable under the terms of this
section if it meets the same standards in regard to smoke production as that of
a fuel containing less than twenty percent volatile matter on a dry basis.
   (g)   Air Pollution Devices. Solid fuel having a volatile content in excess
of twenty percent on a dry basis but not meeting the conditions provided in
this section may be used or consumed in heating devices equipped with
appliances which ensure the complete combustion of all fuel used and which are
further designed to prevent all air pollution prohibited by this section.
   (h)   Dump Fires. No person shall, within the City or within one mile of the
corporate limits thereof, kindle or maintain, or permit the kindling or
maintenance of, any fire on land which is used for the collection, storage or
disposal of rubbish, trash, garbage, junk or waste materials, commonly called
dumps. Violation of this section shall be considered the maintenance of a
nuisance and the conduct of an offensive business.
(1977 Code §§ 46-301 to 46-308; Ord. 94-80. Passed 9-19-94.)
678.06 WATER POLLUTION.
   (a)   Application. This section applies to all waters located within,
bordering and within three miles of the corporate limits of the City.
   (b)   Discarding of Foreign Substances Prohibited. As to all waters and
waterways, it shall be unlawful to discard or place any trash, trees, rubbish,
waste or other substance into the waters or waterways, save and except only as
authorized by these Codified Ordinances.
   (c)   Violation; Remedies. The imposition of a penalty as provided in
Section
678.99 for any violation shall not excuse the violation or permit it to
continue. A person who commits a violation shall be required to correct and
remedy such violation within a reasonable time.
(1977 Code §§ 70-101 to 70-103)
678.07 COMMUNICABLE DISEASES.  (REPEALED)
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: Section 678.07 was repealed by Ordinance 94-80, passed
September 19, 1994.)
678.08 STAGNANT WATER.
   (a)   Any lot, ground, or premises, within the City, on which stagnant water
may be standing, so as to become or likely to become foul, putrid, offensive,
harborage for insect and/or rodents or detrimental to the health and comfort of
persons residing in the vicinity thereof, is hereby declared a nuisance.
   (b)   Responsibility for clean up of same shall be in accordance with
Chapter 1060, Section
1060.13.
(Ord. 2002-24. Passed 5-6-02.)
678.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
202.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
CHAPTER 682
Sex Related Offenses
682.01   Prostitution.
682.02   Indecent activities.
682.03   Window peeping.
682.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Sex offenses - see 720 ILCS 5/11-6 et seq.
   Sexual harassment - see ADM.
270.08
   Venereal diseases - see GEN. OFF.
678.07(g)
682.01 PROSTITUTION.
   (a)   Prohibited. No person shall commit any act as set forth in this
section.
   (b)   Definitions. As used in this section:
      (1)   "Aiding" means to aid, abet, allow, permit or participate in the
commission of an act of prostitution.
      (2)   "Commit" means to perform or agree to perform an act of
prostitution.
      (3)   "Directing" means to direct or offer to direct any person to any
place or building for the purpose of committing an act of prostitution.
      (4)   "Frequenting" means to be in or near any place frequented by the
public, or any public place, for the purpose of inducing, enticing or procuring
another to commit an act of prostitution.
      (5)   "Inmate" means an occupant or visitor of any house of ill fame.
      (6)   "Keeping" means to maintain, directly or indirectly, any bawdy or
disorderly house or house of ill fame.
      (7)   "Meretricious display" means to make a meretricious display in or
near any public place, any place frequented by the public, or any place open to
the public view.
      (8)   "Permitting" means to knowingly receive, or offer or agree to
receive, any person into any place or building for the purpose of performing an
act of prostitution, or knowingly permit any person to remain in any place or
building for such purpose.
      (9)   "Permitting use of premises" means to lease any building or
premises to be used, in whole or in part, as a house of ill fame, or permit any
building or premises to be so used.
      (10)   "Procure" means to entice, influence or persuade, or attempt to
entice, influence or persuade, any person to enter or frequent a house of ill
fame.
      (11)   "Procuring" means to procure or offer another for the purpose of
committing an act of prostitution.
      (12)   "Transportation" means to knowingly transport any person to any
place for the purpose of committing an act of prostitution.
   (c)   Loitering for Purposes of Prostitution. No lewd woman or prostitute
shall in any manner ply her vocation upon the streets, alleys, stairways or
halls of public buildings, parks or other places, by loitering or in any manner
soliciting acts of lewdness.
(1977 Code §§ 46-201, 46-202)
   (d)   Incorporation of Applicable Statutory Provisions. All applicable and
pertinent provisions of 720 ILCS 5/11-14 through 5/11-19, as amended, are
incorporated herein by reference, subject to the provisions of Section
202.05(b) of the Administration Code.
682.02 INDECENT ACTIVITIES.
   (a)   For the purpose of this section, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.
      (1)   “Lewd exposure” means any crude or offensive exposure in a sexual
manner.
      (2)   “Public place” means any place where the conduct may reasonably be
expected to be viewed by others.
      (3)   “Sexual conduct” means any intentional or knowing touching or
fondling of the genitalia, buttocks, or breasts of oneself or another, either
directly or through clothing.
   (b)   Any person who performs any of the following acts in a public place
commits an act of public indecency:
      (1)   An act of sexual penetration as defined in 720 ILCS 5/11-01; or
      (2)   A lewd exposure of the body; or
      (3)   An exposure of one’s genitalia, buttocks, or breasts.
   (c)   Notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained in this section,
the breast- feeding of infants shall not be considered as an act of public
indecency.
(1977 Code §46-111; Ord. 2020-76. Passed 12-7-20.)
682.03 WINDOW PEEPING.
   No person shall look into, or loiter within view of, any residential window
with intent to observe or invade the private activities of any person.
(1977 Code § 46-128)
682.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
202.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
CHAPTER 684
Solicitation
684.01   Definitions.
684.02   Prohibited acts.
684.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Soliciting contributions for political purposes - see 70 ILCS 1215/22 et
seq.
   Solicitation generally - see 720 ILCS 5/1-5, 5/8-1 et seq.
   Soliciting by members of the Fire Department - see ADM.
242.28
   Noise from solicitors - see GEN. OFF.
670.05(c)(12)
   Solicitors generally - see B.R. & T.
Ch. 864
   Transient merchants - see B.R. & T.
Ch. 872
684.01 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   "Aggressive manner" means and includes:
      (1)   Intentionally or recklessly making any physical contact with or
touching another person in the course of the solicitation without the person's
consent;
      (2)   Following the person being solicited, if that conduct is intended
to or is likely to cause a reasonable person to fear imminent bodily harm or
the commission of a criminal act upon property in the person's possession, or
is intended to or is reasonably likely to intimidate the person being solicited
into responding affirmatively to the solicitation;
      (3)   Continuing to solicit within five feet of the person being
solicited after the person has made a negative response, if continuing the
solicitation is intended to or is likely to cause a reasonable person to fear
imminent bodily harm or the commission of a criminal act upon property in the
person's possession, or is intended to or is reasonably likely to intimidate
the person being solicited into responding affirmatively to the solicitation;
      (4)   Intentionally or recklessly blocking the safe or free passage of
the person being solicited or requiring the person to take evasive action to
avoid physical contact with the person making the solicitation. Acts authorized
as an exercise of one's constitutional right to picket or legally protest, and
acts authorized by a certificate of registration issued pursuant to
Chapter 864 of these Codified Ordinances, shall not constitute obstruction of
pedestrian traffic.
      (5)   Intentionally or recklessly using obscene or abusive language or
gestures intended to or likely to cause a reasonable person to fear imminent
bodily harm or the commission of a criminal act upon property in the person's
possession, or words intended to or reasonably likely to intimidate the person
into responding affirmatively to the solicitation; or
      (6)   Approaching the person being solicited in a manner that is intended
to or is likely to cause a reasonable person to fear imminent bodily harm or
the commission of a criminal act upon property in the person's possession, or
that is intended to or is reasonably likely to intimidate the person being
solicited into responding affirmatively to the solicitation.
   (b)   "Automated teller machine" means a device, linked to a financial
institution's account records, which is able to carry out transactions,
including, but not limited to, account transfers, deposits, cash withdrawals,
balance inquiries and mortgage and loan payments.
   (c)   "Automated teller machine facility" means the area comprised of one or
more automatic teller machines and any adjacent space which is made available
to banking customers after regular banking hours.
   (d)   "Public area" means an area to which the public or a substantial group
of persons has access, and includes, but is not limited to, alleys, bridges,
buildings, driveways, parking lots, parks, playgrounds, plazas, sidewalks and
streets open to the general public, and the doorways and entrances to buildings
and dwellings and the grounds enclosing them.
   (e)   "Solicit" means to request an immediate donation of money or other
thing of value from another person, regardless of the solicitor's purpose or
intended use of the money or other thing of value. The solicitation may be,
without limitation, by the spoken, written or printed word or by other means of
communication.
(Ord. 96-66. Passed 10-7-96.)
684.02 PROHIBITED ACTS.
   No person shall solicit money or any other thing of value, or solicit the
sale of goods or services, in an aggressive manner in a public area, or within
fifteen feet of any entrance or exit of any bank or within fifteen feet of any
automated teller machine or the entrance or exit of any automated teller
machine facility.
(Ord. 96-66. Passed 10-7-96.)
684.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
202.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
CHAPTER 686
Theft and Fraud
686.01   Retail theft.
686.02   Swindling or cheating.
686.03   Slugs.

   CROSS REFERENCES
   Municipal suppression of fraudulent devices - see 65 ILCS 5/11-5-1
   Theft - see 720 ILCS 5/16-1 et seq.
   Offenses relating to property - see GEN. OFF.

   Possession of burglary tools - see GEN. OFF.

   Removing barricades and warning lights - see S.U. & P.S.

686.01 RETAIL THEFT.
   (a)   Definitions. As used in this section, unless the context indicates or
requires otherwise:
      (1)   "Conceal merchandise" means that, although there may be some notice
of its presence, merchandise is not visible through ordinary observation.
      (2)   "Full retail value" means the merchant's stated or advertised price
of the merchandise.
      (3)   "Merchandise" means any item of tangible personal property.
      (4)   "Merchant" means an owner or operator of any retail mercantile
establishment or any agent, employee, lessee, consignee, officer, director,
franchisee or independent contractor of such owner or operator.
      (5)   "Person" means any natural person or individual.
      (6)   "Premises of a retail mercantile establishment" includes, but is
not limited to, the retail mercantile establishment, any common use areas in
shopping centers and all parking areas set aside by a merchant or on behalf of
a merchant for the parking of vehicles for the convenience of the patrons of
such retail mercantile establishment.
      (7)   "Retail mercantile establishment" means any place where merchandise
is displayed, held, stored or offered for sale to the public.
      (8)   "Shopping cart" means those push carts of the type or types which
are commonly provided by grocery stores, drug stores or other retail mercantile
establishments for the use of the public in transporting commodities in stores
and markets and, incidentally, from the stores to a place outside the stores.
      (9)   "Under-ring" means to cause the cash register or other sales
recording device to reflect less than the full retail value of the merchandise.
   (b)   Commission of Offense. A person commits the offense of retail theft
when he or she knowingly:
      (1)   Takes possession of, carries away, transfers or causes to be
carried away or transferred, any merchandise displayed, held, stored or offered
for sale in a retail mercantile establishment with the intention of retaining
such merchandise or with the intention of depriving the merchant permanently of
the possession, use or benefit of such merchandise without paying the full
retail value of such merchandise;
      (2)   Alters, transfers or removes any label, price tag, marking, indicia
of value or any other marking which aids in determining value affixed to any
merchandise displayed, held, stored or offered for sale in a retail mercantile
establishment and attempts to purchase such merchandise personally or in
consort with another at less than the full retail value with the intention of
depriving the merchant of the full retail value of such merchandise;
      (3)   Transfers any merchandise displayed, held, stored or offered for
sale in a retail mercantile establishment from the container in or on which
such merchandise is displayed to any other container with the intention of
depriving the merchant of the full retail value of such merchandise;
      (4)   Under-rings with the intention of depriving the merchant of the
full retail value of the merchandise; or
      (5)   Removes a shopping cart from the premises of a retail mercantile
establishment without the consent of the merchant given at the time of such
removal with the intention of depriving the merchant permanently of the
possession, use or benefit of such cart.
   (c)   Presumptions. If any person conceals upon his or her person or among
his or her belongings, unpurchased merchandise displayed, held, stored or
offered for sale in a retail mercantile establishment, and removes that
merchandise beyond the last known station for receiving payments for that
merchandise in that retail mercantile establishment, such person shall be
presumed to have possessed, carried away or transferred such merchandise with
the intention of retaining it or with the intention of depriving the merchant
permanently of the possession, use or benefit of such merchandise without
paying the full retail value of such merchandise.
(1977 Code §§ 46-130 to 46-141; Ord. 77-87. Passed 11-21-77.)
686.02 SWINDLING OR CHEATING.
   No person shall obtain possession of any money, property or other thing of
value, or attempt to do so, by swindling, cheating, fraud or false proceedings,
or by any trick, sleight of hand game or device, nor induce, or attempt to
induce, any person to bet, loan, deposit or stake money or other property upon
the result of any game, trick or device.
(1977 Code § 46-123)
686.03 SLUGS.
   No person shall insert, or attempt to insert, into a coin slot or telephone
any substance other than legal tender coin of the United States, nor manipulate
or operate any coin, instrument or other mechanism in a coin device with the
intent to obtain merchandise or service without full payment.
(1977 Code § 46-121)
686.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
202.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)

692.01 DISCHARGING FIREARMS AND OTHER WEAPONS.
   No person shall discharge any firearm or other weapon as set forth in
Section
692.03, except in an authorized shooting gallery, on private grounds or within
a private residence under circumstances when such instrument can be discharged
so as not to endanger any persons or property and so as to prevent the
projectile from traversing any grounds or space outside the limits of such
gallery, grounds or residence, or except as otherwise authorized by ordinance
or statute.
(Ord. 93-3. Passed 2-1-93.)
692.02 CONCEALED WEAPONS.
   (a)   Prohibited. No person shall wear or carry concealed about his or her
person any gun, pistol, revolver, metallic knuckles, bowie-knife, dirk, razor
or other dangerous or deadly weapon, or display or flourish any such weapon in
a boisterous or threatening manner.
   (b)   Exceptions. This provision does not apply, however, to the following
officers, while engaged in the discharge of their official duties: sheriffs,
coroners, policemen or other duly constituted peace officers; nor to the
following employees or agents, while in the discharge of the duties of their
employment: special agents and policemen employed by railroads; nor to persons
lawfully summoned by an officer to assist in making arrests or preserving the
peace while so engaged in assisting such an officer; nor to the concealed
carrying of any type of gun by hunters when unloaded and properly cased, to or
from any range or gallery or to or from a hunting area; nor to persons
possessing a validly issued, unexpired license to carry a concealed handgun,
pursuant to the Illinois Firearm Concealed Carry Act, 430 ILCS 66/1 et seq., as
amended, and not located in a prohibited area, as defined by 430 ILCS 66/65, as
amended.
(1977 Code §27-102; Ord. 2017-60. Passed 8-7-17.)
692.03 OTHER PROHIBITED WEAPONS.
   No person shall use, carry on his or her person or within a motor vehicle in
a position accessible to the occupants of such motor vehicle or discharge a
sling-shot, air-gun, BB gun, blow gun; any other implement or device for the
casting or throwing of stones, pellets, bullets, shot, BBs or darts; any other
item that reasonably resembles the shape and color of a real firearm; or any
other article of a dangerous or annoying character.
(Ord. 93-3. Passed 2-1-93.)
692.04 SWITCH-BLADE KNIVES.
   No person shall sell, offer for sale, give, carry, possess, loan or display
any knife, the blade or blades of which can be opened by the flick of a button,
pressure on the handle or other mechanical device. Such knife is hereby
declared to be a dangerous or deadly weapon.
(1977 Code § 27-104)
692.05 UNLAWFUL USE OF WEAPONS.
   No person shall use any weapon unlawfully, as specified in 720 ILCS 5/24-
1 and 5/24-2, as amended.
(1977 Code § 27-105)
692.06 UNLAWFUL SALE OF WEAPONS.
   No person shall sell or give any weapon unlawfully, as specified in 720 ILCS
5/24-3 and 5/24-4, as amended.
(1977 Code § 27-106)
692.07 SELLING OR GIVING WEAPONS TO INTOXICATED OR AGITATED PERSONS.
   No person shall sell or give any weapon to any person under the influence of
alcohol or to any person in a visibly agitated or excited condition.
(1977 Code § 27-107)
692.08 DEFACING MARKS OF IDENTIFICATION ON FIREARMS.
   No person shall change, alter, remove or obliterate the name of the maker,
model, manufacturer's number or other mark of identification of any firearm.
(1977 Code § 27-108)
692.09 FORFEITURE OF WEAPONS.
   The owner of a weapon who is convicted of a violation of this chapter shall
forfeit to the City, for the use of or the destruction by the City, the weapon
involved in such violation, and such forfeiture shall be in addition to any
other penalty which may be imposed by the court.
(Ord. 93-3. Passed 2-1-93.)
692.10 INCORPORATION OF APPLICABLE STATUTORY PROVISIONS.
   All applicable and pertinent provisions of 720 ILCS 5/24-1 et seq., as
amended, are incorporated herein by reference, subject to the provisions of
Section
202.05(b) of the Administration Code.
692.11 REPORTING OF WOUNDS CAUSED BY DANGEROUS WEAPONS.
   Every physician or surgeon, whenever he or she shall treat any person in the
City for a wound inflicted by a dangerous or deadly weapon of any kind, shall
notify the Police Department within one hour of the time when he or she renders
or is requested to render, such professional service.
(1977 Code § 27-111)
692.12 THROWING OF STONES, SNOWBALLS AND OTHER MISSILES.
   No person shall cast or throw any stone, snowball, iceball, disc-shaped
object, frisbee, stick or other missile at, on or into any public street,
walkway, parking area, vehicle, building or adjoining premises.
(1977 Code § 46-115; Ord. 77-73. Passed 11-21-77.)
692.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
202.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
CHAPTER 694
Weeds and Grass
694.01   Nuisance declared.
694.02   Violation defined.
694.03   Weeds or tall grasses defined.
694.04   Grass and weeds; duty to cut; noncompliance; remedy of city.
694.05   Collection; minimum charge; notice of lien; contents; release.
694.06
   Mandatory injunction.
694.07
   Incorporation of applicable statutory provisions.
694.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Municipal regulation of weeds - see 65 ILCS 5/11-20-6, 5/11-20-7
   Grass clippings; Litter Control Act - see 415 ILCS 105/1 et seq.
   Nuisances - see GEN. OFF.
Ch. 658
   Forestry - see S.U. & P.S.
Ch. 1068
694.01 NUISANCE DECLARED.
   Whoever shall suffer or permit any cockleburs, thistles, burdocks or rank or
noxious weeds, grass or vegetation to grow or be upon any lot or premises
owned, occupied or controlled by him or her shall be deemed guilty of
maintaining a nuisance.
(Ord. 98-26. Passed 6-1-98.)
694.02 VIOLATION DEFINED.
   Whoever shall suffer or permit weeds or tall grasses to grow or be upon any
lot or premises owned, occupied or controlled by him or her shall be deemed
guilty of maintaining a nuisance.
(Ord. 2001-26. Passed 7-2-01.)
694.03 WEEDS OR TALL GRASSES DEFINED.
   Under this chapter, weeds or tall grasses shall be defined as grass or
weeds, including, but not limited to, burdock, ragweed (giant), ragweed
(common), thistle, cocklebur, jimson, vervain, common milkweed, wild carrot,
poison ivy, wild mustard, rough pigweed, lambs-quarter, wild lettuce, curled
dock, nettles, smartweeds (all varieties), poison hemlock and wild hemp, when
such grass or weeds shall have reached a height in excess of eight inches.
(Ord. 2001-26. Passed 7-2-01.)
694.04 GRASS AND WEEDS; DUTY TO CUT; NONCOMPLIANCE; REMEDY OF CITY
   (a)   If any owner of real estate or tenant of property permits weeds and/or
tall grass in excess of eight inches in height to remain standing upon his or
her property, the City may issue a citation to the owner or tenant to cut or
remove the grass or weeds. The Public Works Department, in its sole discretion,
may issue or post a warning notice to the owner or tenant prior to issuing a
citation. Posted notices shall be in at least twelve-point type and prominently
posted on or near the property.
   (b)   In addition to issuing a citation, and concurrent with same, the City
or its agent may cut or remove the grass or weeds and recover its expenses for
such work as provided in Section
694.05. All fees recovered for such abatement shall be in addition to any
penalties under Section
694.99.
(Ord. 2001-26. Passed 7-2-01; Ord. 2012-24. Passed 4-16-12.)
694.05 COLLECTION; MINIMUM CHARGE; NOTICE OF LIEN; CONTENTS; RELEASE.
   (a)   Collection; Minimum Charge. If grass or weeds are cut by the City, or
by someone directed to cut them on its behalf, the City may assess actual costs
for same, but in no event less than forty dollars ($40.00) per hour, plus an
administrative fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00). The City shall take
reasonable steps to collect its expenses for such work. Reasonable steps may
include written notice to the owner of record followed by placement in
collection and/or filing of a suit to collect in Circuit Court. Such suit may
include collection for accumulated cuttings and associated labor and multiple
administrative fees together with reasonable attorney's fees and court costs.
The City may also file a lien against the real estate as provided in this
section. These remedies shall not be considered mutually exclusive.
   (b)   Notice of Lien. If grass or weeds are cut by the City or by someone
directed to cut them on its behalf, a notice of lien for expenses incurred
shall be recorded in the office of the County Clerk and Recorder within one
year after the expense is incurred.
   (c)   Contents. The notice of lien shall consist of a sworn statement
setting out the following:
      (1)   A description of the real estate sufficient for identification
thereof;
      (2)   The amount of money representing the cost and expense incurred or
payable for the service; and
      (3)   The date or dates when said cost and expense were incurred.
   (d)   Release of Lien. Upon payment of the cost and expense, the lien shall
be released by the City or person in whose name the lien has been filed, and
the release shall be filed of record in the same manner as filing notice of
lien.
(Ord. 98-26. Passed 6-1-98; Ord. 2001-26. Passed 7-2-01; Ord. 2017-58. Passed
7-17-17.)
694.06 MANDATORY INJUNCTION.
   In addition to all other penalties and remedies provided for in this
chapter, the City shall have the right to seek and obtain a mandatory
injunction against the owner of any such real estate who is in violation of any
of the provisions of this chapter, enjoining and ordering him or her to cut
grass and grass or weeds in compliance with the provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. 98-26. Passed 6-1-98; Ord. 2001-26. Passed 7-2-01.)
694.07 INCORPORATION OF APPLICABLE STATUTORY PROVISIONS.
   All applicable and pertinent provisions of 65 ILCS 5/11-20-7, as heretofore
and hereafter amended, are incorporated herein by reference, subject to the
provisions of Section
202.05(b) of the Administration Code.
(Ord. 98-26. Passed 6-1-98; Ord. 2001-26. Passed 7-2-01.)
694.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
202.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
   In addition to any other penalties and remedies set forth in this chapter,
whoever violates any of the provisions of Section
694.02 shall be subject to a fine of not less than one hundred dollars
($100.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for a first offense and
not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than five hundred dollars
($500.00) for each subsequent offense.
(Ord. 98-26. Passed 6-1-98; Ord. 2001-26. Passed 7-2-01; Ord. 2017-29. Passed
7-3-17.)

802.01 LICENSE AND LICENSEE DEFINED.
   "License" and "licensee," as used in this chapter, shall include,
respectively, the words "permit" and "permittee," or the holder for any use or
period of time of any similar privilege, wherever relevant to any provision of
this Title Two of the Business Regulation and Taxation Code or other law or
ordinance.
(1977 Code § 9-101)
802.02 COMPLIANCE REQUIRED; APPLICATION OF CHAPTER.
   It shall be unlawful for any person, either directly or indirectly, to
conduct any business or activity, in whole or in part, for which a license or
permit is required by any ordinance, without a license or permit being first
procured and kept in effect at all such times as required by this Title Two of
the Business Regulation and Taxation Code or other ordinances. The procedures
and provisions of this chapter shall apply to all other chapters of this
Business Regulation and Taxation Code, except where inconsistent therewith.
(1977 Code § 9-102)
802.03 LICENSE OFFICER.
   (a)   The City Manager, or his or her duly appointed designee, shall be the
License Officer for the City. The City Manager may designate one or more
individuals to perform all or some of the duties of the License Officer under
the provisions of this Title Two of the Business Regulation and Taxation Code.
The License Officer shall be a resident of the City.
   (b)   The License Officer shall:
      (1)   Issue licenses to all persons qualified.
      (2)   Promulgate and enforce all reasonable rules and regulations
necessary to the operation and enforcement of this Business Regulation and
Taxation Code.
      (3)   Adopt all forms and prescribe the information to be given thereon.
      (4)   Investigate and determine the eligibility of any applicant for a
license.
      (5)   Examine books and records of any applicant or licensee when
reasonably necessary to the administration of this Business Regulation and
Taxation Code.
      (6)   Revoke or suspend licenses as required.
(1977 Code §§9-106, 9-107; Ord. 89-67. Passed 11-20-89; Ord. 2017-56. Passed 7-
17-17.)
802.04 DUTIES OF CITY CLERK.
   The City Clerk shall:
   (a)   Receive all applications.
   (b)   Keep a license register in which shall be entered the name of each
person licensed and the date, class or purpose and duration of the license.
   (c)   Require applicants to submit all necessary forms, records and
affidavits.
   (d)   Submit all applications, in a proper case, to the appropriate City
officers for their endorsements thereon as to compliance by the applicant with
all regulations which such officers have the duty of enforcing.
   (e)   Notify any applicant of the acceptance or rejection of his or her
application, and, at the applicant's request, state, in writing, the reasons
for any rejection.
(Ord. 97-21. Passed 7-21-97.)
802.05 RESPONSIBILITY OF AGENTS FOR COMPLIANCE.
   Agents or representatives shall be personally responsible for the compliance
of their principals and of the businesses they represent.
(1977 Code § 9-103)
802.06 BRANCH ESTABLISHMENTS.
   A license shall be obtained for each branch establishment or location of a
business engaged in, as if each such branch establishment or location were a
separate business.
(1977 Code § 9-104)
802.07 SPECIAL PERMITS FOR NON-PROFIT ENTERPRISES.
   (a)   The License Officer shall issue special permits, without the payment
of license fees, to any organization for the conduct of a non-profit
enterprise, either regularly or temporarily, when he or she finds that the
applicant operates, without private profit, for a public, charitable,
educational, literary, fraternal or religious purpose.
   (b)   An applicant for a special permit shall submit an application and such
additional information as the License Officer shall require.
   (c)   An organization operating under a special permit shall operate the
enterprise in compliance with this Title Two of the Business Regulation and
Taxation Code and all other applicable rules and regulations.
(1977 Code § 9-105)
802.08 CONFIDENTIALITY OF INFORMATION.
   The License Officer and City Clerk shall keep all information relative to
licenses in strict confidence, except as to authorized persons.
(1977 Code § 9-109)
802.09 LICENSE APPLICATIONS.
   Every person required to procure a license, or a renewal of a license, shall
submit an application therefor. The application shall:
   (a)   Be written and verified upon forms provided by the City.
   (b)   Disclose all information required by Section
802.14 and any other information which the License Officer shall find to be
reasonably necessary.
   (c)   Be accompanied by the full amount of the license fee.
   (d)   Disclose the full name and address of the applicant; if a corporation,
the names and addresses of the president, secretary and treasurer of the
corporation; and if a co-partnership, the names and addresses of all the
partners.
   (e)   Disclose the length of residence in the City of each person named in
the application and if any such person is not a resident of the City for at
least five years immediately preceding the date of application, the place of
residence of such person during such five years. If any person named in the
application is a nonresident of the City, or the period of residence is less
than five years, letters of recommendation for such person by at least two
reputable and responsible acquaintances, vouching for his or her honesty,
integrity and good moral character, shall accompany the application.
   (f)   Disclose the name under which the business will be operated.
   (g)   Disclose the street address of the place of business.
(1977 Code § 9-110)
802.10 RECEIPTS FOR APPLICATION FEES.
   The Finance Director or his or her designee shall collect all license fees
and shall issue a receipt for the application fee. Such receipt shall not be
construed as issuance of a license, nor authorize the applicant to open or
maintain any business prior to the issuance of a license.
(Ord. 97-21. Passed 7-21-97.)
802.11 REFUND OF FEES UPON DISAPPROVAL OF APPLICATIONS.
   The License Officer shall, upon disapproving any application, refund all
fees paid in advance, provided that the applicant is not otherwise indebted to
the City, and except as is otherwise provided.
(1977 Code § 9-112)
802.12 LOST LICENSES; ISSUANCE OF DUPLICATES.
   A duplicate license or special permit shall be issued by the License Officer
to replace any license previously issued which has been lost, stolen, defaced
or destroyed, without any willful conduct on the part of the licensee, upon the
payment of a fee of five dollars ($5.00).
(1977 Code § 9-113)
802.13 BUILDING CONSTRUCTION OR OCCUPANCY NOT AUTHORIZED BY LICENSES.
   A license issued under this Title Two of the Business Regulation and
Taxation Code shall not be considered a substitute for a building or occupancy
permit, nor shall it convey any right, in itself, to do any building or
construction whatsoever.
(1977 Code § 9-114)
802.14 QUALIFICATIONS OF APPLICANTS.
   An applicant for a license shall:
   (a)   Be a citizen of the United States, or a declarant therefor as
authorized by law, or a resident alien.
   (b)   Not, either individually, or as a member of any party, group or
organization, at the time of application for a license or special permit,
advocate or resort to any practices designed for the overthrow, destruction or
sabotage of the government of the United States.
   (c)   Be of good moral character. In making such determination, the License
Officer shall consider:
      (1)   All criminal convictions, especially crimes and misdemeanors
opposed to decency and morality, the reasons therefor and the record, conduct
and demeanor of the applicant subsequent to his or her release.
      (2)   The license history of the applicant, including whether such
person, in previously operating in this or another state under a license, has
had such license revoked or suspended, the reasons therefor and the record,
conduct and demeanor of the applicant subsequent to such action.
      (3)   Such other facts relevant to the general personal history of the
applicant as the License Officer shall find necessary to a fair determination
of the eligibility of the applicant.
   (d)   Not be in default under the provisions of this Business Regulation and
Taxation Code or indebted in any manner to the City.
   (e)   Present a certificate of occupancy furnished by the Building
Commissioner to the effect that the proposed use of the premises is not in
violation of the Zoning Code.
(Ord. 94-7. Passed 3-7-94; Ord. 94-81. Passed 9-19-94; Ord. 2013-10. Passed 3-
4-13.)
802.15 ADDITIONAL STANDARDS FOR ISSUANCE.
   In addition to regular qualifications, the License Officer shall consider
whether:
   (a)   There is any apparent danger to the health, morals and safety of the
people of the City;
   (b)   The applicant, its officer or agents, if any, are capable of operating
the proposed business in a manner consistent with the public health, safety and
good morals;
   (c)   Conducting such business at the location designated will result in the
violation of any law or ordinance, or will result in a disturbance of the peace
and quiet of the neighborhood;
   (d)   The applicant, if the application is for renewal of a license, would
be eligible for such license upon a first application;
   (e)   If the business is a co-partnership, all of the members of such co-
partnership are qualified to obtain a license;
   (f)   If the business is a corporation, any stockholder, officer, manager,
director or any person directly or indirectly associated therewith, would not
be qualified to obtain a license;
   (g)   If the place of business is to be conducted by a manager or agent,
such manner or agent is qualified to obtain a license; and
   (h)   There is reasonable cause to believe that the place or building at
which the business is to be conducted is a fit and proper place, constructed
and maintained in accordance with the ordinances covering and controlling such
places.
(1977 Code § 9-116)
802.16 COMPLIANCE REQUIRED PENDING LEGAL ACTION RE LICENSE ISSUANCE.
   When a license is denied and an action is instituted to compel its issuance,
such applicant shall not engage in the business for which the license was
refused except by court order.
(1977 Code § 9-117)
802.17 DURATION OF LICENSES; FEES.
   Unless otherwise provided by the specific chapter(s) under this Title Two -
Business Regulation, no license shall be granted for a longer or shorter period
than one year. Unless otherwise provided by the specific chapter(s) under this
Title Two - Business Regulation, all licenses shall expire on April 30 in each
year. Unless otherwise provided by the specific chapter(s) under this Title Two
- Business Regulation, license fees shall be fifty dollars ($50.00) for the
initial license and twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for an annual renewal
thereafter, and as further provided under this chapter.
(1977 Code § 9-118; Ord. 2012-25. Passed 4-16-12; Ord. 2012-26. Passed 5-7-12.)
802.18 PRORATED FEES FOR NEW BUSINESSES.
   For new businesses, license fees shall be prorated in proportion to the full
calendar months which have expired since the preceding April 30, but no fee
shall be less than one-quarter of the annual fee.
(1977 Code § 9-119)
802.19 REFUNDS OF FEES.
   There shall be no rebate or refund of any license fee, or part thereof, by
reason of the non-use of such license through revocation, suspension, change of
location or cessation of business, voluntarily or involuntarily.
(1977 Code § 9-120)
802.20 CONTENTS OF LICENSE.
   Each license shall state upon its face:
   (a)   The name of the licensee and any other name under which such business
is to be conducted;
   (b)   The kind of business so licensed and the address thereof;
   (c)   The amount of the license fee;
   (d)   The dates of issuance and expiration; and
   (e)   Such other information as the License Officer shall determine.
(1977 Code § 9-121)
802.21 GENERAL STANDARDS OF CONDUCT OF LICENSEES.
   Every licensee shall:
   (a)   Permit all reasonable inspection of his or her business and premises,
examination of his or her books and testing of his or her equipment, by
authorized public authorities;
   (b)   Ascertain and comply with all laws and regulations applicable to the
licensed business;
   (c)   Avoid all forbidden, improper or unnecessary practices or conditions
which do or may affect the public health, morals or welfare; and
   (d)   Not operate the business or premises after expiration of the license,
or during a period in which the license is revoked or suspended.
(1977 Code § 9-122)
802.22 DISPLAY OF LICENSES.
   Every licensee shall:
   (a)   Post and maintain the license upon the licensed premises in a place
where it may be seen at all times;
   (b)   Carry the license on his or her person when he or she has no licensed
business premises;
   (c)   Affix any insignia delivered for use in connection therewith upon the
outside of any coin, vending or other business machine or device, so that it
may be seen at all times;
   (d)   Not allow any license, special permit or insignia to remain posted,
displayed or used after it has expired or when it has been suspended or
revoked; and
   (e)   Not loan, sell, or assign to any other person, or allow any other
person to use, display, destroy, damage, remove, or have in his or her
possession, except as authorized by the License Officer or by law, any license
or insignia which has been issued to the licensee.
(1977 Code § 9-123)
802.23 CHANGES OF LOCATION.
   A licensee shall have the right to change the location of the licensed
business, provided that he or she shall obtain written permission from the
License Officer, submit to necessary inspections by representatives of the
Community Development Department or other officer and pay a removal fee of five
dollars ($5.00) to the Finance Director or his or her designee.
(Ord. 97-21. Passed 7-21-97.)
802.24 RETENTION OF RECORDS.
   A licensee shall keep all records and books necessary to the enforcement of
this Business Regulation and Taxation Code.
(1977 Code § 9-125)
802.25 DETERMINATION OF FINANCIAL STATUS OF BUSINESSES IN ABSENCE OF RECORDS.
   The License Officer shall be empowered to make his or her own determination
as to the financial status for any business where the licensee has failed to
keep books and records as required.
(1977 Code § 9-126)
802.26 TRANSFER OF LICENSES.
   A license shall be personal to the licensee, shall not be transferable or
assignable and shall apply only to the premises specified.
(1977 Code § 9-127)
802.27 INSPECTIONS.
   (a)   License Officer. The License Officer shall make all investigations
reasonably necessary to the enforcement of this chapter, and may order the
inspection of licensees, their businesses and premises, by all City officials
having duties to perform with reference to such licensees or businesses.
   (b)   Police. All police officers shall inspect and examine businesses
located within their respective jurisdictions or beats to enforce compliance
with this chapter.
(1977 Code §§ 9-128, 9-129)
802.28 RIGHT OF ENTRY.
   All authorized persons, including any Alderperson, may enter, with or
without a search warrant, at all reasonable times, premises for which a license
is required, premises for which a license is issued and premises for which a
license has been revoked or suspended.
(1977 Code § 9-130)
802.29 REPORT OF VIOLATIONS.
   Persons performing inspections authorized by this chapter shall report all
violations of this Title Two of the Business Regulation and Taxation Code, or
of other laws or ordinances, to the License Officer, and shall submit such
other reports as the License Officer shall require.
(1977 Code § 9-131)
802.30 LICENSE REVOCATION.
   (a)   Power to Revoke License Implicit in License Agreement. The acceptance
of any license shall constitute an agreement between the licensee and the City,
even though the license itself does not state such fact, that the same may be
revoked.
   (b)   Reasons for Revocation. A license may be revoked according to the
procedure hereinafter set forth, for any of the following reasons:
      (1)   A false statement made in the application;
      (2)   The occurrence of any event or condition which would have justified
a refusal had it occurred prior to the application;
      (3)   A violation of any applicable provision of this Business Regulation
and Taxation Code or of these Codified Ordinances;
      (4)   Fraud, misrepresentation or a false statement made in the course of
carrying on the business licensed;
      (5)   Conducting the business licensed in any unlawful manner, or in such
a manner as to constitute a breach of the peace or a menace to the health,
safety or general welfare of the public;
      (6)   Possession of a Federal Wagering Stamp as provided by the United
States Internal Revenue Code, which possession shall be considered prima-facie
evidence that a violation of law has occurred on the licensee's premises; or
      (7)   Any other act, event or condition constituting a threat to the
health, safety, morals or welfare of the public.
   (c)   Issuance of Provisional Order of Compliance.
      (1)   When an inspector has reported a violation of this Title Two of the
Business Regulation and Taxation Code, or of any law or ordinance, the License
Officer shall issue to the affected person a provisional order to comply, if
compliance is possible. If compliance is not possible, the provisional order
shall require the licensee to show cause why the license should not be
suspended or revoked.
      (2)   The provisional order, and all other notices issued in compliance
with this Title Two of the Business Regulation and Taxation Code, shall be in
writing, shall be served personally or by United States mail and shall apprise
the person affected of specific charges or violations. In the absence of the
person affected, or his or her agent or employee, a copy of such notice may be
affixed to some structure on the premises.
      (3)   The provisional order shall require compliance within five days of
service.
   (d)   Hearings. Upon written application by the person affected, before the
expiration of the five-day period for compliance, the License Officer shall
order a hearing.
   (e)   Modification of Compliance and Hearing Dates or Orders. Upon written
application, or on his or her own motion, the License Officer may, in proper
cases, extend the time for compliance, grant a new hearing date and change,
modify or rescind any recommendation or order.
   (f)   Final Orders. Upon the failure or refusal of the violator to comply
with either the provisional order or any order made after hearing, or upon
failure to show cause, the License Officer shall enter a final order.
   (g)   Summary Action; Hearing.
      (1)   When the conduct of any licensee, agent or employee is so inimical
to the public health, safety, morals or general welfare as to constitute a
nuisance and thus give rise to an emergency, the License Officer may summarily
order the cessation of business and either close the premises or suspend or
revoke the license.
      (2)   Unless waived in writing, within three days after he or she has
acted summarily, the License Officer shall conduct a special hearing with
respect to the summary order. Notice of such hearing shall be given the
affected person.
   (h)   Appeals. Any person aggrieved by any decision of the License Officer
shall have the right to appeal under the Administrative Review Act of the
State, as amended.
(1977 Code §§ 9-132 to 9-140)
802.31 LIABILITY OF VIOLATOR FOR UNPAID FEES.
   The amount of any unpaid fee shall constitute a debt due the City by any
violator of any of the provisions of this Title Two of the Business Regulation
and Taxation Code.
(1977 Code § 9-141)
802.32 CRIMINAL PROSECUTIONS.
   No civil judgment or any act by the License Officer or a violator shall bar
a criminal prosecution for each violation of this Title Two of the Business
Regulation and Taxation Code.
(1977 Code § 9-142)
802.33 CONFLICTS WITH PROVISIONS RELATING TO ALCOHOLIC LIQUOR.
   Whenever a provision of
Chapter 806 of this Business Regulation and Taxation Code, or of
Chapter 608 of the General Offenses Code, conflicts with a provision of any
other chapter in this Business Regulation and Taxation Code, the provision of
Chapter 608 or
Chapter 806 shall control.
(1977 Code § 9-143)
802.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
202.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
