CHAPTER 823
Community Gardens
823.01   License required.
823.02   License fee and deposit required.
823.03   Application.
823.04   Liability insurance.
823.05   Failure to maintain.
 
823.99   Penalty.
823.01   LICENSE REQUIRED.
   No person shall maintain, or permit to be maintained on property owned by
them, a community garden, as defined in
Chapter 1478, except in strict compliance with that chapter, and pursuant to a
validly issued license under this chapter.
(Ord. 2023-42. Passed 9-18-23.)
823.02   LICENSE FEE AND DEPOSIT REQUIRED.
   An annual license fee of fifty dollars ($50.00) shall be paid at the time of
submission of any application. Additionally, a refundable deposit of two
hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) shall be deposited with the City Clerk for
purposes of ensuring compliance with the requirements of these ordinances and
reimbursement to the City for any costs incurred in remediating any condition
caused by the improper care or maintenance of a community garden.
(Ord. 2023-42. Passed 9-18-23.)
823.03   APPLICATION.
   Application for a license under this chapter shall be made on forms issued
by the City Clerk. Said application shall provide, at a minimum:
   (a)   Name of owner of property;
   (b)   Address of property to be licensed;
   (c)   Site diagram, including:
      (1)   Distance from any proposed garden plot to any primary or accessory
structure located on an adjoining parcel;
      (2)   Distance from any proposed garden plot to any adjacent roadway; and
      (3)   Dimensions of proposed plot;
   (d)   Approximate number of participants;
   (e)   An acknowledgment and consent as required by Section
823.05;
   (f)   Watering plan specifying any on-site sources of water and/or plans for
bringing water to the site; and
   (g)   Any additional information reasonably requested by the City for
purposes of evaluating and processing any application.
(Ord. 2023-42. Passed 9-18-23.)
823.04   LIABILITY INSURANCE.
   Prior to issuance of any license under this chapter, the licensee shall
deposit a certificate of insurance with the City Clerk, issued by a company
licensed to do business in the state, which shall show that the applicant has
secured, and will maintain, public liability insurance with a limit of
liability of five hundred thousand dollars ($500,000) for injuries to any one
person, and one million dollars ($1,000,000) in any one accident, and naming
the City of Freeport as additional insured.
(Ord. 2023-42. Passed 9-18-23.)
823.05   FAILURE TO MAINTAIN.
   All licensees shall be deemed on notice that the license granted hereunder
is a privilege, and the usage of a vacant lot for purposes of gardening is not
otherwise provided for by City ordinance. Licensees must expressly agree, as a
condition of the grant of a license:
   (a)   A community garden may only be kept in strict compliance with these
Codified Ordinances, including, but not limited to,
Chapter 1478 hereof.
   (b)   If any community garden is not maintained in a neat, orderly, and
weed-free manner, it will create a substantial blight on the surrounding
neighborhood and each licensee agrees that in the event the Community
Development Director determines, in his or her sole discretion, that a
community garden is not being kept in a neat, orderly, and weed-free manner,
the Community Development Director may order the destruction of the garden, in
whole or in part, and City personnel may enter onto the licensed property for
the purposes of removing vegetation.
(Ord. 2023-42. Passed 9-18-23.)
823.99   PENALTY.
   Any violation of this chapter shall be punishable by fine as set forth in
Section
202.99 of these Codified Ordinances for violations generally.
(Ord. 2023-42. Passed 9-18-23.)
CHAPTER 824:
Community Reintegration Facilities
824.01   Applicability.
824.02   License required; fee.
824.03   Requirements for licensure.
824.04   Requirements for operation.
824.05   Nuisance prohibited.
824.06   Density and proximity restrictions.
824.07   Liability insurance.
824.08   Effective period of licenses; fees.
824.01 APPLICABILITY.
   The provisions of this chapter shall apply to the operation of all community
reintegration facilities as defined in Section
1240.06(118) of these Codified Ordinances, and the term community reintegration
facility as used in this chapter shall have the same meaning as set forth in
Section
1240.06(118) and its subparts.
(Ord. 2019-12. Passed 3-4-19.)
824.02 LICENSE REQUIRED; FEE.
   No facility shall be operated as a community reintegration facility, whether
on a for-profit or not-for-profit basis, unless licensed to operate as such
pursuant to the provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. 2019-12. Passed 3-4-19.)
824.03 REQUIREMENTS FOR LICENSURE.
   No license shall be issued for the operation of a community reintegration
facility unless the requirements of this section are first met:
   (a)   Inspections Required. The following inspections shall be completed and
submitted with the permit application:
      (1)   An inspection report from the City Building Inspector indicating
that the structure in which the community reintegration facility is located
complies with all applicable provisions of the Building and Housing Code of the
City of Freeport (for purposes of Code compliance only, a community
reintegration facility may be deemed a rooming house or other similar facility
based upon actual usage);
      (2)   A health inspection report from the Stephenson County Department of
Public Health stating that the community reintegration facility complies with
applicable State and county public health statutes, laws and regulations.
   (b)   Prohibited Persons. No license may be issued to:
      (1)   A person who is not a resident of Stephenson County, Illinois;
      (2)   A person who is not of good character and reputation in the
community;
      (3)   A person who is not a citizen of the United States;
      (4)   A person who has been convicted of a felony offense under Federal
or State Law;
      (5)   A person whose license issued under this chapter has been revoked
for cause;
      (6)   A person who at the time of application for renewal of a license
hereunder would not be eligible for such a license on first application;
      (7)   Any business entity, including, but not limited to, a corporation,
limited liability company or partnership, in which more than five percent of
the ownership or control of the entity is held by any person who would not
qualify for licensure in his or her own person for any reason other than
residency within Stephenson County;
      (8)   Any business entity, or natural person whose business is conducted
by an agent, unless managed by a person who meets all requirements of a
licensee hereunder, including the residency requirement; or
      (9)   A person who does not own the premises at which the licensed
facility will be located and does not have a lease for the premises for the
entire term of the license.
   (c)   Application for License. The application for licensure shall include,
at a minimum.
      (1)   The names and addresses of the persons responsible for operation of
the facility. At a minimum, the name of the owner of the property on which the
community reintegration facility is to be located shall be provided, along with
the name, address, and telephone contact information for the on-site supervisor
or manager of the facility, if different.
      (2)   A statement as to whether the facility will be operated as a:
         A.   Community reintegration facility, substance abuse;
         B.   Community reintegration facility, ex-offender; or
      (3)   Proof of proper zoning for the requested use.
(Ord. 2019-12. Passed 3-4-19.)
824.04 REQUIREMENTS FOR OPERATION.
   At all times, all persons and organizations licensed pursuant to this
chapter shall comply with the following:
   (a)   The licensee shall notify the Chief of Police no less than seven days
prior to the introduction of a new residence into any community reintegration
facility of the resident's name, last known address, and the nature of the
program from which they are to be discharged. If a resident is being discharged
from a detention facility where the resident was being held for violation of a
criminal offense, the licensee shall include with such notice the nature of the
offense or offenses for which the resident was incarcerated.
   (b)   All relevant licenses issued by State and local jurisdictions required
for the operation of the facility shall at all times be maintained in good
standing.
   (c)   The premises on which any community reintegration facility is operated
shall be maintained in a clean and orderly fashion, and in a state of good
repair.
   (d)   The licensee shall comply with and enforce the provisions of this
chapter and report promptly to the Police Department any violations of law, or
suspected violations thereof, which may come to the licensee's attention.
   (e)   The licensee shall report to the Stephenson County Health Department
all cases of persons or animals affected, or suspected of being affected, with
any communicable disease.
   (f)   The licensee shall comply at all times with all discharge requirements
for individuals housed at the facility, including, but not limited to, all
conditions of parole, host site agreements, or treatment guidelines.
   (g)   The licensee shall maintain at all times a resident manager who is
regularly on, or frequently visits, the premises, and who is charged with the
day to day operation of the facility. The name, address, and telephone number
of the resident manager shall be placed on file with the City Clerk, and shall
be updated immediately upon any change in responsible parties.
(Ord. 2019-12. Passed 3-4-19.)
824.05 NUISANCE PROHIBITED.
   No community reintegration facility shall be operated in such a manner as to
become a public nuisance. For purposes of this section, a property shall be
considered a "public nuisance" if any of the following occur on the premises:
   (a)   Loitering, gathering, or other unauthorized assemblages or persons who
are not registered residents of the facility.
   (b)   Disturbances of the peace or any other violation of this Code or law
of the State of Illinois resulting in a response by the Freeport Police
Department occurring more than one time in a ninety day period.
(Ord. 2019-12. Passed 3-4-19.)
824.06 DENSITY AND PROXIMITY RESTRICTIONS.
   (a)   No community reintegration facility shall be allowed to be located
within 1,000 feet of another community reintegration facility.
   (b)   No community reintegration facility shall be allowed to be located
within 100 feet of any church, school, or hospital.
(Ord. 2019-12. Passed 3-4-19.)
824.07 LIABILITY INSURANCE.
   Prior to obtaining a license under this chapter, and at all times during
which a license is maintained hereunder, every community reintegration facility
shall provide the City Clerk with proof of liability insurance coverage in an
amount not less than one million dollars (US$1,000,000) per person/per
occurrence for personal injury and property damage, or two million dollars
(US$2,000,000) in combined single limits, and no less than two million dollars
(US$2,000,000) in the aggregate.
(Ord. 2019-12. Passed 3-4-19.)
824.08 EFFECTIVE PERIOD OF LICENSES; FEES.
   The term of an annual license issued pursuant to this chapter shall be from
May 1 in any given year to April 30 of the following year. The annual license
fee shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00). The initial license term shall be
from the date of the issuance of the license to the following May 1. The
initial license fee shall be a proration of the annual license fee based on the
months and fraction thereof of the term of the initial license. A licensee in
good standing may renew his or her license by paying the annual fee not later
than March 31 in any year, provided that upon payment of such fee. Provided,
that upon application, the City Manager may allow the fee to be waived or
reduced for a not-for-profit enterprise as provided for in Section
802.07.
(Ord. 2019-12. Passed 3-4-19.)
CHAPTER 826
Dances and Dance Halls
826.01   Definitions.
826.02   License required; fee.
826.03   Prohibited hours.
826.04   Intoxicated persons; disorderly conduct.
826.05   Lighting.
826.06   Exemption of religious, charitable or educational organizations or
institutions.
826.07   Liability insurance.
826.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Employment of children - see 720 ILCS 150/1, 150/5
   Dance Studio Act - see 815 ILCS 610/1 et seq.
   Teen dance centers - see B.R. & T.
Ch. 869
   Theaters and shows - see B.R. & T.
Ch. 870
   Special events - see S.U. & P.S.
Ch. 1030
826.01 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   "Public dance" means any dance which is or may be attended or
patronized by the public generally, and for which a charge or fee is made for
admission or for the privilege of dancing.
   (b)   "Public dance hall" means any place or premises where the public is
admitted and where dancing is regularly allowed or permitted and for which a
charge or fee for admission, or for the privilege of dancing, is made
regularly, meaning at least four times per year.
(1977 Code § 9-801; Ord. 2012-26. Passed 5-7-12.)
826.02 LICENSE REQUIRED; FEE.
   No person shall conduct or operate a public dance hall, or public dance,
without first obtaining a license therefor.
   The initial and annual license fees shall be as stated in
Chapter 802.
(1977 Code §§ 9-802, 9-803; Ord. 2012-26. Passed 5-7-12.)
826.03 PROHIBITED HOURS.
   No licensee shall permit dancing between 1:00 a.m. and 7:00 a.m.
(1977 Code § 9-804)
826.04 INTOXICATED PERSONS; DISORDERLY CONDUCT.
   No licensee shall admit persons under the influence of liquor or permit any
person to engage in disorderly conduct or in any lewd or lascivious behavior.
(1977 Code § 9-805)
826.05 LIGHTING.
   All public dance halls and public dances shall be brightly lighted during
all times when open to the public.
(1977 Code § 9-806)
826.06 EXEMPTION OF RELIGIOUS, CHARITABLE OR EDUCATIONAL ORGANIZATIONS OR
INSTITUTIONS.
   The provisions of this chapter shall not be applicable to a dance conducted
by a religious, charitable or educational organization or institution.
(1977 Code § 9-807)
826.07 LIABILITY INSURANCE.
   A licensee shall deposit a certificate of insurance with the License
Officer, issued by a company licensed to do business in the State, which shall
show that the applicant has secured, and will maintain, public liability
insurance with a limit of liability of three hundred thousand dollars
($300,000) for injuries to any one person, or one million dollars ($1,000,000)
in any one accident.
(Ord. 2012-26. Passed 5-7-12.)
826.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
202.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
CHAPTER 830
Foreign Fire Insurance Companies
830.01   Foreign Fire Insurance Board.
830.02   Tax or license fees.
830.03   Reports by agents; payment of fees.
830.04   Disposition of moneys.
830.05   Incorporation of applicable statutory provisions.
830.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Foreign fire insurance company fees - see 65 ILCS 5/11-10-1 et seq.
   Certificates of authority - see 215 ILCS 5/109 et seq.
   Fire Department - see ADM.
Ch. 242
   BOCA National Fire Prevention Code - see F.P.
Ch. 1610
   NFPA Life Safety Code - see F.P.
Ch. 1620
830.01 FOREIGN FIRE INSURANCE BOARD.
   (a)   Establishment. There is hereby established a Foreign Fire Insurance
Board.
   (b)   Definitions. For purposes of establishing a Foreign Fire Insurance
Board, the following definitions shall apply:
      (1)   "Board" means the Foreign Fire Insurance Board.
      (2)   "Department" means the Freeport Fire Department.
      (3)   "Fund" means the Foreign Fire Insurance Tax Fund.
      (4)   "Members of the Department" means any person currently employed by
the Freeport Fire Department in the following ranks: Firefighter, Lieutenant,
Captain, Deputy Chief and Fire Chief.
      (5)   "Temporary Election Committee" means the Freeport Fire Department
Election Committee.
   (c)   Composition; Election of Members; Terms; Vacancies.
      (1)   The Foreign Fire Insurance Board shall consist of five members with
one vote each. The members of the Freeport Fire Department shall elect four
officers who shall serve as the members of the Board. The fifth position shall
be filled by the Chief of the Fire Department.
      (2)   The members of the Board shall elect the following officers:
         A.   Chairperson;
         B.   Vice-Chairperson;
         C.   Treasurer; and
         D.   Secretary.
      (3)   Elected members of the Board shall serve two-year terms and until
their successors are elected and installed. The initial terms of office of the
elected members of the Board shall begin on May 1, 1992, and shall expire on
April 30 of the applicable year as follows: the first Board elected will
consist of two members elected for two years, and two members elected for one
year.
      (4)   Vacancies shall be filled by election of the members of the
Department for the balance of the unexpired term, if more than three months
remain in the term of the member leaving the Board.
   (d)   Establishment of Temporary Election Committee; Election Procedure.
      (1)   There is hereby established a Temporary Election Committee. The
Temporary Election Committee shall consist of three members: the Chief of the
Fire Department, the President of Local 441 and one other member to be
appointed jointly by the Chief and the President to serve on the Committee, who
shall be a member of the Department.
      (2)   The Temporary Election Committee shall be responsible for
organizing, conducting and supervising the initial election of Department
members to serve on the Board. The Temporary Election Committee shall establish
election procedures consistent with this section. Thereafter, the elected Board
shall establish its own election procedures consistent with this section.
      (3)   The Board shall develop a procedure for governing the nomination of
members to serve on the Board. The nominating procedure shall be established a
minimum of thirty days prior to the expiration of the Board members' terms of
office.
      (4)   The Board shall develop a procedure for the final election of
Department members on the Board. The final election procedure shall be
established a minimum of thirty days prior to the expiration of the Board
members' terms of office.
      (5)   The Board may adopt rules and regulations governing the election of
officers of the Board. All rules and regulations with respect to the election
process shall be posted throughout the Department a minimum of thirty days
prior to the election.
   (e)   Foreign Fire Insurance Tax Fund Established.
      (1)   All funds received by the City from foreign fire insurance gross
receipts tax shall be deposited (upon receipt of such funds) in a special fund
within the City Treasury called the Foreign Fire Insurance Tax Fund.
      (2)   The City shall provide the Treasurer of the Board with a monthly
accounting of receipts and expenditures of the Fund.
      (3)   No expenditure shall be made from the Fund without the majority
approval of the Board at a regular or special meeting held in accordance with
applicable State and local laws.
      (4)   The Treasurer of the Board shall notify the Finance Director or his
or her designee of expenditures authorized by the Board, and such expenditures
shall be paid from the Fund by the Finance Director or his or her designee.
      (5)   The Treasurer of the Board shall give sufficient bond to the City.
This bond shall be approved by the City Manager.
      (6)   This Fund shall be included in the annual audit of City funds.
   (f)   Meetings; Quorum.
      (1)   The Board shall, in accordance with the Open Meetings Act, as
amended, establish a regular time and place for its meetings. The Chairperson
shall preside at the meetings. The Secretary shall keep a record of all
resolutions, proceedings, minutes and actions of the Board, and these records
shall be open to the public.
      (2)   Three members of the Board shall constitute a quorum for the
transaction of its business. The affirmative vote of three members of the Board
shall constitute approval of business before it.
      (3)   Special meetings may be called by the Chairperson, or by no less
than three members of the Board.
      (4)   Members on duty at the time of any meeting of the Board shall be
excused from duty to attend such meetings.
   (g)   Powers and Duties; Rules and Regulations.
      (1)   The Board shall have the power to approve the expenditure of moneys
from the Foreign Fire Insurance Tax Fund solely for the maintenance, use and
benefit of the Fire Department.
      (2)   The Board may adopt rules and regulations for governing itself and
for the execution of its duties, and may provide for election of its members
and management of the Fund.
      (3)   The Board may amend or revoke rules and regulations so adopted.
      (4)   The Board shall, in accordance with City budget and appropriations
procedures, annually prepare a budget for the Fund, which shall be considered
by Council together with the Fire Department budget, and the approved
expenditures of the Fund shall be included in the annual appropriation
ordinance.
      (5)   All purchases authorized by the Board shall be made only after
strict compliance with the competitive bidding and the open market procedures
set forth in Chapter 238 of these Codified Ordinances, except that the Board
shall not be required to procure City Manager approval of any purchase for
which a current appropriation exists which is sufficient to pay such purchase
price in full.
      (6)   The Board shall not authorize a purchase in excess of the current
appropriation for such purpose without first obtaining from Council an
amendment of the current annual appropriation ordinance.
(Ord. 92-5. Passed 3-16-92; Ord. 97-21. Passed 7-21-97; Ord. 2017-56. Passed 7-
17-17.)
830.02 TAX OR LICENSE FEES.
   Effective on or before January 1, 1998, all corporations, companies and
associations not incorporated under the laws of the State, and which are
engaged in the City in effecting fire insurance, shall pay to the Finance
Director or his or her designee the sum of two percent of the gross receipts
received by the agencies of such corporations, companies and associations in
the City. Such corporations, companies and associations shall pay such sum at
such rate of two percent upon the amount of all premiums which, during every
year ending on July 1, shall have been received for any insurance effected, or
agreed to be effected, in such City by, or with, such corporations, companies
and associations.
(Ord. 97-21. Passed 7-21-97.)
830.03 REPORTS BY AGENTS; PAYMENT OF FEES.
   (a)   Every person who shall act in the City as an agent or otherwise, for
or on behalf of any corporation, company or association provided for in Section
830.02, shall, on or before July 15 of each year, render to the City Clerk a
full, true and just account, verified by his or her oath, of all the premiums
which during the year ending on every July 1, preceding such report, shall have
been received by him or her, or any other person for him or her, on behalf of
any such corporation, company or association, and shall specify in such report
the amount received for fire insurance.
   (b)   Effective on or before January 1, 1998, such agent shall also pay to
the Finance Director or his or her designee, at the time of rendering the
aforesaid report, the amount of rates herein fixed for which the companies,
corporations or associations represented by him or her are severally chargeable
as provided in this section. If such account is not rendered on or before the
day herein designated for that purpose, or if such rates shall remain unpaid
after that day, it shall be unlawful for any corporation, company or
association so in default to transact any business of insurance in the City
until the requisition shall have been fully complied with, provided that no
provision of this chapter shall relieve any company, corporation or association
from the payment of any risk that may be taken in violation hereof.
(1977 Code §§ 26-402, 26-403; Ord. 97-21. Passed 7-21-97.)
830.04 DISPOSITION OF MONEYS.
   Effective on or before January 1, 1998, any and all sums received under the
provisions of this chapter shall be deposited by the Finance Director and the
Treasurer of the Foreign Fire Insurance Board for the use and benefit of the
Foreign Fire Insurance Board of the City in accordance with the provisions of
this chapter.
(Ord. 97-21. Passed 7-21-97; Ord. 2018-67. Passed 12-17-18.)
830.05 INCORPORATION OF APPLICABLE STATUTORY PROVISIONS.
   All pertinent and applicable provisions of 65 ILCS 5/11-10-1 and 11-10-3, as
heretofore and hereafter amended, are incorporated herein by reference, subject
to the provisions of Section
202.05(b) of the Administration Code.
830.99 PENALTY.
   If any person, agent, corporation, company or association fails to render
the report or account required by this chapter, or if the tax or license fees
provided for in this chapter remain unpaid after the day designated, to wit,
July 15, every such person, agent, corporation, company or association shall
forfeit and pay to the City, upon conviction, the sum of two hundred dollars
($200.00) for each and every offense. In addition to such penalty, the City
shall recover in an action in its name, for its use, against such person,
agent, corporation, company or association so failing to make such report, or
pay such license fee or tax, the full amount of such license fee or tax which
would be due under the provisions of this chapter.
(1977 Code § 26-404)
CHAPTER 832
Fortunetelling
832.01   Fortunetelling for remuneration prohibited.
832.02   Application of chapter.
832.03   Advertising.
832.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
    Theft by deception - see 720 ILCS 5/16-1
    Fraud generally - see GEN. OFF.
Ch. 686
832.01 FORTUNETELLING FOR REMUNERATION PROHIBITED.
   No person shall obtain money or property from another by holding himself or
herself out as skilled in fortunetelling by means of card reading, palmistry,
clairvoyancy, astrology, spirit and mediumship or any other practice or
pretense of the exercise of occult or psychic powers.
(1977 Code § 46-105)
832.02 APPLICATION OF CHAPTER.
   (a)   Religious Activity. The provisions of Section
832.01 shall not prohibit or interfere with the exercise of the spiritual
functions or offices of any priest, minister or accredited representative of
any religion.
   (b)   Spiritualism. The provisions of Section
832.01 shall not prohibit the practice of the belief known as spiritualism, or
any attempted communication with the spirit world by or through so-called
mediums.
(1977 Code §§ 46-106, 46-107)
832.03 ADVERTISING.
   No person shall print, publish, distribute or circulate, or cause to be
printed, published, circulated or advertised, in any newspaper, periodical,
magazine or other publication, or by display signs, circulars, handbills or any
other means, any advertisement of any person's ability, skill or power in
telling fortunes or revealing the future, or offering advice of any kind or
nature by means of occult or psychic powers, faculties or forces.
(1977 Code § 46-108)
832.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
202.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
CHAPTER 836
Hotels and Motels
836.01   Definitions.

   CROSS REFERENCES
   Hotels and motels - see 740 ILCS 90/1 et seq.
   Stephenson County Convention and Visitors Bureau - see ADM.
Ch. 286
   Bed and breakfast establishments - see B.R. & T.
Ch. 810
   Hotel tax - see B.R. & T.
Ch. 886
836.01 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   "Accommodation" means any unit, or combination of units, set aside as
a rental unit.
   (b)   "Advertising sign" means any sign within the City limits visible to a
passerby, located outside of a motel, advertising rates and other information
pertaining to the motel.
   (c)   "Auto tourist" or "transient" means any person who uses lodging space
in a motel.
   (d)   "Hotel" means any building or buildings in which the public may, for a
consideration, obtain living quarters or sleeping or housekeeping
accommodations. The term includes inns, motels, tourist homes or courts,
lodging houses, rooming houses, and apartment houses.
   (e)   "Motel" means a series of attached, semi-attached or detached dwelling
units with separate entrances, operated as a single business, containing
individual sleeping or living units with bathrooms and closet space, with or
without kitchens, designed for, or used by, automobile tourists and transients,
with convenient access to a parking space for the use of guests and direct and
convenient access to a traveled road, and maintained as accommodations for auto
tourists and transients by the day, week or month.
   (f)   "Occupancy" means the use or possession, or the right to the use or
possession, of any room or rooms in a hotel for any purpose, or the right to
the use or possession of the furnishings or to the services and accommodations
accompanying the use and possession of the room or rooms.
   (g)   "Owner" and "operator" mean the owner, manager, tenant or person in
charge of a motel.
   (h)   "Rent" and "rental" mean the consideration received for occupancy,
valued in money, whether received in money or otherwise, including all
receipts, cash, credits and property or services of any kind or nature.
   (i)   "Room" and "rooms" mean any living quarters or sleeping or
housekeeping accommodations.
   (j)   "Unit" means a room, or suite of rooms, in a motel, designed for
occupation for living or sleeping purposes.
(1977 Code §§ 9-1201, 31-202; Ord. 2020-10. Passed 3-2-20)
836.02 MANAGEMENT.
   (a)   Office Building; Posting of Chapter. In every motel there shall be an
office building in which shall be located the office of the owner of the motel.
A copy of this chapter shall be posted therein, and the motel register shall at
all times be kept in such office.
   (b)   Duties of Owner. The owner shall:
      (1)   Keep a register of guests, open at all times to inspection by City,
State and Federal officers, showing, for all guests:
         A.   The name and address of each guest;
         B.   The dates of entrance and departure of each guest; and
         C.   The license number and the make, type and licensing state of
every automobile;
      (2)   Maintain the motel in a clean, orderly and sanitary condition at
all times;
      (3)   Comply with and enforce this chapter and report promptly to the
Police Department any violations of law which may come to his or her attention;
      (4)   Report to the Stephenson County Sanitarian all cases of persons or
animals affected, or suspected of being affected, with any communicable
disease;
      (5)   Prevent the running at large of dogs, cats or other animals or
pets;
      (6)   Maintain, in convenient places approved by the Fire Department,
hand fire extinguishers in good operating condition;
      (7)   Prohibit the lighting of open fires on the premises;
      (8)   Prohibit the use of any motel unit by a greater number of occupants
than that which it is designed to accommodate;
      (9)   Not rent any room or rooms more than once between the hours of 8:00
p.m. and 6:00 a.m. of the next day; and
      (10)   Not rent any motel, hotel, lodging house, rooming house or other
place where transients are accommodated in violation of this chapter.
(1977 Code §§ 9-1203, 31-103, 31-105)
836.03 SITE PLANS.
   Structures and other improvements shall be built or installed in accordance
with a site plan approved by the Planning Commission with respect to the
location of structures, the layout and improvement of off-street parking and
loading areas, the location and width of driveways, ingress and egress to and
from the site, the location and planting of landscaped areas and the location
and design of lighting and signs.
(1977 Code § 9-1204)
836.04 DRAINAGE; GRADING.
   Every motel shall be located on a well-drained area, and the premises shall
be properly graded, or tubed, so as to prevent the accumulation of storm or
other waters.
(1977 Code § 9-1205)
836.05 DRIVEWAYS AND PARKING AREAS.
   All units shall face on a driveway giving easy access to a public street.
Driveways and parking areas shall be paved and maintained in good condition, be
well lighted at night and not be obstructed. Lighting as provided in this
section shall be installed so as to prevent glare into abutting properties.
Bumper rails shall be provided where needed for safety or to protect property.
(1977 Code § 9-1206)
836.06 PARKING SPACES.
   A motel shall be provided with at least one parking space for each unit,
plus one space for the owner, and sufficient space for the maneuvering of
vehicles on the site.
(1977 Code § 9-1207)
836.07 WINDOWS.
   (a)   Generally. Each unit shall have at least two windows, located on
separate walls, preferably opposite. The total window area shall be at least
four square feet per person, when open for ventilation, and no unit shall have
less than twelve square feet of window area.
   (b)   Toilet Room Windows. The toilet room in each motel unit shall have at
least one window or sky light opening to the outside with an area of not less
than two square feet, so constructed that it can be opened for ventilation, or
an alternative ventilating system approved by the Building Commissioner.
(1977 Code §§9-1208, 9-1209; Ord. 94-97. Passed 11-7-94; Ord. 2013-10. Passed
3-4-13.)
836.08 SCREENING; CONSTRUCTION OF OFF-STREET PARKING AREAS.
   Whenever a motel site adjoins a residential area, a suitable wall or fence
not less than five feet in height shall be erected, and off-street parking
areas shall be constructed in compliance with the Zoning Code. Within a
required front yard, or within fifty feet of a street intersection, the height
of the wall or fence shall be limited to three and one-half feet.
(1977 Code § 9-1210)
836.09 SIGNS; ADVERTISING.
   (a)   No sign shall be illuminated unless the source of light is steady and
suitably shielded, and if there is an adjoining residential area, the lighting
shall be deflected away from it so as to eliminate annoying glare.
   (b)   No sign shall be located less than ten feet from the front or side lot
except where affixed to the wall of the building and not extending over the
sidewalk.
   (c)   No owner of a motel shall charge a price greater than the
accommodation price advertised on the outdoor signs, or as set out on the rate
cards displayed in each room.
   (d)   No owner of a motel shall post, or allow to remain posted, on any
outdoor advertising sign rates for accommodation unless there shall be
accommodation available for immediate occupancy at the rate posted on such
sign.
   (e)   No owner of a motel shall make an extra charge for the use of
appliances or facilities such as air-conditioning, television, fans, radio, or
swimming pool, unless such extra charge is clearly shown on an advertising
sign.
(1977 Code § 9-1211)
836.10 REQUIRED FACILITIES.
   Each motel unit shall have a complete bathroom, including flush toilet,
sink, bath or shower. Floors of bathrooms shall be constructed of concrete,
tile or similar materials which are impervious to water and shall be pitched to
a floor drain. Each bathroom shall be provided with an adequate supply of hot
and cold running water, soap, individual or paper towels and toiler paper at
all times. Each motel unit containing a kitchen shall be provided with a
kitchen sink constructed of non-absorbent material and supplied at all times
with hot and cold running water.
(1977 Code § 9-1212)
836.11 REGISTRATION UNDER FICTITIOUS NAMES.
   No person shall write, or knowingly permit to be written, in any register in
any motel, hotel, lodging house, rooming house or other place where transients
are accommodated, any other or different name or designation than the true name
of such person so registered therein, or the name by which such person is
generally known.
(1977 Code § 31-101)
836.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
202.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
CHAPTER 838
Junk Dealers
838.01   License required; fee.
838.02   Register of purchases; inspection by Police Department.
838.03   Enclosure of premises required.
838.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   License and regulation by municipalities - see 65 ILCS 5/11-42-3
   Receiving property from minors - see 720 ILCS 345/1, 345/2
   Inoperable motor vehicles - see GEN. OFF.
Ch. 638
   Secondhand store dealers prohibited to act as junk dealers - see B.R. & T.
860.03
838.01 LICENSE REQUIRED; FEE.
   No person shall carry on the business of buying or selling old iron, rags,
metals or other junk, either at an established place of business or by going
from house to house, without a license as a junk dealer.
   The annual fee for such license shall be fifty dollars ($50.00), plus
twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for each separate or branch yard or storage lot.
(1977 Code §§ 9-901, 9-902)
838.02 REGISTER OF PURCHASES; INSPECTION BY POLICE DEPARTMENT.
   Every licensee shall keep a register of the names of all persons from whom
any iron or other metals, rags, old rope or other junk are purchased, the date
when purchased and the full description of the article so purchased.
   Such register shall be open to inspection by the Police Department, which
may enter the premises of a licensee and examine any articles belonging to, or
temporarily left in charge of, such licensee.
(1977 Code § 9-903)
838.03 ENCLOSURE OF PREMISES REQUIRED.
   All licensed premises shall be kept enclosed within a building or a fence so
that junk is not exposed to public view. No person shall permit junk to be
outside such enclosure.
(1977 Code § 9-904)
838.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
202.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
CHAPTER 840
Garage Sales
840.01   Definitions.
840.02   Property permitted to be sold.
840.03   Limitation on number of sales.
840.04   Days and hours of operation.
840.05   Display of sale property.
840.06   Display of signs.
840.07   Maintenance of order.
840.08   Parking.
840.09   City wide sale.
840.99   Penalty.
840.01 DEFINITIONS.
   For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have
the meanings, and are hereby defined, as follows:
   (a)   "Garage sale." Includes all general sales open to the public,
conducted from a residential premise for the purpose of disposing of personal
property including, but not limited to, all sales entitled "garage", "lawn",
"yard", "attic", "porch", "room", "backyard", "patio", "flea market", or
"rummage" sale.
   (b)   "Personal property." Property which is owned, utilized and maintained
by an individual or members of his or her residence and acquired in the normal
course of living in or maintaining a residence. It does not include merchandise
which was purchased for resale or obtained on consignment.
(Ord. 2006-56. Passed 10-16-06.)
840.02 PROPERTY PERMITTED TO BE SOLD.
   It shall be unlawful for any individual to sell or offer for sale, under
authority granted by this chapter, property other than personal property.
However, members of more than one residence may join in a garage sale to be
conducted at the residence of one of them.
(Ord. 2006-56. Passed 10-16-06.)
840.03 LIMITATION ON NUMBER OF SALES.
   No more than three garage sales may be conducted at any one residence, or by
members of one residence and/or family household during any calendar year. If
members of more than one residence join in conducting a garage sale, then said
garage sale shall be considered as one garage sale toward the annual limit of
three for each and all participating residences.
(Ord. 2006-56. Passed 10-16-06.)
840.04 DAYS AND HOURS OF OPERATION.
   Garage sales shall be conducted only on Thursdays, Fridays, and Saturdays,
from the hours of 8:00 a.m. to 6:00 p.m. and are limited to no more than three
consecutive days.
(Ord. 2006-56. Passed 10-16-06.)
840.05 DISPLAY OF SALE PROPERTY.
   Personal property offered for sale may be displayed within the residence, in
a garage, driveway, carport and/or a front or rear yard. No personal property
offered for a sale at a garage sale shall be displayed in any public right-of-
way.
(Ord. 2006-56. Passed 10-16-06.)
840.06 DISPLAY OF SIGNS.
   (a)   No more than two garage sale signs which advertise a garage sale may
be used provided that:
      (1)   Such signs do not exceed six square feet each;
      (2)   Signs are located with no more than one sign per lot of frontage
either on the premises conducting the garage sale or on other private property
with that property owner's permission; and
      (3)   Signs must be removed within twenty-four hours of the conclusion of
garage sale.
   (b)   No sign shall be posted within the public right-of-way or any City
street or thoroughfare, or on any sign post, utility pole, or tree.
(Ord. 2006-56. Passed 10-16-06.)
840.07 MAINTENANCE OF ORDER.
   The individual conducting the garage sale and the owner or tenant of the
premises on which such sale or activity is conducted shall be responsible for
the maintenance of good order on the premises during such sale. In the event
good order is not maintained or the sale shall violate any of the provisions of
this chapter, the person violating the provisions of this chapter shall be
subject to the penalties provided in accord with Section
840.11.
(Ord. 2006-56. Passed 10-16-06.)
840.08 PARKING.
   The Police Department may enforce temporary traffic and parking controls to
alleviate any traffic hazards or congestion created by a garage sale.
(Ord. 2006-56. Passed 10-16-06.)
840.09 CITY WIDE SALE.
   There shall be two City wide garage sale weekends per calendar year. These
City wide garage sales shall be set for the three days beginning on the third
Thursday in June and the three days beginning on the third Thursday in
September. The City wide garage sale weekends shall not be counted toward the
maximum of three garage sales authorized in Section
840.03.
(Ord. 2006-56. Passed 10-16-06.)
840.99 PENALTY.
   Any person violating any section of this chapter shall be subject to a fine
of not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) and not more than five hundred dollars
($500.00). Each day that a garage sale is conducted in violation of this
chapter shall constitute a separate offense.
(Ord. 2006-56. Passed 10-16-06.)
CHAPTER 842
Master Antenna Television Collection and Distribution System
842.01   Granting of franchises.
842.02   Television defined.

842.10   Inconvenience to public during maintenance and construction; street
openings; barricades and warning lights.
842.11   Restoration of surfaces.
842.12   Relocation of portions of the system upon alterations or changes of
streets, alleys, etc.
842.13   Temporary movement of lines.
842.14   Service requirements.
842.15   City regulations.
842.16   Indemnification; insurance requirements.

   Interfering with television broadcasts - see GEN. OFF.
664.05,
664.06
   Cable television - see B.R. & T.
Ch. 816
   Telecommunications infrastructure maintenance fee - see B.R. & T.
Ch. 891
   Satellite dishes or antennae in yards - see P. & Z.
1268.02(j)
842.01 GRANTING OF FRANCHISES.
   In consideration of the faithful performance and observance of the
conditions and reservations herein specified, and in consideration of the
payment of the amounts provided herein, the City may, from time to time, grant
to qualified persons, firms or corporations, the right to erect, maintain and
operate a master antenna television collection and distribution system, and
facilities and extensions thereto, in, under, over, along and upon streets,
lanes, avenues, sidewalks, alleys and other public places within designated
neighborhoods and areas in the City solely for the purpose of transmission and
distribution of audio and visual impulses and television energy, as hereinafter
defined and restricted, in accordance with the laws and regulations of the
United States of America and the State of Illinois and with the ordinances and
regulations of the City, for the period provided for in this chapter.
(1977 Code § 43-101)
842.02 TELEVISION DEFINED.
   Whenever used in this chapter, the word "television" shall mean a system for
the transmission of audio signals and visual images by means of electrical
impulses solely for the purposes specified in Section
842.01.
(1977 Code § 43-102)
842.03 USE OF EXISTING POLES AND APPURTENANCES.
   (a)   To the extent possible, the franchisee shall make attachment to poles
already in existence within the City. To the extent that existing poles are
insufficient for its purposes, or if the franchisee is unable to negotiate
agreements satisfactory to it providing for the use of existing poles, the
franchisee shall have the right to erect and maintain its own poles, as
necessary for the construction and maintenance of its television distribution
system, with the approval of the location of such poles by the Public Works
Director.
   (b)   It is the stated intention of the City that all holders of public
licenses and franchises within the corporate limits of the City shall cooperate
with the franchisee to allow its usage of their poles and pole line facilities
wherever possible and wherever such usage does not interfere with the normal
operation of said poles and pole lines, so that the number of new or additional
poles constructed by the franchisee within the City may be minimized.
(1977 Code §§ 43-103, 43-105; Ord. 94-80. Passed 9-19-94.)
842.04 OBSTRUCTION AND INTERFERENCE BY THE TRANSMISSION AND DISTRIBUTION
SYSTEM.
   The franchisee's transmission and distribution system poles, wires and
appurtenances shall be located, erected and maintained so as not to endanger or
interfere with the lives of persons, to interfere with new improvements the
City may deem proper to make or to hinder or obstruct unnecessarily the free
use of the streets, alleys, bridges or other public property.
(1977 Code § 43-104)
842.05 USE OF POLES BY CITY.
   The franchisee shall extend to the City, free of expense, joint use of any
and all poles owned by it for any proper Municipal purpose insofar as may be
accomplished without interference with the use and enjoyment of the
franchisee's own wires and fixtures. The City shall hold the franchisee
harmless from any and all actions caused by the placement of the City's wires
or appurtenances upon the poles of the franchisee.
(1977 Code § 43-106)
842.06 TREE TRIMMING; AUTHORITY OF FORESTRY COMMISSION.
   The franchisee shall have the authority, subject to jurisdiction of the
Forestry Commission, to trim trees upon and overhanging all streets, alleys,
easements, sidewalks and other public places within City so as to prevent the
branches of such trees from coming into contact with the equipment of the
franchisee.
(1977 Code § 43-107)
842.07 PLACEMENT, REMOVAL OR RELOCATION OF TRANSMISSION EQUIPMENT.
   The City reserves the right to require the franchisee to place conductors
underground and to designate the districts in which such work shall be
performed, and also to order the removal or relocation of poles, wires and
other appurtenances erected by the franchisee whenever, in the judgment of the
City Manager, such action is in the public interest. The franchisee shall
forthwith comply with any and all instructions and directives in such matters,
at its own expense.
(1977 Code §43-108) (Ord. 2017-56. Passed 7-17-17.)
842.08 CONSTRUCTION AND MAINTENANCE STANDARDS; COMPLIANCE WITH NATIONAL
ELECTRICAL CODE.
   Construction and maintenance of the transmission distribution system,
including house connections, shall be in accordance with the provisions of the
National Electrical Code, as adopted in Section
1426.01 of the Building and Housing Code, and such applicable ordinances and
regulations of the City affecting electrical installations which may be, from
time to time, in effect.
(1977 Code § 43-109)
842.09 UNIFORM HARDWARE.
   Installation and housedrop hardware shall be uniform throughout the City,
except that the franchisee shall be free to change its hardware and
installation procedure to keep abreast of technological changes.
(1977 Code § 43-110)
842.10 INCONVENIENCE TO PUBLIC DURING MAINTENANCE AND CONSTRUCTION; STREET
OPENINGS; BARRICADES AND WARNING LIGHTS.
   In the maintenance and operation of the television transmission and
distribution system and in the course of any new construction or addition to
its facilities, the franchisee shall proceed so as to cause the least possible
inconvenience to the general public. Any opening or obtrusion in the streets or
other public places made by the franchisee in the course of its operations
shall be guarded and protected at all times by the placement of adequate
barriers, fences or boardings, the bounds of which, during periods of dusk and
darkness, shall be clearly designated by red warning lights
(1977 Code § 43-111)
842.11 RESTORATION OF SURFACES.
   In case of any disturbance of pavement, sidewalks, driveways or other
surfaces, the franchisee shall, at its own expense and in a manner approved by
the City, remove, replace and restore all pavement, sidewalks, driveways or
surfaces so disturbed in as good condition as before said work was commenced.
(1977 Code § 43-112)
842.12 RELOCATION OF PORTIONS OF THE SYSTEM UPON ALTERATIONS OR CHANGES OF
STREETS, ALLEYS, ETC.
   In the event that the City shall elect to alter or change any street, alley,
easement or other public way requiring the relocation of the facilities of the
franchisee, the franchisee, upon reasonable notice by the City, shall remove
and relocate the same at its own expense.
(1977 Code § 43-113)
842.13 TEMPORARY MOVEMENT OF LINES.
   The franchisee shall, when necessary, on the request of any person holding
an appropriate permit issued by the City, temporarily raise or lower its lines
to permit the moving of any building or other structure. The actual expense of
such temporary removal shall be paid by the person requesting the same, and the
franchisee shall have the right to require such payment in advance of such
temporary removal.
(1977 Code § 43-114)
842.14 SERVICE REQUIREMENTS.
   (a)   Required Channels and Radio Bands. The franchisee shall construct an
all-bands system capable of providing twelve channels of television reception
and the entire FM radio band to its subscribers, and installation and
maintenance of equipment shall be such that standard color signals shall be
transmitted to subscribers.
   (b)   Interruption of Service for Repairs, Installations, etc. Whenever it
is necessary to shut off or interrupt service for the purpose of making
repairs, installations or adjustments, the franchisee shall do so at such times
as will cause the least amount of inconvenience to its customers, and unless
such interruption is of short duration or is unforeseen and immediately
necessary, it shall give reasonable notice thereof to its customers.
   (c)   Service Rules. The franchisee shall have the right to prescribe the
reasonable service rules and regulations for the conduct of its business, not
inconsistent with the provisions of this chapter. Such rules shall be filed
with the City Clerk, shall be effective as of the date of such filing and shall
be subject to approval or disapproval by Council within six months after such
filing.
   (d)   Picture Quality. The franchisee shall design and maintain its
distribution system so as to present to all of its subscribers pictures of
substantially the same quality as it receives at its antennas.
   (e)   Limits of Service Area. The franchisee shall service only the area or
neighborhood described in the franchise grant and only subscribers who are
residents of public housing in the City. The franchisee may contract directly
with the residents in said area or with the owner and operator of the public
housing.
(1977 Code §§ 43-115 to 43-119)
842.15 CITY REGULATIONS.
   The franchisee shall, at all times during the term hereof, be subject to the
lawful exercise of its police power by the City and to such reasonable
regulations as the City shall hereafter, by resolution or ordinance, provide.
(1977 Code § 43-120)
842.16 INDEMNIFICATION; INSURANCE REQUIREMENTS.
   The franchisee shall indemnify, protect and save harmless the City from and
against losses and physical damage to property and bodily injury or death to
persons, including payments made under any workmen's compensation law which may
arise out of, or be caused by, the erection, maintenance, presence, use or
removal of attachments on poles within the City, or by any act of the
franchisee, its agents or employees. The franchisee shall carry insurance to
protect the parties hereto from and against all claims, demands, actions,
judgments, costs, expenses and liabilities which may arise or result, directly
or indirectly, from, or by reason of such loss, injury or damage. The amounts
of such insurance against liability due to physical damage to property shall
not be less than one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000) as to any one person,
and not less than three hundred thousand ($300,000) as to any one accident. All
insurance thus required shall be and remain in full force and effect for the
entire term of the franchise. The policy or policies of insurance, or a
certificate thereof, shall be deposited with and kept on file by the City
Clerk.
(1977 Code § 43-121)
842.17 EFFECTIVE DATE AND DURATION OF FRANCHISES.
   The rights granted hereunder shall take effect and be in full force from and
after the date of acceptance by the franchisee, and shall continue in full
force and effect for a term of fifteen years from the date of acceptance by the
franchisee.
(1977 Code § 43-122)
842.18 COMPENSATION OF CITY; REPORTING OF ANNUAL GROSS RECEIPTS; BOOKS AND
RECORDS; INSPECTIONS AND AUDITS.
   (a)   In further consideration of the granting of a franchise, the
franchisee will pay to the City five percent of the annual gross revenues
received by the franchisee from monthly service charges to subscribers who are
serviced by any lines, cables or equipment which travel over, under or above
public streets or public ways. Quarterly payments will be made within thirty
days after the close of each calendar year.
   (b)   In keeping with the above, and as of the close of business at the end
of each calendar year, the franchisee shall compile a report of annual gross
receipts as provided in subsection (a) hereof. The report shall be delivered to
the City Clerk within thirty days following the close of such calendar year.
   (c)   The franchisee shall keep full and accurate books and records of
accounts. The duly authorized agent of the City shall have the right, power and
authority to inspect and audit the current records of gross revenues of the
franchisee at any reasonable time. The City shall have the right, at its own
expense, to audit the records of gross revenues of the franchisee for any
annual period at any reasonable time within three years after expiration of
such annual period.
(1977 Code §§ 43-123 to 43-125)
842.19 SELLING, RENTING OR REPAIRING TELEVISION RECEIVERS.
   As a condition of this chapter, the franchisee agrees that neither it nor
its employees, agents or subsidiaries will engage in the business of the sale,
rental or repair of television receivers. Any service furnished by the
franchisee to the subscriber shall terminate at the point of connection of the
franchisee's facilities to the subscriber's receiver.
(1977 Code § 43-126)
842.20 PAY TELEVISION.
   The franchisee shall not engage in the pay television business or in any
variation thereof, defined as a service wherein programs are sold on a "per
program" basis and delivered to the subscriber's television set.
(1977 Code § 43-127)
842.21 VIOLATIONS; FORFEITURE OF FRANCHISE.
   If a franchisee violates any of the terms, conditions or provisions of this
chapter, or if the franchisee fails to comply with any reasonable provisions of
any ordinance of the City, and should the franchisee continue to violate the
same for a period of thirty days after the franchisee shall have been notified,
in writing, by the City to desist from such violations, the franchisee may, at
the City's option, be deemed to have forfeited and annulled all the rights and
privileges of this chapter.
(1977 Code § 43-128)
842.22 BONDS.
   At the time a franchise becomes effective, the franchisee shall furnish a
bond to the City in the amount of five thousand dollars ($5,000) in such form
and with such sureties as shall be acceptable to the City, guaranteeing the
payment of all sums which may, at any time, become due from the franchisee to
the City under the terms of a franchise, including the cost of removal of all
facilities and installations of the franchisee from public property or rights
of way upon termination or forfeiture of the franchise, and also the repayment
to customers of the franchisee of the unearned value of any deposits or
connection charges exacted by the franchisee.
(1977 Code § 43-129)
842.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
202.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
CHAPTER 844
Mechanical and Electronic Games and Devices
   EDITOR'S NOTE: Ordinance No. 2025-24, repealed Chapter 844 in its entirety.
CHAPTER 846
Mobile Home Parks
846.01   Definitions.
846.02   Enforcement.
846.03   Licenses.
846.04   Water supply.
846.05   Drainage; grading.
846.06   Spacing.
846.07   Walkways.
846.08   Driveways.
846.09   Electricity.
846.10   Parking locations.
846.11   Motor vehicle parking.
846.12   Recreation areas.
846.13   Independent mobile homes required.
846.14   Service buildings.
846.15   Wastewater and garbage disposal.
846.16   Fire protection.
846.17   Animals and pets.
846.18   Management.
846.19   Duties of person in charge.
846.20   Plumbing, electrical, building and other construction work.
846.21   Alterations and additions.
846.22   Curbs and gutters.
846.23   Mobile home standards.
846.24   Incorporation of applicable statutory provisions.
846.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Mobilehomes and mobilehome parks - see 210 ILCS 115/1 et seq.
   Licensing in general - see B.R. & T.
Ch. 802
   Zoning regulations for mobile homes - see P. & Z.
1268.12
846.01 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   "Independent mobile home" means a mobile home with self-contained
toilet and bath or shower facilities.
   (b)   "Mobile home" means any vehicle used, or constructed for use, as a
conveyance upon streets or highways, duly licensable as such and constructed in
such manner as will permit occupancy as a dwelling.
   (c)   "Mobile home park" means any ground upon which two or more mobile
homes, occupied for dwelling or sleeping purposes, are located, regardless of
whether a charge is made for such accommodations.
   (d)   "Mobile home space" means a plot within a mobile home park designed
for the accommodation of one mobile home.
(1977 Code § 41-101)
846.02 ENFORCEMENT.
   The Community Development Director shall enforce all provisions of this
chapter, and applications for licenses shall be referred to him or her. The
Community Development Director may enter any premises on which mobile homes are
located and inspect them, and all accommodations connected therewith, at any
reasonable time.
(Ord. 94-80. Passed 9-19-94.)
846.03 LICENSES.
   (a)   Required. No person shall establish, operate, maintain or permit, upon
any property owned or controlled by him or her, a mobile home park without a
license.
   (b)   Fees. The application for a license shall be accompanied by an
examination fee of fifty dollars ($50.00). The initial license fee, and each
annual renewal, shall be two hundred dollars ($200.00) for the first twenty-
five mobile home spaces, or fraction thereof, and twenty-five dollars ($25.00)
for each additional twenty-five mobile home spaces, or fraction thereof.
   (c)   Applications. The initial application shall, in addition to standard
application requirements:
      (1)   Contain such legal description as will readily identify and locate
the premises; and
      (2)   Be accompanied by four copies of the court plan showing the
following, either existing or as proposed:
         A.   The extent and area used for court purposes;
         B.   Roadways and driveways;
         C.   The location of spaces for mobile homes;
         D.   The location and number of sanitary conveniences, including
toilets, washrooms, laundries and utility rooms;
         E.   The method and plan of sewage disposal;
         F.   The method and plan of garbage removal;
         G.   The plan for water supply; and
         H.   The plan for electrical lighting.
(1977 Code §§ 41-103 to 41-105; Ord. 2001-48. Passed 11-5-01; Ord. 2001-62.
Passed 1-8-02.)
846.04 WATER SUPPLY.
   (a)   No mobile home park shall be located within the City unless City water
and sewer connections are made thereto.
   (b)   An adequate pipe distribution system shall be provided, which shall
serve each mobile home space and permit connection thereto.
(1977 Code § 41-106)
846.05 DRAINAGE; GRADING.
   Every mobile home park shall be located on a well-drained area, and the
premises shall be properly graded, or tubed, so as to prevent the accumulation
of storm or other waters.
(1977 Code § 41-107)
846.06 SPACING.
   (a)   Mobile home spaces shall not be less than forty feet by seventy-five
feet and shall be clearly designated by proper markers at each corner.
   (b)   All mobile home spaces shall face on an improved driveway giving
access to a public street.
(1977 Code § 41-108)
846.07 WALKWAYS.
   Public walkways and walkways to service buildings not less than three feet
wide, and entrance walks to mobile home spaces of not less than two feet, all
of permanent surface, shall be provided.
(1977 Code § 41-109)
846.08 DRIVEWAYS.
   (a)   All driveways within the mobile home park shall be not less than forty
feet in width, of a permanent type surface approved by the Public Works
Director, lighted at night with electric lamps of not less than 150 watts each,
and spaced at intervals of not more than 150 feet.
   (b)   Driveways shall be maintained in good condition and shall not be
obstructed.
   (c)   The fee in such driveways shall remain in the owner of the tract and
shall not be dedicated as public streets.
   (d)   All entrances and exits from the mobile home park shall be well-marked
and so arranged that they may be easily controlled and supervised.
   (e)   The City shall not maintain or plow such driveways, but it shall be
the duty of the licensee to do so.
(1977 Code § 41-110; Ord. 94-80. Passed 9-19-94.)
846.09 ELECTRICITY.
   (a)   Every mobile home space shall be furnished with a weatherproof 115-
volt and 240-volt service outlet. Such outlet shall be equipped with an
externally operated switch or fuse of not less than thirty amps for the 115-
volt outlet and sixty amps for the 240-volt outlet.
   (b)   No power line shall be on the ground or suspended less than eighteen
feet above the ground, but such line may be installed underground.
(1977 Code § 41-111)
846.10 PARKING LOCATIONS.
   (a)   Mobile homes shall be parked in each space so that there will be a
minimum of ten feet between each side of the home and side space lines and a
minimum of ten feet between front and rear ends of the home and front and rear
space lines.
   (b)   No mobile home shall be located closer than fifteen feet to the
property line bounding the park.
   (c)   No mobile home shall be located closer than twenty-five feet to any
permanent building within the park.
   (d)   No mobile home shall be parked more than 500 feet from a service
building.
   (e)   No mobile home shall be parked so as to obstruct any street, roadway
or walkway.
   (f)   No mobile home shall remain in a park unless a mobile home space is
available.
(1977 Code § 41-112)
846.11 MOTOR VEHICLE PARKING.
   Areas shall be provided for the parking of motor vehicles, with parking
spaces at least equal to the number of mobile home spaces.
(1977 Code § 41-113)
846.12 RECREATION AREAS.
   Recreation areas shall be provided, shall be restricted to recreational uses
and shall be protected from roadway or parking areas. A minimum of 100 square
feet per home space shall be available, in one or more places, for such
recreation areas.
(1977 Code § 41-114)
846.13 INDEPENDENT MOBILE HOMES REQUIRED.
   Only independent mobile homes shall be permitted in mobile home parks.
(1977 Code § 41-115)
846.14 SERVICE BUILDINGS.
   (a)   Each mobile home park shall have at least one service building, which
shall contain at least one washing machine, two rinse tubs, a table, a hot
water heater and heat.
   (b)   Such service building shall be of permanent construction, be
adequately lighted and heated, be constructed of moisture-resistant material to
permit frequent washing and cleaning and have all rooms well ventilated, with
all openings effectively screened.
   (c)   Floors of such service building shall be of concrete, tile or similar
materials, impervious to water, easily cleaned and pitched to a floor drain.
   (d)   All service buildings, and the grounds of the park, shall be
maintained in a clean, sightly condition and kept free of any condition that
will menace the health of any occupant or the public, or constitute a nuisance.
(1977 Code § 41-116)
846.15 WASTEWATER AND GARBAGE DISPOSAL.
   (a)   All waste from showers, toilets, laundries, faucets and lavatories
shall be discharged to a sewer system serving each service building and mobile
home space.
   (b)   Each faucet shall be equipped with facilities for drainage of waste
and water into the sewer. In no case shall any waste or water be discharged
upon the surface of the ground or disposed of by means other than as herein
provided.
   (c)   Every mobile home space shall be provided with a substantial fly-tight
metal garbage depository and a fly-tight metal trash depository, from which
contents shall be carried away, by the licensee, at least every three days.
   (d)   No trash or garbage shall be disposed of in any way or burned within
the confines of the mobile home park unless in an incinerator approved by the
Community Development Director.
   (e)   When a water carriage system of sewage is used, each mobile home site
shall be provided with a sewer connection for the combined liquid waste outlet
or outlets of each mobile home. It shall be the duty of the owner or operator
of such mobile home park to provide an approved type of water and odor-tight
connection from the mobile home water drainage to the sewer connection, and it
shall be the duty of such owner or operator to make such connection and keep
all occupied mobile homes connected to such sewer while located in a mobile
home park. Sewer connections in unoccupied mobile home sites shall be closed so
that they will not emit odors or cause a breeding place for flies. No water or
waste shall be allowed to fall on the ground from a mobile home.
(1977 Code § 41-117; Ord. 94-81. Passed 9-19-94.)
846.16 FIRE PROTECTION.
   Fire extinguishers of a type approved by the State Fire Marshal for use at
mobile home parks shall be placed at locations within 200 feet of each
individual mobile home site. Each fire extinguisher shall be periodically
examined and kept, at all times, in a condition for use.
(1977 Code § 41-118)
846.17 ANIMALS AND PETS.
   No owner or person in charge of a dog, cat or any other animal shall permit
it to run at large or commit any nuisance within the limits of a mobile home
park.
(1977 Code § 41-119)
846.18 MANAGEMENT.
   In every mobile home park there shall be a well-marked building located near
the park entrance, in which shall be located the office of the person in charge
of such mobile home park. A copy of the park license, a copy of this chapter
and the park register shall be kept in such office.
(1977 Code § 41-120)
846.19 DUTIES OF PERSON IN CHARGE.
   The attendant or person in charge, together with the licensee, shall:
   (a)   Keep a register of all guests, which shall be open at all times to
inspection for City, State and Federal officers, showing, for all guests:
      (1)   Names and addresses;
      (2)   Dates of entrance and departure; and
      (3)   License numbers of mobile homes and automobiles, the years and
makes of mobile homes, and states issuing such licenses.
   (b)   Maintain the court in a clean, orderly and sanitary condition at all
times.
   (c)   See that the provisions of this chapter are complied with and enforced
and report promptly to the Police Department any violations of the law which
come to his or her attention.
(1977 Code § 41-121)
   (d)   Notify the Police Chief immediately of any suspected communicable or
contagious diseases within the park. In the case of diseases diagnosed as
quarantinable, the licensee shall not permit the departure of a mobile home or
its occupants, or the removal therefrom of clothing or other articles which
have been exposed to infection, without approval of the Police Chief.
(Ord. 94-97. Passed 11-7-94.)
   (e)   Prohibit the use of any mobile home by a greater number of occupants
than that which it is designed to accommodate.
   (f)   Not sell mobile home spaces as single units to any person. Ownership
of all spaces in the park shall be kept in the licensee.
(1977 Code § 41-121)
846.20 PLUMBING, ELECTRICAL, BUILDING AND OTHER CONSTRUCTION WORK.
   All plumbing, electrical, building and other work at any licensed park shall
be in accordance with these Codified Ordinances.
(1977 Code § 41-122)
846.21 ALTERATIONS AND ADDITIONS.
   No permanent additions of any kind shall be built on any mobile home.
Skirting of coaches is permissible, but such skirting shall not attach the home
permanently to the ground, provide a harborage for rodents or create a fire
hazard. The wheels of the coach shall not be removed, except temporarily when
necessary for repairs. Jacks or stabilizers may be placed under the frame of
the coach to prevent movement on the springs while the coach is parked or
occupied. Removable-type canopies and awnings may be installed. Small storage
sheds, separate from the mobile home, may be constructed on the rear of the
mobile home space.
(1977 Code § 41-123)
846.22 CURBS AND GUTTERS.
   The licensee shall install curbs and gutters on all drives and ways intended
for vehicular use in the mobile home park.
(1977 Code § 41-124)
846.23 MOBILE HOME STANDARDS.
   All plumbing, electrical facilities and construction of mobile homes shall
comply with the specifications of the manufacturer.
(1977 Code § 41-125)
846.24 INCORPORATION OF APPLICABLE STATUTORY PROVISIONS.
   All pertinent and applicable provisions of 210 ILCS 115/1 to 115/27,
inclusive, as heretofore or hereafter amended, are incorporated herein by
reference, subject to the provisions of Section
202.05(b) of the Administration Code.
(1977 Code § 41-126; Ord. 82-23. Passed 5-17-82.)
846.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
202.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)

(1977 Code § 9-1301)
848.02 APPLICATION OF STATE STANDARDS, RULES AND REGULATIONS.

the State of Illinois under 210 ILCS 45/3-801, as heretofore or hereafter

Illinois or ordinances of the City.
(1977 Code § 9-1302)
848.03 INSPECTIONS.

the Fire Department and the Building Commissioner.
(1977 Code §9-1303; Ord. 94-81. Passed 9-19-94; Ord. 2013-10. Passed 3-4-13.)
848.99 PENALTY.
