CHAPTER 852
Pawnbrokers
852.01   Licenses.
852.02   Record of loans and pledges.
852.03   Memorandum of pledge.
852.04   Inspections by Police Department.
852.05   Engaging in business with minors or incompetents.
852.06   Return of stolen property.
852.07   Liability of licensee for violations.
852.08   Incorporation of relevant statutory provisions.
852.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Pawnbrokers - see 205 ILCS 510/0.01 et seq.
   Fraud generally - see GEN. OFF.
Ch. 686
   Licensing in general - see B.R. & T.
Ch. 802
   Secondhand store dealers prohibited to act as pawn brokers - see B.R. & T.
860.03
852.01 LICENSES.
   (a)   Required. Any person engaged in loaning money on deposit or pledge of
personal property, or dealing in the purchase of personal property on condition
of selling the same back at a stipulated price, is hereby declared to be a
pawnbroker and shall obtain a license therefor before engaging in such
business.
   (b)   Annual Fee. The annual fee for a license as provided in subsection (a)
hereof shall be one hundred and fifty dollars ($150.00).
(1977 Code §§ 9-1401, 9-1402; Ord. 2001-48. Passed 11-5-01.)
852.02 RECORD OF LOANS AND PLEDGES.
   Every licensee shall keep a record of the goods, articles or things pawned
or pledged, the amount of money loaned thereon, the time of pledging the same,
the rate of interest to be paid on such loan and the name and residence of the
person pawning or pledging the property. No entry made in such record shall be
erased, obliterated or defaced.
(1977 Code § 9-1403)
852.03 MEMORANDUM OF PLEDGE.
   Every licensee shall, at the time of each loan, deliver to the person
pawning or pledging any goods a memorandum of pledge containing the substance
of the record provided for in Section
852.02. No charge shall be made or received by any licensee for any such entry,
memorandum or note.
(1977 Code § 9-1404)
852.04 INSPECTIONS BY POLICE DEPARTMENT.
   The record, as well as every article or other thing of value pawned or
pledged, shall, at all reasonable times, be open to inspection of the Police
Department.
(1977 Code § 9-1405)
852.05 ENGAGING IN BUSINESS WITH MINORS OR INCOMPETENTS.
   No licensee shall take or receive, in pawn or pledge for money loaned, any
property, tangible or intangible, from any minor, or any property owned or
claimed by any minor, or which may be in the possession or under the control of
any minor, drunkard, intoxicated person, spendthrift or insane person.
(1977 Code § 9-1406)
852.06 RETURN OF STOLEN PROPERTY.
   When any person is found to be the owner of stolen property which has been
pawned, such property shall be returned to the owner thereof without the
payment of the money advanced by the licensee or any cost or charges of any
kind which the licensee may have placed upon the same.
(1977 Code § 9-1407)
852.07 LIABILITY OF LICENSEE FOR VIOLATIONS.
   Every licensee shall be subject to the penalty provided in Section
852.99 for a violation of this chapter, whether such violation is committed by
himself or herself or by his or her clerk, agent or employee.
(1977 Code § 9-1408)
852.08 INCORPORATION OF RELEVANT STATUTORY PROVISIONS.
   All pertinent and applicable provisions of 210 ILCS 45/3-104, as heretofore
or hereafter amended, are incorporated herein by reference, subject to Section
202.05(b) of the Administration Code.
852.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
202.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
CHAPTER 856
Railroads
856.01   Speed of trains.
856.02   Street obstructions.
856.03   Construction and maintenance of crossings.
856.04   Streets requiring automatic signals.
856.05   Grade of tracks.
856.06   Drainage.
856.07   Application of Illinois Commerce Commission rules.
856.08   Warning lights at railroad grade crossings.
856.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Railroads - see 610 ILCS 5/0.01 et seq.
   Minors loitering about railroad tracks - see GEN. OFF.
650.03
   Licensing in general - see B.R. & T.
Ch. 802
856.01 SPEED OF TRAINS.
   No railroad engine or car shall be propelled upon any railroad track at a
speed greater than thirty-five miles per hour.
(1977 Code § 9-1501)
856.02 STREET OBSTRUCTIONS.
   No person shall cause or allow any railroad engine or car to stop in,
obstruct or remain upon any part of any street, except for the purpose of
receiving or discharging passengers or freight, taking in or setting out cars
or receiving necessary fuel and water, and in no case shall such obstruction
exceed ten minutes.
(1977 Code § 9-1502)
856.03 CONSTRUCTION AND MAINTENANCE OF CROSSINGS.
   Each railroad company shall construct and keep in good repair suitable and
convenient crossings at the intersections of its railroad tracks with any
street, alley, lane, ditch, culvert or sewer, shall keep in good repair all
streets, lanes and alleys through which its tracks may run and shall so
construct its tracks, crossings and switches as to interfere as little as
possible with necessary and ordinary travel.
(1977 Code § 9-1503)
856.04 STREETS REQUIRING AUTOMATIC SIGNALS.
   All railroad companies whose tracks cross or intersect East Stephenson
Street, North Van Buren Avenue or East Shawnee Street shall place at such
crossings a bell or flashing light which shall operate automatically upon the
approach of a train or engine.
(1977 Code § 9-1504)
856.05 GRADE OF TRACKS.
   Railroad companies shall adjust tracks to conform to any grade which, at any
time, is established by the City. Where the tracks run lengthwise on any street
or alley, tracks shall be kept on a level with the surface, as provided in 65
ILCS 5/11-57-1.
(1977 Code § 9-1505)
856.06 DRAINAGE.
   Railroad companies shall make, open and repair ditches, drains, sewers and
culverts along and under their tracks so that water cannot stand on their
property and so that the natural drainage of the adjacent property is not
impeded, as provided in 65 ILCS 5/11-57-1.
(1977 Code § 9-1506)
856.07 APPLICATION OF ILLINOIS COMMERCE COMMISSION RULES.
   The provisions of this chapter are subject to the lawful orders, rules and
regulations of the Illinois Commerce Commission.
(1977 Code § 9-1507)
856.08 WARNING LIGHTS AT RAILROAD GRADE CROSSINGS.
   (a)   Flashing red warning lights shall be maintained in operable condition
at the following railroad grade crossings in the City:
      (1)   South Galena Avenue;
      (2)   East Stephenson Street;
      (3)   North Van Buren Avenue;
      (4)   East Shawnee Street; and
      (5)   West Beach Street.
   (b)   It shall be the duty of the owner of the railroad tracks and the right
of way at each such crossing to keep such lights in operable condition. Failure
to do so shall subject the owner to a fine of fifty dollars ($50.00) per day
for each day the lights remain inoperable. Notice that the lights are
inoperable shall be given by the Public Works Director to the owner.
(1977 Code § 64-123; Ord. 78-56. Passed 7-17-78; Ord. 94-80. Passed 9-19-94.)
856.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
202.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
CHAPTER 857
Meeting Halls
857.01   License required.
857.02   Definition.
857.03   License fee.
857.04   License application.
857.05   Insurance required.
857.06   Site requirements.
857.07   Prohibited activities.
857.08   Exceptions.
857.01 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   It shall be unlawful to rent, lease, loan, donate or otherwise permit the
use of, with or without fee or other exchange or payment, any meeting hall in
the City without first having obtained a license to operate such business
pursuant to the provisions of this chapter. Such license shall be in addition
to any other license required by this Code. This license will be in effect from
May 1 to April 30 of each year.
(Ord. 2020-55. Passed 11-2-20.)
857.02 DEFINITION.
   Definition. "Meeting hall" as used in this chapter shall refer to any
building, facility, room or portion thereof, which is regularly rented, leased,
donated, or otherwise made available to any person or entity other than the
owner or occupant thereof for public or private events, unless expressly
excepted under the provisions of Section
857.08. The term "meeting hall" as used in this chapter shall include, but is
not limited to, all rental halls, banquet rooms, conference centers, social
clubs or other similar locations where space is regularly made available for
non-residential use by persons who are not the owners or lessees of the subject
premises.
(Ord. 2020-55. Passed 11-2-20.)
857.03 LICENSE FEE.
   The license fee for a new meeting hall license shall be one hundred dollars
($100.00). The license fee for renewals of an existing meeting hall license
shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00) per year.
(Ord. 2020-55. Passed 11-2-20; Ord. 2021-24. Passed 7-6-21.)
857.04 LICENSE APPLICATION.
   Application for license hereunder shall be made in writing to the City Clerk
and shall be processed in accordance with the provisions of
Chapter 802 of this Code. The application shall be on a form provided by the
City Clerk and shall provide, at a minimum:
   (a)   The full legal name of the applicant and any assumed business names
associated with the operation of the business. If the applicant is a
corporation, limited liability company, or other business entity, the names of
any owners holding more than 5.00% ownership shall be included.
   (b)   Proof of site control, in the form of a deed in the name of the
applicant for the licensed premises, or a written lease signed by the owner of
the licensed premises showing the applicant as lessee;
   (c)   Certificate of insurance as required by Section
857.05;
   (d)   Any additional information determined to be necessary for the License
Officer to make a decision as to the issuance of any license.
(Ord. 2020-55. Passed 11-2-20.)
857.05 INSURANCE REQUIRED.
   Each application for issuance or renewal of a license under this chapter
shall be accompanied by a certificate of insurance from a reputable insurance
company licensed to do business in the State of Illinois, showing evidence of
insurance against general liability in an amount not less than (a) one million
dollars ($1,000,000.00) per person/occurrence and two million dollars
($2,000,000.00) in the aggregate) or (b) two million dollars ($2,000,000.00)
combined single limits for bodily injury, personal injury and property damage
liability.
(Ord. 2020-55. Passed 11-2-20.)
857.06 SITE REQUIREMENTS.
   In order to be eligible for a license under this chapter, or for any renewal
thereof, the following requirements must be met with respect to the
establishment in which meeting hall activities will be conducted:
   (a)   The building shall be in compliance with all applicable provisions of
the City of Freeport's Zoning Code, Building and Housing Code, and Fire
Prevention Code.
   (b)   Adequate off-street parking shall be provided in accordance with
Chapter 1262 of these Codified Ordinances where applicable.
(Ord. 2020-55. Passed 11-2-20.)
857.07 PROHIBITED ACTIVITIES.
   The following activities shall be prohibited in any meeting hall. A finding
of a violation of any provision of this section shall be sufficient grounds to
revoke any license granted hereunder.
   (a)   No food shall be served on the premises except in strict accordance
with applicable Stephenson County Health Department requirements;
   (b)   No liquor shall be served or brought onto the premises, whether for
sale or personal consumption, except in strict accordance with the terms of
Chapter 806 of these Codified Ordinances.
   (c)   No gambling or wagering of any kind shall occur on the premises unless
the licensee also holds a Tier I liquor license with a supplemental video
gaming license in strict compliance with
Chapter 806 of these Codified Ordinances.
   (d)   Licensee, nor any of its owners, employees, or agents shall commit any
act which constitutes a violation of these Codified Ordinances in conjunction
with the operation of the licensed business or premises.
(Ord. 2020-55. Passed 11-2-20; Ord. 2024-15. Passed 4-1-24.)
857.08 EXCEPTIONS.
   Notwithstanding anything to the contrary contained in this chapter, the
provisions of this chapter shall not apply to the following locations:
   (a)   Property owned or leased by a not-for-profit entity which has been
recognized by the Internal Revenue Service as a qualified tax-exempt
organization under section 501(c) of the Internal Revenue Code;
   (b)   Property owned or leased by a governmental unit or political
subdivision whose boundaries contain any property within the corporate limits
of the City; or
   (c)   Property owned or leased by a church or other religious organization
keeping a permanent house of worship within the corporate limits of the City.
   (d)   The principal place of any business when conducting meetings held in
space normally occupied by such business in its day to day operations and
furthering the principal purpose of such business, so long as no entry fee or
room rental is charged to any person.
   (e)   Property occupied by any person as a private residence where events
are held solely by the owner or occupant thereof as social gatherings and no
entry fee or room rental is charged to any person.
   (f)   Any portion of the property occupied by a Tier I or Tier II Licensee
under the provisions of Chapter 806 (Alcoholic Liquor Sales) for consumption of
alcoholic liquors on the premises.
(Ord. 2020-55. Passed 11-2-2020; Ord. 2021-24. Passed 7-6-21.)

CHAPTER 879
Pet Stores
879.01   Definitions.
879.02   Restrictions on sale of animals.
879.03   Penalty.
879.01 DEFINITIONS.
   “Animal care facility” shall be defined as an animal control center or
animal shelter, maintained by or under contract with any State, County, or
municipality, whose mission and practice is, in whole, or significant part, the
rescue and placement of animals in permanent homes or rescue organizations.
   “Animal rescue organization” shall be defined as any not-for-profit
organization which has tax-exempt status under Section 501(c)(3) of the United
States Internal Revenue Code, whose mission and practice is, in whole or in
significant part, the rescue and placement of animals in permanent homes. This
term does not include an entity that is a breeder or broker or one that obtains
animals from a breeder or broker for profit or compensation.
   “Breeder” shall be defined as a person that maintains a dog or cat for the
purpose of breeding and selling their offspring.
   “Cat” shall be defined as a member of the species of domestic cat, Felis
catus.
   “Dog” shall be defined as a member of the species of domestic dog, Canis
familiaris.
   “Offer for sale” shall be defined as to advertise for the sale, barter, or
auction, or to otherwise give away or dispose of a dog or cat on a for-profit
basis.
   “Pet store” shall be defined as a retail establishment where dogs or cats
are sold, exchanged, bartered or offered for sale as pet animals to the general
public at retail value. Such definition shall not include an animal care
facility or animal rescue organization, as defined in this section. Further,
such definition shall not include a retail establishment where dogs or cats are
offered for adoption on a not-for-profit basis in partnership with an animal
care facility or animal rescue organization.
(Ord. 2020-53. Passed 10-5-20.)
879.02 RESTRICTIONS ON SALE OF ANIMALS.
   No pet store shall sell, deliver, offer for sale, barter, auction, give
away, or otherwise transfer or dispose of cats or dogs. Nothing in this section
shall prohibit pet stores from collaborating with animal care facilities or
animal rescue organizations to offer space for such entities to showcase
adoptable dogs or cats provided the pet store shall not have any ownership
interest in the animals offered for adoption and shall not receive a fee for
providing space for the adoption of any of these animals. Pet stores which
collaborate with animal care facilities or animal rescue organizations to offer
pet adoptions shall take reasonable steps to ensure that potential pet adoptees
follow all protocols set forth by animal care facilities or animal rescue
organizations regarding adoption criteria including the completion of an
adoption registration form.
(Ord. 2020-53. Passed 10-5-20.)
879.03 PENALTY.
   A pet store that violates this section shall be subject to a civil penalty
of five hundred dollars ($500.00), and each dog or cat offered for sale in
violation of this section shall constitute a separate violation.
(Ord. 2020-53. Passed 10-5-20.)
CHAPTER 860
Secondhand Stores
860.01   License required.
860.02   Record of purchases.
860.03   Operation as pawnbroker or junk dealer prohibited.
860.04   Engaging in business with minors or intoxicated persons.
860.05   Stolen property.
860.06   Sales of weapons.
860.07   Persons ineligible for licenses.
860.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   License and regulation by municipalities - see 65 ILCS 5/11-42-3
   Receiving property from minors - see 720 ILCS 345/2
   Junk dealers - see B.R. & T.
Ch. 838
   Pawnbrokers - see B.R. & T.
Ch. 852
860.01 LICENSE REQUIRED.
   It shall be unlawful for any person to carry on the business or trade of a
dealer in secondhand radios, radio equipment, television sets, television
equipment, refrigerators, clothes washers, clothes dryers, jewelry, silverware,
cameras, camera equipment, coins, currency, stamps, precious metals, chainsaws,
clocks, watches, guns, rifles, shotguns, handguns, weapons, ammunition or
sporting goods equipment within the City without first obtaining a license
therefor from the City. A person shall be considered to be a dealer in such
secondhand articles if such person buys or takes in trade any of such articles
secondhand or used and offers the same for sale or trade at wholesale or
retail, provided that this chapter shall not apply to any person who is a
dealer in such secondhand articles but who, as part of the same business at the
same location, also sells such articles new and is either a licensed,
authorized or franchised dealer for the sale of such articles new or is the
manufacturer of such articles.
(1977 Code § 9-2301)
860.02 RECORD OF PURCHASES.
   Every licensee shall keep a written record of all purchases of any items of
personal property described in Section
860.01 made by the licensee in the course of carrying on the licensed business,
which shall contain entries made at the time of purchase giving an accurate
account and description of the item purchased, the date and time of the
purchase, the price paid and the name, driver's license identification number
or State identification card number and residence of the person from whom such
purchase was made. Such record shall be open at all times to the inspection of
the City Manager and any member of the Police Department of the City. The
written record shall be completed by the licensee for each purchase on a form
entitled "Official Record of Transaction," one copy of which shall be provided
by the City to each licensee at the time of the issuance of the original
license as provided in this chapter and upon the modification of such form by
the City.
(1977 Code §9-2304; Ord. 2017-56. Passed 7-17-17)
860.03 OPERATION AS PAWNBROKER OR JUNK DEALER PROHIBITED.
   No secondhand store dealer shall receive or hold a license to carry on a
business as a pawnbroker or as a junk dealer, and no licensed secondhand store
dealer shall carry on a pawnbroker business or a junk dealer business.
(1977 Code § 9-2305)
860.04 ENGAGING IN BUSINESS WITH MINORS OR INTOXICATED PERSONS.
   No dealer in secondhand articles shall purchase any article described in
Section
860.01 from any minor without the written consent of the parent or guardian of
such minor, which consent shall be given and written in the presence of such
dealer, nor shall any such dealer purchase any article described in Section
860.01 from an intoxicated person. A minor shall be any person under the age of
eighteen years.
(1977 Code § 9-2306)
860.05 STOLEN GOODS.
   Every secondhand store dealer who shall receive or be in possession of any
goods, articles or things of value which may have been lost or stolen, shall,
upon demand, produce such article or thing to any member of the Police
Department for examination, and it shall be the duty of every dealer to report
to the Police Department any article or thing which was sold to the dealer or
which is offered to the dealer for purchase if the dealer shall have reason to
believe that the article or thing was stolen. Whenever it is determined that
any such article or thing is stolen property, the same shall be turned over to
the Police Department to be dealt with by it as in the case of all other items
of stolen property received by it.
(1977 Code § 9-2308)
860.06 SALES OF WEAPONS.
   No secondhand store dealer shall sell or offer for sale at wholesale or
retail any pistols, revolvers, derringers, bowie knives, dirks or other deadly
weapons without complying with all State laws regarding licensing and keeping
of registers and records of such sales and without being licensed as a dealer
under the Federal Firearms Act of the United States.
(1977 Code § 9-2309)
860.07 PERSONS INELIGIBLE FOR LICENSES.
   No license shall be issued to or renewed for:
   (a)   A person who is not of good character and reputation;
   (b)   A person who is not a citizen or a resident alien of the United
States;
   (c)   A person who has been convicted of a felony under the laws of any
state;
   (d)   A person who has been convicted of any crime or misdemeanor opposed to
decency and morality;
   (e)   A person whose license has been revoked for cause;
   (f)   A partnership, unless all of the members of such partnership are
qualified under this chapter;
   (g)   A corporation, if any officer, manager or director thereof, or
stockholder or stockholders owning in the aggregate more than five percent of
the stock of such corporation, are not qualified hereunder for any reason other
than citizenship and residence;
   (h)   A person whose place of business is conducted by a manager or agent
unless such manager or agent possesses the same qualifications required of a
license;
   (i)   A person who does not own the premises for which a license is sought,
or does not have a written lease thereon for the full period for which the
license is to be issued; or
   (j)   Any law enforcing public official, including any member of the Police
Department, the Mayor, any Alderperson or any officer of the City.
860.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be fined not less than
one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for
each offense. Each day that such person shall neglect, fail or refuse to comply
with this chapter shall constitute a separate offense.
(1977 Code § 9-2311)
CHAPTER 862
Self-Service Gas Stations
862.01   Permitted conditions.
862.02   Definitions.
862.03   Permit required; fee; renewal.
862.04   Investigation of applications by Bureau of Fire Prevention; display of
permits.
862.05   Rules for operation.
862.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Licenses and permits for self-service stations - see 430 ILCS 15/2
   False advertising of gasoline prices - see 720 ILCS 305/1, 305/2
   Signs accessory to gas stations - see B. & H.
1468.30
   Districts for the storage of liquefied petroleum gas - see F.P.
1610.04(BOCA F-3605.3)
862.01 PERMITTED CONDITIONS.
   Self-service gasoline stations are hereby authorized in the City, subject to
requirements of this chapter and those of the International Fire Code, as
adopted in Section
1610.01 of these Codified Ordinances, and subsequent fire prevention codes
which the City may enact.
(1977 Code § 9-2101; Ord. 77-19. Passed 4-18-77; Ord. 2010-20. Passed 4-19-10.)
862.02 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   "Approved self-service dispensing devices" means those which meet the
following requirements:
      (1)   The dispensing nozzle is an approved automatic-closing type without
a latch-open device;
      (2)   The devices meet the requirements of the International Fire Code,
as adopted in Section
1610.01 of these Codified Ordinances, and all amendments thereto;
      (3)   The devices have been inspected and approved by a representative of
the Bureau of Fire Prevention; and
      (4)   The devices are operated in compliance with the requirements of
Section
862.05.
   (b)   "Self-service station" means that portion of property where flammable
and combustible liquids used as motor fuels are stored and subsequently
dispensed from fixed approved dispensing equipment into the fuel tanks of motor
vehicles by persons other than the service station attendant.
   (c)   "Split-island station" means a station which includes islands for
self-service and islands for attendant or "full-service."
(1977 Code § 9-2102; Ord. 77-19. Passed 4-18-77; Ord. 2010-20. Passed 4-19-10.)
862.03 PERMIT REQUIRED; FEE; RENEWAL.
   No person shall operate a self-service gasoline station without a permit
issued in conformity with the requirements of this Business Regulation and
Taxation Code related to licenses and permits. Applications for self-service
station permits shall be made to the City Clerk upon forms to be provided by
the City Clerk and shall be accompanied by complete, detailed plans, in
triplicate, for each proposed self-service installation. Each application shall
be accompanied by a permit fee of two hundred and fifty dollars ($250.00). A
separate application shall be required for each proposed self-service station,
regardless of common ownership of two or more stations. An application for
renewal of each permit issued hereunder shall be filed not later than December
31 of each year.
(1977 Code § 9-2103; Ord. 77-19. Passed 4-18-77; Ord. 2001-48. Passed 11-5-01.)
862.04 INVESTIGATION OF APPLICATIONS BY BUREAU OF FIRE PREVENTION; DISPLAY OF
PERMITS.
   Every application for a self-service installation shall be investigated by a
representative of the Bureau of Fire Prevention to determine whether the
applicable provisions of this Business Regulation and Taxation Code and the
Fire Prevention Code are being complied with. The approval of the inspector
shall be noted on the permit application before a permit shall be issued. A
self-service station permit shall be issued by the City Clerk only after the
requirements of this section have been complied with. The permit authorizing
self-service operations shall be prominently displayed at all times on the site
of the operations.
(1977 Code § 9-2103; Ord. 77-19. Passed 4-18-77.)
862.05 RULES FOR OPERATION.
   (a)   It shall be unlawful to provide for or use live-in facilities or
accommodations for the benefit of any owner, operator or employee of a self-
service station on the premises of such station.
   (b)   All self-service stations shall have at least one attendant on duty at
all times while the station is open to the public. The attendant's primary
function shall be to supervise, observe and control the dispensing of Class I
liquids while such liquids are actually being dispensed. Stations operating on
a split-island basis shall have at least two attendants on duty at all times
while the station is open to the public on a self-service basis. The attendant
responsible for the self-service segment of a split-island operation shall not
leave his or her location at the remote controls for the self-service pumps to
participate in the operation of pumps dispensing fuels on a full-service basis.
   (c)   The dispensing area shall at all times be in clear view of the
attendant, and the placing or allowing of any obstacle between the dispensing
area and the attendant control area shall be prohibited. The attendant shall at
all times be able to communicate with persons in the dispensing area.
   (d)   The attendant shall have immediate access to emergency cutoff
switches, provided at a location remote from the dispensing devices, which
location shall be subject to approval by the Bureau of Fire Prevention.
   (e)   The attendant shall supervise the dispensing of motor fuels. The
attendant shall refuse service to any person who is smoking or who appears, for
any reason, to be unable to dispense the motor fuel safely, and shall shut off
the dispensing unit if a patron fails to follow instructions in compliance with
this section.
   (f)   All attendants and other employees shall be thoroughly instructed in
the operation and use of the communication system, the control station, the
fire extinguishing equipment, the operation of the dispensing units and safety
regulations for the dispensing of motor fuels.
   (g)   For minimum safety standards for the location and operation of self-
service dispensing units, dispensing pumps shall be located a minimum of ten
feet inside station property lines and a minimum of five feet from any building
opening.
   (h)   At least one type-ABC fire extinguisher, with a capacity of ten
pounds, shall be at the attendant's control station.
   (i)   Conspicuous and legible signs, prohibiting smoking and directing
customers to turn off ignitions while dispensing motor fuel, shall be posted
and maintained. The lettering on such signs shall be red on white background
and not less than four inches in height. The signs shall be made of an all-
weather rigid material. The wording, lettering, size, design, material,
mounting and location of such signs shall be subject to the approval of the
Bureau of Fire Prevention.
   (j)   Dispensing units shall be mounted either on a concrete island or
protected against collision damage by suitable means in a manner approved by
the Bureau of Fire Prevention.
   (k)   No portable containers of more than six gallons shall be filled with
gasoline, except as dispensed directly into the fuel tank attached to a motor
vehicle. All portable receptacles for gasoline shall be red and shall be
labeled in letters of a contrasting color and a height of not less than one-
half inch, and it shall be unlawful to put any other liquids or oils except
gasoline in such receptacles theretofore used for gasoline, so long as such
receptacles are so painted red and labeled "gasoline." In all circumstances,
the container shall be metal.
(1977 Code § 9-2104; Ord. 77-19. Passed 4-18-77.)
862.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
202.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
CHAPTER 864
Solicitors
   EDITOR'S NOTE: Chapter 864, previously a codification of 1977 Code Sections
61-101 through 61-111, Ordinance 91-89, passed November 18, 1991, and Ordinance
93-77, passed October 4, 1993, was re-enacted in its entirety by Ordinance 94-
9, passed April 4, 1994.
864.01   Definitions.
864.02   Certificate of registration required; application.
864.03   Denial or revocation of certificate by Chief of Police.
864.04   City policy on solicitation.
864.04   City policy on solicitation.
864.05   "No solicitors invited" signs.
864.06   Duties of solicitors.
864.07   Solicitation from occupants of vehicles on public ways.
864.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Soliciting contributions for political purposes - see 70 ILCS 1215/22 et
seq.
   Solicitation generally - see 720 ILCS 5/1-5, 5/8-1 et seq.
   Soliciting by Fire Department members - see ADM.
242.18
   Noise from solicitors - see GEN. OFF.
670.05(c)(12)
   Solicitation - see GEN. OFF.
Ch. 684
   Transient merchants - see B.R. & T.
Ch. 872
864.01 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   "Registered solicitor" means and includes any person who has obtained
a valid certificate of registration as provided in this chapter, which
certificate is in the possession of the solicitor or on his or her person while
engaged in soliciting.
   (b)   "Residence" means and includes every separate living unit occupied for
residential purposes by one or more persons, contained within any type of
building or structure.
   (c)   "Soliciting" means and includes the act of seeking to obtain, without
invitation from an occupant of a residence, any one or more of the following:
      (1)   Orders for the purchase of goods, wares, merchandise, foodstuffs or
services of any kind, character or description whatsoever, for any kind of
consideration whatsoever;
      (2)   Prospective customers for application or purchase of insurance of
any type, kind or character;
      (3)   Subscriptions to books, magazines, periodicals, newspapers and
every other type or kind of publication; or
      (4)   Gifts or contributions of money, clothing or any other valuable
thing for the support or benefit of any charitable or nonprofit association,
organization, corporation or project.
(Ord. 94-9. Passed 4-4-94.)
864.02 CERTIFICATE OF REGISTRATION REQUIRED; APPLICATION.
   (a)   General Requirement. Any person desiring to engage in soliciting from
persons in residences within the City is required to make written application
for a certificate of registration as provided herein.
   (b)   Application.
      (1)   Application for a certificate of registration shall be made upon a
form provided by the Chief of Police and filed with the Chief. The initial non-
refundable application fee shall be $250.00 and shall be paid at the time the
application is submitted to the City. The fee for an extension (as provided for
below) shall be $100.00 The applicant shall truthfully state in full the
following information requested on the application:
         A.   His or her name, the address of his or her present place of
residence, the length of residence at such address, his or her business
address, if other than his or her residence address, and his or her Social
Security number;
         B.   The address of his or her place of residence during the past
three years, if other than his or her present address;
         C.   His or her driver's license number, expiration date and State of
issuance;
         D.   A physical description of the applicant;
         E.   The name and address of the person, firm, corporation or
association whom the applicant is employed by or represents, and the length of
time of such employment or representation;
         F.   The name and address of his or her employer during the past three
years, if other than the present employer;
         G.   A description, sufficient for identification, of the subject
matter of the soliciting in which the applicant will engage;
         H.   The initial period of time for which the certificate is applied
for. The initial period of time shall not exceed thirty days. An extension for
an additional thirty days may be applied for one time in any given calendar
year. Any person, firm, corporation or association shall not be permitted to
solicit for more than a total of sixty days in any given calendar year;
         I.   The date, or approximate date, of the latest previous application
for a certificate under the provisions of this chapter, if any;
         J.   A statement as to whether or not the applicant ever had a
certificate of registration issued to him or her under the provisions of this
chapter revoked;
         K.   A statement as to whether or not the applicant has ever been
convicted of a violation of any of the provisions of this chapter, or an
ordinance of any other Illinois municipality regulating soliciting;
         L.   A statement as to whether or not the applicant has ever been
convicted of the commission of a felony under the laws of the State, any other
state or the Federal Government; and
         M.   Such additional information as the Chief of Police may deem
necessary to process the application.
      (2)   All statements made by the applicant upon the application or in
connection therewith shall be under oath.
      (3)   The Chief of Police may require an applicant to submit to
fingerprinting by the Police Department in connection with the application for
a certificate.
      (4)   The Chief of Police shall cause to be kept in his or her office an
accurate record of every application received and acted upon, together with all
other information and data pertaining thereto. All certificates of registration
issued under the provisions of this chapter shall be numbered in consecutive
order as filed. Every certificate issued, and any renewal thereof, shall be
identified with the duplicate number of the application upon which it was
issued.
      (5)   No certificate of registration shall be issued to any person who
has been convicted of the commission of a felony under the laws of the State,
any other state or the Federal Government, within five years of the date of the
application, to any person who has been convicted of a violation of any of the
provisions of this chapter, or to any person whose certificate of registration
issued under the provisions of this chapter has previously been revoked as
herein provided. (Ord. 94-9. Passed 4-4-94; Ord. 2024-20. Passed 5-6-24.)
864.03 DENIAL OR REVOCATION OF CERTIFICATE BY CHIEF OF POLICE.
   (a)   The Chief of Police, after consideration of the application and all
information obtained relative thereto, shall deny the application if the
applicant does not possess the qualifications for such certificate as required
by this chapter, or if the issuance of a certificate of registration to the
applicant would not be in accordance with the intent and purpose of this
chapter. Endorsement of the denial shall be made by the Chief of Police upon
the application. In the event the applicant is thereafter found to be fully
qualified, the certificate of registration shall be issued.
   (b)   Any certificate of registration issued under the provisions of this
chapter shall be revoked by the Chief of Police if the holder of the
certificate is convicted of a violation of any of the provisions of this
chapter, makes a false material statement in the application or otherwise
becomes disqualified for the issuance of a certificate of registration under
the provisions of this chapter. Immediately upon such revocation, written
notice thereof shall be given by the Chief of Police to the holder of the
certificate, in person or by certified U.S. mail addressed to his or her
residence address set forth in the application.
   (c)   Immediately upon the giving of such notice, the certificate of
registration shall become null and void.
   (d)   The certificate of registration shall state the expiration date
thereof.
(Ord. 94-9. Passed 4-4-94.)
864.04 CITY POLICY ON SOLICITATION.
   It is hereby declared to be the policy of the City that the occupant or
occupants of residences in the City shall make the determination of whether
solicitors shall be, or shall not be, invited to their respective residence.
(Ord. 94-9. Passed 4-4-94.)
864.05 "NO SOLICITORS INVITED" SIGNS.
   Every person desiring to secure the protection intended to be provided by
the regulations pertaining to soliciting contained in this chapter shall comply
with the following directions: Notice of the occupant's determination to refuse
to invite any solicitors into his or her residence shall be given in the
following manner:
   (a)   A weatherproof card, approximately six inches by twelve inches in
size, shall be exhibited upon or near the main entrance door to the residence,
indicating the determination by the occupant, containing the applicable words,
as follows:
   "NO SOLICITORS INVITED"
   (b)   The letters shall be at least one-third inch in height. For the
purpose of uniformity, the cards may be provided by the City Clerk to persons
requesting the same, at the cost thereof.
   (c)   Such card so exhibited shall constitute sufficient notice by the
occupant of the residence to any solicitor of such occupant's determination to
refuse any invitation to any solicitor.
(Ord. 94-9. Passed 4-4-94.)
864.06 DUTIES OF SOLICITORS.
   (a)   Entrance Upon Premises. It shall be the duty of every solicitor going
onto any premises in the City upon which a residence is located to first
examine any notice provided for in this chapter and to be governed by the
statement contained on the notice. If the notice states "NO SOLICITORS
INVITED," then the solicitor shall immediately and peacefully depart from the
premises.
   Any solicitor who has gained entrance to any residence, whether invited or
not, shall immediately and peacefully depart from the premises when requested
to do so by the occupant.
   (b)   Uninvited Soliciting Prohibited. It is hereby declared to be unlawful,
and it shall constitute a nuisance, for any person to go upon any premises and
ring the doorbell upon or near any door, or create any sound in any other
manner calculated to attract the attention of the occupant of such residence,
for the purpose of securing an audience with the occupant and engaging in
soliciting as defined in this chapter, in defiance of any notice exhibited at
the residence in accordance with the provisions of this chapter.
   (c)   Lawful Hours for Solicitation. It is hereby declared to be unlawful,
and it shall constitute a nuisance, for a person to go upon any premises and
ring the doorbell of a residence, rap or knock upon any door or create any
sound in any other manner calculated to attract the attention of the occupant
of such residence, for the purpose of securing an audience with the occupant
and engaging in soliciting, as defined in this chapter, prior to 9:00 a.m. or
after 5:00 p.m. Monday through Saturday. Soliciting shall be prohibited on
Sundays and on a State or national holiday.
   (d)   Unlawful Use of Fictitious Name, Occupation, Etc.; Fraud. No person
shall, directly or indirectly, solicit contributions for any purpose by
misrepresentation of his or her name, occupation, financial condition, social
condition or residence, and no person shall make or perpetrate any other
misstatement, deception or fraud in connection with any solicitation of any
contribution for any purpose.
(Ord. 94-9. Passed 4-4-94; Ord. 2024-20. Passed 5-6-24.)
864.07 SOLICITATION FROM OCCUPANTS OF VEHICLES ON PUBLIC WAYS.
   (a)   Allowable Solicitation in General. It is lawful for persons to stand
upon highways or other public streets within the City limits for the purpose of
soliciting contributions from occupants of vehicles only upon strict compliance
with the following express provisions:
      (1)   On highways. Solicitation on highways within the City limits shall
be allowed only under the following conditions:
         A.   The soliciting agency shall be registered with the Attorney
General of the State as a charitable organization, as provided by "An Act to
Regulate Solicitation and Collection of Funds for Charitable Purposes,
Providing for Violations Thereof, and Making an Appropriation Therefor,"
approved July 26, 1963, as amended;
         B.   The soliciting agency shall be engaged in a State-wide fund-
raising activity.
      (2)   On public streets. Solicitation on public streets within the City
limits shall be allowed only under the following conditions:
         A.   The soliciting agency shall be a recognized charitable
organization either by:
            1.   Having registered with the Attorney General of the State as a
charitable organization as provided in this section;
            2.   Having qualified as a tax-exempt charitable organization under
Section 501 of the United States Internal Revenue Code; or
            3.   Having obtained prior recognition as a charitable organization
by the City Manager.
         B.   The soliciting agency shall be engaged in a City-wide fund-
raising activity.
      (3)   Conditions under which solicitations are allowed on highways or
streets. Solicitation on highways or other public streets within the City
limits shall be allowed only under the following conditions:
         A.   The soliciting agency shall be liable for, and shall hold the
City harmless and indemnify the City from, any injury to any person or property
during the solicitation which is causally related to an act of the soliciting
agent or to the solicitation itself. The soliciting agency shall, at the time
of application for approval to solicit, furnish the City Clerk with proof that
the agency has general liability insurance coverage in amounts of at least five
hundred thousand dollars ($500,000) to one million dollars ($1,000,000), and
such proof of insurance shall include the City as an additional named insured.
         B.   All solicitation shall be restricted to intersections where all
traffic is required to come to a full stop.
         C.   Solicitation shall be limited to the intersections with a limit
from each intersection of 100 feet within which solicitation shall be
permitted.
         D.   A solicitation area shall be clearly marked with safety cones.
         E.   All persons engaged in the solicitation shall be at least
eighteen years of age and shall be wearing a high-visibility vest at all times
during the solicitation.
         F.   The soliciting agency shall secure permission from either the
Illinois Department of Transportation or the Public Works Director to have any
traffic signals at the intersection changed to a flashing red signal during the
solicitation period.
         G.   The soliciting agency shall obtain a permit from the office of
the City Clerk and be approved for the solicitation activity by the City
Manager.
   (b)   Permit Application. Any application for a permit to solicit on
highways or other public streets within the City shall be made to the City
Clerk at least thirty days prior to the requested solicitation day. The
application shall be accompanied by proof of compliance with all of the
requirements provided herein.
   (c)   Additional Restrictions. Restrictions may be made in the discretion of
the City Manager with respect to the certainty of dates, times, locations,
number of solicitors and such other restrictions as the City Manager determines
to be necessary for the public health, safety and welfare. The following time
restrictions may apply: not earlier than 9:00 a.m. and not later than 6:00 p.m.
   (d)   Number of Solicitations Permitted Per Month. Solicitation approval on
any given intersection of a public street within the City limits shall be
restricted to no more than two weekends per calendar month.
(Ord. 94-9. Passed 4-4-94; Ord. 2017-56. Passed 7-17-17.)
864.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
202.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
CHAPTER 866
Sound Advertising
866.01   Definitions.
866.02   Licenses.
866.03   Hours of operation.
866.04   Operation regulations.
866.05   Noise.
866.06   Display of licenses.
866.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Noise prevention or suppression by municipal authorities - see 65 ILCS 5/11-
5-2
   Noise pollution - see 415 ILCS 5/23 et seq.
   Crimes and offenses; fraud - see 720 ILCS 295/1a et seq.
   Noise from advertising - see GEN. OFF.
670.05(c)(3)
866.01 DEFINITIONS.
   As used in this chapter:
   (a)   "Aircraft" means any contrivance now known or hereafter invented, used
or designated for flight in the air, including airplanes, helicopters, lighter-
than-air dirigibles and balloons.
   (b)   "Sound-amplifying equipment" means any machine or device used for the
amplification of the human voice, music or any other sound, but not including
standard radios when used and heard only by occupants of the vehicle in which
they are installed, warning devices on authorized emergency vehicles and horns
or other warning devices used only for traffic safety.
   (c)   "Sound truck" means any motor or horse-drawn vehicle having mounted
thereon, or attached thereto, any sound-amplifying equipment.
(1977 Code § 9-1701)
866.02 LICENSES.
   (a)   Required. No person shall operate or cause to be operated any sound
truck or aircraft in or over the City, for noncommercial or commercial
advertising purposes, with sound-amplifying equipment in operation, without
first obtaining a license therefor.
   (b)   Application. An application for a license shall contain, in addition
to standard application requirements:
      (1)   The license number and motor number of the sound truck, or the
Federal N.C. registration number and aircraft motor number of the aircraft, to
be used by the applicant;
      (2)   Names and addresses of all persons who will operate the truck or
aircraft;
      (3)   The proposed hours of operation; and
      (4)   The number of days of proposed operation.
   (c)   Fees. The fees for a license under subsection (a) hereof shall be ten
dollars ($10.00) for each day on which such equipment is operated.
(1977 Code §§ 9-1702 to 9-1704)
866.03 HOURS OF OPERATION.
   The period of operation of any sound-amplifying equipment shall be limited
to the hours of 11:30 a.m. to 1:30 p.m. and from 4:00 p.m. to 6:00 p.m. No such
device shall be operated on Sundays or legal holidays.
(1977 Code § 9-1705)
866.04 OPERATION REGULATIONS.
   Licensees and their equipment shall be subject to the following regulations:
   (a)   The only sounds permitted are music or human speech.
   (b)   Sound truck equipment shall not be operated unless the truck is
operated at a speed of at least ten miles per hour, except when stopped or
impeded by traffic. The sound equipment shall not be operated for longer than
one minute during each such stop.
   (c)   Sound shall not be issued from a truck within 100 yards of hospitals,
schools in session or churches.
   (d)   The human speech and music amplified shall not be profane, lewd,
indecent or slanderous.
   (e)   The volume of sound shall be controlled so that it will not be
unreasonably loud, raucous, jarring, disturbing or a nuisance to persons within
the area of audibility.
   (f)   No sound-amplifying equipment shall be operated with an excess of
thirty watts of power in the last stage of amplification.
   (g)   Sound-amplifying equipment shall not be operated while an aircraft is
flying at an altitude of less than 1,500 feet.
   (h)   Sound shall be issued from one loudspeaker only on each aircraft.
(1977 Code § 9-1706)
866.05 NOISE.
   Licensees and their equipment shall be subject to all of the provisions of
Section
670.05 of the General Offenses Code, except as specifically modified by this
chapter.
(1977 Code § 9-1707)
866.06 DISPLAY OF LICENSES.
   A licensee shall keep such license in his or her possession in the truck or
aircraft during the time the sound-amplifying equipment is in operation. The
license shall be promptly displayed and shown to any police officer upon
request.
(1977 Code § 9-1708)
866.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
202.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
