1062.01 ESTABLISHMENT.
   A cemetery known as the "City Cemetery" is hereby established and shall be
maintained by the City.
(1977 Code § 12-101)
1062.02 LOCATION.
   The City Cemetery shall be located on, and shall consist of, the following
described real estate:
   The West Half of the North East Quarter of the South East Quarter, and the
North Half of the North West Quarter of the South East Quarter of the South
East Quarter, of Section Thirty-six in Township Twenty-seven, Range Seven, East
of the fourth P.M., situated in the City of Freeport, County of Stephenson and
State of Illinois.
(1977 Code § 12-102)
1062.03 DESCRIPTION OF LOTS.
   Lots in the City Cemetery shall be described by reference to the replat of
the plats recorded in the County Recorder's Office in Book "U" of Deeds, page
542, and Book "A" of Plats, at pages 44 and 45, and the Plat of March 3, 1882,
by F.E. Josel, City Engineer, such replat having been recorded in said
Recorder's Office on September 17, 1962, in Book "G" of Plats, page 21.
(1977 Code § 12-103)
1062.04 VACATION OF ALLEYS TO ABUTTING LOTS.
   The vacation of certain alleys is hereby confirmed, with such vacated alleys
to be divided in the center thereof, one-half to be attached to, and become
part of, the lots adjoining on each side of such alleys, and the title of such
alleys so divided to be passed with the lots to which they are hereby attached
without any further description, such alleys being described as follows:
   The alleys between Ranges Five and Six, Ten and Eleven, Twelve and Thirteen,
Fifteen and Sixteen, One and Two, Three and Four, Seven and Eight, in the
Northwest Quarter of the Cemetery; the alleys between Ranges One and Two, Four
and Five, Six and Seven, Eight and Nine, Ten and Eleven, Twelve and Thirteen,
Fourteen and Fifteen, Sixteen and Seventeen, in the Northeast Quarter of the
Cemetery; the alleys between Ranges One and Two, Four and Five, Six and Seven,
Eight and Nine, Ten and Eleven, Twelve and Thirteen, Fourteen and Fifteen,
Sixteen and Seventeen, in the Southeast Quarter of the Cemetery; the alleys
between Ranges One and Two, Three and Four, Five and Six, Eight and Nine, Ten
and Eleven, Twelve and Thirteen, Fourteen and Fifteen, Sixteen and Seventeen,
in the Southwest Quarter of the Cemetery; and the alley between lots Thirteen
and Fourteen, in Range Nine, and Thirteen and Fourteen, in Range Ten, in Block
One in the Addition to the Cemetery.
(1977 Code § 12-104)
1062.05 VACATION OF ALLEYS AND AISLES FOR ADDITIONAL LOTS.
   The vacation of the following alleys and aisles is hereby confirmed, with
the vacated land being restored for sale and use for burial purposes:
   A strip of land ten feet in width off the North side of Fourth Street in the
Addition to the Cemetery; a strip of land five feet in width off the North side
of the alley South of Lot Twelve in Range Nine and Lot Twelve in Range Ten,
both in Block One in the Addition to the Cemetery; Aisles A 1 through A 34,
inclusive in Central Row; Aisles A 1, A 2, A 3, A 4, A 6, A 7, in Block One;
Aisles A 10 and A 11 in Block One, except the part lying between Lots 13 and 14
of said Block; Aisles A 1, A 2, A 3, A 4, A 6, A 7, A 8, A 9 in Block Two;
Aisles A 1, A 2, A 3, A 4, A 6, A 7, A 8, A 9, in Block Three; Aisles A 1, A 2,
A 3, A 4, A 6, A 7, A 8, A 9, in Block Three; Aisles A 1, A 2, A 3, A 4, A 6, A
7, A 8, A 9, in Block Five; Aisles A 1, A 2, A 3, A 4, A 6, A 7, A 8, A 9, in
Block Six.
(1977 Code § 12-105)
1062.06 VACATION OF LOTS FOR ALLEYS.
   Lots Twelve in Ranges Nine and Ten, in Block One, in the Addition to the
Cemetery, are hereby vacated and discontinued as burial lots in the Cemetery,
and such lots are hereby set apart as an alley.
(1977 Code § 12-106)
1062.07 DESIGNATED BURIAL AISLES.
   (a)   Veterans' Aisles. Aisle nine, aisle eight and aisle seven in block
four are hereby set aside for the burial of veterans and their spouses, and no
body shall be buried in said aisles except a veteran or a spouse of a veteran
of the Armed Services of the United States. The burial site may be obtained at
no charge to the veteran; however, the fees established in this chapter shall
be paid for the burial site of the veteran's spouse. Veterans may be buried in
a location other than the designated Veteran's Aisles within the City Cemetery;
however, in such event, fees established in this chapter shall be paid for said
veteran's burial site.
   (b)   Infant Aisles. Aisle one in block three and aisle one in block six are
hereby set aside for the burial of infants under the age of two years. No body
shall be buried in said aisles except infants under the age of two years.
Infants may be buried in a location other than the designated Infant Aisles
within the City Cemetery; however, in such event, fees established in this
chapter shall be paid for said infant's burial site.
   (c)   Cremation Lots. From time to time, the Sexton shall, at his or her
discretion, designate certain burial sites for cremation burials. The location
of such sites shall be determined by, but not limited to, accessibility and
demand for such location. In the event that a family lot is full, cremation
burials will be allowed on top of previously interred family members, but in no
event shall more than two cremation burials be allowed on the same burial lot.
In such cremation burials, fees for opening and closing only shall be charged.
Cremation burials are not limited to the designated lots; however, in such
event, fees established in this chapter shall be paid for said cremation
burial. The person requesting a cremation burial shall provide to the City an
acceptable permanent marker of the name of the person whose cremains are within
said cremation burial container. The Sexton shall affix said permanent marker
to the burial lot which contains said cremation burial container.
(Ord. 98-63. Passed 10-5-98; Ord. 2017-39. Passed 6-5-17.)
1062.08 MANAGEMENT AND CONTROL.
   The City Manager shall have the care, charge, management and control of the
Cemetery, and among other things, shall:
   (a)   Employ a Sexton, prescribe his or her duties and fix his or her
salary.
   (b)   Administer and preserve all records of the Cemetery, particularly with
reference to the ownership of all lots.
   (c)   Receive funds for the maintenance of individual lots, and expend such
funds for the purposes designated.
   (d)   Appraise the value of each lot owned by the City.
   (e)   Make all reasonable rules and regulations for the conduct of the
Cemetery.
   (f)   Fix the fees and charges for the services of the Sexton and the
facilities of the Cemetery.
(1977 Code §12-108; Ord. 2017-56. Passed 7-17-17.)
1062.09 SEXTON.
   (a)   Appointment. The City Manager shall appoint the Sexton.
   (b)   Compensation. Council shall fix the compensation of the Sexton, and he
or she shall not retain for his or her own use any fees or charges coming into
his or her hands as Sexton.
   (c)   Removal. The Sexton may be removed at any time by the City Manager,
with or without cause.
   (d)   Duties. The Sexton shall:
      (1)   Have charge of the City Cemetery.
      (2)   Keep the public grounds, walks and streets free from grass, weeds
and obstructions.
      (3)   Keep the potter's field and the graves of all veterans of the
United States Armed Services in good order.
      (4)   Enforce the ordinances concerning the Cemetery and report
violations thereof to the Police or City Legal Counsel for prosecution.
      (5)   Have power to direct how and where any dead body not belonging to
the owner of any lot shall be buried, and to prevent the burial of any body in
any lot which is the property of another, without the consent, in writing, of
the owner of such lot.
      (6)   Be subject to the orders and directions of the City Manager.
      (7)   Keep a record of all interments made in the Cemetery, stating the
name, sex and age of the deceased, the date of death, the place in which the
deceased resided, and the number of the lot and block, or range, in which the
deceased shall be interred.
      (8)   Make a detailed monthly report, in writing, upon forms to be
furnished by the Public Works Director.
      (9)   Wait on prospective purchasers of lots, showing the exact location,
with price and legal description, and make sales thereof.
      (10)   Deliver to the purchaser an order for a deed upon forms furnished
by the Public Works Director.
      (11)   Dig, or cause to be dug, all graves in the Cemetery, attend to the
interment of all persons buried therein, attend to all disinterments, and
backfill and keep filled all graves therein. In backfilling and filling graves,
he or she shall use dirt or clay, entirely free from sticks, stone, gravel or
rubbish, of any kind.
      (12)   Keep all grass, shrubs, plants and trees in the Cemetery
seasonally mowed, trimmed and cut so as to maintain the Cemetery in a most
presentable and attractive condition.
      (13)   Keep in repair all public buildings, fences and sidewalks, and
maintain them in good order and condition.
      (14)   Ascertain that all graves hereafter dug, except those of infants,
are at least five feet deep.
      (15)   Be subject to the criminal penalties of this chapter for violation
of any of his or her duties, in addition to the penalty of discharge.
      (16)   Be, and he or she hereby is constituted, a police officer and
conservator of the peace for the City, and as such shall have full power to
arrest and take before the appropriate court any person who shall cause any
disturbance, or in any manner break, or threaten to break, the peace, disobey
any order of the Sexton within or about the Cemetery or violate any ordinance
of the City.
      (17)   Perform duties designated by the Superintendent of Streets,
including, but not limited to, plowing of snow.
   (e)   Extra Work. The Sexton shall perform extra work, such as repairing
graves, grading, care of flowers and the like, for lot owners or persons
interested in the upkeep of any lot in the Cemetery, in accordance with the
following requirements: persons desiring such work shall apprise the Sexton of
the work required, and the Sexton shall complete a proper form as to the name
of the applicant, a description of the lot and the work and his or her estimate
of the cost. This written statement, and the estimated fee, shall be delivered
by the applicant to the Finance Director or his or her designee. The Finance
Director or his or her designee shall issue a receipt therefor in triplicate,
one of which receipts shall be given to the Sexton, who shall then perform the
work. The Sexton shall not receive any money for extra work whatsoever.
(1977 Code §§12-109 to 12-113; Ord. 86-15. Passed 3-17-86; Ord. 97-21. Passed
7-21-97; Ord. 98-63. Passed 10-5-98; Ord. 2017-56. Passed 7-17-17; Ord. 2019-
03. Passed 1-14-19; Ord. 2022-75. Passed 12-19-22.)
1062.10 SALE OF LOTS.
   Applications for lots in the Cemetery shall be made to the Finance Director
or his or her designee in the Finance Department. The Finance Department, in
cooperation with the Cemetery Sexton, shall maintain a list of all lots, with
numbers and ranges described as in the plats, together with columns for the
name of the purchaser, date of sale, and amount received for each lot. On
payment of the purchase price to the Finance Department, the City Clerk shall
deliver a deed for the lot to the purchaser, executed by the City Manager and
the City Clerk, under the corporate seal. No payment of money for the purchase
of any lot shall be binding upon the City unless made directly to the Finance
Department.
(Ord. 98-63. Passed 10-5-98; Ord. 2017-56. Passed 7-17-17.)
1062.11 FEES.
   (a)   Grave Opening Fees. The Finance Director shall receive, in advance,
for interments or disinterments, the sum of six hundred and fifty dollars
($650.00) per grave opening, except that the fee for openings for infants under
the age of two years at death, and for the burial of a cremation urn or box,
shall be one hundred seventy-five dollars ($175.00).
   (b)   Grave Sales. Except as otherwise provided herein, the Finance Director
shall receive, and the Finance Director shall hold in perpetual trust, the sum
of six hundred eighty-six dollars ($686.00) per burial lot.
      (1)   No fee shall be paid for veterans or infants buried within the
designated Veteran or Infant Aisles.
      (2)   The sum of one hundred dollars ($100.00) shall be paid for the
burial of crematory urns or boxes within the designated crematory lots.
      (3)   The fee for any burial of a person on public assistance shall be
six hundred eighty-six dollars ($686.00) or the maximum, amount allowed by the
Illinois Department of Human Services as revised from time to time, whichever
is less. Acceptable proof of public assistance shall be determined by the
Finance Director.
      (4)   An additional fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) will be charged
for weekends and holidays.
      (5)   An additional fee of seventy-five dollars ($75.00) will be charged
when equipment is used for thawing purposes.
(Ord. 98-63. Passed 10-5-98; Ord. 2004-07. Passed 5-3-04; Ord. 2009- 26. Passed
4-20-09; Ord. 2018-67. Passed 12-17-18; Ord. 2021-01. Passed 1-4-21.)
1062.12 PERPETUAL FUND.
   (a)   In General. All monies received by the Finance Director or his or her
designee for the sale of lots shall be held by the Finance Director in a
perpetual trust for the maintenance, repair, upkeep and ornamentation of the
Cemetery. The principal of such trust fund shall be kept intact and perpetually
invested, and the interest income earned from such investment may used for the
maintenance, repair, upkeep and ornamentation of the Cemetery.
   (b)   Investment. All perpetual fund monies received by the Finance Director
shall be invested pursuant to the City Investment Policy, approved by the City
Council, in a manner which will provide the highest investment return using
authorized instruments, while conforming to all State statutes governing the
investment of public funds.
(Ord. 97-21. Passed 7-21-97; Ord. 98-63. Passed 10-5-98; Ord. 2018-67. Passed
12-17-18; Ord. 2021-34. Passed 9-7-21.)
1062.13 DISPOSITION OF FEES.
   All fees and monies received by the Finance Department for grave opening
fees or for any permit, service or charge, other than for the sale of lots,
shall be considered corporate fund receipts of the City.
(Ord. 98-63. Passed 10-5-98.)
1062.14 BURIAL PROHIBITED IN UNPAID LOTS.
   No person shall bury a body in any lot in the Cemetery until the price for
such lot shall have been paid.
(1977 Code § 12-120)
1062.15 PRIVATE PLANTINGS.
   No private person shall plant trees, bushes or other shrubbery in the
Cemetery. The Sexton shall have power to remove any existing trees, bushes,
plants or shrubbery which become or are unsightly, or an obstruction to passage
or view.
(1977 Code § 12-121)
1062.16 CORNERSTONES, FENCES, BOUNDARIES AND GRADES.
   No barbed wire or barbed wire fences shall be placed or maintained anywhere
in the Cemetery. The Sexton may remove any and all lot cornerstones, lot
boundary markers, fences, railings, ornamental ironwork, ornamental stonework
or other improvements or constructions in the Cemetery, other than monuments,
headstones, vaults, footstones or other markers which actually locate, contain
or identify a grave, or series of graves, at any time. The Sexton may level or
change the grade or height of any lots, aisles or alleyways in the Cemetery at
any time. Hereafter, no monument, stone, marker or other construction or
obstruction shall be placed or erected in the Cemetery unless the same is in
compliance with the reasonable rules and regulations issued from time to time
and unless the same has been authorized, in writing, by the Sexton. The City
Manager, and its appropriate committee, shall guide and direct the Sexton in
the exercise of such powers.
(1977 Code §12-122; Ord. 2017-56. Passed 7-17-17)
1062.17 VIOLATIONS.
   No person shall resist the Sexton in the execution of any duty, refuse or
neglect to obey his or her lawful direction, be found discharging firearms,
hunting or trespassing, in any manner, in the Cemetery, injure, deface or
destroy any tree, shrub, stone, stake, post, fence, monument, vault, other
fixture, building, thing of value or ornament in the Cemetery, trespass on any
grave in the Cemetery or violate any provision of this chapter.
(1977 Code § 12-123)
1062.18 HOURS OPEN TO THE PUBLIC.
   The Cemetery shall be open to the general public daily from sunrise to
sunset. During the time between sunset and sunrise of any day, any person found
in the Cemetery or who enters the Cemetery or who remains in the Cemetery shall
be guilty of trespassing and shall be subject to the penalty provided in
Section
1062.99, provided, however, that the provisions of this section shall not apply
to any State, County or City official, including elected officers, appointed
officers, police officers, firefighters, employees, and legal counsel or
agents, when any such person is in the Cemetery pursuant to or in connection
with any official Cemetery or governmental business.
(1977 Code § 12-124)
1062.19 INCORPORATION OF APPLICABLE STATUTORY PROVISIONS.
   All pertinent and applicable provisions of 65 ILCS 5/11-49-1 et seq., 410
ILCS 5/1 and 5/2 and 805 ILCS 320/0.01 et seq., as heretofore and hereafter
amended, are incorporated herein by reference, subject to the provisions of
Section
202.05(b) of the Administration Code.
1062.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
202.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
CHAPTER 1063
Cemeteries Generally
1063.01   Purpose; intent.
1063.02   Standards of care.
1063.03   Public access.
1063.04   Rules and regulations.
1063.05   Non-exclusive remedy.
1063.06   Mandatory injunction.
1063.07   Violations; abatement.
1063.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Cemeteries and dead bodies generally - see 410 ILCS 5/1, 5/2; 805 ILCS 320/
0.01 et seq.
   City Cemetery - see S.U. & P.S.
Ch. 1062
   Cemetery Department as Administrative Agency for Lincoln -Douglas Debate
Site - see S.U. & P.S.
1074.03
1063.01 PURPOSE; INTENT.
   This chapter is declared to bear a reasonable relation to public health,
safety and welfare; and is intended to prescribe certain minimal standards of
care applicable to any cemetery located within the territorial boundaries of
the City of Freeport, as now existing or hereafter changed, and within one-half
mile of such corporate limits pursuant to 65 ILCS 5/7-4-1. This chapter shall
not abridge the right of a cemetery owner to enact reasonable rules and
regulations not inconsistent with the provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. 98-18. Passed 3-16-98.)
1063.02 STANDARDS OF CARE.
   Subject to acts of God and any other causes beyond the control of the
cemetery owner which could not be avoided by the exercise of care, prudence,
foresight or diligence, the following minimal standards of care shall be met by
any cemetery owner or operator, or any representative or agent thereof:
   (a)   Keep all walks, driveways and roads free from grass, weeds and
obstructions in keeping with a well-maintained cemetery.
   (b)   Keep all grass, shrubs, plants and trees seasonally mowed, trimmed and
cut, and provide for seasonal pick-up and removal of leaves so as to maintain
the cemetery in keeping with a well-maintained cemetery.
   (c)   Maintain drains, water lines, buildings, fences and other structures
in keeping with a well-maintained cemetery.
   (d)   Backfill, fill and reseed or resod all graves, using dirt or clay
which is free from environmental contaminants, and in keeping with a well-
maintained cemetery.
   (e)   Responsibly prevent negligent damage by the cemetery owner or any
agent thereof to any gravestone, memorial, monument, marker, or burial plot,
except where such damage is the result of natural causes or customary
deterioration resulting from age of such gravestone, memorial, monument, marker
or burial plot.
   (f)   Responsibly prevent negligent damage by the cemetery owner or any
agent thereof to any property, gravestone, memorial, monument or marker which
is provided by or supported in whole or in part with Federal funds, State
funds, or funds of a unit of local government, except where such damage is the
result of natural causes or customary deterioration resulting from the age of
such gravestone, memorial, monument, marker or burial plot.
(Ord. 98-18. Passed 3-16-98.)
1063.03 PUBLIC ACCESS.
   Any cemetery owner or operator, or any representative or agent, shall assure
the following minimal customer service standards:
   (a)   Permit members of the general public to enter the cemetery during the
hours of sunrise to sunset.
   (b)   Refrain from unreasonably interfering with the right of relatives of
the deceased to attend, care for, and beautify a gravesite.
   (c)   Ensure that interment rights owners have the right to decorate graves
in accordance with uniformity, maintenance and safety standards of the
cemetery.
   Nothing in this section is intended to restrict a cemetery owner or operator
from establishing and enforcing reasonable rules and regulations concerning
trespass and other inappropriate behavior within the cemetery.
(Ord. 98-18. Passed 3-16-98.)
1063.04 RULES AND REGULATIONS.
   The Community and Economic Development Director may establish, issue, and
enforce such reasonable rules and regulations adopted by the City Council,
relating to the administration and enforcement of the provisions of this
chapter, including notice provisions to any cemetery owner or operator setting
forth timely remediation of any violation of this chapter. The Community and
Economic Development Director shall consider any existing rules and regulations
of the cemetery in determining whether a violation has occurred.
(Ord. 98-18. Passed 3-16-98; Ord. 2017-56. Passed 7-17-17.)
1063.05 NON-EXCLUSIVE REMEDY.
   The provisions of this chapter are not intended in any way to abridge or
replace any private right of action to which an aggrieved party may be
entitled.
(Ord. 98-18. Passed 3-16-98.)
1063.06 MANDATORY INJUNCTION.
   In addition to all other penalties and remedies provided for in this
chapter, the City shall have the right to seek and obtain a mandatory
injunction against the owner of any such cemetery which is being maintained in
violation of any of the provisions of this chapter, enjoining and ordering him
or her to comply with the provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. 98-18. Passed 3-16-98.)
1063.07 VIOLATIONS; ABATEMENT.
   (a)   Court Order. When any person shall have been convicted of any
violation of this chapter or any rule or regulation established by the
Community Development Director, the court before which such conviction is
entered may order the defendant to abate and remove such violation within such
time as may be specified by order of such court.
   (b)   Abatement by Community and Economic Development Director. Whenever any
person, having been found guilty of any violation of this chapter or any rule
or regulation established by the Community and Economic Development Director,
shall fail to abate or remove the same as provided in subsection (a) hereof,
the Community and Economic Development Director shall proceed, with due care
and without any unnecessary destruction of property, to remove or abate such
violation, to keep an accurate account of all expenses incurred in such
abatement, and to report the same to the City Legal Counsel for filing and
recording a lien against the subject property.
   (c)   Liability for Costs. In addition to the penalty provided in Section
1063.99 , any person found guilty of any violation of this chapter or any rule
or regulation of the Community Development Director, and ordered to abate such
violation, shall be liable for all costs and expenses of such abatement.
(Ord. 98-18. Passed 3-16-98; Ord. 2017-56. Passed 7-17-17.)
1063.99 PENALTY.
   Whoever violates or fails to comply with any of the provisions of this
chapter shall be fined not less than three hundred dollars ($300.00) nor more
than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for the first violation and not less than
five hundred dollars ($500.00) for the second and each subsequent violation.
Each day that a violation occurs or continues shall be a separate violation.
Enforcement proceedings may be commenced by either a notice to appear or by a
summons.
(Ord. 98-18. Passed 3-16-98.)
CHAPTER 1064
Emergency Police Alarm Systems

1064.02   Alarm holder permits; applications.
1064.03   Automatic dialers prohibited.

1064.11   Rights of the City.
1064.12   Duties of police officers responding to alarms.
1064.13   Enforcement.
1064.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Alarm contractors - see 225 ILCS 445/1 et seq.
   False alarms - see 720 ILCS 5/26-1; GEN. OFF.
670.04
   Police emergencies; immunity from liability - see 745 ILCS 20/1
   Police Department - see ADM.
Ch. 240
   Tampering with alarm systems - see GEN. OFF.
664.09
1064.01 DEFINITIONS. 
   As used in this chapter, the following terms, phrases, words and their
derivations are hereby defined as follows:
   (a)   "Alarm holder" means the owner, lessor or person responsible for the
existence of an alarm system within or on his or her premises.
   (b)   "Alarm system" means an assembly of equipment, components or devices
arranged to signal the presence of a hazard requiring urgent attention and to
which personnel of the Police Department are expected to respond. Such system
shall be construed hereunder to include burglar alarm systems, manual holdup
alarm systems and local alarm systems.
   (c)   "Automatic dialers" means an alarm system that, when activated,
automatically relays over regular telephone lines (as distinguished from
dedicated telephone lines) a prerecorded voice message or coded signal
indicating the existence of an emergency situation.
   (d)   "Burglar alarm" means an alarm system activated by signaling an entry
or attempted entry into the area protected by the alarm system.
   (e)   "Central answering point" means an office or place to which alarm
systems are relayed and where operators monitor and investigate such alarm
signals prior to notifying the appropriate agency of an emergency situation.
   (f)   "Dedicated telephone line" means a telephone line which is used solely
for the transmission of an alarm signal.
   (g)   "Direct connection" means a method of using a telephone line which is
used solely for the transmission of an alarm signal to a central receiving
facility provided by the City.
   (h)   "False alarm" means an alarm signal resulting from a malfunction,
improper installation, human error, a hurricane, a tornado, an earthquake, a
thunderstorm, other acts of God or an interruption of service supplied by a
carrier of the signal.
   (i)   "Fire alarm" means an alarm system designed to detect heat or smoke.
   (j)   "Holdup alarm" means an alarm system which is activated manually to
signal a robbery or an attempted robbery.
   (k)   "Local alarm" means an alarm system which, when activated, causes an
audible or visual signal in or on the premises that the system is designed to
protect. Such alarm may or may not be a part of a system to notify an answering
point.
   (l)   "Service charge" means an assessment by the City against an alarm
holder for false alarms emanating from the alarm system as provided in this
chapter.
   (m)   "Trouble indication" means a transmitted signal different from the
alarm signal which indicates a mechanical/electrical problem in the system.
(1977 Code § 54-502; Ord. 90-78. Passed 11-5-90.)
1064.02 ALARM HOLDER PERMITS; APPLICATIONS.
   (a)   No person shall, within thirty days from the effective date of this
chapter, be authorized to operate an alarm system, other than local alarms as
defined herein, without first obtaining an alarm user's permit. Users requiring
new installations shall obtain permits within ten days following passage of
this chapter.
   (b)   Known existing alarm holders shall have ninety days after this chapter
has been adopted to obtain the required permit.
   (c)   All applications for a permit shall be made upon forms prescribed by
the Police Chief, which may be obtained at the Police Department, located at
320 West Exchange Street, Freeport, Illinois 61032.
   (d)   All applications for new permits must contain the updated names of the
agent or key holder.
   (e)   All applicants and all manufacturers and companies under contract to
maintain receiving alarm equipment within facilities of the City, by their
several acts in applying for and in receiving permits to use said facilities,
shall be deemed to have agreed that the City shall not be held liable for any
alarm failure of service and shall not be held liable for any consequential
damages resulting from such failure. Further, such permit holders, upon
receiving their permits, also agree thereby that the City shall not be liable
for any damage that may result from the installation, maintenance or operation
of the alarm system, such installation, maintenance and operation being the
sole responsibility of the alarm holder. Further, alarm holders, by the act of
obtaining issuance of a permit to them, shall be deemed to have agreed to all
of the provisions of subsections (f) and (g) hereof.
   (f)   All applicants, by receiving a permit, agree to indemnify, defend and
save harmless the City, its agents, servants and employees, and the
manufacturers and companies, if any, under contract or agreement to maintain
the receiving alarm equipment in the City facilities, from any and all claims,
demands, judgments, liability, costs and expenses that may arise, in any way,
as a result of utilization of the alarm connection to City.
   (g)   All permit holders agree that the City, the equipment manufacturers
and companies under contract to maintain receiving alarm equipment within City
facilities shall not be liable for any costs or expenses of installation,
maintenance of leased services or any other charge or fee for any alarm
equipment leased or owned by the applicant.
   (h)   All applicants, at the time of making application for a permit
hereunder, must certify that they have a system of alarm maintenance available
to them on a twenty-four hour basis and that an alternative power source is
available to prevent false alarms due to any failure of power supplied by a
utility company.
   (i)   The alarm holders permit application form will be reviewed by the
Police Chief to determine whether such form complies with this chapter. If the
Police Chief approves such form, the Police Chief shall issue a permit.
(1977 Code § 54-503; Ord. 90-78. Passed 11-5-90.)
1064.03 AUTOMATIC DIALERS PROHIBITED.
   As of January 1, 1992, no person shall install, maintain or use or permit
the installation, maintenance or use of any automatic dialer which is
programmed to contact the City's alarm facilities.
(1977 Code § 54-503.5; Ord. 90-78. Passed 11-5-90.)
1064.04 DIRECT COMMUNICATION TO CITY FACILITIES. 
   (a)   After issuance by the Police Chief of a permit, the holders of permits
for alarms from business premises, financial institutions and residences may
have such systems so installed as to terminate within the City's alarm
facilities.
   (b)   An alarm holder approved for direct connection to City alarm
facilities or the company contracting for servicing the subscriber's alarm
system shall be responsible for obtaining the data path between the alarm
holder's premises and the alarm receiving equipment, if required, in order to
provide an input signal which is compatible with the receiving equipment.
   (c)   All signals transmitted over wires shall be transmitted in a method
compatible with the alarm receiving equipment and the requirements of the City.
   (d)   Such alarms shall be subject to the same provisions concerning false
alarms as other systems addressed in this chapter.
   (e)   Each direct communication alarm system user in the City shall provide
an alternative source of power for the alarm system in order to prevent false
alarms due to failure of power supplied from the utility company. Such
alternative source of power shall have the capacity to provide power for at
least twenty-four hours subsequent to any power failure.
(1977 Code § 54-504; Ord. 90-78. Passed 11-5-90.)
1064.05 CENTRAL ANSWERING POINTS.  
   Upon approval of an application for a permit, an alarm holder may utilize an
alarm system connected to a central answering point other than the City's
facility. The operator of such answering point shall first attempt to determine
the validity of an alarm signal, and, if unable to do so, shall notify the
Police Department whether the signal is believed to be a valid or genuine
alarm.
(1977 Code § 54-505; Ord. 90-78. Passed 11-5-90.)
1064.06 LOCAL ALARMS.  
   Local alarms shall have an automatic shutoff which will deactivate the sound
within ten minutes after activation of the alarm. In the event that such alarm
shall not respond to the automatic shutoff, neither the City nor its employees
shall be liable for damages by reason of failure of such shutoff device.
(1977 Code § 54-506; Ord. 90-78. Passed 11-5-90.)
1064.07 FALSE ALARMS.
   (a)   Three false alarms shall be without charge in any twelve-month period.
A service charge of fifty dollars ($50.00) shall be billed to the alarm holder
reporting the fourth false alarm. A service charge of one hundred dollars
($100.00) shall be billed to the alarm holder reporting the fifth false alarm.
A service charge of one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00) shall be billed to the
alarm holder reporting the sixth false alarm and for each false alarm
thereafter in any twelve-month period, except as provided in Section
1064.10(b).
   (b)   Should a false alarm be transmitted by a piece of electronic equipment
under service by an alarm company, there shall be no charge for a false alarm,
provided that the alarm holder gives the Police Chief proof that the defect is
being corrected.
   (c)   In the event false alarms or trouble alarms continue during any
twelve-month period, the Police Chief may direct the company maintaining the
City monitoring equipment to disconnect the premises from which such false
alarms, or trouble alarms, originate, from such equipment. Reconnection of such
premises to the monitoring equipment shall not be made until all false alarm
fees and a reconnection charge of two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00) have been
paid by the company.
   (d)   Failure or refusal of any alarm holder to pay any service charge or
charges for false alarms may result in discontinuance of the alarm service.
   (e)   A thirty-day grace period for new alarm systems or for major
modification or addition to existing alarm systems shall be granted upon
approval by the Police Chief.
(1977 Code § 54-507; Ord. 90-78. Passed 11-5-90.)
1064.08 TESTING OF EQUIPMENT.
   (a)   Alarm systems transmitting emergency signals directly to the
communication center of the City shall be tested or demonstrated only with
prior approval from the Police Chief.
   (b)   Approval of the Police Chief is not required to test or demonstrate
alarm devices not transmitting emergency messages directly to the communication
center unless the messages are to be relayed to City facilities.
(1977 Code § 54-508; Ord. 90-78. Passed 11-5-90.)
1064.09 DISCONNECTION FROM CITY FACILITIES.
   (a)   Failure of an alarm holder to pay any service charges required to be
paid by this chapter shall be cause for the Police Chief to disconnect an alarm
system.
   (b)   If any alarm system records twelve false alarms within any twelve-
month period, such shall be cause for the Police Chief to disconnect an alarm
system upon giving sixty days written notice to the alarm holder.
   (c)   Twelve or more trouble indicators from any alarm system within any
twelve-month period shall be cause for the Police Chief to disconnect an alarm
system after sixty days written notice to the alarm holder.
   (d)   Any disconnection hereunder shall not be of any cost to the City.
(1977 Code § 54-509; Ord. 90-78. Passed 11-5-90.)
1064.10 RECONNECTION TO CITY FACILITIES.
   (a)   If an alarm system has been disconnected because of nonpayment of any
charges, the alarm system may be reconnected to City facilities only after
payment of all outstanding charges.
   (b)   If an alarm system has been disconnected because of excessive false
alarms or trouble indicators, the alarm holder affected must submit to the
Police Chief a written statement showing all reasons, if any, for the false
alarms or trouble indicators, and setting forth what measures have been taken
to prevent or to minimize future or similar problems. The Police Chief shall
review such statement, and, if the Police Chief recommends reconnection of the
alarm system in question, the alarm holder shall apply for a permit as in the
instance of initial application.
(1977 Code § 54-510; Ord. 90-78. Passed 11-5-90.)
1064.11 RIGHTS OF THE CITY.
   (a)   The City reserves the right to disconnect the services connected with
monitoring any alarm system after giving sixty days written notice of its
intent to disconnect.
   (b)   The City is under no obligation to provide this special type of
monitoring service to any person, and the City expressly reserves the right to
deny to any person the privilege of connecting an alarm system to facilities of
the City.
(1977 Code § 54-511(a), (b); Ord. 90-78. Passed 11-5-90.)
1064.12 DUTIES OF POLICE OFFICERS RESPONDING TO ALARMS.
   (a)   In those instances in which an alarm is activated and a police officer
responds by going to the premises, if such police officer finds no evidence of
breaking and entering, the police officer shall not be required to remain at
the premises.
   (b)   In those instances in which an alarm is activated and a police officer
responds by going to the premises, if such police officer finds evidence of
breaking and entering, the investigating officer will remain at the premises
until the owner or his or her agent arrives in response to the alarm.
(1977 Code § 54-511(c), (d); Ord. 90-78. Passed 11-5-90.)
1064.13 ENFORCEMENT.
   (a)   The Police Chief shall have the responsibility for enforcement of this
chapter.
   (b)   In connection with enforcement of this chapter, the Police Chief may
prescribe and publish minimum standards and regulations for the construction
and maintenance of all alarm systems.
(1977 Code § 54-512; Ord. 90-78. Passed 11-5-90.)
1064.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
202.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)

1066.01 APPLICATION TO CONNECT REQUIRED; EVIDENCE OF COMPLIANCE.
   Any person desiring to connect to the fire alarm system of the City shall
make written application to the Fire Chief, and shall include written
verification that the applicant is complying with the provisions of Section
1066.02.
(1977 Code § 26-501; Ord. 89-12. Passed 4-17-89; Ord. 90-14. Passed 2-19-90;
Ord. 90-16. Passed 2-19-90.)
1066.02 REQUIREMENTS FOR CONNECTION.
   When a fire alarm system is installed and is to be interfaced to the Simplex
#2088-8001 receiving panel at the Fire Department, the following criteria must
be met:
   (a)   Either a Simplex fire alarm control panel must be installed; or
   (b)   If a control panel of a different manufacturer is installed, a Simplex
#2080-9014 (4219-4) remote station connection panel must be used to interface
the fire alarm panel to the receiving panel.
   (c)   A Simplex #2088-6001 Zone module must also be provided to be installed
in the receiving panel to accommodate the new fire alarm system.
   No automatic dialing systems for fire alarms will be allowed.
(1977 Code § 26-502; Ord. 89-12. Passed 4-17-89; Ord. 90-14. Passed 2-19-90.)
1066.03 COST OF CONNECTIONS.
   There shall be no fee or rental charge made for the Simplex system, but
persons using the Simplex system will be obligated to pay all maintenance and
repair costs for their system.
(1977 Code § 26-503; Ord. 89-12. Passed 4-17-89; Ord. 90-14. Passed 2-19-90.)
1066.04 CONNECTION AT APPLICANT'S RISK; INDEMNIFICATION OF CITY.
   The connection to the system shall be solely at the risk of the person
granted the permit and shall not impose upon the City any liability for direct
damages or consequential damages for property damage, personal injuries or loss
of life resulting from failure of the fire alarm system to operate properly,
and the person granted the permit shall agree, and does by accepting the permit
agree, to indemnify and hold harmless the City from any liability for any such
damages.
(1977 Code § 26-504; Ord. 89-12. Passed 4-17-89; Ord. 90-14. Passed 2-19-90.)
1066.05 RIGHT OF ENTRY; INSPECTIONS.
   The Fire Inspector and/or Fire Department shall have free and unobstructed
access to any connections, or portions thereof, for the purpose of inspection
at all reasonable hours.
(1977 Code § 26-505; Ord. 89-12. Passed 4-17-89; Ord. 90-14. Passed 2-19-90.)
1066.06 CONNECTION WITHOUT PERMIT.
   No person shall make, cause to be made or use any connection with the City
system without first having obtained permission as provided in this chapter.
(1977 Code § 26-506; Ord. 89-12. Passed 4-17-89; Ord. 90-14. Passed 2-19-90.)
1066.07 LIABILITY FOR DAMAGE.
   No person shall unlawfully disturb or damage any connection with the City
system, or any appurtenance thereto.
(1977 Code § 26-507; Ord. 89-12. Passed 4-17-89; Ord. 90-14. Passed 2-19-90.)
1066.08 FALSE ALARMS; EVIDENCE.
   (a)   It shall be unlawful for any person to transmit a false alarm to the
City. Any person having an alarm system or device on his or her premises shall
be subject to a charge of eighty dollars ($80.00) for false fire alarms for
each and every alarm over five false alarms per premises per calendar year.
   (b)   In any prosecution for a violation of any law regulating alarms, proof
that a false alarm occurred at the particular building, place or premises
described in the complaint, together with proof that the defendant named in the
complaint owned, operated, maintained, controlled or leased that building,
place or premises, shall constitute in evidence a prima-facie presumption that
the person named in the complaint was the person who transmitted a false alarm
to the City.
(1977 Code § 26-508; Ord. 89-12. Passed 4-17-89; Ord. 90-14. Passed 2-19-90.)
1066.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
202.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
   Whoever violates Section
1066.06 shall be subject to the penalty provided for herein for each day such
offender shall continue to use such connection.
(1977 Code § 26-506; Ord. 89-12. Passed 4-17-89; Ord. 90-14. Passed 2-19-90.)

Forestry
1068.01   Forestry Commission.

1068.04   Study of species; certain species prohibited.

1068.06   Deposit of materials harmful to trees or shrubs.

1068.08   Deposit of toxic chemicals.

1068.11   Trees or shrubs overhanging public property; declaration of nuisance;

1068.12   Planting near sidewalks.
1068.13   Shrubs at street intersections.
1068.14   Duty of owners to trim trees near streets, sidewalks or street
lights.
1068.15   Notice to move wires.
1068.16   Authorized activities of utility companies.
1068.17   Authority of City Manager over acts of the City Forester or Forestry
Commission.
1068.18   Violations as nuisances; abatement.
1068.19   Incorporation of applicable statutory provisions.
1068.99   Penalty.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Municipal forestry program and tax - see 65 ILCS 5/11-73-1, 5/11-73-2
   Urban forestry assistance - see 765 ILCS 515/1 et seq.
   Weeds and grass - see GEN. OFF.
Ch. 694
   Trimming of trees by master antenna television collection and distribution
system franchisees - see B.R. & T.
842.06
1068.01 FORESTRY COMMISSION.
   (a)   Establishment; Purposes. There is hereby established a commission
which shall be known as the Forestry Commission of the City. The purposes of
the Forestry Commission, and of this chapter, shall be to regulate and control
the planting, transplanting, removal, maintenance and protection of trees and
shrubs in the City in order to eliminate and guard against dangerous conditions
which may result in injury to persons using the streets, alleys, sidewalks or
property of the City; to promote and enhance the beauty and general welfare of
the City; to prevent damage and disorder to any public sewer, water main,
street, sidewalk or other public property; to protect trees and shrubs located
in public areas from undesirable and unsafe planting, removal, treatment and
maintenance practices; and to guard all trees and shrubs against the spread of
disease or pests. It is the intent of Council that the provisions of this
chapter shall apply to all trees, shrubs or plants growing or hereafter planted
in or upon any public land, and also to all trees or shrubs growing or to be
planted in or upon any private premises which shall threaten the lives, health,
safety or welfare of the public or of public property.
   (b)   Appointment. The Commission shall consist of five members, appointed
by the Mayor, with the consent and approval of Council. Each Commissioner shall
be appointed for a term of five years, with one Commissioner being appointed,
or reappointed, on May 1, in each year.
   (c)   Residence; Terms. Each Commissioner shall, at the time of his or her
appointment, and during his or her term of office, be a resident of the City
and shall hold office until his or her successor has been appointed and shall
have qualified.
   (d)   Officers. A Chairperson of the Commission shall be named, as such, by
the Mayor, from among the members. A Vice Chairperson and a Secretary shall be
elected annually, from the Commission, by the members.
   (e)   Compensation. The members of the Commission shall receive no
compensation, but shall be reimbursed for necessary expenses.
   (f)   Vacancies. In the event of a vacancy, a successor shall be appointed
for the unexpired term only.
   (g)   Removals. A Commissioner shall be removable for cause by the Mayor,
subject to confirmation of such removal by the recorded vote of the majority of
the members of the City Council, after hearing. For purposes of this section,
missing three consecutive meetings of the Forestry Commission shall be deemed
to be due cause for removal.
   (h)   Meetings. The Chairperson shall call special meetings when he or she
deems them necessary, or upon the request of any two Commissioners. One regular
meeting shall be held each month, of which special notice need not be given.
The Secretary shall keep a record of the proceedings, which shall be available
for inspection.
   (i)   Quorum. A majority of the Commissioners shall constitute a quorum for
the transaction of business.
   (j)   Reports to City Manager. The Commission shall render written reports
to the City Manager annually, or more frequently upon request of the City
Manager. Such reports shall review the activities of the Forestry Department
and shall also contain recommendations for further legislative action required
by Council for the accomplishment of the purposes and objectives of the
Forestry Department.
   (k)   Rights, Powers and Duties. The Commission shall, under the
jurisdiction and control of City Manager, establish and maintain a long term
forestry program for the propagation and preservation of trees and shrubs
within the City, administer the provisions of this chapter and direct the
activities of the City Forester and of the employees of the Forestry
Department.
(1977 Code §§28-101 to 28-111; Ord. 2017-56. Passed 7-17-17; Ord. 2017-85.
Passed 12-18-17.)
1068.02 CITY FORESTER.
   (a)   Establishment; Appointment. The office of City Forester of the City is
hereby established. A City Forester may be appointed by the City Manager, and
may be removed from office at any time, with or without cause, by the City
Manager.
   (b)   Oath and Bond. The City Forester shall take the oath prescribed by law
and shall execute a bond, with security to be approved by the City Manager, in
the penal sum of one thousand dollars ($1,000), conditioned upon the faithful
performance of his or her duties and the accounting for all money and property
of the Forestry Department.
   (c)   Compensation. The City Forester shall receive such compensation
(salary and expenses) as Council shall fix annually by appropriation.
   (d)   Assistants. The City Forester shall have such assistants as the City
Manager shall annually provide. Assistant Foresters shall be hired by the City
Forester, under the direction and control of the City Manager. In the absence
of a City Forester, the Senior Assistant Forester shall be in charge of the
Department.
   (e)   Duties as Executive Head. The City Forester shall be the executive
head of the Forestry Department. He or she shall supervise the work of all
employees in the Department and shall administer the provisions of this
chapter.
   (f)   Records. The City Forester shall keep a complete record of all
transactions in the Department, and all such books, records and files shall be
the exclusive property of the City.
   (g)   Reports. The City Forester shall assist the Forestry Commission in its
reports to the City Manager.
   (h)   Cooperation With Other Departments. There shall be close cooperation
between the City Forester and other City departments, and he or she shall be
afforded assistance by, and shall furnish assistance to, other City departments
when needed.
(1977 Code §§28-112 to 28-119; Ord. 2017-56. Passed 7-17-17.)
1068.03 RESPONSIBILITY OF FORESTRY COMMISSION AND CITY FORESTER FOR TREES AND
SHRUBS ON PUBLIC PROPERTY.
   (a)   The Forestry Commission, under the control of the City Manager, shall
direct the purchase, planting, maintenance, trimming, pruning and removal of
all trees and shrubs in any public area of the City. No person shall plant,
maintain, trim, prune or remove any tree or shrub on or from any public land
without written permission from the City Forester, which permit may include
specific qualifications and conditions.
   (b)   The terms "public property," "public area" and "public land" shall
include all land within the City not privately owned or not controlled by any
other political subdivision.
(1977 Code §§28-120, 28-121; Ord. 2017-56. Passed 7-17-17.)
1068.04 STUDY OF SPECIES; CERTAIN SPECIES PROHIBITED.
   The Forestry Commission shall make due investigation and study of various
species of trees and shrubs, with consideration given to length of life,
beauty, freedom from disease, care requirements, growth habits, cleanliness and
other pertinent characteristics. Only such species as are approved by the
Forestry Commission shall be planted on public lands, or on private land within
forty feet of any public land. The following specifies are specifically
prohibited for such planting: American Elm, Chinese Elm, Silver Maple, Ash,
Poplar, Cottonwood, Willow, Catalpa, Box Elder and Tree of Heaven.
(1977 Code § 28-122)
1068.05 FASTENING OF MATERIALS TO TREES OR SHRUBS.
   No person, other than employees of public utility companies, shall fasten
any sign, wire, rope or other material to, around, under or through, any tree
or shrub on public land without the written permit of the City Forester, except
in emergencies, such as storms and accidents.
(1977 Code § 28-123)
1068.06 DEPOSIT OF MATERIALS HARMFUL TO TREES OR SHRUBS.
   No person shall deposit, place, store or maintain, except during
construction work for a period not to exceed thirty days, upon any public land,
any stone, brick, sand, concrete or other materials which may impede the free
passage of water, air and fertilizer to the roots of any tree or shrub growing
thereon, except by written permission of the City Forester.
(1977 Code § 28-124)
1068.07 DAMAGING TREES OR SHRUBS.
   No person shall break, mutilate, injure, kill or destroy any tree or shrub,
or permit any fire to burn where it will injure any portion of any tree or
shrub on public land.
(1977 Code § 28-125)
1068.08 DEPOSIT OF TOXIC CHEMICALS.
   No person shall knowingly permit any toxic chemical to seep, drain or be
emptied on or about any tree or shrub on public land.
(1977 Code § 28-126)
1068.09 CONTACT BETWEEN ELECTRIC WIRES AND TREES PROHIBITED.
   No person shall knowingly permit electric wires to come in contact with any
tree or shrub on public land unless protected by approved methods. No person
shall attach any electrical insulation to any tree on public land.
(1977 Code § 28-127)
1068.10 PROXIMITY OF DITCHES AND DRIVEWAYS TO TREES.
   Ditches, trenches, tunnels and driveways shall be kept as far away from
existing trees as possible. Builders shall erect suitable barriers around trees
or shrubs on public lands to prevent injury from construction work.
(1977 Code § 28-128)
1068.11 TREES OR SHRUBS OVERHANGING PUBLIC PROPERTY; DECLARATION OF NUISANCE;
ABATEMENT.
   Any tree or shrub which overhangs any public land of the City, and which, in
the opinion of the City Forester, endangers the life, health, safety or
property of the public, shall be declared a public nuisance. The owner shall be
notified, in writing, of the existence of the nuisance and given a reasonable
time for its correction or removal as provided in
Chapter 658 of the General Offenses Code. If not corrected, action shall be
taken by the City Forester to abate the nuisance, and the cost shall be
assessed to the owner, recoverable by suit. Such remedy shall be in addition to
the penalty provided in Section
1068.99.
1068.12 PLANTING NEAR SIDEWALKS.
   No hedge or shrubbery shall be planted closer than eighteen inches to a
sidewalk, and such hedge or shrubbery shall be kept trimmed at all times so
that no part shall project over a sidewalk.
(1977 Code § 28-130)
1068.13 SHRUBS AT STREET INTERSECTIONS.
   No shrub or bush growing at the intersection of any two streets in the City
shall be allowed to grow taller than two and one-half feet from the ground
within a thirty-foot radius from the intersection of the two curb lines.
(1977 Code § 28-131)
1068.14 DUTY OF OWNERS TO TRIM TREES NEAR STREETS, SIDEWALKS OR STREET LIGHTS.
   The owner of property abutting upon any street or sidewalk shall trim the
branches of all trees standing along such street or sidewalk so that the
branches shall not obstruct the passage of light from any street light to the
adjacent street or sidewalk, and he or she shall also trim all branches which
overhang any street, alley or sidewalk so that there shall be a clear height of
fifteen feet above the street or alley and a clear height of ten feet above the
sidewalk. Owners shall remove all dead, decayed or broken trees, limbs or
branches which overhang any street, alley or sidewalk.
(1977 Code § 28-132)
1068.15 NOTICE TO MOVE WIRES.
   Whenever it is necessary for the work of the Forestry Department to move or
protect service wires, the City Forester shall serve written notice on the
owner of such wires and the owner shall comply with the order within a
reasonable time.
(1977 Code § 28-133)
1068.16 AUTHORIZED ACTIVITIES OF UTILITY COMPANIES.
   (a)   Public utilities, under the supervision and direction of the City
Forester, are authorized, but not obligated, to trim trees upon and overhanging
the streets, avenues, alleys, highways, sidewalks and other public lands in the
City, to prevent the branches of such trees from coming in contact with wires
and cables.
   (b)   Public utilities, under the supervision and direction of the City
Forester, are authorized, but not obligated, to cut roots of trees and shrubs
under the streets, avenues, alleys, highways, sidewalks and other public lands
in the City, in order to construct, maintain and operate their facilities in
and about the City.
(1977 Code § 28-134)
1068.17 AUTHORITY OF CITY MANAGER OVER ACTS OF THE CITY FORESTER OR FORESTRY
COMMISSION.
   The City Manager shall have the final authority, after appeal to him or her
by a person interested, to change, alter, amend or revoke any decision, order,
permit, or other act, of the City Forester or the Forestry Commission.
(1977 Code §28-139; Ord. 2017-56. Passed 7-17-17.)
1068.18 VIOLATIONS AS NUISANCES; ABATEMENT.
   The maintenance of any tree, plant or shrub within the City in violation of
any provision of this chapter is hereby declared to be a nuisance. Such
nuisance shall be abated following the procedure set forth in
Chapter 658 of the General Offenses Code.
1068.19 INCORPORATION OF APPLICABLE STATUTORY PROVISIONS.
   All pertinent and applicable provisions of 65 ILCS 5/11-72-1 et seq. and 5/
11-73-1 et seq., as heretofore and hereafter amended, are incorporated herein
by reference, subject to the provisions of Section
202.05 (b) of the Administration Code.
1068.99 PENALTY.
   (EDITOR'S NOTE: See Section
202.99 for general Code penalty if no specific penalty is provided.)
