1268.01 USE AND BULK REGULATIONS.
   (a)   Use. No building, structure or land shall hereafter be used or
occupied, and no building or part thereof, or other structure, shall be
erected, raised, moved, reconstructed, extended, enlarged or altered, except in
conformity with the regulations herein specified for the district in which it
is located.
   (b)   Bulk. All new buildings and structures shall conform to the building
regulations established herein for the district in which each building shall be
located, except that parapet walls, chimneys, cooling towers, elevator
bulkheads, fire towers, stacks and necessary mechanical appurtenances shall be
permitted to exceed the maximum height provisions when erected in accordance
with all other ordinances of the City.
(1977 Code § 73-203)
1268.02 LOT COVERAGE.
   (a)   Maintenance of Yards, Courts and Other Open Spaces. The maintenance of
yards, courts and other open spaces and the minimum lot area legally required
for a building shall be a continuing obligation of the owner of such building,
or of the property on which it is located, as long as the building is in
existence. Further, no legally required yards, courts or other open space, or
minimum lot area allocated to any building, shall, by virtue of change of
ownership or for any other reason, be used to satisfy yard, court or other open
space or minimum lot area requirements for any other building.
   (b)   Division of Zoning Lots. No improved zoning lot shall hereafter be
divided into two or more zoning lots, unless all improved zoning lots resulting
from each such division shall conform with all applicable bulk regulations of
the zoning district in which the property is located. However, with respect to
the resubdivision of improved zoning lots in the R-5, R-6 and R-7 Districts,
side yard requirements shall not apply between attached buildings.
   (c)   Location of Required Open Space. All yards, courts and other open
spaces allocated to a building or dwelling group shall be located on the same
zoning lot as such building or dwelling group.
   (d)   Required Yards for Existing Buildings. No yards now or hereafter
provided for a building existing on the effective date of this Zoning Code
shall subsequently be reduced below, or further reduced below if already less
than, the minimum yard requirements of this Zoning Code for equivalent new
construction.
   (e)   Permitted Obstructions in Required Yards. The following shall not be
considered to be obstructions when located in the required yards specified:
      (1)   In all yards. Open terraces not over four feet above the average
level of the adjoining ground, but not including a permanently roofed-over
terrace or porch; awnings and canopies; steps, four feet or less above grade,
which are necessary for access to a permitted building or for access to a
zoning lot from a street or alley; chimneys projecting eighteen inches or less
into the yard; and arbors, trellises and flag poles. Mesh-type fences having a
height of six feet or less may be used to locate property lines within the
required side or rear yards in residential districts.
         Fences, walls or lattice-work screens which form outside living rooms
or provide necessary privacy for swimming pools or other activities, and are
actual projections from the bearing walls of existing dwellings, may be
extended into either the side or the rear yards, but not both yards where the
fence, wall or screen has not less than fifty percent of the surface open or is
a vertical type of louvered fence, which can prevent free movement of air from
one or more directions and yet have more than fifty percent of its surface open
when viewed on an angle from two directions, provided, however:
         A.   That the projection shall not prohibit the erection of an open-
mesh type fence over six feet in height enclosing an elementary or high school
site; and
         B.   That this projection shall not limit the height, type or location
of a fence, wall or other structure which is located within the buildable area
exclusive of the side or rear yards of the property.
      (2)   In front yards. One-story bay windows projecting three feet or less
into the yard; and overhanging eaves and gutters projecting three feet or less
into the yard.
      (3)   In rear yards. Enclosed, attached or detached off-street parking
spaces; open off-street parking spaces; recreational and laundry-drying
equipment; accessory sheds, tool rooms and similar buildings or structures for
domestic or agricultural storage; balconies; breezeways and open porches; a
one-story bay window projecting three feet or less into the yard; and
overhanging eaves and gutters projecting three feet or less into the yard. In
any residential district, no accessory building shall be nearer than five feet
to the side lot line or nearer than ten feet to any principal building unless
it is attached.
      (4)   In side yards. Overhanging eaves and gutters projecting into a yard
for a distance not exceeding forty percent of the required yard width, but in
no case exceeding thirty inches.
   (f)   Vision Clearance at Corner Lots. No building or structure hereafter
erected, and no planting or other obstruction to the vision of drivers of motor
vehicles, shall be located:
      (1)   In any residential district, exceeding a height of three feet above
the street grade within twelve feet of the intersecting street lines bordering
corner lots; and
      (2)   In any business or manufacturing district, within eight feet of the
intersecting street lines bordering a corner lot, provided that this regulation
shall not apply to that part of a building above the first floor.
   (g)   Exceptions for Existing Developments.
      (1)   Where forty percent, or more, of the frontage on one side of a
street between two intersecting streets is developed with buildings that have
had (within a variation of five feet or less) a front yard greater in depth
than herein required, new buildings shall not be erected closer to the street
than the average front yard so established by the existing buildings.
      (2)   Where forty percent, or more, of the frontage on one side of a
street between two intersecting streets is developed with buildings that have
not had a front yard as herein required, then:
         A.   Where a building is to be erected within 100 feet of existing
buildings on both sides, the minimum front yard shall be a line drawn between
the closest front corners of the two existing buildings.
         B.   Where a building is to be erected within 100 feet of an existing
building on one side only, it may be erected as close to the street as the
existing building.
      (3)   This subsection shall apply to all lots, including reverse corner
lots, in all districts, and it shall take precedence over all over provisions
of this Zoning Code regarding setback lines or yard areas in residential
districts.
   (h)   Front Yards in Reverse Corner Lots. In all residential districts,
reverse corner lots, except when subject to the provisions of subsection (g)
hereof, shall be subject to the front yard setback requirements of their zoning
district for each yard adjoining a street, i.e. such reverse corner lots shall
have two front yards.
   (i)   Back Yards in Reverse Corner Lots. In all residential districts, the
back yard of a reverse corner lot shall be one of the two yards opposite the
yard fronting on a street, and of such two yards it shall be the one having the
greatest depth.
   (j)   Television Satellite Dishes or Antennae. Television satellite dishes
or antennae for receiving television signals from orbiting satellites or from
other sources may be located only in side yards or rear yards in locations to
be shown on building permits to be obtained from the Community Development
Director and to be approved by him or her. Such dishes or antennae shall be
considered structures and shall require a building permit before the same may
be erected. No such dishes or antennae shall exceed thirty feet in height from
ground level.
   (k)   PV Arrays. With respect to PV arrays as defined in Section
1240.06 (164), the following provisions shall apply:
      (1)   Ground mounted PV arrays shall not be deemed buildings or accessory
buildings for any purposes hereof; and
      (2)   Ground mounted PV arrays shall not be allowed as obstructions in
any required yard
(1977 Code §73-204; Ord. 78-13. Passed 2-20-78; Ord. 78-53. Passed 7-4-78; Ord.
85-6. Passed 3-4-85; Ord. 85-54. Passed 10-7-85; Ord. 94-81. Passed 9-19-94;
Ord. 2018-40. Passed 9-17-18.)
1268.03 LOT AREA AND DIMENSIONS.
   (a)   Contiguous Parcels. When two or more parcels of land, each of which
lacks adequate area and dimensions to qualify for a permitted use under the
requirements of the use district in which it is located, are contiguous and are
held in one ownership, they shall be used as one zoning lot for such use.
   (b)   Lots or Parcels of Land of Record. Any single lot or parcel of land,
held in one ownership, which was of record at the time of adoption of this
Zoning Code, that does not meet the requirements for minimum lot width and
area, may be utilized for a permitted use, provided that yards, courts or
usable open spaces are not less than seventy-five percent of the minimum
required dimensions or areas.
(1977 Code § 73-205)
1268.04 ACCESS TO PUBLIC STREETS.
   Except as otherwise provided for herein, every building shall be constructed
or erected upon a lot or parcel of land which abuts upon a public street,
unless a permanent easement of access to a public street was of record prior to
the adoption of this Zoning Code.
(1977 Code § 73-206)
1268.05 NUMBER OF BUILDINGS ON A ZONING LOT.
   Except in the case of a planned development, not more than one principal
detached residential building shall be located on a residential zoning lot, nor
shall a principal detached residential building be located on the same zoning
lot with any other principal building.
(1977 Code § 73-207)
1268.06 REZONING OF PUBLIC AND SEMI-PUBLIC AREAS.
   An area indicated on the Zoning Map as a public park, recreation area,
public school site, cemetery, or other similar open space, shall not be used
for any other purpose than that designated; and when the use of the area is
discontinued, it shall automatically be zoned to the most restricted adjoining
district until appropriate zoning is authorized by the City Council within
three months after the date of the application filed for rezoning.
(1977 Code § 73-208)
1268.07 ACCESSORY BUILDINGS.
   (a)   Location. When a side yard is required, no part of an accessory
building shall be located closer than five feet to the side lot line along such
side yard. When a rear yard is required, no part of an accessory building shall
be located closer than five feet to the rear lot line or to those portions of
the side lot lines abutting such required rear yard. In a residential district,
no detached accessory building shall be closer than ten feet to the principal
building.
   Accessory buildings on lots of record prior to September 20, 1965, shall not
be located closer than two feet from the side lot line along such side yard,
except that when an accessory building is located closer than ten feet from the
principal building, the minimum side yard shall be the same as that required
for the principal building. When a rear yard is required, no part of an
accessory building shall be located closer than three feet from the rear lot
line, except that an accessory building with vehicular access from an alley
shall not be located closer than five feet from the rear lot line.
   (b)   Time of Construction. No accessory building or structure shall be
constructed on any lot prior to the start of construction of the principal
building to which it is accessory.
   (c)   Percentage of Required Rear Yard to be Occupied. No accessory building
or buildings shall occupy more than forty percent of the area of a required
rear yard.
   (d)   Height in Required Rear Yards. No accessory building or portion
thereof located in a required rear yard shall exceed fifteen feet in height.
   (e)   On Reversed Corner Lots. On a reversed corner lot in a residential
district, and within fifteen feet of an adjacent property to the rear in a
residential district, no accessory building or portion thereof located in a
required rear yard shall be closer to the side lot line abutting the street
than a distance equal to sixty percent of the least depth which would be
required hereunder for the front yard on such adjacent property to the rear.
Further, in the above instance, no such accessory building shall be located
within five feet of any part of a rear lot line which coincides with a side lot
line, or portion thereof, of property in a residential district.
(1977 Code § 73-209)
1268.08 TEMPORARY BUILDINGS.
   (a)   A temporary real estate office may be allowed in conjunction with a
new housing development, limited to the selling or renting of new units in such
development, but in no case to be in operation for more than one year following
completion of construction of said housing development.
   (b)   Temporary buildings for construction purposes may be allowed for a
period not to exceed the completion date of such construction.
(1977 Code § 73-210)
1268.09 PERFORMANCE STANDARDS.
   The performance standards of the M-1 Manufacturing District shall also apply
to all residential and business districts.
(1977 Code § 73-211)
1268.10 EXISTING SPECIAL USES.
   Where a use is classified as a special use and exists as a permitted use on
the date of the adoption of this Zoning Code, it shall be considered a legal
use, without further action of the City Council, the Zoning Administrator, the
Board of Zoning Appeals or the Planning Commission.
(1977 Code § 73-212)
1268.11 USES NOT SPECIFICALLY PERMITTED IN DISTRICTS.
   When a use is not specifically listed as a permitted, special or
transitional use, it shall be assumed that such use is hereby expressly
prohibited, unless, by a written decision of the Planning Commission, it is
determined that said use is similar to and not more objectionable than uses
listed. Such use may then be permitted.
(1977 Code § 73-213)
1268.12 MOBILE HOMES AND TRAILERS.
   Except as a special use in an M-2 District, no person shall occupy or
permanently locate a mobile home or residential trailer, except in a mobile
home park licensed under
Chapter 846 of the Business Regulation and Taxation Code. The provisions of
Chapter 846 of the Business Regulation and Taxation Code are incorporated
herein by reference.
(1977 Code § 73-214)
1268.13 MAXIMUM COVERAGE.
   No provision or requirement for maximum coverage of a zoning lot by a
building or buildings, as specified for any zoning district in this Zoning
Code, shall be applicable to zoning lots in the expanded Central Business
District, as described in Section
1262.02(g).
(1977 Code § 73-216)
CHAPTER 1270
Fences
1270.01   Definitions.
1270.02   Permit.
1270.03   Fence installation.
1270.04   Maintenance of fences.
1270.05   Existing fences.
1270.06   Prohibitions.
1270.07   Fences permitted without a permit.
1270.08   Non-boundary related fence standards.
1270.09   Domestic animal enclosures.
1270.10   Visual clearance violations.
1270.11   Administration and appeals.
1270.12   Severability.
1270.01 DEFINITIONS.
   The following words and terms, for purposes of this chapter, shall have the
meanings herein provided:
   (a)   "Arbor." A decorative solid or latticework structure or trellis which
is used as an entrance focal point along a barrier which serves the purpose of
a fence.
   (b)   "Berm." A mound of earth higher than the final elevation of a lot.
   (c)   "Department." The City Community Development Department.
   (d)   "Domestic animal enclosure." Any outdoor structure or enclosure used
to restrict animals to a contained yard area.
   (e)   "Fence(s)." A vertical screen device used to provide privacy, visual
or otherwise, or for containment. "Fence" includes but is not limited to living
fences, trellises, railings and walls.
   (f)   "Fence, agricultural/farm." A fence consisting of chicken wire, deer
fence, hog wire, high tensile wire strands, used in the agricultural, farming
and livestock business, specifically for livestock, animal and bird control.
   (g)   "Fence, patio." A fence which fully or partially encloses a patio.
   (h)   "Fence, good neighbor." A fence constructed of solid or spaced boards,
where the face boards are installed at the center of the posts so that the
fence looks the same from both sides.
   (i)   "Install, installation, installed." To construct, erect, place, modify
or replace over sixteen lineal feet (l.f.) of fence.
   (j)   "Lot, corner." A lot situated at the junction of and abutting on two
or more intersecting streets, or a lot at the point of deflection in alignment
of a single street, the interior angle of which is 135 degrees or less.
   (k)   "Lot, through." A lot having frontage on two parallel or approximately
parallel streets and which is not a corner lot. On a through lot both street
lines shall be deemed front lot lines.
   (l)   "Person." Any person, firm, corporation, association or other legal
entity.
   (m)   "Property owner." A person that owns or controls real property, wholly
or partly, situated in the City.
   (n)   "Trellis." A frame or structure of open latticework.
   (o)   "Vision clearance area." A triangular area on a lot at the
intersection of two streets or a street and driveway/alley and sidewalk, other
point of vehicular access or railroad, two sides of which are lot lines
measured from the corner intersection of the property lines to a minimum
distance of fifteen feet from their intersection and the third side of which is
the line measured from the end points of each of the other two lines.
   (p)   "Zoning Administrator." The Community Development Director and
designees thereof.
(Ord. 2006-07. Passed 2-21-06.)
1270.02 PERMIT.
   (a)   Permit Required. No person shall install a fence in the City without
first obtaining a fence permit and complying in all respects with the terms and
conditions of the permit and of this chapter. A fence permit shall be valid
only for the term of issuance, unless sooner suspended or revoked. A fence
permit is not required for painting, maintenance, or repair or replacement of
less than sixteen lineal feet (l.f.) of a fence.
   (b)   Permit Application. A fence permit application shall be filed with the
Department, consisting of the following:
      (1)   A fully completed fence permit application form and payment of full
permit fee.
      (2)   A drawing, site plan or plat map displaying property boundaries,
the location of the buildings and structures on the property, the proposed
location of the fence and the distances from the proposed fence to the existing
structures on the property.
      (3)   If the fence is proposed to be installed on rented or leased
property, the written consent of all of the owner(s) of the property.
      (4)   Other information as may be required by the Department to assist in
the review of the application.
   (c)   Permit Fee. A permit fee shall be remitted upon submittal of the fence
application, the amount of which shall be established, from time to time, by
the City Council.
   (d)   Application Review and Approval Required, Permit Issuance. The Zoning
Administrator shall review, approve and issue the fence permit application
provided that the application is in compliance with this chapter and the
standards of this chapter for the fence to be installed have been met. The
fence permit may contain reasonable conditions stated in the permit.
   (e)   Completion of Installation.
      (1)   A fence authorized by a fence permit shall be fully installed in
accordance with this chapter and permit conditions, and within 180 days of the
date of permit issuance. A fence permit shall expire 180 days after the date of
issuance. After a fence permit expires, no work requiring such a permit shall
be commenced, resumed or undertaken until a new permit is issued or the
original permit is extended.
      (2)   The permit applicant may file a written request for an extension of
the fence permit, stating the reason for the request, for up to 180 additional
days to complete the fence installation. The Zoning Administrator, in
administering this Code, shall grant the request if the applicant demonstrates
that unusual conditions have prevented the timely completion of the
installation of the fence.
   (f)   Responsibility of Department. The Department, through the Zoning
Administrator, shall:
      (1)   Review and issue fence permits where the application is in
compliance with this chapter.
      (2)   May issue reasonable site specific conditions.
      (3)   May waive or reduce vision clearance requirements where:
         A.   Traffic can safely approach and enter the intersection, alley,
driveway or street given existing traffic control devices or other physical
conditions of the area; or,
         B.   Topographic conditions are so extreme or building structures
exist such that it is not practical to provide required vision clearance.
      (4)   May inspect the fence for compliance with this chapter and the
permit;
      (5)   May require copy of survey prior to issuance of permit;
      (6)   Shall enforce this chapter with the assistance of the Corporation
Counsel.
   (g)   Responsibility of Applicant. The applicant is solely responsible for
installing the fence:
      (1)   Within the boundaries of their property determined by survey, in
compliance with this chapter and the permit, including, but not limited to,
proper materials, height, setback and vision clearance. Such property line
survey shall be the sole responsibility of the applicant and owner of the
property, and the City shall in no way be responsible to applicant, owner or
adjacent property owners for such survey or its accuracy.
      (2)   In compliance with any subdivision covenants or restrictions, deed
restrictions, utility easement restrictions, land use restrictions of record,
including applicable plan review and approval, or waiver requirements.
      (3)   In a manner as will not obstruct storm water drainage, violate a
City approved storm water plan, or unreasonably divert storm water onto the
property of another.
      (4)   In compliance with the City's Flood Management Ordinance (
Chapter 1460).
(Ord. 2006-07. Passed 2-21-06; Ord. 2015-54. Passed 10-19-15.)
1270.03 FENCE INSTALLATION.
   (a)   General Requirements. No fence shall be installed, except in strict
compliance with this chapter, site specific permit conditions, and the
following requirements:
      (1)   Structural and support components of a fence shall face away from
adjacent properties and public rights-of-way.
      (2)   Fences shall be installed with the finished side facing the
adjacent property, or public right-of-way, and the fence posts must be located
on the inside of the fence facing the property on which the fence is located,
except when the style of fence commonly described as a "Good Neighbor Fence" is
installed.
      (3)   Fences shall be installed plumb and the top finish of the fence
shall be uniform. Fences shall follow the contour of the ground to the extent
practical. Adjustments for grade shall occur at the bottom of the fence.
      (4)   The height of the fence shall be controlled by the applicable
provisions of the City Zoning Ordinance for the district in which the fence
will be located. Fence height shall be measured from the surface of the ground
immediately below the fence. Berms, retaining walls or other methods to raise
the elevation of the site shall require approval by the Department prior to
installation.
      (5)   The project site shall be marked by J.U.L.I.E. before digging holes
for fence installation.
      (6)   No fence in the vision clearance area shall exceed three feet in
height above the street grade.
      (7)   The height of walls and fences shall be measured vertically from
the finished grade on the exterior side of the fence. Raising the finished
grade by placing fill is prohibited. If a fence is placed on a berm, the berm
shall be included in the height of the fence and the height shall be measured
vertically from the base of the berm, unless said fence is approved in
conjunction with a variance granted by the Zoning Board of Appeals.
      (8)   All fences shall be no closer than two feet to the public sidewalk
and no closer than two feet to any public right-of-way.
      (9)   Fences in front yards shall have setbacks compatible with fences on
abutting properties, unless such fence has been erected on the public right-of-
way.
   (b)   Obstruction of Ingress/Egress Area of a Dwelling. No fence shall be
installed in any yard that will obstruct the view of any window or opening in a
habitable space of a dwelling. A minimum distance of three feet shall be
maintained between any solid fence and any such window or opening in a
dwelling.
   (c)   Modifications. All modifications to an existing fence shall comply
with this chapter.
   (d)   Fences in Front Yards. Fences installed in a front yard shall comply
with the following requirements:
      (1)   On corner, interior, through and reverse frontage lots, fences, not
exceeding four feet in height shall be allowed within a required front yard
setback areas. No fence over four feet in height shall be permitted within
required front yard setback areas. Fences over three feet above the street
grade shall not be installed within vision clearance areas.
      (2)   Fences, including interior and corner double-frontage lots,
fronting a street, shall be installed in accordance with front yard setback
requirements.
   (e)   Fences in Rear/Side Yard. Fences in rear and side yards shall meet the
following requirements:
      (1)   No fence or wall shall exceed six feet in height in any side or
rear yard. Fences not greater than six feet in height are permitted in side or
rear yards and shall be no closer than two feet to the public sidewalk and no
closer than two feet to any public right-of-way.
      (2)   A wall or solid fence not more than six feet in height, as measured
from the highest adjacent grade, may be maintained along the interior side or
rear lot lines provided such a wall or solid fence does not extend into a
required front yard. Fences may not be installed within two feet of the rear or
side property line without proof of survey submitted to the Community
Development Department.
      (3)   Fences which exceed three feet above the street grade in side or
rear yards shall not encroach within vision clearance areas.
   (f)   Fences On Corner Lots. No fence over three feet above the street grade
shall be permitted within a vision clearance area of any portion of the lot.
   (g)   Fences On A Lot-Double Frontage. Fences shall be installed in
accordance with the required front yard setback on both streets, except where
otherwise approved in conjunction with a variance from the Zoning Board of
Appeals.
   (h)   Approved Fence Materials. All fences shall meet the following material
requirements:
      (1)   Fences to be situated in residential side and/or rear yards shall
be constructed using materials suitable for residential-style fencing,
including, but not limited to, brick, fieldstone, wrought iron, vinyl, chain
link (with a minimum thickness of nine gauge and a required top rail support),
stockade or board-on-board wood. Fences in non-residential districts may be
made of other materials, subject to approval of the Community Development
Director, in his or her reasonably exercised discretion, and in accordance with
the overall intent and other provisions of this chapter.
      (2)   No fence shall be constructed of used or discarded materials in
disrepair, including, but not limited to, pallets, tree trunks, trash, tires,
junk, or other similar items.
      (3)   Agricultural/farm. Fences shall only be permitted in agriculturally
zoned or used districts and shall not exceed six feet in height.
      (4)   Residential front yard fences shall be fifty percent open (see-
through) and be of split rail, wrought iron or picket design. Chainlink fencing
is not permitted in residential front yards.
      (5)   Residential side yard fences on corner lots shall be of split rail,
wrought iron, picket design, or decorative wood design. Chainlink and stockade
style fences are not permitted in residential side yards on corner lots.
   (i)   Flood Hazard Areas.
      (1)   No fence shall be constructed within a regulatory floodway (as
defined by the Federal Emergency Management Agency).
      (2)   No fence shall be constructed in any property designated as a
floodpiain or special flood hazard area on the most recent Flood Insurance Rate
Maps in effect for the property at issue, or any property zoned F-1 by the
City, unless the design of such fence otherwise complies with all other
provisions of this section and is in compliance with all floodplain management
policies of the City and National Flood Insurance Program requirements then in
effect.
(Ord. 2006-07. Passed 2-21-06; Ord. 2015-54. Passed 10-19-15; Ord. 2019-15.
Passed 3-4-19.)
1270.04 MAINTENANCE OF FENCES.
   Fences shall be maintained in a manner as to prevent rust, corrosion and
deterioration, so as not to become a public or private nuisance, and so as not
be dilapidated or a danger to adjoining property owners or the public. Fences
shall not be maintained in a state of disrepair. Every fence installed shall be
maintained by the owner in such a way that it will remain plumb and in good
repair.
(Ord. 2006-07. Passed 2-21-06.)
1270.05 EXISTING FENCES.
   (a)   Any fence existing upon the effective date of this chapter shall not
be enlarged or extended by more than sixteen lineal feet, or have fifty percent
or more of its structure replaced, except in strict compliance with all of the
requirements of this chapter. Any fence existing upon the effective date of
this chapter that extends into the public right-of-way or into the vision
clearance area shall not be enlarged or extended by any length, or have fifty
percent or more of its structure replaced, except in strict compliance with all
of the requirements of this chapter.
   (b)   Any fence that exists contrary to the required vision clearance area
requirements shall be brought into compliance within twelve months of the
effective date of this chapter.
   (c)   Any fence that exists contrary to the required setback from the public
right- of-way requirements may remain, provided that the owner of said fence
signs a waiver stating that if access to the public right-of-way is required,
owner will remove the fence at his or her own expense, within five calendar
days of receipt of written notice from the City.
(Ord. 2006-07. Passed 2-21-06.)
1270.06 PROHIBITIONS.
   Prohibited fences. No person shall install:
   (a)   An electric or razor wire fence.
   (b)   Barbed wire may not be installed on fences, except that barbed wire
may be installed above the top line of six-foot fences located in a
nonresidential zoning district and enclosing a storage area. Barbs on chainlink
fences are not allowed on any exposed portion of the fences below six feet.
   (c)   Any wire or chain link-type fence with the cut or salvage end of the
fence exposed at the top.
   (d)   A fence which creates a hazard to users of the street, sidewalk or to
nearby property.
   (e)   A fence composed solely of fence posts.
   (f)   An incomplete fence, consisting only of posts and supporting members.
   (g)   Chain link fencing may not be installed within any of the City's
Historic Districts.
(Ord. 2006-07. Passed 2-21-06.)
1270.07 FENCES PERMITTED WITHOUT A PERMIT.
   The following types of fences are permitted, as specified, without a permit,
subject to the following restrictions and providing that said fence does not in
any way interfere with traffic visibility, or block, redirect or cause a
drainage problem for the adjacent or downstream properties:
   (a)   Snow fencing shall be permitted in all districts not exceeding four
feet in height provided it is removed between May 1 and November 1 of each
year. No snow fence shall extend into the street right-of-way line unless
installed by the City.
   (b)   Agricultural/farm fences are limited to agriculturally zoned
districts.
   (c)   Decorative fences not exceeding two feet in height shall be permitted
in all districts. Such fences shall be no closer than two feet to the public
sidewalk, no closer than two feet to any public right-of-way, and no closer
than two feet to any property line.
   (d)   Underground electrical fences are permitted in all districts.
(Ord. 2006-07. Passed 2-21-06; Ord. 2020-13. Passed 3-3-20.)
1270.08 NON-BOUNDARY RELATED FENCE STANDARDS.
   (a)   Fences and/or enclosures for swimming pools shall be permitted as
required in Section
1474.04 of the City of Freeport Municipal Ordinances.
   (b)   Fences surrounding tennis courts, and baseball and/or softball field
backstops may be erected in conformance with accepted industry standards. A
fence permit shall be required for such installation.
(Ord. 2006-07. Passed 2-21-06.)
1270.09 DOMESTIC ANIMAL ENCLOSURES.
   Domestic animal enclosures shall be permitted in residential districts
subject to the following criteria:
   (a)   No domestic animal enclosure shall be installed on a lot unless
approved by the Department and a permit is issued.
   (b)   Domestic animal enclosures must be located in the buildable area
directly behind and adjacent to the principal building. In no event shall a
domestic animal enclosure encroach into a required setback or be located closer
to a corner or interior side property line than the principal building.
   (c)   No domestic animal enclosure shall be in excess of 250 square feet in
area, nor more than six feet in height above the surface of the ground, as
measured from the ground level at the lowest grade level within five feet of
either side thereof.
   (d)   Domestic animal enclosures may be constructed of any material
permitted for a residential fence.
   (e)   No domestic animal enclosure shall be constructed contrary to required
vision clearance area requirements.
   (f)   No animal which is prohibited from being kept within City limits of
the City of Freeport Codified Ordinances shall be kept in any domestic animal
enclosure.
(Ord. 2006-07. Passed 2-21-06.)
1270.10 VISUAL CLEARANCE VIOLATIONS.
   (a)   Administration of Visual Clearance Violations.
      (1)   The Zoning Administrator shall have the duty of establishing,
restoring and maintaining visual clearance. When the Zoning Administrator has
determined that visual clearance has not been established, restored or
maintained, as required within this chapter, the Zoning Administrator shall, in
writing, notify the owner, operator or other party responsible for managing
and/or maintaining the offending property that visual clearance must be
established or restored within fifteen days from the date of notice. The notice
shall further provide that the notified party or agent shall have the
opportunity to be personally heard by the Zoning Administrator within said
period, and failure to request a hearing shall waive the opportunity to be
sufficient reason. The failure of the owner, operator or other responsible
party to provide or restore visual clearance within the time prescribed shall
authorize the Zoning Administrator to do or to have done such work as will
establish or restore visual clearance, bill the owner, operator or other
responsible party for the actual costs of the service rendered, and demand
payment be made within thirty days of the billing date. The failure of the
owner, operator or other responsible party to promptly pay said bill shall
authorize the Zoning Administrator to charge the cost against the property in
noncompliance as a special assessment, pursuant to the Home Rule Authority of
the City of Freeport. The special assessment shall be a lien upon the real
estate until paid in full, with interest accruing on the unpaid balance. There
shall also be a one hundred dollar ($100.00) administrative charge added to the
charge and special assessment to cover administrative costs of charging and
specially assessing the property.
      (2)   The order of the Zoning Administrator may be appealed to the Board
upon written notice of said appeal being served upon or sent by registered mail
to the Zoning Administrator within ten days after the date of the order.
   (b)   Public Nuisance. Obstruction to visual clearance, as regulated by this
section, shall be deemed to be a public nuisance and the Corporation Counsel is
authorized to abate said nuisance.
(Ord. 2006-07. Passed 2-21-06.)
1270.11 ADMINISTRATION AND APPEALS.
   (a)   Administration. It shall be the duty of the Zoning Administrator to
administer and enforce this chapter.
   (b)   Appeals. An aggrieved person adversely affected by the denial of a
permit or decision, determination or interpretation under this chapter by the
Zoning Administrator may appeal such denial, decision, determination or
interpretation to the Zoning Board of Appeals.
   (c)   Application Procedure. Any application for appeal shall be taken
pursuant to the procedure set forth in Section
1244.02 of the Zoning Ordinance.
(Ord. 2006-07. Passed 2-21-06.)
1270.12 SEVERABILITY.
   This chapter and each section and subsection hereunder are hereby declared
to be independent sections and subsections and, not withstanding any other
evidence of legislative intent, it is hereby declared to be the controlling
legislative intent that if any provisions of said chapter, or the application
thereof to any person or circumstance is held to be invalid, the remaining
sections or subsections and the application of such sections and subsections to
any person or circumstances other than those to which it is held invalid shall
not be affected thereby, and it is hereby declared that such sections and
subsections would have been passed independently of such section or subsection
so known to be invalid.
(Ord. 2006-07. Passed 2-21-06.)
CHAPTER 1272
Landscaping and Screening
1272.01   Purpose.
1272.02   Landscape requirements.
1272.03   Parking lot landscaping.
1272.04   Detention and retention pond landscaping.
1272.05   Dumpster screening and placement.
1272.06   Administration and appeals.
1272.07   Severability.
   CROSS REFERENCES
   Landscaping in subdivisions - see P & Z.
1224.12(e)
   Screening of motel in residential area - see B.R. & T.
836.08
   Yard waste disposal - see S.U. & P.S.
1060.16
1272.01 PURPOSE.
   The landscaping requirements specified herein are intended to foster
aesthetically pleasing, environmentally beneficial, and sustainable development
that will protect and preserve the appearance, character, general health,
safety and welfare of the community. Landscape improvements shall serve to
enhance the appearance of the site, especially as viewed from adjacent property
and public right-of-way. Effective year-round screening shall be provided to
lessen the visual prominence of parking lots, service yards, loading docks,
exterior utility structures, dumpster pads, and detention and retention ponds.
(Ord. 2013-48. Passed 10-7-13.)
1272.02 LANDSCAPE REQUIREMENTS.
   (a)   All Commercial, Industrial, Multi-Family Residential and Mixed Use
Development and Redevelopment Plans for sites one quarter (0.25) acre or
greater shall include a landscaping plan indicating how existing topography,
natural features, and vegetation will be integrated into the overall site
development. A conceptual landscape plan shall be submitted to the City
Engineer and approved prior to final site plan approval. A detailed landscape
plan shall be submitted to the City Engineer and approved prior to the issuance
of a certificate of occupancy. Plans submitted for approval shall be to an
appropriate engineering scale for the size of the development with contour
elevations indicated at one foot (1') intervals.
   (b)   The minimum required permeable area shall be twenty percent (20%) of
the entire site under review. Adjacent lots not included in the initial
development shall not be included as part of the twenty percent (20%) permeable
area.
   (c)   The following is the minimum landscaping requirement of trees and
shrubs, by number, and the type of ground cover required for the entire site
review. Acceptable plant species used for landscaping shall, conform to the
following list, unless approved by the City Engineer:

18. Sedum species (Stonecrop)
19. Vinca minor (Periwinkle)
20. Waldsteinia species (Barren Strawberry varieties)
 
      (1)   Minimum tree planting requirements shall be at least one tree per
one thousand five hundred (1,500) square feet of required permeable area.
Minimum tree size shall be at least two and one-half inch (2 1/2") caliper
measured six inches (6") from the base of the tree for a deciduous tree and six
feet (6') in height for a coniferous tree. At least one-third of all trees on
the site under review shall be coniferous.
      (2)   Minimum shrub planting requirements shall be at least one shrub per
one thousand (1,000) square feet of required permeable area. Minimum shrubs
size shall be at least eighteen inches (18") in height or a minimum of three
(3) gallon potted.
      (3)   Existing mature trees shall be counted toward the planting
requirements if they are located on the subject property in close proximity to
an area requiring landscaping and are of an acceptable quality and species.
Existing trees shall be protected and maintained during construction and
grading activities for them to be counted toward the planting requirements. If
the diameter of the existing tree exceeds six (6) inches measured at four (4)
feet above grade, one additional tree shall be credited for each additional 6-
inch increment in diameter to a maximum credit of four (4) trees.
   (d)   Landscape plans shall also include elevations and details of all
fences, accessory structures, retaining walls, or other decorative features
proposed for location on site. The details shall include, but are not limited
to, materials, colors, styles and sizes.
(Ord. 2013-48. Passed 10-7-13.)
1272.03 PARKING LOT LANDSCAPING.
   Parking bays in excess of ten (10) spaces shall provide landscaping at the
end of each aisle. Parking bays in excess of twenty (20) spaces shall be
divided by intermediate landscape islands and provide landscaping at the ends
of each aisle. Landscape islands, both interior and at the end of each aisle,
shall be a minimum of one hundred and fifty (150) square feet for single bays
and three hundred (300) square feet for double bays. Concrete curbs shall be
installed around ail landscaping in parking areas. All landscape islands shall
be crowned to allow for positive drainage and shall contain a minimum of
twenty-four (24) inches of topsoil. One shade or ornamental tree shall be
required for every three hundred (300) square feet of landscaping in landscape
islands. Parking lot layout shall be in accordance with Chapter
1262 of the Codified Ordinances of Freeport, Illinois. Coordination of parking
lot lighting or utility locations and tree placement is required prior to final
landscape plan approval. Existing developments that are nonconforming with
regard to this section must be brought into conformity when a new parking lot
or paved area is proposed. This section shall also apply when an existing
parking lot is reconstructed where such reconstruction involves the removal,
grinding, or the replacement of the existing surface.
(Ord. 2013-48. Passed 10-7-13.)
1272.04 DETENTION AND RETENTION POND LANDSCAPING.
   Landscaping shall be required atop each side of retention and detention
basins that front a street, alley or parking lot. Such landscaping shall
consist of trees, shrubs, and emergent plantings in a quantity, species, and
arrangement that will create an aesthetically pleasing and ecologically
functional environment. Retention and detention basins shall be designed to
resemble natural landforms, whenever possible. Trees, shrubs, turf and native
prairie plantings shall be located above the normal water line; emergent or
native wet prairie plantings shall be located below the normal water line. All
detention and retention ponds shall be constructed and maintained in accordance
with Chapter
1050 of the Codified Ordinances of Freeport, Illinois and the City’s “Storm
Drainage & Erosion Control Management Design Manual” referenced therein.
(Ord. 2013-48. Passed 10-7-13.)
1272.05 DUMPSTER SCREENING AND PLACEMENT.
   (a)   In residential districts, trash dumpsters shall not be allowed unless
stored indoors or completely screened from view as set forth in this section.
Dumpsters in residential districts which are not stored indoors shall be
screened from public view on three (3) sides by a solid fence or wall at least
six (6) feet in height and on the fourth side by a solid gate at least six (6)
feet in height. The gate and wall shall be maintained in good working order and
shall remain closed except during trash pick-ups. The wall and gate shall be
architecturally compatible with other buildings and structures on the site. The
provisions of this section shall not apply to temporary dumpsters otherwise
properly permitted under the provisions of Section 1060.07 of these Codified
Ordinances.
   (b)   In all other districts, trash dumpsters shall be placed so as to be
generally inconspicuous from the public right of way. The Community Development
Director, in his or her discretion, may by written notice to the owner of any
property require the location of a dumpster be screened from view or be moved
to a less conspicuous location, if available.
(Ord. 2013-48. Passed 10-7-13; Ord. 2018-52. Passed 11-5-18; Ord. 2021-41.
Passed 11-1-21.)
1272.06 ADMINISTRATION AND APPEALS.
   (a)   Administration. It shall be the duty of the Zoning Administrator to
administer and enforce this Chapter.
   (b)   Appeals. An aggrieved person adversely affected by the denial of a
permit or decision, determination or interpretation under this Chapter by the
Zoning Administrator may appeal such denial, decision, determination or
interpretation to the Zoning Board of Appeals.
   (c)   Application Procedure. Any application for appeal shall be taken
pursuant to the procedure set forth in Section
1244.02 of the Zoning Ordinance.
(Ord. 2013-48. Passed 10-7-13.)
1272.07 SEVERABILITY.
   This Chapter and each section and subsection hereunder are hereby declared
to be independent sections and subsections and, not withstanding any other
evidence of legislative intent, it is hereby declared to be the controlling
legislative intent that if any provisions of said Chapter, or the application
thereof to any person or circumstance is held to be invalid, the remaining
sections or subsections and the application of such sections and subsections to
any person or circumstances other than those to which it is held invalid shall
not be affected thereby, and it is hereby declared that such sections and
subsections would have been passed independently of such section or subsection
so known to be invalid.
(Ord. 2013-48. Passed 10-7-13.)
CHAPTER 1274
Adult-Use Cannabis
1274.01   Purpose and applicability.
1274.02   Special use.
1274.03   Adult-use cannabis facility components.
1274.04   Adult-use cannabis craft grower.
1274.05   Adult-use cannabis cultivation center.
1274.06   Adult-use cannabis dispensing organization.
1274.07   Adult-use cannabis infuser organization.
1274.08   Adult-use cannabis processing organization.
1274.09   Adult-use cannabis transporting organization.
1274.10   Additional requirements.
1274.11   Co-location of cannabis business establishments.
1274.01 PURPOSE AND APPLICABILITY.
   It is the intent and purpose of this chapter to provide regulations
regarding the cultivation, processing and dispensing of adult-use cannabis
occurring within the corporate limits of the City of Freeport. Such facilities
shall comply with all regulations provided in the Cannabis Regulation and Tax
Act (P.A. 101-0027) (Act), as it may be amended from time-to-time, and
regulations promulgated thereunder, and the regulations provided below. In the
event that the Act is amended, the more restrictive of the State or local
regulations shall apply.
(Ord. 2019-56. Passed 11-18-19.)
1274.02 SPECIAL USE.
   Adult-use cannabis business establishment facilities, as defined in
Chapter 1240 - General Provisions and Definitions, requiring approval of a
special use permit in the respective district in which they are requested shall
be processed in accordance with Section
1242.07 - Special Use Permits.
(Ord. 2019-56. Passed 11-18-19.)
1274.03 ADULT-USE CANNABIS FACILITY COMPONENTS.
   In determining compliance with this chapter, the following components of the
adult-use cannabis facility shall be evaluated based on the entirety of the
circumstances affecting the particular property in the context of the existing
and intended future use of the properties:
   (a)   Impact of the proposed facility on existing or planned uses located
within the vicinity of the subject property.
   (b)   Proposed structure in which the facility will be located, including
co-tenancy (if in a multi-tenant building), total square footage, security
installations/security plan and building code compliance.
   (c)   Hours of operation and anticipated number of customers/employees.
   (d)   Anticipated parking demand and available private parking supply.
   (e)   Anticipated traffic generation in the context of adjacent roadway
capacity and access to such roadways.
   (f)   Site design, including access points and internal site circulation.
   (g)   Proposed signage plan.
   (h)   Compliance with all requirements provided in Section
1274.04 (Adult-Use Cannabis Craft Grower); Section
1274.05 (Adult-Use Cannabis Cultivation Center); Section
1274.06 (Adult-Use Cannabis Dispensing Organization); Section
1274.07 (Adult-Use Cannabis Infuser Organization); Section
1274.08 (Adult-Use Cannabis Processing Organization); or Section
1274.09 (Adult-Use Cannabis Transporting Organization), as applicable.
   (i)   Other criteria determined to be necessary to assess compliance with
Section
1242.07 - Special Use Permits.
(Ord. 2019-56. Passed 11-18-19.)
1274.04 ADULT-USE CANNABIS CRAFT GROWER.
   In those zoning districts in which an adult-use cannabis craft grower may be
located, the proposed facility must comply with the following:
   (a)   Facility may not be located within 1,500 feet of the property line of
a pre-existing public or private nursery school, preschool, primary or
secondary school, or licensed day care center. Learning centers and vocational/
trade centers shall not be classified as a public or private school for
purposes of this section.
   (b)   Facility may not be located within 300 feet of the property line of a
preexisting property zoned as residential.
   (c)   Facility may not conduct any sales or distribution of cannabis other
than as authorized by the Act.
   (d)   For purposes of determining required parking, adult-use cannabis craft
growers shall be classified as a "Retail Stores and Banks" per
Chapter 1262 - Off-Street Parking and Loading, provided, however, that the City
may require that additional parking be provided as a result of the analysis
completed through Section
1242.07 - Special Use Permits.
   (e)   Petitioner shall file an affidavit with the City affirming compliance
with this
Chapter 1274 as provided herein and all other requirements of the Act.
(Ord. 2019-56. Passed 11-18-19.)
1274.05 ADULT-USE CANNABIS CULTIVATION CENTER.
   In those zoning districts in which an adult-use cannabis cultivation center
may be located, the proposed facility must comply with the following:
   (a)   Facility may not be located within 1,500 feet of the property line of
a pre-existing public or private nursery school, preschool, primary or
secondary school, or licensed day care center. Learning centers and vocational/
trade centers shall not be classified as a public or private school for
purposes of this section.
   (b)   Facility may not be located within 300 feet of the property line of a
pre-existing property zoned as residential.
   (c)   Facility may not conduct any sales or distribution of cannabis other
than as authorized by the Act.
   (d)   For purposes of determining required parking, adult-use cannabis
cultivation centers shall be classified as "Warehouse and Storage Buildings"
per
Chapter 1262 - Off-Street Parking and Loading, provided, however, that the City
may require that additional parking be provided as a result of the analysis
completed through Section
1242.07 - Special Use Permits.
   (e)   Petitioner shall file an affidavit with the City affirming compliance
with this chapter as provided herein and all other requirements of the Act.
(Ord. 2019-56. Passed 11-18-19.)
1274.06 ADULT-USE CANNABIS DISPENSING ORGANIZATION.
   In those zoning districts in which an adult-use cannabis dispensing
organization may be located, the proposed facility must comply with the
following:
   (a)   Facility may not be located within 1,500 feet of the property line of
a preexisting public or private nursery school, preschool, primary or secondary
school, or licensed day care center. Learning centers and vocational/trade
centers shall not be classified as a public or private school for purposes of
this section.
   (b)   Facility may not be located within 300 feet of the property line of a
preexisting property zoned as residential.
   (c)   At least seventy-five percent of the floor area of any tenant space
occupied by a dispensing organization shall be devoted to the activities of the
dispensing organization as authorized by the Act, and no dispensing
organization shall also sell food for consumption on the premises.
   (d)   Facility may not conduct any sales or distribution of cannabis other
than as authorized by the Act.
   (e)   For purposes of determining required parking, said facilities shall be
classified as a "Retail Stores and Banks" per
Chapter 1262 - Off-Street Parking and Loading, provided, however, that the City
may require that additional parking be provided as a result of the analysis
completed through Section
1242.07 - Special Use Permits.
   (f)   Petitioner shall file an affidavit with the City affirming compliance
with this chapter as provided herein and all other requirements of the Act.
(Ord. 2019-56. Passed 11-18-19.)
1274.07 ADULT-USE CANNABIS INFUSER ORGANIZATION.
   In those zoning districts in which an adult-use cannabis infuser
organization may be located, the proposed facility must comply with the
following:
   (a)   Facility may not be located within 1,500 feet of the property line of
a preexisting public or private nursery school, preschool, primary or secondary
school, or licensed day care center. Learning centers and vocational/trade
centers shall not be classified as a public or private school for purposes of
this section.
   (b)   Facility may not be located within 300 feet of the property line of a
preexisting property zoned as residential.
   (c)   At least seventy-five percent of the floor area of any tenant space
occupied by an infusing organization shall be devoted to the activities of the
infusing organization as authorized by the Act. Facility may not conduct any
sales or distribution of cannabis other than as authorized by the Act.
   (d)   For purposes of determining required parking, said facilities shall be
classified as "establishments engaged in production, processing, cleaning,
service, testing or repair of materials, goods or products" per
Chapter 1262 - Off-Street Parking and Loading, provided, however, that the City
may require that additional parking be provided as a result of the analysis
completed through Section
1242.07 - Special Use Permits.
   (e)   Petitioner shall file an affidavit with the City affirming compliance
with this chapter as provided herein and all other requirements of the Act.
(Ord. 2019-56. Passed 11-18-19.)
1274.08 ADULT-USE CANNABIS PROCESSING ORGANIZATION.
   In those zoning districts in which an adult-use cannabis processing
organization may be located, the proposed facility must comply with the
following:
   (a)   Facility may not be located within 1,500 feet of the property line of
a preexisting public or private nursery school, preschool, primary or secondary
school, or licensed day care center. Learning centers and vocational/trade
centers shall not be classified as a public or private school for purposes of
this section.
   (b)   Facility may not be located within 300 feet of the property line of a
preexisting property zoned as residential.
   (c)   At least seventy-five percent of the floor area of any tenant space
occupied by a processing organization shall be devoted to the activities of the
processing organization as authorized by the Act. Facility may not conduct any
sales or distribution of cannabis other than as authorized by the Act.
   (d)   For purposes of determining required parking, said facilities shall be
classified as "establishments engaged in production, processing, cleaning,
service, testing or repair of materials, goods or products" per
Chapter 1262 - Off-Street Parking and Loading, provided, however, that the City
may require that additional parking be provided as a result of the analysis
completed through Section
1242.07 - Special Use Permits.
   (e)   Petitioner shall file an affidavit with the City affirming compliance
with this chapter as provided herein and all other requirements of the Act.
(Ord. 2019-56. Passed 11-18-19.)
1274.09 ADULT-USE CANNABIS TRANSPORTING ORGANIZATION.
   In those zoning districts in which an adult-use transporting organization
may be located, the proposed facility must comply with the following:
   (a)   Facility may not be located within 1,500 feet of the property line of
a preexisting public or private nursery school, preschool, primary or secondary
school, or licensed day care center. Learning centers and vocational/trade
centers shall not be classified as a public or private school for purposes of
this section.
   (b)   Facility may not be located within 300 feet of the property line of a
preexisting property zoned as residential.
   (c)   The transporting organization shall be the sole use of the tenant
space in which it is located. Facility may not conduct any sales or
distribution of cannabis other than as authorized by the Act.
   (d)   For purposes of determining required parking, said facilities shall be
classified as "warehouses and storage buildings" per
Chapter 1262 - Off-Street Parking and Loading, provided, however, that the City
may require that additional parking be provided as a result of the analysis
completed through Section
1242.07 - Special Use Permits.
   (e)   Petitioner shall file an affidavit with the City affirming compliance
with this chapter as provided herein and all other requirements of the Act.
(Ord. 2019-56. Passed 11-18-19.)
1274.10 ADDITIONAL REQUIREMENTS.
   Petitioner shall install building enhancements, such as security cameras,
lighting or other improvements, as set forth in the special use permit, to
ensure the safety of employees and customers of the adult-use cannabis business
establishments, as well as its environs. Said improvements shall be determined
based on the specific characteristics of the floor plan for an adult-use
cannabis business establishment and the site on which it is located, consistent
with the requirements of the Act.
(Ord. 2019-56. Passed 11-18-19.)
1274.11 CO-LOCATION OF CANNABIS BUSINESS ESTABLISHMENTS.
   The City may approve the co-location of an adult-use cannabis dispensing
organization with an adult-use cannabis craft grower center or an adult-use
cannabis infuser organization, or both, subject to the provisions of the Act
and the special use criteria within the City Zoning Code. In a co-location, the
floor space requirements of Sections
1274.06(c) and
1274.07(c) shall not apply, but the co-located establishments shall be the sole
use of the tenant space.
(Ord. 2019-56. Passed 11-18-19.)
CHAPTER 1276
Drive-Through and Curbside Service
1276.01   Compliance required.
1276.02   Definitions.
1276.03   Construction standards for drive throughs.
1276.04   Operation of drive throughs.
1276.05   Provision of curbside service.
1276.06   Uses not exclusive.
1276.07   Required parking.
1276.01   COMPLIANCE REQUIRED.
   It shall be unlawful to construct, maintain, or operate any drive-through or
curbside service, as defined in this chapter, except in strict compliance with
all provisions of this chapter.
(Ord. 2021-42. Passed 9-20-21.)
1276.02   DEFINITIONS.
   (a)   A “drive through” shall defined as any service which is provided by a
business having an established building location to persons through a window or
other portal in said building without the need for said persons to leave their
vehicle in order to receive such service. Such services shall specifically
include, but are not limited to, transaction of banking services and delivery
of food (prepared, pre-packaged, or otherwise), beverages, pharmaceuticals, or
other items sold at retail, whether purchased at the time of delivery or
previously through electronic or other means.
   (b)   “Curbside service” shall be defined as any delivery of items, whether
purchased at the time of delivery or previously through electronic or other
means, to persons by delivering said items directly to the recipient’s vehicle.
(Ord. 2021-42. Passed 9-20-21.)
1276.03   CONSTRUCTION STANDARDS FOR DRIVE THROUGHS.
   (a)   All drive throughs shall have no less than one (1) dedicated lane for
purposes of accessing the drive through window. Said lane shall meet all of the
following requirements:
      (1)   The lane shall be clearly demarcated and identified as “drive-thru
only” or some reasonably similar language; and
      (2)   The lane shall provide for stacking of no less than five (5)
standard sized passenger vehicles. Provided, that in the discretion of the
Community Development Director, dedicated locations for curbside delivery may
be substituted in place of one or more stacking spaces, if the Community
Development Director determines that the use of said dedicated parking spaces
will not interfere with the flow of traffic generally on the site. In no event
shall any space required to be maintained for purposes of curbside delivery be
used as a substitute for a stacking space.
      (3)   The lane shall be arranged such that any vehicle receiving service
or waiting in a stacking space does not:
         (A)   Block traffic or pedestrian flow on the site; or
         (B)   Block access to any parking spaces.
   (b)   There shall be a bypass lane allowing unimpeded circulation of traffic
around any lane required by subsection (a) of this section. The bypass lane
shall not include any parking spaces.
   (c)   Exterior lighting, including illuminated signage, shall be so shielded
or directed that the light intensity or brightness shall not extend beyond the
subject property line, to be determined by the submission of a lighting plan
acceptable to the Community Development Director.
   (d)   A solid fence or wall four to six feet in height shall be constructed
where any off-street parking area is located, adjacent to a dwelling unit or
any residentially zoned parcel of land. In the discretion of the Community
Development Director, an evergreen hedge maintained in good condition may be
substituted for the required fence or wall, provided however, that the
evergreen hedge provides an opaque screen to prevent the glare of headlights
onto adjoining properties.
   (e)   Entrances and exits shall be located in such a manner as to avoid
interference with traffic on adjacent streets or private property.
   (f)   Where it is necessary for patrons wishing to park and enter such
businesses to cross a drive-through lane, crosswalks leading from parking areas
to building entrances shall be clearly marked.
(Ord. 2021-42. Passed 9-20-21.)
1276.04   OPERATION OF DRIVE THROUGHS.
   (a)   Speakers used for taking orders or providing services shall be
maintained at a volume which is not be able to be heard from adjacent property.
   (b)   No drive through shall be operated in any way which interferes with
access to any adjacent business or residence, or which results in vehicles
waiting for service to block any public way, private access or driveway, or the
unauthorized use of parking space not owned by the business operating the drive
through.
   (c)   The operation of a drive through in a manner which interferes with the
use or enjoyment adjacent properties is hereby declared a nuisance. The
requirements of this section shall be an affirmative and continuing duty on the
part of any person operating a drive through, and compliance with the design
standards in Section 1276.03 shall not be a defense to a violation of this
section.
(Ord. 2021-42. Passed 9-20-21.)
1276.05   PROVISION OF CURBSIDE SERVICE.
   (a)   Except in the Central Business District (as defined in Section 202.03
(5)) adequate dedicated parking spaces shall be provided for curbside service
on the site of any business offering curbside services. Said dedicated spaces
shall be clearly marked as “curbside service only”, or some reasonably similar
language. Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section, in no event
shall any business provide curbside service to any vehicle which is not parked
in a dedicated parking space on the business premises.
   (b)   In the Central Business District, curbside service may be provided to
persons parked in public parking spaces, and no business shall be required to
provide dedicated spaces for curbside delivery. Provided, no business shall
provide curbside service to any vehicle parked in a private parking space which
is not owned or leased by the business.
(Ord. 2021-42. Passed 9-20-21.)
1276.06   USES NOT EXCLUSIVE.
   The operation of a drive-through and the provision of curbside delivery
services are not mutually exclusive. A business may offer both services, and
shall be required to comply with all provisions applicable to any service
provided.
(Ord. 2021-42. Passed 9-20-21.)
1276.07   REQUIRED PARKING.
   No parking space designated under this chapter for use as a stacking space
for a drive through or delivery space for curbside service shall be counted as
a parking space for purposes of complying with the off-street parking
requirements of Chapter 1262 or any other provision of these Codified
Ordinances which requires dedicated parking spaces.
(Ord. 2021-42. Passed 9-20-21.)
CHAPTER 1278
Self Service Storage Facilities
1278.01   Requirements and definitions.
1278.02   Prohibited uses.
1278.03   Design standards.
1278.04   No hazardous substances.
1278.05   Movable units.
1278.06   Outdoor storage prohibited.
1278.01   REQUIREMENTS AND DEFINITIONS.
   (a)   It shall be unlawful to operate a self-service storage facility within
the City of Freeport, except in strict compliance with the provisions of this
chapter.
   (b)   For purposes of this chapter, the following terms shall have the
meanings set forth in this section:
      (1)   “Facility” shall refer to the use of the property as a whole,
including any caretaker’s residence and/or business office.
      (2)   “Unit” or “storage unit” as used in this chapter shall refer to any
separately enclosed space available for rent or lease to customers of the
facility.
      (3)   “Movable unit” shall refer to all pod-type storage units and/or
shipping containers which are capable of being transported on and off of the
facility.
      (4)   “Shipping container” shall refer to an intermodal container
designed and built primarily for freight transport.
      (5)   “Pod-type storage unit” shall refer to a portable storage unit,
designed primarily for the storage of personal goods rather than for intermodal
transport, and which is less than 18 feet in overall length or 850 cubic feet
in volume.
(Ord. 2021-40. Passed 9-20-21.)
1278.02   PROHIBITED USES.
   The only activities permitted in or around individual storage units shall be
the rental of the unit and the pickup and deposit of goods and/or property in
storage. Storage units shall specifically not be used for any the following
activities:
   (a)   Residential use;
   (b)   Offices, workshops, studios, hobby or rehearsal areas or for
manufacturing, fabrication, or processing of goods, service or repair of
vehicles, engines, appliances or other electrical equipment, or any other
industrial activity;
   (c)   Conducting retail sales of any kind, including garage or estate sales
or auctions, except as specified in relation to the foreclosure of a self-
service storage lien in accordance with the Illinois Self-Service Storage Act,
770 ILCS 95/1 et seq.;
   (d)   Storage of flammable liquids, flammable or highly combustible,
radioactive or explosive materials or hazardous chemicals or toxic substances
or any supplies that, whether singly or combined, may produce such explosive,
flammable, toxic materials, chemicals, substances or any hazardous condition;
   (e)   Keeping pets or other animals.
(Ord. 2021-40. Passed 9-20-21.)
1278.03   DESIGN STANDARDS.
   (a)   No electrical outlets are permitted inside or outside for individual
storage units. Lighting fixtures and switches shall be of a secure design that
will not allow tapping the fixtures for other purposes.
   (b)   A minimum of one shrub shall be required for every 3,000 square feet
of lot area.
   (c)   A minimum of one tree shall be required for every 5,000 square feet of
lot area. All proposed deciduous trees shall be a minimum of 1-3/4 inches in
diameter and all evergreen trees shall be a minimum of four feet in height at
the time of planting. Large maturing shade trees shall account for at least 50
percent of the total trees required.
   (d)   Landscape buffers (trees, hedges, plantings, or a combination thereof)
shall be installed adjacent to and across from all residential areas.
   (e)   All areas intended for driving, parking and loading shall be paved
with asphalt or concrete.
   (f)   The overall height of light fixtures installed to illuminate parking
lots and exterior grounds shall not exceed 30 feet or the height of the tallest
structure on the facility, whichever is lesser.
(Ord. 2021-40. Passed 9-20-21.)
1278.04   NO HAZARDOUS SUBSTANCES.
   The storage of flammable liquids, flammable or highly combustible,
radioactive or explosive materials or hazardous chemicals or toxic substances
or any supplies that, whether singly or combined, may produce such explosive,
flammable, toxic materials, chemicals, substances or any hazardous condition is
expressly prohibited. Signage shall be posted in a conspicuous location near
the entrance to the facility or in the business office, if any.
(Ord. 2021-40. Passed 9-20-21.)
1278.05   MOVABLE UNITS.
   (a)   Movable units shall be stored in straight lines within the facility,
or on contoured curves to reflect topography if straight lines are not feasible
on a particular property. Movable units may not be stacked in any way which
causes a danger to adjacent properties or passerby.
   (b)   Except as otherwise provided in this section, no person shall allow a
movable storage unit to be located on any residential property which is not
zoned as a self-service storage facility for a period of time in excess of
fourteen (14) days, unless completely enclosed within a structure. Upon request
in connection with a bona fide emergency, disaster declaration, or restoration
due to casualty loss, the Community Development Director, at his or her sole
discretion, may grant a written extension of the time period otherwise provided
for herein, subject to any terms and conditions as may be deemed appropriate by
the Community Development Director.
(Ord. 2021-40. Passed 9-20-21.)
1278.06   OUTDOOR STORAGE PROHIBITED.
   No property shall be stored outdoors on any facility subject to the
provisions of this chapter. All storage must be fully contained in an enclosed
unit.
(Ord. 2021-40. Passed 9-20-21.)

Definitions
1410.01   Definitions.
1410.01 DEFINITIONS.
   The following terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section
whenever used in these Codified Ordinances.
   (a)   “Building and Housing Code,” as used herein, shall refer to the
cumulative provisions of this Part Fourteen, and shall be deemed to
specifically include:
      (1)   The version of the International Building Code as adopted in
Chapter 1420, subject to any amendments or changes set forth in said
Chapter 1420;
      (2)   The version of the International Plumbing Code as adopted in
Chapter 1422, subject to any amendments or changes set forth in said
Chapter 1422;
      (3)   The version of the National Electrical Code as adopted in
Chapter 1424, subject to any amendments or changes set forth in said
Chapter 1424;
      (4)   The version of the International Energy Conservation Code as
adopted in
Chapter 1425, subject to any amendments or changes set forth in said
Chapter 1425;
      (5)   The version of the International Mechanical Code as adopted in
Chapter 1426, subject to any amendments or changes set forth in said
Chapter 1426;
      (6)   The version of the International Fuel Gas Code as adopted in
Chapter 1427, subject to any amendments or changes set forth in said
Chapter 1427;

Safety Act and related regulations as adopted in
Chapter 1428;
      (8)   The version of the International Existing Building Code as adopted
in
Chapter 1429, subject to any amendments or changes set forth in said
Chapter 1429;
      (9)   The version of the International Property Maintenance Code as
adopted in
Chapter 1480, subject to any amendments or changes set forth in said
Chapter 1480; and
      (10)   The version of the International Residential Code as adopted in
Chapter 1482, subject to any amendments or changes set forth in said
Chapter 1482.
   (b)   “Reference to individual codes” means any reference to an individual
code, such as, without limitation, the International Building Code,
International Mechanical Code, etc., shall be deemed to refer to the version of
the referenced code which has been adopted by the City pursuant to this
Building and Housing Code, and subject to any amendments or modifications
thereto set forth in the relevant chapter or chapters hereof.
(Ord. 2018-52. Passed 11-5-18.)
